I. OLD MOODIE <\p>
The evening before my departure for Blithedale, I was returning to my <\p>
bachelor apartments, after attending the wonderful exhibition of the <\p>
Veiled Lady, when an elderly man of rather shabby appearance met me in <\p>
an obscure part of the street. <\p>
"Mr. Coverdale," said he softly, "can I speak with you a moment?" <\p>
As I have casually alluded to the Veiled Lady, it may not be amiss to <\p>
mention, for the benefit of such of my readers as are unacquainted with <\p>
her now forgotten celebrity, that she was a phenomenon in the mesmeric <\p>
line; one of the earliest that had indicated the birth of a new <\p>
science, or the revival of an old humbug. Since those times her <\p>
sisterhood have grown too numerous to attract much individual notice; <\p>
nor, in fact, has any one of them come before the public under such <\p>
skilfully contrived circumstances of stage effect as those which at <\p>
once mystified and illuminated the remarkable performances of the lady <\p>
in question. Nowadays, in the management of his "subject," <\p>
"clairvoyant," or "medium," the exhibitor affects the simplicity and <\p>
openness of scientific experiment; and even if he profess to tread a <\p>
step or two across the boundaries of the spiritual world, yet carries <\p>
with him the laws of our actual life and extends them over his <\p>
preternatural conquests. Twelve or fifteen years ago, on the contrary, <\p>
all the arts of mysterious arrangement, of picturesque disposition, and <\p>
artistically contrasted light and shade, were made available, in order <\p>
to set the apparent miracle in the strongest attitude of opposition to <\p>
ordinary facts. In the case of the Veiled Lady, moreover, the interest <\p>
of the spectator was further wrought up by the enigma of her identity, <\p>
and an absurd rumor (probably set afloat by the exhibitor, and at one <\p>
time very prevalent) that a beautiful young lady, of family and <\p>
fortune, was enshrouded within the misty drapery of the veil. It was <\p>
white, with somewhat of a subdued silver sheen, like the sunny side of <\p>
a cloud; and, falling over the wearer from head to foot, was supposed <\p>
to insulate her from the material world, from time and space, and to <\p>
endow her with many of the privileges of a disembodied spirit. <\p>
Her pretensions, however, whether miraculous or otherwise, have little <\p>
to do with the present narrative--except, indeed, that I had <\p>
propounded, for the Veiled Lady's prophetic solution, a query as to the <\p>
success of our Blithedale enterprise. The response, by the bye, was of <\p>
the true Sibylline stamp,--nonsensical in its first aspect, yet on <\p>
closer study unfolding a variety of interpretations, one of which has <\p>
certainly accorded with the event. I was turning over this riddle in <\p>
my mind, and trying to catch its slippery purport by the tail, when the <\p>
old man above mentioned interrupted me. <\p>
"Mr. Coverdale!--Mr. Coverdale!" said he, repeating my name twice, in <\p>
order to make up for the hesitating and ineffectual way in which he <\p>
uttered it. "I ask your pardon, sir, but I hear you are going to <\p>
Blithedale tomorrow." <\p>
I knew the pale, elderly face, with the red-tipt nose, and the patch <\p>
over one eye; and likewise saw something characteristic in the old <\p>
fellow's way of standing under the arch of a gate, only revealing <\p>
enough of himself to make me recognize him as an acquaintance. He was <\p>
a very shy personage, this Mr. Moodie; and the trait was the more <\p>
singular, as his mode of getting his bread necessarily brought him into <\p>
the stir and hubbub of the world more than the generality of men. <\p>
"Yes, Mr. Moodie," I answered, wondering what interest he could take in <\p>
the fact, "it is my intention to go to Blithedale to-morrow. Can I be <\p>
of any service to you before my departure?" <\p>
"If you pleased, Mr. Coverdale," said he, "you might do me a very great <\p>
favor." <\p>
"A very great one?" repeated I, in a tone that must have expressed but <\p>
little alacrity of beneficence, although I was ready to do the old man <\p>
any amount of kindness involving no special trouble to myself. "A very <\p>
great favor, do you say? My time is brief, Mr. Moodie, and I have a <\p>
good many preparations to make. But be good enough to tell me what you <\p>
wish." <\p>
"Ah, sir," replied Old Moodie, "I don't quite like to do that; and, on <\p>
further thoughts, Mr. Coverdale, perhaps I had better apply to some <\p>
older gentleman, or to some lady, if you would have the kindness to <\p>
make me known to one, who may happen to be going to Blithedale. You are <\p>
a young man, sir!" <\p>
"Does that fact lessen my availability for your purpose?" asked I. <\p>
"However, if an older man will suit you better, there is Mr. <\p>
Hollingsworth, who has three or four years the advantage of me in age, <\p>
and is a much more solid character, and a philanthropist to boot. I am <\p>
only a poet, and, so the critics tell me, no great affair at that! But <\p>
what can this business be, Mr. Moodie? It begins to interest me; <\p>
especially since your hint that a lady's influence might be found <\p>
desirable. Come, I am really anxious to be of service to you." <\p>
But the old fellow, in his civil and demure manner, was both freakish <\p>
and obstinate; and he had now taken some notion or other into his head <\p>
that made him hesitate in his former design. <\p>
"I wonder, sir," said he, "whether you know a lady whom they call <\p>
Zenobia?" <\p>
"Not personally," I answered, "although I expect that pleasure <\p>
to-morrow, as she has got the start of the rest of us, and is already a <\p>
resident at Blithedale. But have you a literary turn, Mr. Moodie? or <\p>
have you taken up the advocacy of women's rights? or what else can have <\p>
interested you in this lady? Zenobia, by the bye, as I suppose you <\p>
know, is merely her public name; a sort of mask in which she comes <\p>
before the world, retaining all the privileges of privacy,--a <\p>
contrivance, in short, like the white drapery of the Veiled Lady, only <\p>
a little more transparent. But it is late. Will you tell me what I <\p>
can do for you?" <\p>
"Please to excuse me to-night, Mr. Coverdale," said Moodie. "You are <\p>
very kind; but I am afraid I have troubled you, when, after all, there <\p>
may be no need. Perhaps, with your good leave, I will come to your <\p>
lodgings to-morrow morning, before you set out for Blithedale. I wish <\p>
you a good-night, sir, and beg pardon for stopping you." <\p>
And so he slipt away; and, as he did not show himself the next morning, <\p>
it was only through subsequent events that I ever arrived at a <\p>
plausible conjecture as to what his business could have been. Arriving <\p>
at my room, I threw a lump of cannel coal upon the grate, lighted a <\p>
cigar, and spent an hour in musings of every hue, from the brightest to <\p>
the most sombre; being, in truth, not so very confident as at some <\p>
former periods that this final step, which would mix me up irrevocably <\p>
with the Blithedale affair, was the wisest that could possibly be <\p>
taken. It was nothing short of midnight when I went to bed, after <\p>
drinking a glass of particularly fine sherry on which I used to pride <\p>
myself in those days. It was the very last bottle; and I finished it, <\p>
with a friend, the next forenoon, before setting out for Blithedale. <\p>
II. BLITHEDALE <\p>
There can hardly remain for me (who am really getting to be a frosty <\p>
bachelor, with another white hair, every week or so, in my mustache), <\p>
there can hardly flicker up again so cheery a blaze upon the hearth, as <\p>
that which I remember, the next day, at Blithedale. It was a wood <\p>
fire, in the parlor of an old farmhouse, on an April afternoon, but <\p>
with the fitful gusts of a wintry snowstorm roaring in the chimney. <\p>
Vividly does that fireside re-create itself, as I rake away the ashes <\p>
from the embers in my memory, and blow them up with a sigh, for lack of <\p>
more inspiring breath. Vividly for an instant, but anon, with the <\p>
dimmest gleam, and with just as little fervency for my heart as for my <\p>
finger-ends! The staunch oaken logs were long ago burnt out. Their <\p>
genial glow must be represented, if at all, by the merest phosphoric <\p>
glimmer, like that which exudes, rather than shines, from damp <\p>
fragments of decayed trees, deluding the benighted wanderer through a <\p>
forest. Around such chill mockery of a fire some few of us might sit <\p>
on the withered leaves, spreading out each a palm towards the imaginary <\p>
warmth, and talk over our exploded scheme for beginning the life of <\p>
Paradise anew. <\p>
Paradise, indeed! Nobody else in the world, I am bold to <\p>
affirm--nobody, at least, in our bleak little world of New <\p>
England,--had dreamed of Paradise that day except as the pole suggests <\p>
the tropic. Nor, with such materials as were at hand, could the most <\p>
skilful architect have constructed any better imitation of Eve's bower <\p>
than might be seen in the snow hut of an Esquimaux. But we made a <\p>
summer of it, in spite of the wild drifts. <\p>
It was an April day, as already hinted, and well towards the middle of <\p>
the month. When morning dawned upon me, in town, its temperature was <\p>
mild enough to be pronounced even balmy, by a lodger, like myself, in <\p>
one of the midmost houses of a brick block,--each house partaking of <\p>
the warmth of all the rest, besides the sultriness of its individual <\p>
furnace--heat. But towards noon there had come snow, driven along the <\p>
street by a northeasterly blast, and whitening the roofs and sidewalks <\p>
with a business-like perseverance that would have done credit to our <\p>
severest January tempest. It set about its task apparently as much in <\p>
earnest as if it had been guaranteed from a thaw for months to come. <\p>
The greater, surely, was my heroism, when, puffing out a final whiff of <\p>
cigar-smoke, I quitted my cosey pair of bachelor-rooms,--with a good <\p>
fire burning in the grate, and a closet right at hand, where there was <\p>
still a bottle or two in the champagne basket and a residuum of claret <\p>
in a box,--quitted, I say, these comfortable quarters, and plunged into <\p>
the heart of the pitiless snowstorm, in quest of a better life. <\p>
The better life! Possibly, it would hardly look so now; it is enough <\p>
if it looked so then. The greatest obstacle to being heroic is the <\p>
doubt whether one may not be going to prove one's self a fool; the <\p>
truest heroism is to resist the doubt; and the profoundest wisdom to <\p>
know when it ought to be resisted, and when to be obeyed. <\p>
Yet, after all, let us acknowledge it wiser, if not more sagacious, to <\p>
follow out one's daydream to its natural consummation, although, if the <\p>
vision have been worth the having, it is certain never to be <\p>
consummated otherwise than by a failure. And what of that? Its <\p>
airiest fragments, impalpable as they may be, will possess a value that <\p>
lurks not in the most ponderous realities of any practicable scheme. <\p>
They are not the rubbish of the mind. Whatever else I may repent of, <\p>
therefore, let it be reckoned neither among my sins nor follies that I <\p>
once had faith and force enough to form generous hopes of the world's <\p>
destiny--yes!--and to do what in me lay for their accomplishment; even <\p>
to the extent of quitting a warm fireside, flinging away a freshly <\p>
lighted cigar, and travelling far beyond the strike of city clocks, <\p>
through a drifting snowstorm. <\p>
There were four of us who rode together through the storm; and <\p>
Hollingsworth, who had agreed to be of the number, was accidentally <\p>
delayed, and set forth at a later hour alone. As we threaded the <\p>
streets, I remember how the buildings on either side seemed to press <\p>
too closely upon us, insomuch that our mighty hearts found barely room <\p>
enough to throb between them. The snowfall, too, looked inexpressibly <\p>
dreary (I had almost called it dingy), coming down through an <\p>
atmosphere of city smoke, and alighting on the sidewalk only to be <\p>
moulded into the impress of somebody's patched boot or overshoe. Thus <\p>
the track of an old conventionalism was visible on what was freshest <\p>
from the sky. But when we left the pavements, and our muffled <\p>
hoof-tramps beat upon a desolate extent of country road, and were <\p>
effaced by the unfettered blast as soon as stamped, then there was <\p>
better air to breathe. Air that had not been breathed once and again! <\p>
air that had not been spoken into words of falsehood, formality, and <\p>
error, like all the air of the dusky city! <\p>
"How pleasant it is!" remarked I, while the snowflakes flew into my <\p>
mouth the moment it was opened. "How very mild and balmy is this <\p>
country air!" <\p>
"Ah, Coverdale, don't laugh at what little enthusiasm you have left!" <\p>
said one of my companions. "I maintain that this nitrous atmosphere is <\p>
really exhilarating; and, at any rate, we can never call ourselves <\p>
regenerated men till a February northeaster shall be as grateful to us <\p>
as the softest breeze of June!" <\p>
So we all of us took courage, riding fleetly and merrily along, by <\p>
stone fences that were half buried in the wave-like drifts; and through <\p>
patches of woodland, where the tree-trunks opposed a snow-incrusted <\p>
side towards the northeast; and within ken of deserted villas, with no <\p>
footprints in their avenues; and passed scattered dwellings, whence <\p>
puffed the smoke of country fires, strongly impregnated with the <\p>
pungent aroma of burning peat. Sometimes, encountering a traveller, we <\p>
shouted a friendly greeting; and he, unmuffling his ears to the bluster <\p>
and the snow-spray, and listening eagerly, appeared to think our <\p>
courtesy worth less than the trouble which it cost him. The churl! He <\p>
understood the shrill whistle of the blast, but had no intelligence for <\p>
our blithe tones of brotherhood. This lack of faith in our cordial <\p>
sympathy, on the traveller's part, was one among the innumerable tokens <\p>
how difficult a task we had in hand for the reformation of the world. <\p>
We rode on, however, with still unflagging spirits, and made such good <\p>
companionship with the tempest that, at our journey's end, we professed <\p>
ourselves almost loath to bid the rude blusterer good-by. But, to own <\p>
the truth, I was little better than an icicle, and began to be <\p>
suspicious that I had caught a fearful cold. <\p>
And now we were seated by the brisk fireside of the old farmhouse, the <\p>
same fire that glimmers so faintly among my reminiscences at the <\p>
beginning of this chapter. There we sat, with the snow melting out of <\p>
our hair and beards, and our faces all ablaze, what with the past <\p>
inclemency and present warmth. It was, indeed, a right good fire that <\p>
we found awaiting us, built up of great, rough logs, and knotty limbs, <\p>
and splintered fragments of an oak-tree, such as farmers are wont to <\p>
keep for their own hearths, since these crooked and unmanageable boughs <\p>
could never be measured into merchantable cords for the market. A <\p>
family of the old Pilgrims might have swung their kettle over precisely <\p>
such a fire as this, only, no doubt, a bigger one; and, contrasting it <\p>
with my coal-grate, I felt so much the more that we had transported <\p>
ourselves a world-wide distance from the system of society that <\p>
shackled us at breakfast-time. <\p>
Good, comfortable Mrs. Foster (the wife of stout Silas Foster, who was <\p>
to manage the farm at a fair stipend, and be our tutor in the art of <\p>
husbandry) bade us a hearty welcome. At her back--a back of generous <\p>
breadth--appeared two young women, smiling most hospitably, but looking <\p>
rather awkward withal, as not well knowing what was to be their <\p>
position in our new arrangement of the world. We shook hands <\p>
affectionately all round, and congratulated ourselves that the blessed <\p>
state of brotherhood and sisterhood, at which we aimed, might fairly be <\p>
dated from this moment. Our greetings were hardly concluded when the <\p>
door opened, and Zenobia--whom I had never before seen, important as <\p>
was her place in our enterprise--Zenobia entered the parlor. <\p>
This (as the reader, if at all acquainted with our literary biography, <\p>
need scarcely be told) was not her real name. She had assumed it, in <\p>
the first instance, as her magazine signature; and, as it accorded well <\p>
with something imperial which her friends attributed to this lady's <\p>
figure and deportment, they half-laughingly adopted it in their <\p>
familiar intercourse with her. She took the appellation in good part, <\p>
and even encouraged its constant use; which, in fact, was thus far <\p>
appropriate, that our Zenobia, however humble looked her new <\p>
philosophy, had as much native pride as any queen would have known what <\p>
to do with. <\p>
III. A KNOT OF DREAMERS <\p>
Zenobia bade us welcome, in a fine, frank, mellow voice, and gave each <\p>
of us her hand, which was very soft and warm. She had something <\p>
appropriate, I recollect, to say to every individual; and what she said <\p>
to myself was this:--"I have long wished to know you, Mr. Coverdale, <\p>
and to thank you for your beautiful poetry, some of which I have <\p>
learned by heart; or rather it has stolen into my memory, without my <\p>
exercising any choice or volition about the matter. Of course--permit <\p>
me to say you do not think of relinquishing an occupation in which you <\p>
have done yourself so much credit. I would almost rather give you up <\p>
as an associate, than that the world should lose one of its true poets!" <\p>
"Ah, no; there will not be the slightest danger of that, especially <\p>
after this inestimable praise from Zenobia," said I, smiling, and <\p>
blushing, no doubt, with excess of pleasure. "I hope, on the contrary, <\p>
now to produce something that shall really deserve to be called <\p>
poetry,--true, strong, natural, and sweet, as is the life which we are <\p>
going to lead,--something that shall have the notes of wild birds <\p>
twittering through it, or a strain like the wind anthems in the woods, <\p>
as the case may be." <\p>
"Is it irksome to you to hear your own verses sung?" asked Zenobia, <\p>
with a gracious smile. "If so, I am very sorry, for you will certainly <\p>
hear me singing them sometimes, in the summer evenings." <\p>
"Of all things," answered I, "that is what will delight me most." <\p>
While this passed, and while she spoke to my companions, I was taking <\p>
note of Zenobia's aspect; and it impressed itself on me so distinctly, <\p>
that I can now summon her up, like a ghost, a little wanner than the <\p>
life but otherwise identical with it. She was dressed as simply as <\p>
possible, in an American print (I think the dry-goods people call it <\p>
so), but with a silken kerchief, between which and her gown there was <\p>
one glimpse of a white shoulder. It struck me as a great piece of good <\p>
fortune that there should be just that glimpse. Her hair, which was <\p>
dark, glossy, and of singular abundance, was put up rather soberly and <\p>
primly--without curls, or other ornament, except a single flower. It <\p>
was an exotic of rare beauty, and as fresh as if the hothouse gardener <\p>
had just clipt it from the stem. That flower has struck deep root into <\p>
my memory. I can both see it and smell it, at this moment. So <\p>
brilliant, so rare, so costly as it must have been, and yet enduring <\p>
only for a day, it was more indicative of the pride and pomp which had <\p>
a luxuriant growth in Zenobia's character than if a great diamond had <\p>
sparkled among her hair. <\p>
Her hand, though very soft, was larger than most women would like to <\p>
have, or than they could afford to have, though not a whit too large in <\p>
proportion with the spacious plan of Zenobia's entire development. It <\p>
did one good to see a fine intellect (as hers really was, although its <\p>
natural tendency lay in another direction than towards literature) so <\p>
fitly cased. She was, indeed, an admirable figure of a woman, just on <\p>
the hither verge of her richest maturity, with a combination of <\p>
features which it is safe to call remarkably beautiful, even if some <\p>
fastidious persons might pronounce them a little deficient in softness <\p>
and delicacy. But we find enough of those attributes everywhere. <\p>
Preferable--by way of variety, at least--was Zenobia's bloom, health, <\p>
and vigor, which she possessed in such overflow that a man might well <\p>
have fallen in love with her for their sake only. In her quiet moods, <\p>
she seemed rather indolent; but when really in earnest, particularly if <\p>
there were a spice of bitter feeling, she grew all alive to her <\p>
finger-tips. <\p>
"I am the first comer," Zenobia went on to say, while her smile beamed <\p>
warmth upon us all; "so I take the part of hostess for to-day, and <\p>
welcome you as if to my own fireside. You shall be my guests, too, at <\p>
supper. Tomorrow, if you please, we will be brethren and sisters, and <\p>
begin our new life from daybreak." <\p>
"Have we our various parts assigned?" asked some one. <\p>
"Oh, we of the softer sex," responded Zenobia, with her mellow, almost <\p>
broad laugh,--most delectable to hear, but not in the least like an <\p>
ordinary woman's laugh,--"we women (there are four of us here already) <\p>
will take the domestic and indoor part of the business, as a matter of <\p>
course. To bake, to boil, to roast, to fry, to stew,--to wash, and <\p>
iron, and scrub, and sweep,--and, at our idler intervals, to repose <\p>
ourselves on knitting and sewing,--these, I suppose, must be feminine <\p>
occupations, for the present. By and by, perhaps, when our individual <\p>
adaptations begin to develop themselves, it may be that some of us who <\p>
wear the petticoat will go afield, and leave the weaker brethren to <\p>
take our places in the kitchen." <\p>
"What a pity," I remarked, "that the kitchen, and the housework <\p>
generally, cannot be left out of our system altogether! It is odd <\p>
enough that the kind of labor which falls to the lot of women is just <\p>
that which chiefly distinguishes artificial life--the life of <\p>
degenerated mortals--from the life of Paradise. Eve had no dinner-pot, <\p>
and no clothes to mend, and no washing-day." <\p>
"I am afraid," said Zenobia, with mirth gleaming out of her eyes, "we <\p>
shall find some difficulty in adopting the paradisiacal system for at <\p>
least a month to come. Look at that snowdrift sweeping past the <\p>
window! Are there any figs ripe, do you think? Have the pineapples <\p>
been gathered to-day? Would you like a bread-fruit, or a cocoanut? <\p>
Shall I run out and pluck you some roses? No, no, Mr. Coverdale; the <\p>
only flower hereabouts is the one in my hair, which I got out of a <\p>
greenhouse this morning. As for the garb of Eden," added she, <\p>
shivering playfully, "I shall not assume it till after May-day!" <\p>
Assuredly Zenobia could not have intended it,--the fault must have been <\p>
entirely in my imagination. But these last words, together with <\p>
something in her manner, irresistibly brought up a picture of that <\p>
fine, perfectly developed figure, in Eve's earliest garment. Her free, <\p>
careless, generous modes of expression often had this effect of <\p>
creating images which, though pure, are hardly felt to be quite <\p>
decorous when born of a thought that passes between man and woman. I <\p>
imputed it, at that time, to Zenobia's noble courage, conscious of no <\p>
harm, and scorning the petty restraints which take the life and color <\p>
out of other women's conversation. There was another peculiarity about <\p>
her. We seldom meet with women nowadays, and in this country, who <\p>
impress us as being women at all,--their sex fades away and goes for <\p>
nothing, in ordinary intercourse. Not so with Zenobia. One felt an <\p>
influence breathing out of her such as we might suppose to come from <\p>
Eve, when she was just made, and her Creator brought her to Adam, <\p>
saying, "Behold! here is a woman!" Not that I would convey the idea of <\p>
especial gentleness, grace, modesty, and shyness, but of a certain warm <\p>
and rich characteristic, which seems, for the most part, to have been <\p>
refined away out of the feminine system. <\p>
"And now," continued Zenobia, "I must go and help get supper. Do you <\p>
think you can be content, instead of figs, pineapples, and all the <\p>
other delicacies of Adam's supper-table, with tea and toast, and a <\p>
certain modest supply of ham and tongue, which, with the instinct of a <\p>
housewife, I brought hither in a basket? And there shall be bread and <\p>
milk, too, if the innocence of your taste demands it." <\p>
The whole sisterhood now went about their domestic avocations, utterly <\p>
declining our offers to assist, further than by bringing wood for the <\p>
kitchen fire from a huge pile in the back yard. After heaping up more <\p>
than a sufficient quantity, we returned to the sitting-room, drew our <\p>
chairs close to the hearth, and began to talk over our prospects. <\p>
Soon, with a tremendous stamping in the entry, appeared Silas Foster, <\p>
lank, stalwart, uncouth, and grizzly-bearded. He came from foddering <\p>
the cattle in the barn, and from the field, where he had been <\p>
ploughing, until the depth of the snow rendered it impossible to draw a <\p>
furrow. He greeted us in pretty much the same tone as if he were <\p>
speaking to his oxen, took a quid from his iron tobacco-box, pulled off <\p>
his wet cowhide boots, and sat down before the fire in his <\p>
stocking-feet. The steam arose from his soaked garments, so that the <\p>
stout yeoman looked vaporous and spectre-like. <\p>
"Well, folks," remarked Silas, "you'll be wishing yourselves back to <\p>
town again, if this weather holds." <\p>
And, true enough, there was a look of gloom, as the twilight fell <\p>
silently and sadly out of the sky, its gray or sable flakes <\p>
intermingling themselves with the fast-descending snow. The storm, in <\p>
its evening aspect, was decidedly dreary. It seemed to have arisen for <\p>
our especial behoof,--a symbol of the cold, desolate, distrustful <\p>
phantoms that invariably haunt the mind, on the eve of adventurous <\p>
enterprises, to warn us back within the boundaries of ordinary life. <\p>
But our courage did not quail. We would not allow ourselves to be <\p>
depressed by the snowdrift trailing past the window, any more than if <\p>
it had been the sigh of a summer wind among rustling boughs. There <\p>
have been few brighter seasons for us than that. If ever men might <\p>
lawfully dream awake, and give utterance to their wildest visions <\p>
without dread of laughter or scorn on the part of the audience,--yes, <\p>
and speak of earthly happiness, for themselves and mankind, as an <\p>
object to be hopefully striven for, and probably attained, we who made <\p>
that little semicircle round the blazing fire were those very men. We <\p>
had left the rusty iron framework of society behind us; we had broken <\p>
through many hindrances that are powerful enough to keep most people on <\p>
the weary treadmill of the established system, even while they feel its <\p>
irksomeness almost as intolerable as we did. We had stepped down from <\p>
the pulpit; we had flung aside the pen; we had shut up the ledger; we <\p>
had thrown off that sweet, bewitching, enervating indolence, which is <\p>
better, after all, than most of the enjoyments within mortal grasp. It <\p>
was our purpose--a generous one, certainly, and absurd, no doubt, in <\p>
full proportion with its generosity--to give up whatever we had <\p>
heretofore attained, for the sake of showing mankind the example of a <\p>
life governed by other than the false and cruel principles on which <\p>
human society has all along been based. <\p>
And, first of all, we had divorced ourselves from pride, and were <\p>
striving to supply its place with familiar love. We meant to lessen <\p>
the laboring man's great burden of toil, by performing our due share of <\p>
it at the cost of our own thews and sinews. We sought our profit by <\p>
mutual aid, instead of wresting it by the strong hand from an enemy, or <\p>
filching it craftily from those less shrewd than ourselves (if, indeed, <\p>
there were any such in New England), or winning it by selfish <\p>
competition with a neighbor; in one or another of which fashions every <\p>
son of woman both perpetrates and suffers his share of the common evil, <\p>
whether he chooses it or no. And, as the basis of our institution, we <\p>
purposed to offer up the earnest toil of our bodies, as a prayer no <\p>
less than an effort for the advancement of our race. <\p>
Therefore, if we built splendid castles (phalansteries perhaps they <\p>
might be more fitly called), and pictured beautiful scenes, among the <\p>
fervid coals of the hearth around which we were clustering, and if all <\p>
went to rack with the crumbling embers and have never since arisen out <\p>
of the ashes, let us take to ourselves no shame. In my own behalf, I <\p>
rejoice that I could once think better of the world's improvability <\p>
than it deserved. It is a mistake into which men seldom fall twice in <\p>
a lifetime; or, if so, the rarer and higher is the nature that can thus <\p>
magnanimously persist in error. <\p>
Stout Silas Foster mingled little in our conversation; but when he did <\p>
speak, it was very much to some practical purpose. For <\p>
instance:--"Which man among you," quoth he, "is the best judge of <\p>
swine? Some of us must go to the next Brighton fair, and buy half a <\p>
dozen pigs." <\p>
Pigs! Good heavens! had we come out from among the swinish multitude <\p>
for this? And again, in reference to some discussion about raising <\p>
early vegetables for the market:--"We shall never make any hand at <\p>
market gardening," said Silas Foster, "unless the women folks will <\p>
undertake to do all the weeding. We haven't team enough for that and <\p>
the regular farm-work, reckoning three of your city folks as worth one <\p>
common field-hand. No, no; I tell you, we should have to get up a <\p>
little too early in the morning, to compete with the market gardeners <\p>
round Boston." <\p>
It struck me as rather odd, that one of the first questions raised, <\p>
after our separation from the greedy, struggling, self-seeking world, <\p>
should relate to the possibility of getting the advantage over the <\p>
outside barbarians in their own field of labor. But, to own the truth, <\p>
I very soon became sensible that, as regarded society at large, we <\p>
stood in a position of new hostility, rather than new brotherhood. Nor <\p>
could this fail to be the case, in some degree, until the bigger and <\p>
better half of society should range itself on our side. Constituting so <\p>
pitiful a minority as now, we were inevitably estranged from the rest <\p>
of mankind in pretty fair proportion with the strictness of our mutual <\p>
bond among ourselves. <\p>
This dawning idea, however, was driven back into my inner consciousness <\p>
by the entrance of Zenobia. She came with the welcome intelligence <\p>
that supper was on the table. Looking at herself in the glass, and <\p>
perceiving that her one magnificent flower had grown rather languid <\p>
(probably by being exposed to the fervency of the kitchen fire), she <\p>
flung it on the floor, as unconcernedly as a village girl would throw <\p>
away a faded violet. The action seemed proper to her character, <\p>
although, methought, it would still more have befitted the bounteous <\p>
nature of this beautiful woman to scatter fresh flowers from her hand, <\p>
and to revive faded ones by her touch. Nevertheless, it was a singular <\p>
but irresistible effect; the presence of Zenobia caused our heroic <\p>
enterprise to show like an illusion, a masquerade, a pastoral, a <\p>
counterfeit Arcadia, in which we grown-up men and women were making a <\p>
play-day of the years that were given us to live in. I tried to <\p>
analyze this impression, but not with much success. <\p>
"It really vexes me," observed Zenobia, as we left the room, "that Mr. <\p>
Hollingsworth should be such a laggard. I should not have thought him <\p>
at all the sort of person to be turned back by a puff of contrary wind, <\p>
or a few snowflakes drifting into his face." <\p>
"Do you know Hollingsworth personally?" I inquired. <\p>
"No; only as an auditor--auditress, I mean--of some of his lectures," <\p>
said she. "What a voice he has! and what a man he is! Yet not so much <\p>
an intellectual man, I should say, as a great heart; at least, he moved <\p>
me more deeply than I think myself capable of being moved, except by <\p>
the stroke of a true, strong heart against my own. It is a sad pity <\p>
that he should have devoted his glorious powers to such a grimy, <\p>
unbeautiful, and positively hopeless object as this reformation of <\p>
criminals, about which he makes himself and his wretchedly small <\p>
audiences so very miserable. To tell you a secret, I never could <\p>
tolerate a philanthropist before. Could you?" <\p>
"By no means," I answered; "neither can I now." <\p>
"They are, indeed, an odiously disagreeable set of mortals," continued <\p>
Zenobia. "I should like Mr. Hollingsworth a great deal better if the <\p>
philanthropy had been left out. At all events, as a mere matter of <\p>
taste, I wish he would let the bad people alone, and try to benefit <\p>
those who are not already past his help. Do you suppose he will be <\p>
content to spend his life, or even a few months of it, among tolerably <\p>
virtuous and comfortable individuals like ourselves?" <\p>
"Upon my word, I doubt it," said I. "If we wish to keep him with us, we <\p>
must systematically commit at least one crime apiece! Mere peccadillos <\p>
will not satisfy him." <\p>
Zenobia turned, sidelong, a strange kind of a glance upon me; but, <\p>
before I could make out what it meant, we had entered the kitchen, <\p>
where, in accordance with the rustic simplicity of our new life, the <\p>
supper-table was spread. <\p>
IV. THE SUPPER-TABLE <\p>
The pleasant firelight! I must still keep harping on it. The kitchen <\p>
hearth had an old-fashioned breadth, depth, and spaciousness, far <\p>
within which lay what seemed the butt of a good-sized oak-tree, with <\p>
the moisture bubbling merrily out at both ends. It was now half an <\p>
hour beyond dusk. The blaze from an armful of substantial sticks, <\p>
rendered more combustible by brushwood and pine, flickered powerfully <\p>
on the smoke-blackened walls, and so cheered our spirits that we cared <\p>
not what inclemency might rage and roar on the other side of our <\p>
illuminated windows. A yet sultrier warmth was bestowed by a goodly <\p>
quantity of peat, which was crumbling to white ashes among the burning <\p>
brands, and incensed the kitchen with its not ungrateful fragrance. <\p>
The exuberance of this household fire would alone have sufficed to <\p>
bespeak us no true farmers; for the New England yeoman, if he have the <\p>
misfortune to dwell within practicable distance of a wood-market, is as <\p>
niggardly of each stick as if it were a bar of California gold. <\p>
But it was fortunate for us, on that wintry eve of our untried life, to <\p>
enjoy the warm and radiant luxury of a somewhat too abundant fire. If <\p>
it served no other purpose, it made the men look so full of youth, warm <\p>
blood, and hope, and the women--such of them, at least, as were anywise <\p>
convertible by its magic--so very beautiful, that I would cheerfully <\p>
have spent my last dollar to prolong the blaze. As for Zenobia, there <\p>
was a glow in her cheeks that made me think of Pandora, fresh from <\p>
Vulcan's workshop, and full of the celestial warmth by dint of which he <\p>
had tempered and moulded her. <\p>
"Take your places, my dear friends all," cried she; "seat yourselves <\p>
without ceremony, and you shall be made happy with such tea as not many <\p>
of the world's working-people, except yourselves, will find in their <\p>
cups to-night. After this one supper, you may drink buttermilk, if you <\p>
please. To-night we will quaff this nectar, which, I assure you, could <\p>
not be bought with gold." <\p>
We all sat down,--grizzly Silas Foster, his rotund helpmate, and the <\p>
two bouncing handmaidens, included,--and looked at one another in a <\p>
friendly but rather awkward way. It was the first practical trial of <\p>
our theories of equal brotherhood and sisterhood; and we people of <\p>
superior cultivation and refinement (for as such, I presume, we <\p>
unhesitatingly reckoned ourselves) felt as if something were already <\p>
accomplished towards the millennium of love. The truth is, however, <\p>
that the laboring oar was with our unpolished companions; it being far <\p>
easier to condescend than to accept of condescension. Neither did I <\p>
refrain from questioning, in secret, whether some of us--and Zenobia <\p>
among the rest--would so quietly have taken our places among these good <\p>
people, save for the cherished consciousness that it was not by <\p>
necessity but choice. Though we saw fit to drink our tea out of <\p>
earthen cups to-night, and in earthen company, it was at our own option <\p>
to use pictured porcelain and handle silver forks again to-morrow. <\p>
This same salvo, as to the power of regaining our former position, <\p>
contributed much, I fear, to the equanimity with which we subsequently <\p>
bore many of the hardships and humiliations of a life of toil. If ever <\p>
I have deserved (which has not often been the case, and, I think, <\p>
never), but if ever I did deserve to be soundly cuffed by a fellow <\p>
mortal, for secretly putting weight upon some imaginary social <\p>
advantage, it must have been while I was striving to prove myself <\p>
ostentatiously his equal and no more. It was while I sat beside him on <\p>
his cobbler's bench, or clinked my hoe against his own in the <\p>
cornfield, or broke the same crust of bread, my earth-grimed hand to <\p>
his, at our noontide lunch. The poor, proud man should look at both <\p>
sides of sympathy like this. <\p>
The silence which followed upon our sitting down to table grew rather <\p>
oppressive; indeed, it was hardly broken by a word, during the first <\p>
round of Zenobia's fragrant tea. <\p>
"I hope," said I, at last, "that our blazing windows will be visible a <\p>
great way off. There is nothing so pleasant and encouraging to a <\p>
solitary traveller, on a stormy night, as a flood of firelight seen <\p>
amid the gloom. These ruddy window panes cannot fail to cheer the <\p>
hearts of all that look at them. Are they not warm with the <\p>
beacon-fire which we have kindled for humanity?" <\p>
"The blaze of that brushwood will only last a minute or two longer," <\p>
observed Silas Foster; but whether he meant to insinuate that our moral <\p>
illumination would have as brief a term, I cannot say. <\p>
"Meantime," said Zenobia, "it may serve to guide some wayfarer to a <\p>
shelter." <\p>
And, just as she said this, there came a knock at the house door. <\p>
"There is one of the world's wayfarers," said I. "Ay, ay, just so!" <\p>
quoth Silas Foster. "Our firelight will draw stragglers, just as a <\p>
candle draws dorbugs on a summer night." <\p>
Whether to enjoy a dramatic suspense, or that we were selfishly <\p>
contrasting our own comfort with the chill and dreary situation of the <\p>
unknown person at the threshold, or that some of us city folk felt a <\p>
little startled at the knock which came so unseasonably, through night <\p>
and storm, to the door of the lonely farmhouse,--so it happened that <\p>
nobody, for an instant or two, arose to answer the summons. Pretty <\p>
soon there came another knock. The first had been moderately loud; the <\p>
second was smitten so forcibly that the knuckles of the applicant must <\p>
have left their mark in the door panel. <\p>
"He knocks as if he had a right to come in," said Zenobia, laughing. <\p>
"And what are we thinking of?--It must be Mr. Hollingsworth!" <\p>
Hereupon I went to the door, unbolted, and flung it wide open. There, <\p>
sure enough, stood Hollingsworth, his shaggy greatcoat all covered with <\p>
snow, so that he looked quite as much like a polar bear as a modern <\p>
philanthropist. <\p>
"Sluggish hospitality this!" said he, in those deep tones of his, which <\p>
seemed to come out of a chest as capacious as a barrel. "It would have <\p>
served you right if I had lain down and spent the night on the <\p>
doorstep, just for the sake of putting you to shame. But here is a <\p>
guest who will need a warmer and softer bed." <\p>
And, stepping back to the wagon in which he had journeyed hither, <\p>
Hollingsworth received into his arms and deposited on the doorstep a <\p>
figure enveloped in a cloak. It was evidently a woman; or, <\p>
rather,--judging from the ease with which he lifted her, and the little <\p>
space which she seemed to fill in his arms, a slim and unsubstantial <\p>
girl. As she showed some hesitation about entering the door, <\p>
Hollingsworth, with his usual directness and lack of ceremony, urged <\p>
her forward not merely within the entry, but into the warm and strongly <\p>
lighted kitchen. <\p>
"Who is this?" whispered I, remaining behind with him, while he was <\p>
taking off his greatcoat. <\p>
"Who? Really, I don't know," answered Hollingsworth, looking at me <\p>
with some surprise. "It is a young person who belongs here, however; <\p>
and no doubt she had been expected. Zenobia, or some of the women <\p>
folks, can tell you all about it." <\p>
"I think not," said I, glancing towards the new-comer and the other <\p>
occupants of the kitchen. "Nobody seems to welcome her. I should <\p>
hardly judge that she was an expected guest." <\p>
"Well, well," said Hollingsworth quietly, "We'll make it right." <\p>
The stranger, or whatever she were, remained standing precisely on that <\p>
spot of the kitchen floor to which Hollingsworth's kindly hand had <\p>
impelled her. The cloak falling partly off, she was seen to be a very <\p>
young woman dressed in a poor but decent gown, made high in the neck, <\p>
and without any regard to fashion or smartness. Her brown hair fell <\p>
down from beneath a hood, not in curls but with only a slight wave; her <\p>
face was of a wan, almost sickly hue, betokening habitual seclusion <\p>
from the sun and free atmosphere, like a flower-shrub that had done its <\p>
best to blossom in too scanty light. To complete the pitiableness of <\p>
her aspect, she shivered either with cold, or fear, or nervous <\p>
excitement, so that you might have beheld her shadow vibrating on the <\p>
fire-lighted wall. In short, there has seldom been seen so depressed <\p>
and sad a figure as this young girl's; and it was hardly possible to <\p>
help being angry with her, from mere despair of doing anything for her <\p>
comfort. The fantasy occurred to me that she was some desolate kind of <\p>
a creature, doomed to wander about in snowstorms; and that, though the <\p>
ruddiness of our window panes had tempted her into a human dwelling, <\p>
she would not remain long enough to melt the icicles out of her hair. <\p>
Another conjecture likewise came into my mind. Recollecting <\p>
Hollingsworth's sphere of philanthropic action, I deemed it possible <\p>
that he might have brought one of his guilty patients, to be wrought <\p>
upon and restored to spiritual health by the pure influences which our <\p>
mode of life would create. <\p>
As yet the girl had not stirred. She stood near the door, fixing a <\p>
pair of large, brown, melancholy eyes upon Zenobia--only upon <\p>
Zenobia!--she evidently saw nothing else in the room save that bright, <\p>
fair, rosy, beautiful woman. It was the strangest look I ever <\p>
witnessed; long a mystery to me, and forever a memory. Once she seemed <\p>
about to move forward and greet her,--I know not with what warmth or <\p>
with what words,--but, finally, instead of doing so, she dropped down <\p>
upon her knees, clasped her hands, and gazed piteously into Zenobia's <\p>
face. Meeting no kindly reception, her head fell on her bosom. <\p>
I never thoroughly forgave Zenobia for her conduct on this occasion. <\p>
But women are always more cautious in their casual hospitalities than <\p>
men. <\p>
"What does the girl mean?" cried she in rather a sharp tone. "Is she <\p>
crazy? Has she no tongue?" <\p>
And here Hollingsworth stepped forward. <\p>
"No wonder if the poor child's tongue is frozen in her mouth," said he; <\p>
and I think he positively frowned at Zenobia. "The very heart will be <\p>
frozen in her bosom, unless you women can warm it, among you, with the <\p>
warmth that ought to be in your own!" <\p>
Hollingsworth's appearance was very striking at this moment. He was <\p>
then about thirty years old, but looked several years older, with his <\p>
great shaggy head, his heavy brow, his dark complexion, his abundant <\p>
beard, and the rude strength with which his features seemed to have <\p>
been hammered out of iron, rather than chiselled or moulded from any <\p>
finer or softer material. His figure was not tall, but massive and <\p>
brawny, and well befitting his original occupation; which as the reader <\p>
probably knows--was that of a blacksmith. As for external polish, or <\p>
mere courtesy of manner, he never possessed more than a tolerably <\p>
educated bear; although, in his gentler moods, there was a tenderness <\p>
in his voice, eyes, mouth, in his gesture, and in every indescribable <\p>
manifestation, which few men could resist and no woman. But he now <\p>
looked stern and reproachful; and it was with that inauspicious meaning <\p>
in his glance that Hollingsworth first met Zenobia's eyes, and began <\p>
his influence upon her life. <\p>
To my surprise, Zenobia--of whose haughty spirit I had been told so <\p>
many examples--absolutely changed color, and seemed mortified and <\p>
confused. <\p>
"You do not quite do me justice, Mr. Hollingsworth," said she almost <\p>
humbly. "I am willing to be kind to the poor girl. Is she a protegee <\p>
of yours? What can I do for her?" <\p>
"Have you anything to ask of this lady?" said Hollingsworth kindly to <\p>
the girl. "I remember you mentioned her name before we left town." <\p>
"Only that she will shelter me," replied the girl tremulously. "Only <\p>
that she will let me be always near her." <\p>
"Well, indeed," exclaimed Zenobia, recovering herself and laughing, <\p>
"this is an adventure, and well-worthy to be the first incident in our <\p>
life of love and free-heartedness! But I accept it, for the present, <\p>
without further question, only," added she, "it would be a convenience <\p>
if we knew your name." <\p>
"Priscilla," said the girl; and it appeared to me that she hesitated <\p>
whether to add anything more, and decided in the negative. "Pray do <\p>
not ask me my other name,--at least not yet,--if you will be so kind to <\p>
a forlorn creature." <\p>
Priscilla!--Priscilla! I repeated the name to myself three or four <\p>
times; and in that little space, this quaint and prim cognomen had so <\p>
amalgamated itself with my idea of the girl, that it seemed as if no <\p>
other name could have adhered to her for a moment. Heretofore the poor <\p>
thing had not shed any tears; but now that she found herself received, <\p>
and at least temporarily established, the big drops began to ooze out <\p>
from beneath her eyelids as if she were full of them. Perhaps it showed <\p>
the iron substance of my heart, that I could not help smiling at this <\p>
odd scene of unknown and unaccountable calamity, into which our <\p>
cheerful party had been entrapped without the liberty of choosing <\p>
whether to sympathize or no. Hollingsworth's behavior was certainly a <\p>
great deal more creditable than mine. <\p>
"Let us not pry further into her secrets," he said to Zenobia and the <\p>
rest of us, apart; and his dark, shaggy face looked really beautiful <\p>
with its expression of thoughtful benevolence. "Let us conclude that <\p>
Providence has sent her to us, as the first-fruits of the world, which <\p>
we have undertaken to make happier than we find it. Let us warm her <\p>
poor, shivering body with this good fire, and her poor, shivering heart <\p>
with our best kindness. Let us feed her, and make her one of us. As <\p>
we do by this friendless girl, so shall we prosper. And, in good time, <\p>
whatever is desirable for us to know will be melted out of her, as <\p>
inevitably as those tears which we see now." <\p>
"At least," remarked I, "you may tell us how and where you met with <\p>
her." <\p>
"An old man brought her to my lodgings," answered Hollingsworth, "and <\p>
begged me to convey her to Blithedale, where--so I understood him--she <\p>
had friends; and this is positively all I know about the matter." <\p>
Grim Silas Foster, all this while, had been busy at the supper-table, <\p>
pouring out his own tea and gulping it down with no more sense of its <\p>
exquisiteness than if it were a decoction of catnip; helping himself to <\p>
pieces of dipt toast on the flat of his knife blade, and dropping half <\p>
of it on the table-cloth; using the same serviceable implement to cut <\p>
slice after slice of ham; perpetrating terrible enormities with the <\p>
butter-plate; and in all other respects behaving less like a civilized <\p>
Christian than the worst kind of an ogre. Being by this time fully <\p>
gorged, he crowned his amiable exploits with a draught from the water <\p>
pitcher, and then favored us with his opinion about the business in <\p>
hand. And, certainly, though they proceeded out of an unwiped mouth, <\p>
his expressions did him honor. <\p>
"Give the girl a hot cup of tea and a thick slice of this first-rate <\p>
bacon," said Silas, like a sensible man as he was. "That's what she <\p>
wants. Let her stay with us as long as she likes, and help in the <\p>
kitchen, and take the cow-breath at milking time; and, in a week or <\p>
two, she'll begin to look like a creature of this world." <\p>
So we sat down again to supper, and Priscilla along with us. <\p>
V. UNTIL BEDTIME <\p>
Silas Foster, by the time we concluded our meal, had stript off his <\p>
coat, and planted himself on a low chair by the kitchen fire, with a <\p>
lapstone, a hammer, a piece of sole leather, and some waxed-ends, in <\p>
order to cobble an old pair of cowhide boots; he being, in his own <\p>
phrase, "something of a dab" (whatever degree of skill that may imply) <\p>
at the shoemaking business. We heard the tap of his hammer at <\p>
intervals for the rest of the evening. The remainder of the party <\p>
adjourned to the sitting-room. Good Mrs. Foster took her <\p>
knitting-work, and soon fell fast asleep, still keeping her needles in <\p>
brisk movement, and, to the best of my observation, absolutely footing <\p>
a stocking out of the texture of a dream. And a very substantial <\p>
stocking it seemed to be. One of the two handmaidens hemmed a towel, <\p>
and the other appeared to be making a ruffle, for her Sunday's wear, <\p>
out of a little bit of embroidered muslin which Zenobia had probably <\p>
given her. <\p>
It was curious to observe how trustingly, and yet how timidly, our poor <\p>
Priscilla betook herself into the shadow of Zenobia's protection. She <\p>
sat beside her on a stool, looking up every now and then with an <\p>
expression of humble delight at her new friend's beauty. A brilliant <\p>
woman is often an object of the devoted admiration--it might almost be <\p>
termed worship, or idolatry--of some young girl, who perhaps beholds <\p>
the cynosure only at an awful distance, and has as little hope of <\p>
personal intercourse as of climbing among the stars of heaven. We men <\p>
are too gross to comprehend it. Even a woman, of mature age, despises <\p>
or laughs at such a passion. There occurred to me no mode of <\p>
accounting for Priscilla's behavior, except by supposing that she had <\p>
read some of Zenobia's stories (as such literature goes everywhere), or <\p>
her tracts in defence of the sex, and had come hither with the one <\p>
purpose of being her slave. There is nothing parallel to this, I <\p>
believe,--nothing so foolishly disinterested, and hardly anything so <\p>
beautiful,--in the masculine nature, at whatever epoch of life; or, if <\p>
there be, a fine and rare development of character might reasonably be <\p>
looked for from the youth who should prove himself capable of such <\p>
self-forgetful affection. <\p>
Zenobia happening to change her seat, I took the opportunity, in an <\p>
undertone, to suggest some such notion as the above. <\p>
"Since you see the young woman in so poetical a light," replied she in <\p>
the same tone, "you had better turn the affair into a ballad. It is a <\p>
grand subject, and worthy of supernatural machinery. The storm, the <\p>
startling knock at the door, the entrance of the sable knight <\p>
Hollingsworth and this shadowy snow-maiden, who, precisely at the <\p>
stroke of midnight, shall melt away at my feet in a pool of ice-cold <\p>
water and give me my death with a pair of wet slippers! And when the <\p>
verses are written, and polished quite to your mind, I will favor you <\p>
with my idea as to what the girl really is." <\p>
"Pray let me have it now," said I; "it shall be woven into the ballad." <\p>
"She is neither more nor less," answered Zenobia, "than a seamstress <\p>
from the city; and she has probably no more transcendental purpose than <\p>
to do my miscellaneous sewing, for I suppose she will hardly expect to <\p>
make my dresses." <\p>
"How can you decide upon her so easily?" I inquired. <\p>
"Oh, we women judge one another by tokens that escape the obtuseness of <\p>
masculine perceptions!" said Zenobia. "There is no proof which you <\p>
would be likely to appreciate, except the needle marks on the tip of <\p>
her forefinger. Then, my supposition perfectly accounts for her <\p>
paleness, her nervousness, and her wretched fragility. Poor thing! She <\p>
has been stifled with the heat of a salamander stove, in a small, close <\p>
room, and has drunk coffee, and fed upon doughnuts, raisins, candy, and <\p>
all such trash, till she is scarcely half alive; and so, as she has <\p>
hardly any physique, a poet like Mr. Miles Coverdale may be allowed to <\p>
think her spiritual." <\p>
"Look at her now!" whispered I. <\p>
Priscilla was gazing towards us with an inexpressible sorrow in her wan <\p>
face and great tears running down her cheeks. It was difficult to <\p>
resist the impression that, cautiously as we had lowered our voices, <\p>
she must have overheard and been wounded by Zenobia's scornful estimate <\p>
of her character and purposes. <\p>
"What ears the girl must have!" whispered Zenobia, with a look of <\p>
vexation, partly comic and partly real. "I will confess to you that I <\p>
cannot quite make her out. However, I am positively not an ill-natured <\p>
person, unless when very grievously provoked,--and as you, and <\p>
especially Mr. Hollingsworth, take so much interest in this odd <\p>
creature, and as she knocks with a very slight tap against my own heart <\p>
likewise,--why, I mean to let her in. From this moment I will be <\p>
reasonably kind to her. There is no pleasure in tormenting a person of <\p>
one's own sex, even if she do favor one with a little more love than <\p>
one can conveniently dispose of; and that, let me say, Mr. Coverdale, <\p>
is the most troublesome offence you can offer to a woman." <\p>
"Thank you," said I, smiling; "I don't mean to be guilty of it." <\p>
She went towards Priscilla, took her hand, and passed her own rosy <\p>
finger-tips, with a pretty, caressing movement, over the girl's hair. <\p>
The touch had a magical effect. So vivid a look of joy flushed up <\p>
beneath those fingers, that it seemed as if the sad and wan Priscilla <\p>
had been snatched away, and another kind of creature substituted in her <\p>
place. This one caress, bestowed voluntarily by Zenobia, was evidently <\p>
received as a pledge of all that the stranger sought from her, whatever <\p>
the unuttered boon might be. From that instant, too, she melted in <\p>
quietly amongst us, and was no longer a foreign element. Though always <\p>
an object of peculiar interest, a riddle, and a theme of frequent <\p>
discussion, her tenure at Blithedale was thenceforth fixed. We no more <\p>
thought of questioning it, than if Priscilla had been recognized as a <\p>
domestic sprite, who had haunted the rustic fireside of old, before we <\p>
had ever been warmed by its blaze. <\p>
She now produced, out of a work-bag that she had with her, some little <\p>
wooden instruments (what they are called I never knew), and proceeded <\p>
to knit, or net, an article which ultimately took the shape of a silk <\p>
purse. As the work went on, I remembered to have seen just such purses <\p>
before; indeed, I was the possessor of one. Their peculiar excellence, <\p>
besides the great delicacy and beauty of the manufacture, lay in the <\p>
almost impossibility that any uninitiated person should discover the <\p>
aperture; although, to a practised touch, they would open as wide as <\p>
charity or prodigality might wish. I wondered if it were not a symbol <\p>
of Priscilla's own mystery. <\p>
Notwithstanding the new confidence with which Zenobia had inspired her, <\p>
our guest showed herself disquieted by the storm. When the strong <\p>
puffs of wind spattered the snow against the windows and made the oaken <\p>
frame of the farmhouse creak, she looked at us apprehensively, as if to <\p>
inquire whether these tempestuous outbreaks did not betoken some <\p>
unusual mischief in the shrieking blast. She had been bred up, no <\p>
doubt, in some close nook, some inauspiciously sheltered court of the <\p>
city, where the uttermost rage of a tempest, though it might scatter <\p>
down the slates of the roof into the bricked area, could not shake the <\p>
casement of her little room. The sense of vast, undefined space, <\p>
pressing from the outside against the black panes of our uncurtained <\p>
windows, was fearful to the poor girl, heretofore accustomed to the <\p>
narrowness of human limits, with the lamps of neighboring tenements <\p>
glimmering across the street. The house probably seemed to her adrift <\p>
on the great ocean of the night. A little parallelogram of sky was all <\p>
that she had hitherto known of nature, so that she felt the awfulness <\p>
that really exists in its limitless extent. Once, while the blast was <\p>
bellowing, she caught hold of Zenobia's robe, with precisely the air of <\p>
one who hears her own name spoken at a distance, but is unutterably <\p>
reluctant to obey the call. <\p>
We spent rather an incommunicative evening. Hollingsworth hardly said <\p>
a word, unless when repeatedly and pertinaciously addressed. Then, <\p>
indeed, he would glare upon us from the thick shrubbery of his <\p>
meditations like a tiger out of a jungle, make the briefest reply <\p>
possible, and betake himself back into the solitude of his heart and <\p>
mind. The poor fellow had contracted this ungracious habit from the <\p>
intensity with which he contemplated his own ideas, and the infrequent <\p>
sympathy which they met with from his auditors,--a circumstance that <\p>
seemed only to strengthen the implicit confidence that he awarded to <\p>
them. His heart, I imagine, was never really interested in our <\p>
socialist scheme, but was forever busy with his strange, and, as most <\p>
people thought it, impracticable plan, for the reformation of criminals <\p>
through an appeal to their higher instincts. <\p>
Much as I liked Hollingsworth, it cost me many a groan to tolerate him <\p>
on this point. He ought to have commenced his investigation of the <\p>
subject by perpetrating some huge sin in his proper person, and <\p>
examining the condition of his higher instincts afterwards. <\p>
The rest of us formed ourselves into a committee for providing our <\p>
infant community with an appropriate name,--a matter of greatly more <\p>
difficulty than the uninitiated reader would suppose. Blithedale was <\p>
neither good nor bad. We should have resumed the old Indian name of <\p>
the premises, had it possessed the oil-and-honey flow which the <\p>
aborigines were so often happy in communicating to their local <\p>
appellations; but it chanced to be a harsh, ill-connected, and <\p>
interminable word, which seemed to fill the mouth with a mixture of <\p>
very stiff clay and very crumbly pebbles. Zenobia suggested "Sunny <\p>
Glimpse," as expressive of a vista into a better system of society. <\p>
This we turned over and over for a while, acknowledging its prettiness, <\p>
but concluded it to be rather too fine and sentimental a name (a fault <\p>
inevitable by literary ladies in such attempts) for sunburnt men to <\p>
work under. I ventured to whisper "Utopia," which, however, was <\p>
unanimously scouted down, and the proposer very harshly maltreated, as <\p>
if he had intended a latent satire. Some were for calling our <\p>
institution "The Oasis," in view of its being the one green spot in the <\p>
moral sand-waste of the world; but others insisted on a proviso for <\p>
reconsidering the matter at a twelvemonths' end, when a final decision <\p>
might be had, whether to name it "The Oasis" or "Sahara." So, at last, <\p>
finding it impracticable to hammer out anything better, we resolved <\p>
that the spot should still be Blithedale, as being of good augury <\p>
enough. <\p>
The evening wore on, and the outer solitude looked in upon us through <\p>
the windows, gloomy, wild, and vague, like another state of existence, <\p>
close beside the little sphere of warmth and light in which we were the <\p>
prattlers and bustlers of a moment. By and by the door was opened by <\p>
Silas Foster, with a cotton handkerchief about his head, and a tallow <\p>
candle in his hand. <\p>
"Take my advice, brother farmers," said he, with a great, broad, <\p>
bottomless yawn, "and get to bed as soon as you can. I shall sound the <\p>
horn at daybreak; and we've got the cattle to fodder, and nine cows to <\p>
milk, and a dozen other things to do, before breakfast." <\p>
Thus ended the first evening at Blithedale. I went shivering to my <\p>
fireless chamber, with the miserable consciousness (which had been <\p>
growing upon me for several hours past) that I had caught a tremendous <\p>
cold, and should probably awaken, at the blast of the horn, a fit <\p>
subject for a hospital. The night proved a feverish one. During the <\p>
greater part of it, I was in that vilest of states when a fixed idea <\p>
remains in the mind, like the nail in Sisera's brain, while innumerable <\p>
other ideas go and come, and flutter to and fro, combining constant <\p>
transition with intolerable sameness. Had I made a record of that <\p>
night's half-waking dreams, it is my belief that it would have <\p>
anticipated several of the chief incidents of this narrative, including <\p>
a dim shadow of its catastrophe. Starting up in bed at length, I saw <\p>
that the storm was past, and the moon was shining on the snowy <\p>
landscape, which looked like a lifeless copy of the world in marble. <\p>
From the bank of the distant river, which was shimmering in the <\p>
moonlight, came the black shadow of the only cloud in heaven, driven <\p>
swiftly by the wind, and passing over meadow and hillock, vanishing <\p>
amid tufts of leafless trees, but reappearing on the hither side, until <\p>
it swept across our doorstep. <\p>
How cold an Arcadia was this! <\p>
VI. COVERDALE'S SICK-CHAMBER <\p>
The horn sounded at daybreak, as Silas Foster had forewarned us, harsh, <\p>
uproarious, inexorably drawn out, and as sleep-dispelling as if this <\p>
hard-hearted old yeoman had got hold of the trump of doom. <\p>
On all sides I could hear the creaking of the bedsteads, as the <\p>
brethren of Blithedale started from slumber, and thrust themselves into <\p>
their habiliments, all awry, no doubt, in their haste to begin the <\p>
reformation of the world. Zenobia put her head into the entry, and <\p>
besought Silas Foster to cease his clamor, and to be kind enough to <\p>
leave an armful of firewood and a pail of water at her chamber door. <\p>
Of the whole household,--unless, indeed, it were Priscilla, for whose <\p>
habits, in this particular, I cannot vouch,--of all our apostolic <\p>
society, whose mission was to bless mankind, Hollingsworth, I <\p>
apprehend, was the only one who began the enterprise with prayer. My <\p>
sleeping-room being but thinly partitioned from his, the solemn murmur <\p>
of his voice made its way to my ears, compelling me to be an auditor of <\p>
his awful privacy with the Creator. It affected me with a deep <\p>
reverence for Hollingsworth, which no familiarity then existing, or <\p>
that afterwards grew more intimate between us,--no, nor my subsequent <\p>
perception of his own great errors,--ever quite effaced. It is so rare, <\p>
in these times, to meet with a man of prayerful habits (except, of <\p>
course, in the pulpit), that such an one is decidedly marked out by the <\p>
light of transfiguration, shed upon him in the divine interview from <\p>
which he passes into his daily life. <\p>
As for me, I lay abed; and if I said my prayers, it was backward, <\p>
cursing my day as bitterly as patient Job himself. The truth was, the <\p>
hot-house warmth of a town residence, and the luxurious life in which I <\p>
indulged myself, had taken much of the pith out of my physical system; <\p>
and the wintry blast of the preceding day, together with the general <\p>
chill of our airy old farmhouse, had got fairly into my heart and the <\p>
marrow of my bones. In this predicament, I seriously wished--selfish <\p>
as it may appear--that the reformation of society had been postponed <\p>
about half a century, or, at all events, to such a date as should have <\p>
put my intermeddling with it entirely out of the question. <\p>
What, in the name of common-sense, had I to do with any better society <\p>
than I had always lived in? It had satisfied me well enough. My <\p>
pleasant bachelor-parlor, sunny and shadowy, curtained and carpeted, <\p>
with the bedchamber adjoining; my centre-table, strewn with books and <\p>
periodicals; my writing-desk with a half-finished poem, in a stanza of <\p>
my own contrivance; my morning lounge at the reading-room or picture <\p>
gallery; my noontide walk along the cheery pavement, with the <\p>
suggestive succession of human faces, and the brisk throb of human life <\p>
in which I shared; my dinner at the Albion, where I had a hundred <\p>
dishes at command, and could banquet as delicately as the wizard <\p>
Michael Scott when the Devil fed him from the king of France's kitchen; <\p>
my evening at the billiard club, the concert, the theatre, or at <\p>
somebody's party, if I pleased,--what could be better than all this? <\p>
Was it better to hoe, to mow, to toil and moil amidst the accumulations <\p>
of a barnyard; to be the chambermaid of two yoke of oxen and a dozen <\p>
cows; to eat salt beef, and earn it with the sweat of my brow, and <\p>
thereby take the tough morsel out of some wretch's mouth, into whose <\p>
vocation I had thrust myself? Above all, was it better to have a fever <\p>
and die blaspheming, as I was like to do? <\p>
In this wretched plight, with a furnace in my heart and another in my <\p>
head, by the heat of which I was kept constantly at the boiling point, <\p>
yet shivering at the bare idea of extruding so much as a finger into <\p>
the icy atmosphere of the room, I kept my bed until breakfast-time, <\p>
when Hollingsworth knocked at the door, and entered. <\p>
"Well, Coverdale," cried he, "you bid fair to make an admirable farmer! <\p>
Don't you mean to get up to-day?" <\p>
"Neither to-day nor to-morrow," said I hopelessly. "I doubt if I ever <\p>
rise again!" <\p>
"What is the matter now?" he asked. <\p>
I told him my piteous case, and besought him to send me back to town in <\p>
a close carriage. <\p>
"No, no!" said Hollingsworth with kindly seriousness. "If you are <\p>
really sick, we must take care of you." <\p>
Accordingly he built a fire in my chamber, and, having little else to <\p>
do while the snow lay on the ground, established himself as my nurse. A <\p>
doctor was sent for, who, being homaeopathic, gave me as much medicine, <\p>
in the course of a fortnight's attendance, as would have laid on the <\p>
point of a needle. They fed me on water-gruel, and I speedily became a <\p>
skeleton above ground. But, after all, I have many precious <\p>
recollections connected with that fit of sickness. <\p>
Hollingsworth's more than brotherly attendance gave me inexpressible <\p>
comfort. Most men--and certainly I could not always claim to be one of <\p>
the exceptions--have a natural indifference, if not an absolutely <\p>
hostile feeling, towards those whom disease, or weakness, or calamity <\p>
of any kind causes to falter and faint amid the rude jostle of our <\p>
selfish existence. The education of Christianity, it is true, the <\p>
sympathy of a like experience and the example of women, may soften and, <\p>
possibly, subvert this ugly characteristic of our sex; but it is <\p>
originally there, and has likewise its analogy in the practice of our <\p>
brute brethren, who hunt the sick or disabled member of the herd from <\p>
among them, as an enemy. It is for this reason that the stricken deer <\p>
goes apart, and the sick lion grimly withdraws himself into his den. <\p>
Except in love, or the attachments of kindred, or other very long and <\p>
habitual affection, we really have no tenderness. But there was <\p>
something of the woman moulded into the great, stalwart frame of <\p>
Hollingsworth; nor was he ashamed of it, as men often are of what is <\p>
best in them, nor seemed ever to know that there was such a soft place <\p>
in his heart. I knew it well, however, at that time, although <\p>
afterwards it came nigh to be forgotten. Methought there could not be <\p>
two such men alive as Hollingsworth. There never was any blaze of a <\p>
fireside that warmed and cheered me, in the down-sinkings and <\p>
shiverings of my spirit, so effectually as did the light out of those <\p>
eyes, which lay so deep and dark under his shaggy brows. <\p>
Happy the man that has such a friend beside him when he comes to die! <\p>
and unless a friend like Hollingsworth be at hand,--as most probably <\p>
there will not,--he had better make up his mind to die alone. How many <\p>
men, I wonder, does one meet with in a lifetime, whom he would choose <\p>
for his deathbed companions! At the crisis of my fever I besought <\p>
Hollingsworth to let nobody else enter the room, but continually to <\p>
make me sensible of his own presence by a grasp of the hand, a word, a <\p>
prayer, if he thought good to utter it; and that then he should be the <\p>
witness how courageously I would encounter the worst. It still <\p>
impresses me as almost a matter of regret that I did not die then, when <\p>
I had tolerably made up my mind to it; for Hollingsworth would have <\p>
gone with me to the hither verge of life, and have sent his friendly <\p>
and hopeful accents far over on the other side, while I should be <\p>
treading the unknown path. Now, were I to send for him, he would <\p>
hardly come to my bedside, nor should I depart the easier for his <\p>
presence. <\p>
"You are not going to die, this time," said he, gravely smiling. "You <\p>
know nothing about sickness, and think your case a great deal more <\p>
desperate than it is." <\p>
"Death should take me while I am in the mood," replied I, with a little <\p>
of my customary levity. <\p>
"Have you nothing to do in life," asked Hollingsworth, "that you fancy <\p>
yourself so ready to leave it?" <\p>
"Nothing," answered I; "nothing that I know of, unless to make pretty <\p>
verses, and play a part, with Zenobia and the rest of the amateurs, in <\p>
our pastoral. It seems but an unsubstantial sort of business, as <\p>
viewed through a mist of fever. But, dear Hollingsworth, your own <\p>
vocation is evidently to be a priest, and to spend your days and nights <\p>
in helping your fellow creatures to draw peaceful dying breaths." <\p>
"And by which of my qualities," inquired he, "can you suppose me fitted <\p>
for this awful ministry?" <\p>
"By your tenderness," I said. "It seems to me the reflection of God's <\p>
own love." <\p>
"And you call me tender!" repeated Hollingsworth thoughtfully. "I <\p>
should rather say that the most marked trait in my character is an <\p>
inflexible severity of purpose. Mortal man has no right to be so <\p>
inflexible as it is my nature and necessity to be." <\p>
"I do not believe it," I replied. <\p>
But, in due time, I remembered what he said. <\p>
Probably, as Hollingsworth suggested, my disorder was never so serious <\p>
as, in my ignorance of such matters, I was inclined to consider it. <\p>
After so much tragical preparation, it was positively rather mortifying <\p>
to find myself on the mending hand. <\p>
All the other members of the Community showed me kindness, according to <\p>
the full measure of their capacity. Zenobia brought me my gruel every <\p>
day, made by her own hands (not very skilfully, if the truth must be <\p>
told), and, whenever I seemed inclined to converse, would sit by my <\p>
bedside, and talk with so much vivacity as to add several gratuitous <\p>
throbs to my pulse. Her poor little stories and tracts never half did <\p>
justice to her intellect. It was only the lack of a fitter avenue that <\p>
drove her to seek development in literature. She was made (among a <\p>
thousand other things that she might have been) for a stump oratress. <\p>
I recognized no severe culture in Zenobia; her mind was full of weeds. <\p>
It startled me sometimes, in my state of moral as well as bodily <\p>
faint-heartedness, to observe the hardihood of her philosophy. She <\p>
made no scruple of oversetting all human institutions, and scattering <\p>
them as with a breeze from her fan. A female reformer, in her attacks <\p>
upon society, has an instinctive sense of where the life lies, and is <\p>
inclined to aim directly at that spot. Especially the relation between <\p>
the sexes is naturally among the earliest to attract her notice. <\p>
Zenobia was truly a magnificent woman. The homely simplicity of her <\p>
dress could not conceal, nor scarcely diminish, the queenliness of her <\p>
presence. The image of her form and face should have been multiplied <\p>
all over the earth. It was wronging the rest of mankind to retain her <\p>
as the spectacle of only a few. The stage would have been her proper <\p>
sphere. She should have made it a point of duty, moreover, to sit <\p>
endlessly to painters and sculptors, and preferably to the latter; <\p>
because the cold decorum of the marble would consist with the utmost <\p>
scantiness of drapery, so that the eye might chastely be gladdened with <\p>
her material perfection in its entireness. I know not well how to <\p>
express that the native glow of coloring in her cheeks, and even the <\p>
flesh-warmth over her round arms, and what was visible of her full <\p>
bust,--in a word, her womanliness incarnated,--compelled me sometimes <\p>
to close my eyes, as if it were not quite the privilege of modesty to <\p>
gaze at her. Illness and exhaustion, no doubt, had made me morbidly <\p>
sensitive. <\p>
I noticed--and wondered how Zenobia contrived it--that she had always a <\p>
new flower in her hair. And still it was a hot-house flower,--an <\p>
outlandish flower,--a flower of the tropics, such as appeared to have <\p>
sprung passionately out of a soil the very weeds of which would be <\p>
fervid and spicy. Unlike as was the flower of each successive day to <\p>
the preceding one, it yet so assimilated its richness to the rich <\p>
beauty of the woman, that I thought it the only flower fit to be worn; <\p>
so fit, indeed, that Nature had evidently created this floral gem, in a <\p>
happy exuberance, for the one purpose of worthily adorning Zenobia's <\p>
head. It might be that my feverish fantasies clustered themselves <\p>
about this peculiarity, and caused it to look more gorgeous and <\p>
wonderful than if beheld with temperate eyes. In the height of my <\p>
illness, as I well recollect, I went so far as to pronounce it <\p>
preternatural. <\p>
"Zenobia is an enchantress!" whispered I once to Hollingsworth. "She <\p>
is a sister of the Veiled Lady. That flower in her hair is a talisman. <\p>
If you were to snatch it away, she would vanish, or be transformed into <\p>
something else." <\p>
"What does he say?" asked Zenobia. <\p>
"Nothing that has an atom of sense in it," answered Hollingsworth. "He <\p>
is a little beside himself, I believe, and talks about your being a <\p>
witch, and of some magical property in the flower that you wear in your <\p>
hair." <\p>
"It is an idea worthy of a feverish poet," said she, laughing rather <\p>
compassionately, and taking out the flower. "I scorn to owe anything <\p>
to magic. Here, Mr. Hollingsworth, you may keep the spell while it has <\p>
any virtue in it; but I cannot promise you not to appear with a new one <\p>
to-morrow. It is the one relic of my more brilliant, my happier days!" <\p>
The most curious part of the matter was that, long after my slight <\p>
delirium had passed away,--as long, indeed, as I continued to know this <\p>
remarkable woman,--her daily flower affected my imagination, though <\p>
more slightly, yet in very much the same way. The reason must have <\p>
been that, whether intentionally on her part or not, this favorite <\p>
ornament was actually a subtile expression of Zenobia's character. <\p>
One subject, about which--very impertinently, moreover--I perplexed <\p>
myself with a great many conjectures, was, whether Zenobia had ever <\p>
been married. The idea, it must be understood, was unauthorized by any <\p>
circumstance or suggestion that had made its way to my ears. So young <\p>
as I beheld her, and the freshest and rosiest woman of a thousand, <\p>
there was certainly no need of imputing to her a destiny already <\p>
accomplished; the probability was far greater that her coming years had <\p>
all life's richest gifts to bring. If the great event of a woman's <\p>
existence had been consummated, the world knew nothing of it, although <\p>
the world seemed to know Zenobia well. It was a ridiculous piece of <\p>
romance, undoubtedly, to imagine that this beautiful personage, wealthy <\p>
as she was, and holding a position that might fairly enough be called <\p>
distinguished, could have given herself away so privately, but that <\p>
some whisper and suspicion, and by degrees a full understanding of the <\p>
fact, would eventually be blown abroad. But then, as I failed not to <\p>
consider, her original home was at a distance of many hundred miles. <\p>
Rumors might fill the social atmosphere, or might once have filled it, <\p>
there, which would travel but slowly, against the wind, towards our <\p>
