Northeastern metropolis, and perhaps melt into thin air before reaching <\p>
it. <\p>
There was not--and I distinctly repeat it--the slightest foundation in <\p>
my knowledge for any surmise of the kind. But there is a species of <\p>
intuition,--either a spiritual lie or the subtile recognition of a <\p>
fact,--which comes to us in a reduced state of the corporeal system. <\p>
The soul gets the better of the body, after wasting illness, or when a <\p>
vegetable diet may have mingled too much ether in the blood. Vapors <\p>
then rise up to the brain, and take shapes that often image falsehood, <\p>
but sometimes truth. The spheres of our companions have, at such <\p>
periods, a vastly greater influence upon our own than when robust <\p>
health gives us a repellent and self-defensive energy. Zenobia's <\p>
sphere, I imagine, impressed itself powerfully on mine, and transformed <\p>
me, during this period of my weakness, into something like a mesmerical <\p>
clairvoyant. <\p>
Then, also, as anybody could observe, the freedom of her deportment <\p>
(though, to some tastes, it might commend itself as the utmost <\p>
perfection of manner in a youthful widow or a blooming matron) was not <\p>
exactly maiden-like. What girl had ever laughed as Zenobia did? What <\p>
girl had ever spoken in her mellow tones? Her unconstrained and <\p>
inevitable manifestation, I said often to myself, was that of a woman <\p>
to whom wedlock had thrown wide the gates of mystery. Yet sometimes I <\p>
strove to be ashamed of these conjectures. I acknowledged it as a <\p>
masculine grossness--a sin of wicked interpretation, of which man is <\p>
often guilty towards the other sex--thus to mistake the sweet, liberal, <\p>
but womanly frankness of a noble and generous disposition. Still, it <\p>
was of no avail to reason with myself nor to upbraid myself. <\p>
Pertinaciously the thought, "Zenobia is a wife; Zenobia has lived and <\p>
loved! There is no folded petal, no latent dewdrop, in this perfectly <\p>
developed rose!"--irresistibly that thought drove out all other <\p>
conclusions, as often as my mind reverted to the subject. <\p>
Zenobia was conscious of my observation, though not, I presume, of the <\p>
point to which it led me. <\p>
"Mr. Coverdale," said she one day, as she saw me watching her, while <\p>
she arranged my gruel on the table, "I have been exposed to a great <\p>
deal of eye-shot in the few years of my mixing in the world, but never, <\p>
I think, to precisely such glances as you are in the habit of favoring <\p>
me with. I seem to interest you very much; and yet--or else a woman's <\p>
instinct is for once deceived--I cannot reckon you as an admirer. What <\p>
are you seeking to discover in me?" <\p>
"The mystery of your life," answered I, surprised into the truth by the <\p>
unexpectedness of her attack. "And you will never tell me." <\p>
She bent her head towards me, and let me look into her eyes, as if <\p>
challenging me to drop a plummet-line down into the depths of her <\p>
consciousness. <\p>
"I see nothing now," said I, closing my own eyes, "unless it be the <\p>
face of a sprite laughing at me from the bottom of a deep well." <\p>
A bachelor always feels himself defrauded, when he knows or suspects <\p>
that any woman of his acquaintance has given herself away. Otherwise, <\p>
the matter could have been no concern of mine. It was purely <\p>
speculative, for I should not, under any circumstances, have fallen in <\p>
love with Zenobia. The riddle made me so nervous, however, in my <\p>
sensitive condition of mind and body, that I most ungratefully began to <\p>
wish that she would let me alone. Then, too, her gruel was very <\p>
wretched stuff, with almost invariably the smell of pine smoke upon it, <\p>
like the evil taste that is said to mix itself up with a witch's best <\p>
concocted dainties. Why could not she have allowed one of the other <\p>
women to take the gruel in charge? Whatever else might be her gifts, <\p>
Nature certainly never intended Zenobia for a cook. Or, if so, she <\p>
should have meddled only with the richest and spiciest dishes, and such <\p>
as are to be tasted at banquets, between draughts of intoxicating wine. <\p>
VII. THE CONVALESCENT <\p>
As soon as my incommodities allowed me to think of past occurrences, I <\p>
failed not to inquire what had become of the odd little guest whom <\p>
Hollingsworth had been the medium of introducing among us. It now <\p>
appeared that poor Priscilla had not so literally fallen out of the <\p>
clouds, as we were at first inclined to suppose. A letter, which <\p>
should have introduced her, had since been received from one of the <\p>
city missionaries, containing a certificate of character and an <\p>
allusion to circumstances which, in the writer's judgment, made it <\p>
especially desirable that she should find shelter in our Community. <\p>
There was a hint, not very intelligible, implying either that Priscilla <\p>
had recently escaped from some particular peril or irksomeness of <\p>
position, or else that she was still liable to this danger or <\p>
difficulty, whatever it might be. We should ill have deserved the <\p>
reputation of a benevolent fraternity, had we hesitated to entertain a <\p>
petitioner in such need, and so strongly recommended to our kindness; <\p>
not to mention, moreover, that the strange maiden had set herself <\p>
diligently to work, and was doing good service with her needle. But a <\p>
slight mist of uncertainty still floated about Priscilla, and kept her, <\p>
as yet, from taking a very decided place among creatures of flesh and <\p>
blood. <\p>
The mysterious attraction, which, from her first entrance on our scene, <\p>
she evinced for Zenobia, had lost nothing of its force. I often heard <\p>
her footsteps, soft and low, accompanying the light but decided tread <\p>
of the latter up the staircase, stealing along the passage-way by her <\p>
new friend's side, and pausing while Zenobia entered my chamber. <\p>
Occasionally Zenobia would be a little annoyed by Priscilla's too close <\p>
attendance. In an authoritative and not very kindly tone, she would <\p>
advise her to breathe the pleasant air in a walk, or to go with her <\p>
work into the barn, holding out half a promise to come and sit on the <\p>
hay with her, when at leisure. Evidently, Priscilla found but scanty <\p>
requital for her love. Hollingsworth was likewise a great favorite with <\p>
her. For several minutes together sometimes, while my auditory nerves <\p>
retained the susceptibility of delicate health, I used to hear a low, <\p>
pleasant murmur ascending from the room below; and at last ascertained <\p>
it to be Priscilla's voice, babbling like a little brook to <\p>
Hollingsworth. She talked more largely and freely with him than with <\p>
Zenobia, towards whom, indeed, her feelings seemed not so much to be <\p>
confidence as involuntary affection. I should have thought all the <\p>
better of my own qualities had Priscilla marked me out for the third <\p>
place in her regards. But, though she appeared to like me tolerably <\p>
well, I could never flatter myself with being distinguished by her as <\p>
Hollingsworth and Zenobia were. <\p>
One forenoon, during my convalescence, there came a gentle tap at my <\p>
chamber door. I immediately said, "Come in, Priscilla!" with an acute <\p>
sense of the applicant's identity. Nor was I deceived. It was really <\p>
Priscilla,--a pale, large-eyed little woman (for she had gone far <\p>
enough into her teens to be, at least, on the outer limit of girlhood), <\p>
but much less wan than at my previous view of her, and far better <\p>
conditioned both as to health and spirits. As I first saw her, she had <\p>
reminded me of plants that one sometimes observes doing their best to <\p>
vegetate among the bricks of an enclosed court, where there is scanty <\p>
soil and never any sunshine. At present, though with no approach to <\p>
bloom, there were indications that the girl had human blood in her <\p>
veins. <\p>
Priscilla came softly to my bedside, and held out an article of <\p>
snow-white linen, very carefully and smoothly ironed. She did not seem <\p>
bashful, nor anywise embarrassed. My weakly condition, I suppose, <\p>
supplied a medium in which she could approach me. <\p>
"Do not you need this?" asked she. "I have made it for you." It was a <\p>
nightcap! <\p>
"My dear Priscilla," said I, smiling, "I never had on a nightcap in my <\p>
life! But perhaps it will be better for me to wear one, now that I am <\p>
a miserable invalid. How admirably you have done it! No, no; I never <\p>
can think of wearing such an exquisitely wrought nightcap as this, <\p>
unless it be in the daytime, when I sit up to receive company." <\p>
"It is for use, not beauty," answered Priscilla. "I could have <\p>
embroidered it and made it much prettier, if I pleased." <\p>
While holding up the nightcap and admiring the fine needlework, I <\p>
perceived that Priscilla had a sealed letter which she was waiting for <\p>
me to take. It had arrived from the village post-office that morning. <\p>
As I did not immediately offer to receive the letter, she drew it back, <\p>
and held it against her bosom, with both hands clasped over it, in a <\p>
way that had probably grown habitual to her. Now, on turning my eyes <\p>
from the nightcap to Priscilla, it forcibly struck me that her air, <\p>
though not her figure, and the expression of her face, but not its <\p>
features, had a resemblance to what I had often seen in a friend of <\p>
mine, one of the most gifted women of the age. I cannot describe it. <\p>
The points easiest to convey to the reader were a certain curve of the <\p>
shoulders and a partial closing of the eyes, which seemed to look more <\p>
penetratingly into my own eyes, through the narrowed apertures, than if <\p>
they had been open at full width. It was a singular anomaly of <\p>
likeness coexisting with perfect dissimilitude. <\p>
"Will you give me the letter, Priscilla?" said I. <\p>
She started, put the letter into my hand, and quite lost the look that <\p>
had drawn my notice. <\p>
"Priscilla," I inquired, "did you ever see Miss Margaret Fuller?" <\p>
"No," she answered. <\p>
"Because," said I, "you reminded me of her just now,--and it happens, <\p>
strangely enough, that this very letter is from her." <\p>
Priscilla, for whatever reason, looked very much discomposed. <\p>
"I wish people would not fancy such odd things in me!" she said rather <\p>
petulantly. "How could I possibly make myself resemble this lady <\p>
merely by holding her letter in my hand?" <\p>
"Certainly, Priscilla, it would puzzle me to explain it," I replied; <\p>
"nor do I suppose that the letter had anything to do with it. It was <\p>
just a coincidence, nothing more." <\p>
She hastened out of the room, and this was the last that I saw of <\p>
Priscilla until I ceased to be an invalid. <\p>
Being much alone during my recovery, I read interminably in Mr. <\p>
Emerson's Essays, "The Dial," Carlyle's works, George Sand's romances <\p>
(lent me by Zenobia), and other books which one or another of the <\p>
brethren or sisterhood had brought with them. Agreeing in little else, <\p>
most of these utterances were like the cry of some solitary sentinel, <\p>
whose station was on the outposts of the advance guard of human <\p>
progression; or sometimes the voice came sadly from among the shattered <\p>
ruins of the past, but yet had a hopeful echo in the future. They were <\p>
well adapted (better, at least, than any other intellectual products, <\p>
the volatile essence of which had heretofore tinctured a printed page) <\p>
to pilgrims like ourselves, whose present bivouac was considerably <\p>
further into the waste of chaos than any mortal army of crusaders had <\p>
ever marched before. Fourier's works, also, in a series of horribly <\p>
tedious volumes, attracted a good deal of my attention, from the <\p>
analogy which I could not but recognize between his system and our own. <\p>
There was far less resemblance, it is true, than the world chose to <\p>
imagine, inasmuch as the two theories differed, as widely as the zenith <\p>
from the nadir, in their main principles. <\p>
I talked about Fourier to Hollingsworth, and translated, for his <\p>
benefit, some of the passages that chiefly impressed me. <\p>
"When, as a consequence of human improvement," said I, "the globe shall <\p>
arrive at its final perfection, the great ocean is to be converted into <\p>
a particular kind of lemonade, such as was fashionable at Paris in <\p>
Fourier's time. He calls it limonade a cedre. It is positively a <\p>
fact! Just imagine the city docks filled, every day, with a flood tide <\p>
of this delectable beverage!" <\p>
"Why did not the Frenchman make punch of it at once?" asked <\p>
Hollingsworth. "The jack-tars would be delighted to go down in ships <\p>
and do business in such an element." <\p>
I further proceeded to explain, as well as I modestly could, several <\p>
points of Fourier's system, illustrating them with here and there a <\p>
page or two, and asking Hollingsworth's opinion as to the expediency of <\p>
introducing these beautiful peculiarities into our own practice. <\p>
"Let me hear no more of it!" cried he, in utter disgust. "I never will <\p>
forgive this fellow! He has committed the unpardonable sin; for what <\p>
more monstrous iniquity could the Devil himself contrive than to choose <\p>
the selfish principle,--the principle of all human wrong, the very <\p>
blackness of man's heart, the portion of ourselves which we shudder at, <\p>
and which it is the whole aim of spiritual discipline to eradicate,--to <\p>
choose it as the master workman of his system? To seize upon and <\p>
foster whatever vile, petty, sordid, filthy, bestial, and abominable <\p>
corruptions have cankered into our nature, to be the efficient <\p>
instruments of his infernal regeneration! And his consummated <\p>
Paradise, as he pictures it, would be worthy of the agency which he <\p>
counts upon for establishing it. The nauseous villain!" <\p>
"Nevertheless," remarked I, "in consideration of the promised delights <\p>
of his system,--so very proper, as they certainly are, to be <\p>
appreciated by Fourier's countrymen,--I cannot but wonder that <\p>
universal France did not adopt his theory at a moment's warning. But <\p>
is there not something very characteristic of his nation in Fourier's <\p>
manner of putting forth his views? He makes no claim to inspiration. <\p>
He has not persuaded himself--as Swedenborg did, and as any other than <\p>
a Frenchman would, with a mission of like importance to <\p>
communicate--that he speaks with authority from above. He promulgates <\p>
his system, so far as I can perceive, entirely on his own <\p>
responsibility. He has searched out and discovered the whole counsel <\p>
of the Almighty in respect to mankind, past, present, and for exactly <\p>
seventy thousand years to come, by the mere force and cunning of his <\p>
individual intellect!" <\p>
"Take the book out of my sight," said Hollingsworth with great <\p>
virulence of expression, "or, I tell you fairly, I shall fling it in <\p>
the fire! And as for Fourier, let him make a Paradise, if he can, of <\p>
Gehenna, where, as I conscientiously believe, he is floundering at this <\p>
moment!" <\p>
"And bellowing, I suppose," said I,--not that I felt any ill-will <\p>
towards Fourier, but merely wanted to give the finishing touch to <\p>
Hollingsworth's image, "bellowing for the least drop of his beloved <\p>
limonade a cedre!" <\p>
There is but little profit to be expected in attempting to argue with a <\p>
man who allows himself to declaim in this manner; so I dropt the <\p>
subject, and never took it up again. <\p>
But had the system at which he was so enraged combined almost any <\p>
amount of human wisdom, spiritual insight, and imaginative beauty, I <\p>
question whether Hollingsworth's mind was in a fit condition to receive <\p>
it. I began to discern that he had come among us actuated by no real <\p>
sympathy with our feelings and our hopes, but chiefly because we were <\p>
estranging ourselves from the world, with which his lonely and <\p>
exclusive object in life had already put him at odds. Hollingsworth <\p>
must have been originally endowed with a great spirit of benevolence, <\p>
deep enough and warm enough to be the source of as much disinterested <\p>
good as Providence often allows a human being the privilege of <\p>
conferring upon his fellows. This native instinct yet lived within <\p>
him. I myself had profited by it, in my necessity. It was seen, too, <\p>
in his treatment of Priscilla. Such casual circumstances as were here <\p>
involved would quicken his divine power of sympathy, and make him seem, <\p>
while their influence lasted, the tenderest man and the truest friend <\p>
on earth. But by and by you missed the tenderness of yesterday, and <\p>
grew drearily conscious that Hollingsworth had a closer friend than <\p>
ever you could be; and this friend was the cold, spectral monster which <\p>
he had himself conjured up, and on which he was wasting all the warmth <\p>
of his heart, and of which, at last,--as these men of a mighty purpose <\p>
so invariably do,--he had grown to be the bond-slave. It was his <\p>
philanthropic theory. <\p>
This was a result exceedingly sad to contemplate, considering that it <\p>
had been mainly brought about by the very ardor and exuberance of his <\p>
philanthropy. Sad, indeed, but by no means unusual: he had taught his <\p>
benevolence to pour its warm tide exclusively through one channel; so <\p>
that there was nothing to spare for other great manifestations of love <\p>
to man, nor scarcely for the nutriment of individual attachments, <\p>
unless they could minister in some way to the terrible egotism which he <\p>
mistook for an angel of God. Had Hollingsworth's education been more <\p>
enlarged, he might not so inevitably have stumbled into this pitfall. <\p>
But this identical pursuit had educated him. He knew absolutely <\p>
nothing, except in a single direction, where he had thought so <\p>
energetically, and felt to such a depth, that no doubt the entire <\p>
reason and justice of the universe appeared to be concentrated <\p>
thitherward. <\p>
It is my private opinion that, at this period of his life, <\p>
Hollingsworth was fast going mad; and, as with other crazy people <\p>
(among whom I include humorists of every degree), it required all the <\p>
constancy of friendship to restrain his associates from pronouncing him <\p>
an intolerable bore. Such prolonged fiddling upon one string--such <\p>
multiform presentation of one idea! His specific object (of which he <\p>
made the public more than sufficiently aware, through the medium of <\p>
lectures and pamphlets) was to obtain funds for the construction of an <\p>
edifice, with a sort of collegiate endowment. On this foundation he <\p>
purposed to devote himself and a few disciples to the reform and mental <\p>
culture of our criminal brethren. His visionary edifice was <\p>
Hollingsworth's one castle in the air; it was the material type in <\p>
which his philanthropic dream strove to embody itself; and he made the <\p>
scheme more definite, and caught hold of it the more strongly, and kept <\p>
his clutch the more pertinaciously, by rendering it visible to the <\p>
bodily eye. I have seen him, a hundred times, with a pencil and sheet <\p>
of paper, sketching the facade, the side-view, or the rear of the <\p>
structure, or planning the internal arrangements, as lovingly as <\p>
another man might plan those of the projected home where he meant to be <\p>
happy with his wife and children. I have known him to begin a model of <\p>
the building with little stones, gathered at the brookside, whither we <\p>
had gone to cool ourselves in the sultry noon of haying-time. Unlike <\p>
all other ghosts, his spirit haunted an edifice, which, instead of <\p>
being time-worn, and full of storied love, and joy, and sorrow, had <\p>
never yet come into existence. <\p>
"Dear friend," said I once to Hollingsworth, before leaving my <\p>
sick-chamber, "I heartily wish that I could make your schemes my <\p>
schemes, because it would be so great a happiness to find myself <\p>
treading the same path with you. But I am afraid there is not stuff in <\p>
me stern enough for a philanthropist,--or not in this peculiar <\p>
direction,--or, at all events, not solely in this. Can you bear with <\p>
me, if such should prove to be the case?" <\p>
"I will at least wait awhile," answered Hollingsworth, gazing at me <\p>
sternly and gloomily. "But how can you be my life-long friend, except <\p>
you strive with me towards the great object of my life?" <\p>
Heaven forgive me! A horrible suspicion crept into my heart, and stung <\p>
the very core of it as with the fangs of an adder. I wondered whether <\p>
it were possible that Hollingsworth could have watched by my bedside, <\p>
with all that devoted care, only for the ulterior purpose of making me <\p>
a proselyte to his views! <\p>
VIII. A MODERN ARCADIA <\p>
May-day--I forget whether by Zenobia's sole decree, or by the unanimous <\p>
vote of our community--had been declared a movable festival. It was <\p>
deferred until the sun should have had a reasonable time to clear away <\p>
the snowdrifts along the lee of the stone walls, and bring out a few of <\p>
the readiest wild flowers. On the forenoon of the substituted day, <\p>
after admitting some of the balmy air into my chamber, I decided that <\p>
it was nonsense and effeminacy to keep myself a prisoner any longer. <\p>
So I descended to the sitting-room, and finding nobody there, proceeded <\p>
to the barn, whence I had already heard Zenobia's voice, and along with <\p>
it a girlish laugh which was not so certainly recognizable. Arriving <\p>
at the spot, it a little surprised me to discover that these merry <\p>
outbreaks came from Priscilla. <\p>
The two had been a-maying together. They had found anemones in <\p>
abundance, houstonias by the handful, some columbines, a few <\p>
long-stalked violets, and a quantity of white everlasting flowers, and <\p>
had filled up their basket with the delicate spray of shrubs and trees. <\p>
None were prettier than the maple twigs, the leaf of which looks like a <\p>
scarlet bud in May, and like a plate of vegetable gold in October. <\p>
Zenobia, who showed no conscience in such matters, had also rifled a <\p>
cherry-tree of one of its blossomed boughs, and, with all this variety <\p>
of sylvan ornament, had been decking out Priscilla. Being done with a <\p>
good deal of taste, it made her look more charming than I should have <\p>
thought possible, with my recollection of the wan, frost-nipt girl, as <\p>
heretofore described. Nevertheless, among those fragrant blossoms, and <\p>
conspicuously, too, had been stuck a weed of evil odor and ugly aspect, <\p>
which, as soon as I detected it, destroyed the effect of all the rest. <\p>
There was a gleam of latent mischief--not to call it deviltry--in <\p>
Zenobia's eye, which seemed to indicate a slightly malicious purpose in <\p>
the arrangement. <\p>
As for herself, she scorned the rural buds and leaflets, and wore <\p>
nothing but her invariable flower of the tropics. <\p>
"What do you think of Priscilla now, Mr. Coverdale?" asked she, <\p>
surveying her as a child does its doll. "Is not she worth a verse or <\p>
two?" <\p>
"There is only one thing amiss," answered I. Zenobia laughed, and flung <\p>
the malignant weed away. <\p>
"Yes; she deserves some verses now," said I, "and from a better poet <\p>
than myself. She is the very picture of the New England spring; <\p>
subdued in tint and rather cool, but with a capacity of sunshine, and <\p>
bringing us a few Alpine blossoms, as earnest of something richer, <\p>
though hardly more beautiful, hereafter. The best type of her is one <\p>
of those anemones." <\p>
"What I find most singular in Priscilla, as her health improves," <\p>
observed Zenobia, "is her wildness. Such a quiet little body as she <\p>
seemed, one would not have expected that. Why, as we strolled the <\p>
woods together, I could hardly keep her from scrambling up the trees, <\p>
like a squirrel. She has never before known what it is to live in the <\p>
free air, and so it intoxicates her as if she were sipping wine. And <\p>
she thinks it such a paradise here, and all of us, particularly Mr. <\p>
Hollingsworth and myself, such angels! It is quite ridiculous, and <\p>
provokes one's malice almost, to see a creature so happy, especially a <\p>
feminine creature." <\p>
"They are always happier than male creatures," said I. <\p>
"You must correct that opinion, Mr. Coverdale," replied Zenobia <\p>
contemptuously, "or I shall think you lack the poetic insight. Did you <\p>
ever see a happy woman in your life? Of course, I do not mean a girl, <\p>
like Priscilla and a thousand others,--for they are all alike, while on <\p>
the sunny side of experience,--but a grown woman. How can she be <\p>
happy, after discovering that fate has assigned her but one single <\p>
event, which she must contrive to make the substance of her whole life? <\p>
A man has his choice of innumerable events." <\p>
"A woman, I suppose," answered I, "by constant repetition of her one <\p>
event, may compensate for the lack of variety." <\p>
"Indeed!" said Zenobia. <\p>
While we were talking, Priscilla caught sight of Hollingsworth at a <\p>
distance, in a blue frock, and with a hoe over his shoulder, returning <\p>
from the field. She immediately set out to meet him, running and <\p>
skipping, with spirits as light as the breeze of the May morning, but <\p>
with limbs too little exercised to be quite responsive; she clapped her <\p>
hands, too, with great exuberance of gesture, as is the custom of young <\p>
girls when their electricity overcharges them. But, all at once, midway <\p>
to Hollingsworth, she paused, looked round about her, towards the <\p>
river, the road, the woods, and back towards us, appearing to listen, <\p>
as if she heard some one calling her name, and knew not precisely in <\p>
what direction. <\p>
"Have you bewitched her?" I exclaimed. <\p>
"It is no sorcery of mine," said Zenobia; "but I have seen the girl do <\p>
that identical thing once or twice before. Can you imagine what is the <\p>
matter with her?" <\p>
"No; unless," said I, "she has the gift of hearing those 'airy tongues <\p>
that syllable men's names,' which Milton tells about." <\p>
From whatever cause, Priscilla's animation seemed entirely to have <\p>
deserted her. She seated herself on a rock, and remained there until <\p>
Hollingsworth came up; and when he took her hand and led her back to <\p>
us, she rather resembled my original image of the wan and spiritless <\p>
Priscilla than the flowery May-queen of a few moments ago. These <\p>
sudden transformations, only to be accounted for by an extreme nervous <\p>
susceptibility, always continued to characterize the girl, though with <\p>
diminished frequency as her health progressively grew more robust. <\p>
I was now on my legs again. My fit of illness had been an avenue <\p>
between two existences; the low-arched and darksome doorway, through <\p>
which I crept out of a life of old conventionalisms, on my hands and <\p>
knees, as it were, and gained admittance into the freer region that lay <\p>
beyond. In this respect, it was like death. And, as with death, too, <\p>
it was good to have gone through it. No otherwise could I have rid <\p>
myself of a thousand follies, fripperies, prejudices, habits, and other <\p>
such worldly dust as inevitably settles upon the crowd along the broad <\p>
highway, giving them all one sordid aspect before noon-time, however <\p>
freshly they may have begun their pilgrimage in the dewy morning. The <\p>
very substance upon my bones had not been fit to live with in any <\p>
better, truer, or more energetic mode than that to which I was <\p>
accustomed. So it was taken off me and flung aside, like any other <\p>
worn-out or unseasonable garment; and, after shivering a little while <\p>
in my skeleton, I began to be clothed anew, and much more <\p>
satisfactorily than in my previous suit. In literal and physical <\p>
truth, I was quite another man. I had a lively sense of the exultation <\p>
with which the spirit will enter on the next stage of its eternal <\p>
progress after leaving the heavy burden of its mortality in an early <\p>
grave, with as little concern for what may become of it as now affected <\p>
me for the flesh which I had lost. <\p>
Emerging into the genial sunshine, I half fancied that the labors of <\p>
the brotherhood had already realized some of Fourier's predictions. <\p>
Their enlightened culture of the soil, and the virtues with which they <\p>
sanctified their life, had begun to produce an effect upon the material <\p>
world and its climate. In my new enthusiasm, man looked strong and <\p>
stately,--and woman, oh, how beautiful!--and the earth a green garden, <\p>
blossoming with many-colored delights. Thus Nature, whose laws I had <\p>
broken in various artificial ways, comported herself towards me as a <\p>
strict but loving mother, who uses the rod upon her little boy for his <\p>
naughtiness, and then gives him a smile, a kiss, and some pretty <\p>
playthings to console the urchin for her severity. <\p>
In the interval of my seclusion, there had been a number of recruits to <\p>
our little army of saints and martyrs. They were mostly individuals <\p>
who had gone through such an experience as to disgust them with <\p>
ordinary pursuits, but who were not yet so old, nor had suffered so <\p>
deeply, as to lose their faith in the better time to come. On comparing <\p>
their minds one with another they often discovered that this idea of a <\p>
Community had been growing up, in silent and unknown sympathy, for <\p>
years. Thoughtful, strongly lined faces were among them; sombre brows, <\p>
but eyes that did not require spectacles, unless prematurely dimmed by <\p>
the student's lamplight, and hair that seldom showed a thread of <\p>
silver. Age, wedded to the past, incrusted over with a stony layer of <\p>
habits, and retaining nothing fluid in its possibilities, would have <\p>
been absurdly out of place in an enterprise like this. Youth, too, in <\p>
its early dawn, was hardly more adapted to our purpose; for it would <\p>
behold the morning radiance of its own spirit beaming over the very <\p>
same spots of withered grass and barren sand whence most of us had seen <\p>
it vanish. We had very young people with us, it is true,--downy lads, <\p>
rosy girls in their first teens, and children of all heights above <\p>
one's knee; but these had chiefly been sent hither for education, which <\p>
it was one of the objects and methods of our institution to supply. <\p>
Then we had boarders, from town and elsewhere, who lived with us in a <\p>
familiar way, sympathized more or less in our theories, and sometimes <\p>
shared in our labors. <\p>
On the whole, it was a society such as has seldom met together; nor, <\p>
perhaps, could it reasonably be expected to hold together long. Persons <\p>
of marked individuality--crooked sticks, as some of us might be <\p>
called--are not exactly the easiest to bind up into a fagot. But, so <\p>
long as our union should subsist, a man of intellect and feeling, with <\p>
a free nature in him, might have sought far and near without finding so <\p>
many points of attraction as would allure him hitherward. We were of <\p>
all creeds and opinions, and generally tolerant of all, on every <\p>
imaginable subject. Our bond, it seems to me, was not affirmative, but <\p>
negative. We had individually found one thing or another to quarrel <\p>
with in our past life, and were pretty well agreed as to the <\p>
inexpediency of lumbering along with the old system any further. As to <\p>
what should be substituted, there was much less unanimity. We did not <\p>
greatly care--at least, I never did--for the written constitution under <\p>
which our millennium had commenced. My hope was, that, between theory <\p>
and practice, a true and available mode of life might be struck out; <\p>
and that, even should we ultimately fail, the months or years spent in <\p>
the trial would not have been wasted, either as regarded passing <\p>
enjoyment, or the experience which makes men wise. <\p>
Arcadians though we were, our costume bore no resemblance to the <\p>
beribboned doublets, silk breeches and stockings, and slippers fastened <\p>
with artificial roses, that distinguish the pastoral people of poetry <\p>
and the stage. In outward show, I humbly conceive, we looked rather <\p>
like a gang of beggars, or banditti, than either a company of honest <\p>
laboring-men, or a conclave of philosophers. Whatever might be our <\p>
points of difference, we all of us seemed to have come to Blithedale <\p>
with the one thrifty and laudable idea of wearing out our old clothes. <\p>
Such garments as had an airing, whenever we strode afield! Coats with <\p>
high collars and with no collars, broad-skirted or swallow-tailed, and <\p>
with the waist at every point between the hip and arm-pit; pantaloons <\p>
of a dozen successive epochs, and greatly defaced at the knees by the <\p>
humiliations of the wearer before his lady-love,--in short, we were a <\p>
living epitome of defunct fashions, and the very raggedest presentment <\p>
of men who had seen better days. It was gentility in tatters. Often <\p>
retaining a scholarlike or clerical air, you might have taken us for <\p>
the denizens of Grub Street, intent on getting a comfortable livelihood <\p>
by agricultural labor; or Coleridge's projected Pantisocracy in full <\p>
experiment; or Candide and his motley associates at work in their <\p>
cabbage garden; or anything else that was miserably out at elbows, and <\p>
most clumsily patched in the rear. We might have been sworn comrades <\p>
to Falstaff's ragged regiment. Little skill as we boasted in other <\p>
points of husbandry, every mother's son of us would have served <\p>
admirably to stick up for a scarecrow. And the worst of the matter <\p>
was, that the first energetic movement essential to one downright <\p>
stroke of real labor was sure to put a finish to these poor <\p>
habiliments. So we gradually flung them all aside, and took to honest <\p>
homespun and linsey-woolsey, as preferable, on the whole, to the plan <\p>
recommended, I think, by Virgil,--"Ara nudus; sere nudus, "--which as <\p>
Silas Foster remarked, when I translated the maxim, would be apt to <\p>
astonish the women-folks. <\p>
After a reasonable training, the yeoman life throve well with us. Our <\p>
faces took the sunburn kindly; our chests gained in compass, and our <\p>
shoulders in breadth and squareness; our great brown fists looked as if <\p>
they had never been capable of kid gloves. The plough, the hoe, the <\p>
scythe, and the hay-fork grew familiar to our grasp. The oxen <\p>
responded to our voices. We could do almost as fair a day's work as <\p>
Silas Foster himself, sleep dreamlessly after it, and awake at daybreak <\p>
with only a little stiffness of the joints, which was usually quite <\p>
gone by breakfast-time. <\p>
To be sure, our next neighbors pretended to be incredulous as to our <\p>
real proficiency in the business which we had taken in hand. They told <\p>
slanderous fables about our inability to yoke our own oxen, or to drive <\p>
them afield when yoked, or to release the poor brutes from their <\p>
conjugal bond at nightfall. They had the face to say, too, that the <\p>
cows laughed at our awkwardness at milking-time, and invariably kicked <\p>
over the pails; partly in consequence of our putting the stool on the <\p>
wrong side, and partly because, taking offence at the whisking of their <\p>
tails, we were in the habit of holding these natural fly-flappers with <\p>
one hand and milking with the other. They further averred that we hoed <\p>
up whole acres of Indian corn and other crops, and drew the earth <\p>
carefully about the weeds; and that we raised five hundred tufts of <\p>
burdock, mistaking them for cabbages; and that by dint of unskilful <\p>
planting few of our seeds ever came up at all, or, if they did come up, <\p>
it was stern-foremost; and that we spent the better part of the month <\p>
of June in reversing a field of beans, which had thrust themselves out <\p>
of the ground in this unseemly way. They quoted it as nothing more <\p>
than an ordinary occurrence for one or other of us to crop off two or <\p>
three fingers, of a morning, by our clumsy use of the hay-cutter. <\p>
Finally, and as an ultimate catastrophe, these mendacious rogues <\p>
circulated a report that we communitarians were exterminated, to the <\p>
last man, by severing ourselves asunder with the sweep of our own <\p>
scythes! and that the world had lost nothing by this little accident. <\p>
But this was pure envy and malice on the part of the neighboring <\p>
farmers. The peril of our new way of life was not lest we should fail <\p>
in becoming practical agriculturists, but that we should probably cease <\p>
to be anything else. While our enterprise lay all in theory, we had <\p>
pleased ourselves with delectable visions of the spiritualization of <\p>
labor. It was to be our form of prayer and ceremonial of worship. <\p>
Each stroke of the hoe was to uncover some aromatic root of wisdom, <\p>
heretofore hidden from the sun. Pausing in the field, to let the wind <\p>
exhale the moisture from our foreheads, we were to look upward, and <\p>
catch glimpses into the far-off soul of truth. In this point of view, <\p>
matters did not turn out quite so well as we anticipated. It is very <\p>
true that, sometimes, gazing casually around me, out of the midst of my <\p>
toil, I used to discern a richer picturesqueness in the visible scene <\p>
of earth and sky. There was, at such moments, a novelty, an unwonted <\p>
aspect, on the face of Nature, as if she had been taken by surprise and <\p>
seen at unawares, with no opportunity to put off her real look, and <\p>
assume the mask with which she mysteriously hides herself from mortals. <\p>
But this was all. The clods of earth, which we so constantly belabored <\p>
and turned over and over, were never etherealized into thought. Our <\p>
thoughts, on the contrary, were fast becoming cloddish. Our labor <\p>
symbolized nothing, and left us mentally sluggish in the dusk of the <\p>
evening. Intellectual activity is incompatible with any large amount of <\p>
bodily exercise. The yeoman and the scholar--the yeoman and the man of <\p>
finest moral culture, though not the man of sturdiest sense and <\p>
integrity--are two distinct individuals, and can never be melted or <\p>
welded into one substance. <\p>
Zenobia soon saw this truth, and gibed me about it, one evening, as <\p>
Hollingsworth and I lay on the grass, after a hard day's work. <\p>
"I am afraid you did not make a song today, while loading the <\p>
hay-cart," said she, "as Burns did, when he was reaping barley." <\p>
"Burns never made a song in haying-time," I answered very positively. <\p>
"He was no poet while a farmer, and no farmer while a poet." <\p>
"And on the whole, which of the two characters do you like best?" asked <\p>
Zenobia. "For I have an idea that you cannot combine them any better <\p>
than Burns did. Ah, I see, in my mind's eye, what sort of an <\p>
individual you are to be, two or three years hence. Grim Silas Foster <\p>
is your prototype, with his palm of sole-leather, and his joints of <\p>
rusty iron (which all through summer keep the stiffness of what he <\p>
calls his winter's rheumatize), and his brain of--I don't know what his <\p>
brain is made of, unless it be a Savoy cabbage; but yours may be <\p>
cauliflower, as a rather more delicate variety. Your physical man will <\p>
be transmuted into salt beef and fried pork, at the rate, I should <\p>
imagine, of a pound and a half a day; that being about the average <\p>
which we find necessary in the kitchen. You will make your toilet for <\p>
the day (still like this delightful Silas Foster) by rinsing your <\p>
fingers and the front part of your face in a little tin pan of water at <\p>
the doorstep, and teasing your hair with a wooden pocket-comb before a <\p>
seven-by-nine-inch looking-glass. Your only pastime will be to smoke <\p>
some very vile tobacco in the black stump of a pipe." <\p>
"Pray, spare me!" cried I. "But the pipe is not Silas's only mode of <\p>
solacing himself with the weed." <\p>
"Your literature," continued Zenobia, apparently delighted with her <\p>
description, "will be the 'Farmer's Almanac;' for I observe our friend <\p>
Foster never gets so far as the newspaper. When you happen to sit <\p>
down, at odd moments, you will fall asleep, and make nasal proclamation <\p>
of the fact, as he does; and invariably you must be jogged out of a <\p>
nap, after supper, by the future Mrs. Coverdale, and persuaded to go <\p>
regularly to bed. And on Sundays, when you put on a blue coat with <\p>
brass buttons, you will think of nothing else to do but to go and <\p>
lounge over the stone walls and rail fences, and stare at the corn <\p>
growing. And you will look with a knowing eye at oxen, and will have a <\p>
tendency to clamber over into pigsties, and feel of the hogs, and give <\p>
a guess how much they will weigh after you shall have stuck and dressed <\p>
them. Already I have noticed you begin to speak through your nose, and <\p>
with a drawl. Pray, if you really did make any poetry to-day, let us <\p>
hear it in that kind of utterance!" <\p>
"Coverdale has given up making verses now," said Hollingsworth, who <\p>
never had the slightest appreciation of my poetry. "Just think of him <\p>
penning a sonnet with a fist like that! There is at least this good in <\p>
a life of toil, that it takes the nonsense and fancy-work out of a man, <\p>
and leaves nothing but what truly belongs to him. If a farmer can make <\p>
poetry at the plough-tail, it must be because his nature insists on it; <\p>
and if that be the case, let him make it, in Heaven's name!" <\p>
"And how is it with you?" asked Zenobia, in a different voice; for she <\p>
never laughed at Hollingsworth, as she often did at me. "You, I think, <\p>
cannot have ceased to live a life of thought and feeling." <\p>
"I have always been in earnest," answered Hollingsworth. "I have <\p>
hammered thought out of iron, after heating the iron in my heart! It <\p>
matters little what my outward toil may be. Were I a slave, at the <\p>
bottom of a mine, I should keep the same purpose, the same faith in its <\p>
ultimate accomplishment, that I do now. Miles Coverdale is not in <\p>
earnest, either as a poet or a laborer." <\p>
"You give me hard measure, Hollingsworth," said I, a little hurt. "I <\p>
have kept pace with you in the field; and my bones feel as if I had <\p>
been in earnest, whatever may be the case with my brain!" <\p>
"I cannot conceive," observed Zenobia with great emphasis,--and, no <\p>
doubt, she spoke fairly the feeling of the moment,--"I cannot conceive <\p>
of being so continually as Mr. Coverdale is within the sphere of a <\p>
strong and noble nature, without being strengthened and ennobled by its <\p>
influence!" <\p>
This amiable remark of the fair Zenobia confirmed me in what I had <\p>
already begun to suspect, that Hollingsworth, like many other <\p>
illustrious prophets, reformers, and philanthropists, was likely to <\p>
make at least two proselytes among the women to one among the men. <\p>
Zenobia and Priscilla! These, I believe (unless my unworthy self might <\p>
be reckoned for a third), were the only disciples of his mission; and I <\p>
spent a great deal of time, uselessly, in trying to conjecture what <\p>
Hollingsworth meant to do with them--and they with him! <\p>
IX. HOLLINGSWORTH, ZENOBIA, PRISCILLA <\p>
It is not, I apprehend, a healthy kind of mental occupation to devote <\p>
ourselves too exclusively to the study of individual men and women. If <\p>
the person under examination be one's self, the result is pretty <\p>
certain to be diseased action of the heart, almost before we can snatch <\p>
a second glance. Or if we take the freedom to put a friend under our <\p>
microscope, we thereby insulate him from many of his true relations, <\p>
magnify his peculiarities, inevitably tear him into parts, and of <\p>
course patch him very clumsily together again. What wonder, then, <\p>
should we be frightened by the aspect of a monster, which, after <\p>
all,--though we can point to every feature of his deformity in the real <\p>
personage,--may be said to have been created mainly by ourselves. <\p>
Thus, as my conscience has often whispered me, I did Hollingsworth a <\p>
great wrong by prying into his character; and am perhaps doing him as <\p>
great a one, at this moment, by putting faith in the discoveries which <\p>
I seemed to make. But I could not help it. Had I loved him less, I <\p>
might have used him better. He and Zenobia and Priscilla--both for <\p>
their own sakes and as connected with him--were separated from the rest <\p>
of the Community, to my imagination, and stood forth as the indices of <\p>
a problem which it was my business to solve. Other associates had a <\p>
portion of my time; other matters amused me; passing occurrences <\p>
carried me along with them, while they lasted. But here was the vortex <\p>
of my meditations, around which they revolved, and whitherward they too <\p>
continually tended. In the midst of cheerful society, I had often a <\p>
feeling of loneliness. For it was impossible not to be sensible that, <\p>
while these three characters figured so largely on my private theatre, <\p>
I--though probably reckoned as a friend by all--was at best but a <\p>
secondary or tertiary personage with either of them. <\p>
I loved Hollingsworth, as has already been enough expressed. But it <\p>
impressed me, more and more, that there was a stern and dreadful <\p>
peculiarity in this man, such as could not prove otherwise than <\p>
pernicious to the happiness of those who should be drawn into too <\p>
intimate a connection with him. He was not altogether human. There <\p>
was something else in Hollingsworth besides flesh and blood, and <\p>
sympathies and affections and celestial spirit. <\p>
This is always true of those men who have surrendered themselves to an <\p>
overruling purpose. It does not so much impel them from without, nor <\p>
even operate as a motive power within, but grows incorporate with all <\p>
that they think and feel, and finally converts them into little else <\p>
save that one principle. When such begins to be the predicament, it is <\p>
not cowardice, but wisdom, to avoid these victims. They have no heart, <\p>
no sympathy, no reason, no conscience. They will keep no friend, <\p>
unless he make himself the mirror of their purpose; they will smite and <\p>
slay you, and trample your dead corpse under foot, all the more <\p>
readily, if you take the first step with them, and cannot take the <\p>
second, and the third, and every other step of their terribly strait <\p>
path. They have an idol to which they consecrate themselves <\p>
high-priest, and deem it holy work to offer sacrifices of whatever is <\p>
most precious; and never once seem to suspect--so cunning has the Devil <\p>
been with them--that this false deity, in whose iron features, <\p>
immitigable to all the rest of mankind, they see only benignity and <\p>
love, is but a spectrum of the very priest himself, projected upon the <\p>
surrounding darkness. And the higher and purer the original object, <\p>
and the more unselfishly it may have been taken up, the slighter is the <\p>
probability that they can be led to recognize the process by which <\p>
godlike benevolence has been debased into all-devouring egotism. <\p>
Of course I am perfectly aware that the above statement is exaggerated, <\p>
in the attempt to make it adequate. Professed philanthropists have <\p>
gone far; but no originally good man, I presume, ever went quite so far <\p>
as this. Let the reader abate whatever he deems fit. The paragraph <\p>
may remain, however, both for its truth and its exaggeration, as <\p>
strongly expressive of the tendencies which were really operative in <\p>
Hollingsworth, and as exemplifying the kind of error into which my mode <\p>
of observation was calculated to lead me. The issue was, that in <\p>
solitude I often shuddered at my friend. In my recollection of his <\p>
dark and impressive countenance, the features grew more sternly <\p>
prominent than the reality, duskier in their depth and shadow, and more <\p>
lurid in their light; the frown, that had merely flitted across his <\p>
brow, seemed to have contorted it with an adamantine wrinkle. On <\p>
meeting him again, I was often filled with remorse, when his deep eyes <\p>
beamed kindly upon me, as with the glow of a household fire that was <\p>
burning in a cave. "He is a man after all," thought I; "his Maker's <\p>
own truest image, a philanthropic man!--not that steel engine of the <\p>
Devil's contrivance, a philanthropist!" But in my wood-walks, and in my <\p>
silent chamber, the dark face frowned at me again. <\p>
When a young girl comes within the sphere of such a man, she is as <\p>
perilously situated as the maiden whom, in the old classical myths, the <\p>
people used to expose to a dragon. If I had any duty whatever, in <\p>
reference to Hollingsworth, it was to endeavor to save Priscilla from <\p>
that kind of personal worship which her sex is generally prone to <\p>
lavish upon saints and heroes. It often requires but one smile out of <\p>
the hero's eyes into the girl's or woman's heart, to transform this <\p>
devotion, from a sentiment of the highest approval and confidence, into <\p>
passionate love. Now, Hollingsworth smiled much upon Priscilla,--more <\p>
than upon any other person. If she thought him beautiful, it was no <\p>
wonder. I often thought him so, with the expression of tender human <\p>
care and gentlest sympathy which she alone seemed to have power to call <\p>
out upon his features. Zenobia, I suspect, would have given her eyes, <\p>
bright as they were, for such a look; it was the least that our poor <\p>
Priscilla could do, to give her heart for a great many of them. There <\p>
was the more danger of this, inasmuch as the footing on which we all <\p>
associated at Blithedale was widely different from that of conventional <\p>
society. While inclining us to the soft affections of the golden age, <\p>
it seemed to authorize any individual, of either sex, to fall in love <\p>
with any other, regardless of what would elsewhere be judged suitable <\p>
and prudent. Accordingly the tender passion was very rife among us, in <\p>
various degrees of mildness or virulence, but mostly passing away with <\p>
the state of things that had given it origin. This was all well <\p>
enough; but, for a girl like Priscilla and a woman like Zenobia to <\p>
jostle one another in their love of a man like Hollingsworth, was <\p>
likely to be no child's play. <\p>
Had I been as cold-hearted as I sometimes thought myself, nothing would <\p>
have interested me more than to witness the play of passions that must <\p>
thus have been evolved. But, in honest truth, I would really have gone <\p>
far to save Priscilla, at least, from the catastrophe in which such a <\p>
drama would be apt to terminate. <\p>
Priscilla had now grown to be a very pretty girl, and still kept <\p>
budding and blossoming, and daily putting on some new charm, which you <\p>
no sooner became sensible of than you thought it worth all that she had <\p>
previously possessed. So unformed, vague, and without substance, as <\p>
she had come to us, it seemed as if we could see Nature shaping out a <\p>
woman before our very eyes, and yet had only a more reverential sense <\p>
of the mystery of a woman's soul and frame. Yesterday, her cheek was <\p>
pale, to-day, it had a bloom. Priscilla's smile, like a baby's first <\p>
one, was a wondrous novelty. Her imperfections and shortcomings <\p>
affected me with a kind of playful pathos, which was as absolutely <\p>
bewitching a sensation as ever I experienced. After she had been a <\p>
month or two at Blithedale, her animal spirits waxed high, and kept her <\p>
pretty constantly in a state of bubble and ferment, impelling her to <\p>
far more bodily activity than she had yet strength to endure. She was <\p>
very fond of playing with the other girls out of doors. There is <\p>
hardly another sight in the world so pretty as that of a company of <\p>
young girls, almost women grown, at play, and so giving themselves up <\p>
to their airy impulse that their tiptoes barely touch the ground. <\p>
Girls are incomparably wilder and more effervescent than boys, more <\p>
untamable and regardless of rule and limit, with an ever-shifting <\p>
variety, breaking continually into new modes of fun, yet with a <\p>
harmonious propriety through all. Their steps, their voices, appear <\p>
free as the wind, but keep consonance with a strain of music inaudible <\p>
to us. Young men and boys, on the other hand, play, according to <\p>
recognized law, old, traditionary games, permitting no caprioles of <\p>
fancy, but with scope enough for the outbreak of savage instincts. <\p>
For, young or old, in play or in earnest, man is prone to be a brute. <\p>
Especially is it delightful to see a vigorous young girl run a race, <\p>
with her head thrown back, her limbs moving more friskily than they <\p>
need, and an air between that of a bird and a young colt. But <\p>
Priscilla's peculiar charm, in a foot-race, was the weakness and <\p>
irregularity with which she ran. Growing up without exercise, except <\p>
to her poor little fingers, she had never yet acquired the perfect use <\p>
of her legs. Setting buoyantly forth, therefore, as if no rival less <\p>
swift than Atalanta could compete with her, she ran falteringly, and <\p>
often tumbled on the grass. Such an incident--though it seems too <\p>
slight to think of--was a thing to laugh at, but which brought the <\p>
water into one's eyes, and lingered in the memory after far greater <\p>
joys and sorrows were wept out of it, as antiquated trash. Priscilla's <\p>
life, as I beheld it, was full of trifles that affected me in just this <\p>
way. <\p>
When she had come to be quite at home among us, I used to fancy that <\p>
Priscilla played more pranks, and perpetrated more mischief, than any <\p>
other girl in the Community. For example, I once heard Silas Foster, <\p>
in a very gruff voice, threatening to rivet three horseshoes round <\p>
Priscilla's neck and chain her to a post, because she, with some other <\p>
young people, had clambered upon a load of hay, and caused it to slide <\p>
off the cart. How she made her peace I never knew; but very soon <\p>
afterwards I saw old Silas, with his brawny hands round Priscilla's <\p>
waist, swinging her to and fro, and finally depositing her on one of <\p>
the oxen, to take her first lessons in riding. She met with terrible <\p>
mishaps in her efforts to milk a cow; she let the poultry into the <\p>
garden; she generally spoilt whatever part of the dinner she took in <\p>
charge; she broke crockery; she dropt our biggest water pitcher into <\p>
the well; and--except with her needle, and those little wooden <\p>
instruments for purse-making--was as unserviceable a member of society <\p>
as any young lady in the land. There was no other sort of efficiency <\p>
about her. Yet everybody was kind to Priscilla; everybody loved her <\p>
and laughed at her to her face, and did not laugh behind her back; <\p>
everybody would have given her half of his last crust, or the bigger <\p>
share of his plum-cake. These were pretty certain indications that we <\p>
were all conscious of a pleasant weakness in the girl, and considered <\p>
her not quite able to look after her own interests or fight her battle <\p>
with the world. And Hollingsworth--perhaps because he had been the <\p>
means of introducing Priscilla to her new abode--appeared to recognize <\p>
her as his own especial charge. <\p>
Her simple, careless, childish flow of spirits often made me sad. She <\p>
seemed to me like a butterfly at play in a flickering bit of sunshine, <\p>
and mistaking it for a broad and eternal summer. We sometimes hold <\p>
mirth to a stricter accountability than sorrow; it must show good <\p>
cause, or the echo of its laughter comes back drearily. Priscilla's <\p>
gayety, moreover, was of a nature that showed me how delicate an <\p>
instrument she was, and what fragile harp-strings were her nerves. As <\p>
they made sweet music at the airiest touch, it would require but a <\p>
stronger one to burst them all asunder. Absurd as it might be, I tried <\p>
to reason with her, and persuade her not to be so joyous, thinking <\p>
that, if she would draw less lavishly upon her fund of happiness, it <\p>
would last the longer. I remember doing so, one summer evening, when <\p>
we tired laborers sat looking on, like Goldsmith's old folks under the <\p>
village thorn-tree, while the young people were at their sports. <\p>
"What is the use or sense of being so very gay?" I said to Priscilla, <\p>
while she was taking breath, after a great frolic. "I love to see a <\p>
sufficient cause for everything, and I can see none for this. Pray <\p>
tell me, now, what kind of a world you imagine this to be, which you <\p>
are so merry in." <\p>
"I never think about it at all," answered Priscilla, laughing. "But <\p>
this I am sure of, that it is a world where everybody is kind to me, <\p>
and where I love everybody. My heart keeps dancing within me, and all <\p>
the foolish things which you see me do are only the motions of my <\p>
heart. How can I be dismal, if my heart will not let me?" <\p>
"Have you nothing dismal to remember?" I suggested. "If not, then, <\p>
indeed, you are very fortunate!" <\p>
"Ah!" said Priscilla slowly. <\p>
And then came that unintelligible gesture, when she seemed to be <\p>
listening to a distant voice. <\p>
"For my part," I continued, beneficently seeking to overshadow her with <\p>
my own sombre humor, "my past life has been a tiresome one enough; yet <\p>
I would rather look backward ten times than forward once. For, little <\p>
as we know of our life to come, we may be very sure, for one thing, <\p>
that the good we aim at will not be attained. People never do get just <\p>
the good they seek. If it come at all, it is something else, which <\p>
they never dreamed of, and did not particularly want. Then, again, we <\p>
may rest certain that our friends of to-day will not be our friends of <\p>
a few years hence; but, if we keep one of them, it will be at the <\p>
expense of the others; and most probably we shall keep none. To be <\p>
sure, there are more to be had; but who cares about making a new set of <\p>
friends, even should they be better than those around us?" <\p>
"Not I!" said Priscilla. "I will live and die with these!" <\p>
"Well; but let the future go," resumed I. "As for the present moment, <\p>
if we could look into the hearts where we wish to be most valued, what <\p>
should you expect to see? One's own likeness, in the innermost, <\p>
holiest niche? Ah! I don't know! It may not be there at all. It may <\p>
be a dusty image, thrust aside into a corner, and by and by to be flung <\p>
out of doors, where any foot may trample upon it. If not to-day, then <\p>
to-morrow! And so, Priscilla, I do not see much wisdom in being so <\p>
very merry in this kind of a world." <\p>
It had taken me nearly seven years of worldly life to hive up the <\p>
bitter honey which I here offered to Priscilla. And she rejected it! <\p>
"I don't believe one word of what you say!" she replied, laughing anew. <\p>
"You made me sad, for a minute, by talking about the past; but the past <\p>
never comes back again. Do we dream the same dream twice? There is <\p>
nothing else that I am afraid of." <\p>
So away she ran, and fell down on the green grass, as it was often her <\p>
luck to do, but got up again, without any harm. <\p>
"Priscilla, Priscilla!" cried Hollingsworth, who was sitting on the <\p>
doorstep; "you had better not run any more to-night. You will weary <\p>
yourself too much. And do not sit down out of doors, for there is a <\p>
heavy dew beginning to fall." <\p>
At his first word, she went and sat down under the porch, at <\p>
Hollingsworth's feet, entirely contented and happy. What charm was <\p>
there in his rude massiveness that so attracted and soothed this <\p>
shadow-like girl? It appeared to me, who have always been curious in <\p>
such matters, that Priscilla's vague and seemingly causeless flow of <\p>
felicitous feeling was that with which love blesses inexperienced <\p>
hearts, before they begin to suspect what is going on within them. It <\p>
transports them to the seventh heaven; and if you ask what brought them <\p>
thither, they neither can tell nor care to learn, but cherish an <\p>
ecstatic faith that there they shall abide forever. <\p>
Zenobia was in the doorway, not far from Hollingsworth. She gazed at <\p>
Priscilla in a very singular way. Indeed, it was a sight worth gazing <\p>
at, and a beautiful sight, too, as the fair girl sat at the feet of <\p>
that dark, powerful figure. Her air, while perfectly modest, delicate, <\p>
and virgin-like, denoted her as swayed by Hollingsworth, attracted to <\p>
him, and unconsciously seeking to rest upon his strength. I could not <\p>
turn away my own eyes, but hoped that nobody, save Zenobia and myself, <\p>
was witnessing this picture. It is before me now, with the evening <\p>
twilight a little deepened by the dusk of memory. <\p>
"Come hither, Priscilla," said Zenobia. "I have something to say to <\p>
you." <\p>
She spoke in little more than a whisper. But it is strange how <\p>
expressive of moods a whisper may often be. Priscilla felt at once <\p>
that something had gone wrong. <\p>
"Are you angry with me?" she asked, rising slowly, and standing before <\p>
Zenobia in a drooping attitude. "What have I done? I hope you are not <\p>
angry!" <\p>
"No, no, Priscilla!" said Hollingsworth, smiling. "I will answer for <\p>
it, she is not. You are the one little person in the world with whom <\p>
nobody can be angry!" <\p>
"Angry with you, child? What a silly idea!" exclaimed Zenobia, <\p>
laughing. "No, indeed! But, my dear Priscilla, you are getting to be <\p>
so very pretty that you absolutely need a duenna; and, as I am older <\p>
than you, and have had my own little experience of life, and think <\p>
myself exceedingly sage, I intend to fill the place of a maiden aunt. <\p>
Every day, I shall give you a lecture, a quarter of an hour in length, <\p>
on the morals, manners, and proprieties of social life. When our <\p>
pastoral shall be quite played out, Priscilla, my worldly wisdom may <\p>
stand you in good stead." <\p>
"I am afraid you are angry with me!" repeated Priscilla sadly; for, <\p>
while she seemed as impressible as wax, the girl often showed a <\p>
persistency in her own ideas as stubborn as it was gentle. <\p>
"Dear me, what can I say to the child!" cried Zenobia in a tone of <\p>
humorous vexation. "Well, well; since you insist on my being angry, <\p>
come to my room this moment, and let me beat you!" <\p>
Zenobia bade Hollingsworth good-night very sweetly, and nodded to me <\p>
with a smile. But, just as she turned aside with Priscilla into the <\p>
dimness of the porch, I caught another glance at her countenance. It <\p>
would have made the fortune of a tragic actress, could she have <\p>
borrowed it for the moment when she fumbles in her bosom for the <\p>
concealed dagger, or the exceedingly sharp bodkin, or mingles the <\p>
ratsbane in her lover's bowl of wine or her rival's cup of tea. Not <\p>
that I in the least anticipated any such catastrophe,--it being a <\p>
remarkable truth that custom has in no one point a greater sway than <\p>
over our modes of wreaking our wild passions. And besides, had we been <\p>
in Italy, instead of New England, it was hardly yet a crisis for the <\p>
dagger or the bowl. <\p>
It often amazed me, however, that Hollingsworth should show himself so <\p>
recklessly tender towards Priscilla, and never once seem to think of <\p>
the effect which it might have upon her heart. But the man, as I have <\p>
endeavored to explain, was thrown completely off his moral balance, and <\p>
quite bewildered as to his personal relations, by his great excrescence <\p>
of a philanthropic scheme. I used to see, or fancy, indications that <\p>
he was not altogether obtuse to Zenobia's influence as a woman. No <\p>
doubt, however, he had a still more exquisite enjoyment of Priscilla's <\p>
silent sympathy with his purposes, so unalloyed with criticism, and <\p>
therefore more grateful than any intellectual approbation, which always <\p>
involves a possible reserve of latent censure. A man--poet, prophet, <\p>
or whatever he may be--readily persuades himself of his right to all <\p>
the worship that is voluntarily tendered. In requital of so rich <\p>
benefits as he was to confer upon mankind, it would have been hard to <\p>
deny Hollingsworth the simple solace of a young girl's heart, which he <\p>
held in his hand, and smelled too, like a rosebud. But what if, while <\p>
pressing out its fragrance, he should crush the tender rosebud in his <\p>
grasp! <\p>
As for Zenobia, I saw no occasion to give myself any trouble. With her <\p>
native strength, and her experience of the world, she could not be <\p>
supposed to need any help of mine. Nevertheless, I was really generous <\p>
enough to feel some little interest likewise for Zenobia. With all her <\p>
faults (which might have been a great many besides the abundance that I <\p>
knew of), she possessed noble traits, and a heart which must, at least, <\p>
have been valuable while new. And she seemed ready to fling it away as <\p>
uncalculatingly as Priscilla herself. I could not but suspect that, if <\p>
merely at play with Hollingsworth, she was sporting with a power which <\p>
she did not fully estimate. Or if in earnest, it might chance, between <\p>
Zenobia's passionate force and his dark, self-delusive egotism, to turn <\p>
out such earnest as would develop itself in some sufficiently tragic <\p>
catastrophe, though the dagger and the bowl should go for nothing in it. <\p>
Meantime, the gossip of the Community set them down as a pair of <\p>
lovers. They took walks together, and were not seldom encountered in <\p>
the wood-paths: Hollingsworth deeply discoursing, in tones solemn and <\p>
sternly pathetic; Zenobia, with a rich glow on her cheeks, and her eyes <\p>
softened from their ordinary brightness, looked so beautiful, that had <\p>
her companion been ten times a philanthropist, it seemed impossible but <\p>
that one glance should melt him back into a man. Oftener than anywhere <\p>
else, they went to a certain point on the slope of a pasture, <\p>
commanding nearly the whole of our own domain, besides a view of the <\p>
river, and an airy prospect of many distant hills. The bond of our <\p>
Community was such, that the members had the privilege of building <\p>
cottages for their own residence within our precincts, thus laying a <\p>
hearthstone and fencing in a home private and peculiar to all desirable <\p>
extent, while yet the inhabitants should continue to share the <\p>
advantages of an associated life. It was inferred that Hollingsworth <\p>
and Zenobia intended to rear their dwelling on this favorite spot. <\p>
I mentioned those rumors to Hollingsworth in a playful way. <\p>
"Had you consulted me," I went on to observe, "I should have <\p>
recommended a site farther to the left, just a little withdrawn into <\p>
the wood, with two or three peeps at the prospect among the trees. You <\p>
will be in the shady vale of years long before you can raise any better <\p>
kind of shade around your cottage, if you build it on this bare slope." <\p>
"But I offer my edifice as a spectacle to the world," said <\p>
Hollingsworth, "that it may take example and build many another like <\p>
it. Therefore, I mean to set it on the open hillside." <\p>
Twist these words how I might, they offered no very satisfactory <\p>
import. It seemed hardly probable that Hollingsworth should care about <\p>
educating the public taste in the department of cottage architecture, <\p>
desirable as such improvement certainly was. <\p>
X. A VISITOR FROM TOWN <\p>
Hollingsworth and I--we had been hoeing potatoes, that forenoon, while <\p>
the rest of the fraternity were engaged in a distant quarter of the <\p>
farm--sat under a clump of maples, eating our eleven o'clock lunch, <\p>
when we saw a stranger approaching along the edge of the field. He had <\p>
admitted himself from the roadside through a turnstile, and seemed to <\p>
have a purpose of speaking with us. <\p>
And, by the bye, we were favored with many visits at Blithedale, <\p>
especially from people who sympathized with our theories, and perhaps <\p>
held themselves ready to unite in our actual experiment as soon as <\p>
there should appear a reliable promise of its success. It was rather <\p>
ludicrous, indeed (to me, at least, whose enthusiasm had insensibly <\p>
been exhaled together with the perspiration of many a hard day's toil), <\p>
it was absolutely funny, therefore, to observe what a glory was shed <\p>
about our life and labors, in the imaginations of these longing <\p>
proselytes. In their view, we were as poetical as Arcadians, besides <\p>
being as practical as the hardest-fisted husbandmen in Massachusetts. <\p>
We did not, it is true, spend much time in piping to our sheep, or <\p>
warbling our innocent loves to the sisterhood. But they gave us credit <\p>
for imbuing the ordinary rustic occupations with a kind of religious <\p>
poetry, insomuch that our very cow-yards and pig-sties were as <\p>
delightfully fragrant as a flower garden. Nothing used to please me <\p>
more than to see one of these lay enthusiasts snatch up a hoe, as they <\p>
were very prone to do, and set to work with a vigor that perhaps <\p>
carried him through about a dozen ill-directed strokes. Men are <\p>
wonderfully soon satisfied, in this day of shameful bodily enervation, <\p>
when, from one end of life to the other, such multitudes never taste <\p>
the sweet weariness that follows accustomed toil. I seldom saw the new <\p>
enthusiasm that did not grow as flimsy and flaccid as the proselyte's <\p>
moistened shirt-collar, with a quarter of an hour's active labor under <\p>
a July sun. <\p>
But the person now at hand had not at all the air of one of these <\p>
amiable visionaries. He was an elderly man, dressed rather shabbily, <\p>
yet decently enough, in a gray frock-coat, faded towards a brown hue, <\p>
and wore a broad-brimmed white hat, of the fashion of several years <\p>
gone by. His hair was perfect silver, without a dark thread in the <\p>
whole of it; his nose, though it had a scarlet tip, by no means <\p>
indicated the jollity of which a red nose is the generally admitted <\p>
symbol. He was a subdued, undemonstrative old man, who would doubtless <\p>
drink a glass of liquor, now and then, and probably more than was good <\p>
for him,--not, however, with a purpose of undue exhilaration, but in <\p>
the hope of bringing his spirits up to the ordinary level of the <\p>
world's cheerfulness. Drawing nearer, there was a shy look about him, <\p>
as if he were ashamed of his poverty, or, at any rate, for some reason <\p>
or other, would rather have us glance at him sidelong than take a full <\p>
front view. He had a queer appearance of hiding himself behind the <\p>
patch on his left eye. <\p>
"I know this old gentleman," said I to Hollingsworth, as we sat <\p>
observing him; "that is, I have met him a hundred times in town, and <\p>
have often amused my fancy with wondering what he was before he came to <\p>
be what he is. He haunts restaurants and such places, and has an odd <\p>
way of lurking in corners or getting behind a door whenever <\p>
practicable, and holding out his hand with some little article in it <\p>
which he wishes you to buy. The eye of the world seems to trouble him, <\p>
although he necessarily lives so much in it. I never expected to see <\p>
him in an open field." <\p>
"Have you learned anything of his history?" asked Hollingsworth. <\p>
"Not a circumstance," I answered; "but there must be something curious <\p>
in it. I take him to be a harmless sort of a person, and a tolerably <\p>
honest one; but his manners, being so furtive, remind me of those of a <\p>
rat,--a rat without the mischief, the fierce eye, the teeth to bite <\p>
with, or the desire to bite. See, now! He means to skulk along that <\p>
fringe of bushes, and approach us on the other side of our clump of <\p>
maples." <\p>
We soon heard the old man's velvet tread on the grass, indicating that <\p>
he had arrived within a few feet of where we Sat. <\p>
"Good-morning, Mr. Moodie," said Hollingsworth, addressing the stranger <\p>
as an acquaintance; "you must have had a hot and tiresome walk from the <\p>
city. Sit down, and take a morsel of our bread and cheese." <\p>
The visitor made a grateful little murmur of acquiescence, and sat down <\p>
in a spot somewhat removed; so that, glancing round, I could see his <\p>
gray pantaloons and dusty shoes, while his upper part was mostly hidden <\p>
behind the shrubbery. Nor did he come forth from this retirement <\p>
during the whole of the interview that followed. We handed him such <\p>
food as we had, together with a brown jug of molasses and water (would <\p>
that it had been brandy, or some thing better, for the sake of his <\p>
chill old heart!), like priests offering dainty sacrifice to an <\p>
enshrined and invisible idol. I have no idea that he really lacked <\p>
sustenance; but it was quite touching, nevertheless, to hear him <\p>
nibbling away at our crusts. <\p>
"Mr. Moodie," said I, "do you remember selling me one of those very <\p>
pretty little silk purses, of which you seem to have a monopoly in the <\p>
market? I keep it to this day, I can assure you." <\p>
"Ah, thank you," said our guest. "Yes, Mr. Coverdale, I used to sell a <\p>
good many of those little purses." <\p>
He spoke languidly, and only those few words, like a watch with an <\p>
inelastic spring, that just ticks a moment or two and stops again. He <\p>
seemed a very forlorn old man. In the wantonness of youth, strength, <\p>
and comfortable condition,--making my prey of people's individualities, <\p>
as my custom was,--I tried to identify my mind with the old fellow's, <\p>
and take his view of the world, as if looking through a smoke-blackened <\p>
glass at the sun. It robbed the landscape of all its life. Those <\p>
pleasantly swelling slopes of our farm, descending towards the wide <\p>
meadows, through which sluggishly circled the brimful tide of the <\p>
Charles, bathing the long sedges on its hither and farther shores; the <\p>
broad, sunny gleam over the winding water; that peculiar <\p>
picturesqueness of the scene where capes and headlands put themselves <\p>
boldly forth upon the perfect level of the meadow, as into a green <\p>
lake, with inlets between the promontories; the shadowy woodland, with <\p>
twinkling showers of light falling into its depths; the sultry <\p>
heat-vapor, which rose everywhere like incense, and in which my soul <\p>
delighted, as indicating so rich a fervor in the passionate day, and in <\p>
the earth that was burning with its love,--I beheld all these things as <\p>
through old Moodie's eyes. When my eyes are dimmer than they have yet <\p>
come to be, I will go thither again, and see if I did not catch the <\p>
tone of his mind aright, and if the cold and lifeless tint of his <\p>
perceptions be not then repeated in my own. <\p>
Yet it was unaccountable to myself, the interest that I felt in him. <\p>
"Have you any objection," said I, "to telling me who made those little <\p>
purses?" <\p>
"Gentlemen have often asked me that," said Moodie slowly; "but I shake <\p>
my head, and say little or nothing, and creep out of the way as well as <\p>
I can. I am a man of few words; and if gentlemen were to be told one <\p>
thing, they would be very apt, I suppose, to ask me another. But it <\p>
happens just now, Mr. Coverdale, that you can tell me more about the <\p>
maker of those little purses than I can tell you." <\p>
"Why do you trouble him with needless questions, Coverdale?" <\p>
interrupted Hollingsworth. "You must have known, long ago, that it was <\p>
Priscilla. And so, my good friend, you have come to see her? Well, I <\p>
am glad of it. You will find her altered very much for the better, <\p>
since that winter evening when you put her into my charge. Why, <\p>
Priscilla has a bloom in her cheeks, now!" <\p>
"Has my pale little girl a bloom?" repeated Moodie with a kind of slow <\p>
wonder. "Priscilla with a bloom in her cheeks! Ah, I am afraid I <\p>
shall not know my little girl. And is she happy?" <\p>
"Just as happy as a bird," answered Hollingsworth. <\p>
"Then, gentlemen," said our guest apprehensively, "I don't think it <\p>
well for me to go any farther. I crept hitherward only to ask about <\p>
Priscilla; and now that you have told me such good news, perhaps I can <\p>
do no better than to creep back again. If she were to see this old <\p>
face of mine, the child would remember some very sad times which we <\p>
have spent together. Some very sad times, indeed! She has forgotten <\p>
them, I know,--them and me,--else she could not be so happy, nor have a <\p>
bloom in her cheeks. Yes--yes--yes," continued he, still with the same <\p>
torpid utterance; "with many thanks to you, Mr. Hollingsworth, I will <\p>
creep back to town again." <\p>
"You shall do no such thing, Mr. Moodie," said Hollingsworth bluffly. <\p>
"Priscilla often speaks of you; and if there lacks anything to make her <\p>
cheeks bloom like two damask roses, I'll venture to say it is just the <\p>
sight of your face. Come,--we will go and find her." <\p>
"Mr. Hollingsworth!" said the old man in his hesitating way. <\p>
"Well," answered Hollingsworth. <\p>
"Has there been any call for Priscilla?" asked Moodie; and though his <\p>
face was hidden from us, his tone gave a sure indication of the <\p>
mysterious nod and wink with which he put the question. "You know, I <\p>
think, sir, what I mean." <\p>
"I have not the remotest suspicion what you mean, Mr. Moodie," replied <\p>
Hollingsworth; "nobody, to my knowledge, has called for Priscilla, <\p>
except yourself. But come; we are losing time, and I have several <\p>
things to say to you by the way." <\p>
"And, Mr. Hollingsworth!" repeated Moodie. <\p>
"Well, again!" cried my friend rather impatiently. "What now?" <\p>
"There is a lady here," said the old man; and his voice lost some of <\p>
its wearisome hesitation. "You will account it a very strange matter <\p>
for me to talk about; but I chanced to know this lady when she was but <\p>
a little child. If I am rightly informed, she has grown to be a very <\p>
fine woman, and makes a brilliant figure in the world, with her beauty, <\p>
and her talents, and her noble way of spending her riches. I should <\p>
recognize this lady, so people tell me, by a magnificent flower in her <\p>
hair." <\p>
"What a rich tinge it gives to his colorless ideas, when he speaks of <\p>
Zenobia!" I whispered to Hollingsworth. "But how can there possibly <\p>
