be any interest or connecting link between him and her?" <\p>
"The old man, for years past," whispered Hollingsworth, "has been a <\p>
little out of his right mind, as you probably see." <\p>
"What I would inquire," resumed Moodie, "is whether this beautiful lady <\p>
is kind to my poor Priscilla." <\p>
"Very kind," said Hollingsworth. <\p>
"Does she love her?" asked Moodie. <\p>
"It should seem so," answered my friend. "They are always together." <\p>
"Like a gentlewoman and her maid-servant, I fancy?" suggested the old <\p>
man. <\p>
There was something so singular in his way of saying this, that I could <\p>
not resist the impulse to turn quite round, so as to catch a glimpse of <\p>
his face, almost imagining that I should see another person than old <\p>
Moodie. But there he sat, with the patched side of his face towards me. <\p>
"Like an elder and younger sister, rather," replied Hollingsworth. <\p>
"Ah!" said Moodie more complacently, for his latter tones had harshness <\p>
and acidity in them,--"it would gladden my old heart to witness that. <\p>
If one thing would make me happier than another, Mr. Hollingsworth, it <\p>
would be to see that beautiful lady holding my little girl by the hand." <\p>
"Come along," said Hollingsworth, "and perhaps you may." <\p>
After a little more delay on the part of our freakish visitor, they set <\p>
forth together, old Moodie keeping a step or two behind Hollingsworth, <\p>
so that the latter could not very conveniently look him in the face. I <\p>
remained under the tuft of maples, doing my utmost to draw an inference <\p>
from the scene that had just passed. In spite of Hollingsworth's <\p>
off-hand explanation, it did not strike me that our strange guest was <\p>
really beside himself, but only that his mind needed screwing up, like <\p>
an instrument long out of tune, the strings of which have ceased to <\p>
vibrate smartly and sharply. Methought it would be profitable for us, <\p>
projectors of a happy life, to welcome this old gray shadow, and <\p>
cherish him as one of us, and let him creep about our domain, in order <\p>
that he might be a little merrier for our sakes, and we, sometimes, a <\p>
little sadder for his. Human destinies look ominous without some <\p>
perceptible intermixture of the sable or the gray. And then, too, <\p>
should any of our fraternity grow feverish with an over-exulting sense <\p>
of prosperity, it would be a sort of cooling regimen to slink off into <\p>
the woods, and spend an hour, or a day, or as many days as might be <\p>
requisite to the cure, in uninterrupted communion with this deplorable <\p>
old Moodie! <\p>
Going homeward to dinner, I had a glimpse of him, behind the trunk of a <\p>
tree, gazing earnestly towards a particular window of the farmhouse; <\p>
and by and by Priscilla appeared at this window, playfully drawing <\p>
along Zenobia, who looked as bright as the very day that was blazing <\p>
down upon us, only not, by many degrees, so well advanced towards her <\p>
noon. I was convinced that this pretty sight must have been purposely <\p>
arranged by Priscilla for the old man to see. But either the girl held <\p>
her too long, or her fondness was resented as too great a freedom; for <\p>
Zenobia suddenly put Priscilla decidedly away, and gave her a haughty <\p>
look, as from a mistress to a dependant. Old Moodie shook his head; <\p>
and again and again I saw him shake it, as he withdrew along the road; <\p>
and at the last point whence the farmhouse was visible, he turned and <\p>
shook his uplifted staff. <\p>
XI. THE WOOD-PATH <\p>
Not long after the preceding incident, in order to get the ache of too <\p>
constant labor out of my bones, and to relieve my spirit of the <\p>
irksomeness of a settled routine, I took a holiday. It was my purpose <\p>
to spend it all alone, from breakfast-time till twilight, in the <\p>
deepest wood-seclusion that lay anywhere around us. Though fond of <\p>
society, I was so constituted as to need these occasional retirements, <\p>
even in a life like that of Blithedale, which was itself characterized <\p>
by a remoteness from the world. Unless renewed by a yet further <\p>
withdrawal towards the inner circle of self-communion, I lost the <\p>
better part of my individuality. My thoughts became of little worth, <\p>
and my sensibilities grew as arid as a tuft of moss (a thing whose life <\p>
is in the shade, the rain, or the noontide dew), crumbling in the <\p>
sunshine after long expectance of a shower. So, with my heart full of <\p>
a drowsy pleasure, and cautious not to dissipate my mood by previous <\p>
intercourse with any one, I hurried away, and was soon pacing a <\p>
wood-path, arched overhead with boughs, and dusky-brown beneath my feet. <\p>
At first I walked very swiftly, as if the heavy flood tide of social <\p>
life were roaring at my heels, and would outstrip and overwhelm me, <\p>
without all the better diligence in my escape. But, threading the more <\p>
distant windings of the track, I abated my pace, and looked about me <\p>
for some side-aisle, that should admit me into the innermost sanctuary <\p>
of this green cathedral, just as, in human acquaintanceship, a casual <\p>
opening sometimes lets us, all of a sudden, into the long-sought <\p>
intimacy of a mysterious heart. So much was I absorbed in my <\p>
reflections,--or, rather, in my mood, the substance of which was as yet <\p>
too shapeless to be called thought,--that footsteps rustled on the <\p>
leaves, and a figure passed me by, almost without impressing either the <\p>
sound or sight upon my consciousness. <\p>
A moment afterwards, I heard a voice at a little distance behind me, <\p>
speaking so sharply and impertinently that it made a complete discord <\p>
with my spiritual state, and caused the latter to vanish as abruptly as <\p>
when you thrust a finger into a soap-bubble. <\p>
"Halloo, friend!" cried this most unseasonable voice. "Stop a moment, <\p>
I say! I must have a word with you!" <\p>
I turned about, in a humor ludicrously irate. In the first place, the <\p>
interruption, at any rate, was a grievous injury; then, the tone <\p>
displeased me. And finally, unless there be real affection in his <\p>
heart, a man cannot,--such is the bad state to which the world has <\p>
brought itself,--cannot more effectually show his contempt for a <\p>
brother mortal, nor more gallingly assume a position of superiority, <\p>
than by addressing him as "friend." Especially does the misapplication <\p>
of this phrase bring out that latent hostility which is sure to animate <\p>
peculiar sects, and those who, with however generous a purpose, have <\p>
sequestered themselves from the crowd; a feeling, it is true, which may <\p>
be hidden in some dog-kennel of the heart, grumbling there in the <\p>
darkness, but is never quite extinct, until the dissenting party have <\p>
gained power and scope enough to treat the world generously. For my <\p>
part, I should have taken it as far less an insult to be styled <\p>
"fellow," "clown," or "bumpkin." To either of these appellations my <\p>
rustic garb (it was a linen blouse, with checked shirt and striped <\p>
pantaloons, a chip hat on my head, and a rough hickory stick in my <\p>
hand) very fairly entitled me. As the case stood, my temper darted at <\p>
once to the opposite pole; not friend, but enemy! <\p>
"What do you want with me?" said I, facing about. <\p>
"Come a little nearer, friend," said the stranger, beckoning. <\p>
"No," answered I. "If I can do anything for you without too much <\p>
trouble to myself, say so. But recollect, if you please, that you are <\p>
not speaking to an acquaintance, much less a friend!" <\p>
"Upon my word, I believe not!" retorted he, looking at me with some <\p>
curiosity; and, lifting his hat, he made me a salute which had enough <\p>
of sarcasm to be offensive, and just enough of doubtful courtesy to <\p>
render any resentment of it absurd. "But I ask your pardon! I <\p>
recognize a little mistake. If I may take the liberty to suppose it, <\p>
you, sir, are probably one of the aesthetic--or shall I rather say <\p>
ecstatic?--laborers, who have planted themselves hereabouts. This is <\p>
your forest of Arden; and you are either the banished Duke in person, <\p>
or one of the chief nobles in his train. The melancholy Jacques, <\p>
perhaps? Be it so. In that case, you can probably do me a favor." <\p>
I never, in my life, felt less inclined to confer a favor on any man. <\p>
"I am busy," said I. <\p>
So unexpectedly had the stranger made me sensible of his presence, that <\p>
he had almost the effect of an apparition; and certainly a less <\p>
appropriate one (taking into view the dim woodland solitude about us) <\p>
than if the salvage man of antiquity, hirsute and cinctured with a <\p>
leafy girdle, had started out of a thicket. He was still young, <\p>
seemingly a little under thirty, of a tall and well-developed figure, <\p>
and as handsome a man as ever I beheld. The style of his beauty, <\p>
however, though a masculine style, did not at all commend itself to my <\p>
taste. His countenance--I hardly know how to describe the <\p>
peculiarity--had an indecorum in it, a kind of rudeness, a hard, <\p>
coarse, forth-putting freedom of expression, which no degree of <\p>
external polish could have abated one single jot. Not that it was <\p>
vulgar. But he had no fineness of nature; there was in his eyes <\p>
(although they might have artifice enough of another sort) the naked <\p>
exposure of something that ought not to be left prominent. With these <\p>
vague allusions to what I have seen in other faces as well as his, I <\p>
leave the quality to be comprehended best--because with an intuitive <\p>
repugnance--by those who possess least of it. <\p>
His hair, as well as his beard and mustache, was coal-black; his eyes, <\p>
too, were black and sparkling, and his teeth remarkably brilliant. He <\p>
was rather carelessly but well and fashionably dressed, in a <\p>
summer-morning costume. There was a gold chain, exquisitely wrought, <\p>
across his vest. I never saw a smoother or whiter gloss than that upon <\p>
his shirt-bosom, which had a pin in it, set with a gem that glimmered, <\p>
in the leafy shadow where he stood, like a living tip of fire. He <\p>
carried a stick with a wooden head, carved in vivid imitation of that <\p>
of a serpent. I hated him, partly, I do believe, from a comparison of <\p>
my own homely garb with his well-ordered foppishness. <\p>
"Well, sir," said I, a little ashamed of my first irritation, but still <\p>
with no waste of civility, "be pleased to speak at once, as I have my <\p>
own business in hand." <\p>
"I regret that my mode of addressing you was a little unfortunate," <\p>
said the stranger, smiling; for he seemed a very acute sort of person, <\p>
and saw, in some degree, how I stood affected towards him. "I intended <\p>
no offence, and shall certainly comport myself with due ceremony <\p>
hereafter. I merely wish to make a few inquiries respecting a lady, <\p>
formerly of my acquaintance, who is now resident in your Community, <\p>
and, I believe, largely concerned in your social enterprise. You call <\p>
her, I think, Zenobia." <\p>
"That is her name in literature," observed I; "a name, too, which <\p>
possibly she may permit her private friends to know and address her <\p>
by,--but not one which they feel at liberty to recognize when used of <\p>
her personally by a stranger or casual acquaintance." <\p>
"Indeed!" answered this disagreeable person; and he turned aside his <\p>
face for an instant with a brief laugh, which struck me as a noteworthy <\p>
expression of his character. "Perhaps I might put forward a claim, on <\p>
your own grounds, to call the lady by a name so appropriate to her <\p>
splendid qualities. But I am willing to know her by any cognomen that <\p>
you may suggest." <\p>
Heartily wishing that he would be either a little more offensive, or a <\p>
good deal less so, or break off our intercourse altogether, I mentioned <\p>
Zenobia's real name. <\p>
"True," said he; "and in general society I have never heard her called <\p>
otherwise. And, after all, our discussion of the point has been <\p>
gratuitous. My object is only to inquire when, where, and how this <\p>
lady may most conveniently be seen." <\p>
"At her present residence, of course," I replied. "You have but to go <\p>
thither and ask for her. This very path will lead you within sight of <\p>
the house; so I wish you good-morning." <\p>
"One moment, if you please," said the stranger. "The course you <\p>
indicate would certainly be the proper one, in an ordinary morning <\p>
call. But my business is private, personal, and somewhat peculiar. <\p>
Now, in a community like this, I should judge that any little <\p>
occurrence is likely to be discussed rather more minutely than would <\p>
quite suit my views. I refer solely to myself, you understand, and <\p>
without intimating that it would be other than a matter of entire <\p>
indifference to the lady. In short, I especially desire to see her in <\p>
private. If her habits are such as I have known them, she is probably <\p>
often to be met with in the woods, or by the river-side; and I think <\p>
you could do me the favor to point out some favorite walk, where, about <\p>
this hour, I might be fortunate enough to gain an interview." <\p>
I reflected that it would be quite a supererogatory piece of Quixotism <\p>
in me to undertake the guardianship of Zenobia, who, for my pains, <\p>
would only make me the butt of endless ridicule, should the fact ever <\p>
come to her knowledge. I therefore described a spot which, as often as <\p>
any other, was Zenobia's resort at this period of the day; nor was it <\p>
so remote from the farmhouse as to leave her in much peril, whatever <\p>
might be the stranger's character. <\p>
"A single word more," said he; and his black eyes sparkled at me, <\p>
whether with fun or malice I knew not, but certainly as if the Devil <\p>
were peeping out of them. "Among your fraternity, I understand, there <\p>
is a certain holy and benevolent blacksmith; a man of iron, in more <\p>
senses than one; a rough, cross-grained, well-meaning individual, <\p>
rather boorish in his manners, as might be expected, and by no means of <\p>
the highest intellectual cultivation. He is a philanthropical <\p>
lecturer, with two or three disciples, and a scheme of his own, the <\p>
preliminary step in which involves a large purchase of land, and the <\p>
erection of a spacious edifice, at an expense considerably beyond his <\p>
means; inasmuch as these are to be reckoned in copper or old iron much <\p>
more conveniently than in gold or silver. He hammers away upon his one <\p>
topic as lustily as ever he did upon a horseshoe! Do you know such a <\p>
person?" I shook my head, and was turning away. "Our friend," he <\p>
continued, "is described to me as a brawny, shaggy, grim, and <\p>
ill-favored personage, not particularly well calculated, one would say, <\p>
to insinuate himself with the softer sex. Yet, so far has this honest <\p>
fellow succeeded with one lady whom we wot of, that he anticipates, <\p>
from her abundant resources, the necessary funds for realizing his plan <\p>
in brick and mortar!" <\p>
Here the stranger seemed to be so much amused with his sketch of <\p>
Hollingsworth's character and purposes, that he burst into a fit of <\p>
merriment, of the same nature as the brief, metallic laugh already <\p>
alluded to, but immensely prolonged and enlarged. In the excess of his <\p>
delight, he opened his mouth wide, and disclosed a gold band around the <\p>
upper part of his teeth, thereby making it apparent that every one of <\p>
his brilliant grinders and incisors was a sham. This discovery <\p>
affected me very oddly. <\p>
I felt as if the whole man were a moral and physical humbug; his <\p>
wonderful beauty of face, for aught I knew, might be removable like a <\p>
mask; and, tall and comely as his figure looked, he was perhaps but a <\p>
wizened little elf, gray and decrepit, with nothing genuine about him <\p>
save the wicked expression of his grin. The fantasy of his spectral <\p>
character so wrought upon me, together with the contagion of his <\p>
strange mirth on my sympathies, that I soon began to laugh as loudly as <\p>
himself. <\p>
By and by, he paused all at once; so suddenly, indeed, that my own <\p>
cachinnation lasted a moment longer. <\p>
"Ah, excuse me!" said he. "Our interview seems to proceed more merrily <\p>
than it began." <\p>
"It ends here," answered I. "And I take shame to myself that my folly <\p>
has lost me the right of resenting your ridicule of a friend." <\p>
"Pray allow me," said the stranger, approaching a step nearer, and <\p>
laying his gloved hand on my sleeve. "One other favor I must ask of <\p>
you. You have a young person here at Blithedale, of whom I have <\p>
heard,--whom, perhaps, I have known,--and in whom, at all events, I <\p>
take a peculiar interest. She is one of those delicate, nervous young <\p>
creatures, not uncommon in New England, and whom I suppose to have <\p>
become what we find them by the gradual refining away of the physical <\p>
system among your women. Some philosophers choose to glorify this <\p>
habit of body by terming it spiritual; but, in my opinion, it is rather <\p>
the effect of unwholesome food, bad air, lack of outdoor exercise, and <\p>
neglect of bathing, on the part of these damsels and their female <\p>
progenitors, all resulting in a kind of hereditary dyspepsia. Zenobia, <\p>
even with her uncomfortable surplus of vitality, is far the better <\p>
model of womanhood. But--to revert again to this young person--she <\p>
goes among you by the name of Priscilla. Could you possibly afford me <\p>
the means of speaking with her?" <\p>
"You have made so many inquiries of me," I observed, "that I may at <\p>
least trouble you with one. What is your name?" <\p>
He offered me a card, with "Professor Westervelt" engraved on it. At <\p>
the same time, as if to vindicate his claim to the professorial <\p>
dignity, so often assumed on very questionable grounds, he put on a <\p>
pair of spectacles, which so altered the character of his face that I <\p>
hardly knew him again. But I liked the present aspect no better than <\p>
the former one. <\p>
"I must decline any further connection with your affairs," said I, <\p>
drawing back. "I have told you where to find Zenobia. As for <\p>
Priscilla, she has closer friends than myself, through whom, if they <\p>
see fit, you can gain access to her." <\p>
"In that case," returned the Professor, ceremoniously raising his hat, <\p>
"good-morning to you." <\p>
He took his departure, and was soon out of sight among the windings of <\p>
the wood-path. But after a little reflection, I could not help <\p>
regretting that I had so peremptorily broken off the interview, while <\p>
the stranger seemed inclined to continue it. His evident knowledge of <\p>
matters affecting my three friends might have led to disclosures or <\p>
inferences that would perhaps have been serviceable. I was <\p>
particularly struck with the fact that, ever since the appearance of <\p>
Priscilla, it had been the tendency of events to suggest and establish <\p>
a connection between Zenobia and her. She had come, in the first <\p>
instance, as if with the sole purpose of claiming Zenobia's protection. <\p>
Old Moodie's visit, it appeared, was chiefly to ascertain whether this <\p>
object had been accomplished. And here, to-day, was the questionable <\p>
Professor, linking one with the other in his inquiries, and seeking <\p>
communication with both. <\p>
Meanwhile, my inclination for a ramble having been balked, I lingered <\p>
in the vicinity of the farm, with perhaps a vague idea that some new <\p>
event would grow out of Westervelt's proposed interview with Zenobia. <\p>
My own part in these transactions was singularly subordinate. It <\p>
resembled that of the Chorus in a classic play, which seems to be set <\p>
aloof from the possibility of personal concernment, and bestows the <\p>
whole measure of its hope or fear, its exultation or sorrow, on the <\p>
fortunes of others, between whom and itself this sympathy is the only <\p>
bond. Destiny, it may be,--the most skilful of stage managers,--seldom <\p>
chooses to arrange its scenes, and carry forward its drama, without <\p>
securing the presence of at least one calm observer. It is his office <\p>
to give applause when due, and sometimes an inevitable tear, to detect <\p>
the final fitness of incident to character, and distil in his <\p>
long-brooding thought the whole morality of the performance. <\p>
Not to be out of the way in case there were need of me in my vocation, <\p>
and, at the same time, to avoid thrusting myself where neither destiny <\p>
nor mortals might desire my presence, I remained pretty near the verge <\p>
of the woodlands. My position was off the track of Zenobia's customary <\p>
walk, yet not so remote but that a recognized occasion might speedily <\p>
have brought me thither. <\p>
XII. COVERDALE'S HERMITAGE <\p>
Long since, in this part of our circumjacent wood, I had found out for <\p>
myself a little hermitage. It was a kind of leafy cave, high upward <\p>
into the air, among the midmost branches of a white-pine tree. A wild <\p>
grapevine, of unusual size and luxuriance, had twined and twisted <\p>
itself up into the tree, and, after wreathing the entanglement of its <\p>
tendrils around almost every bough, had caught hold of three or four <\p>
neighboring trees, and married the whole clump with a perfectly <\p>
inextricable knot of polygamy. Once, while sheltering myself from a <\p>
summer shower, the fancy had taken me to clamber up into this seemingly <\p>
impervious mass of foliage. The branches yielded me a passage, and <\p>
closed again beneath, as if only a squirrel or a bird had passed. Far <\p>
aloft, around the stem of the central pine, behold a perfect nest for <\p>
Robinson Crusoe or King Charles! A hollow chamber of rare seclusion <\p>
had been formed by the decay of some of the pine branches, which the <\p>
vine had lovingly strangled with its embrace, burying them from the <\p>
light of day in an aerial sepulchre of its own leaves. It cost me but <\p>
little ingenuity to enlarge the interior, and open loopholes through <\p>
the verdant walls. Had it ever been my fortune to spend a honeymoon, I <\p>
should have thought seriously of inviting my bride up thither, where <\p>
our next neighbors would have been two orioles in another part of the <\p>
clump. <\p>
It was an admirable place to make verses, tuning the rhythm to the <\p>
breezy symphony that so often stirred among the vine leaves; or to <\p>
meditate an essay for "The Dial," in which the many tongues of Nature <\p>
whispered mysteries, and seemed to ask only a little stronger puff of <\p>
wind to speak out the solution of its riddle. Being so pervious to <\p>
air-currents, it was just the nook, too, for the enjoyment of a cigar. <\p>
This hermitage was my one exclusive possession while I counted myself a <\p>
brother of the socialists. It symbolized my individuality, and aided <\p>
me in keeping it inviolate. None ever found me out in it, except, <\p>
once, a squirrel. I brought thither no guest, because, after <\p>
Hollingsworth failed me, there was no longer the man alive with whom I <\p>
could think of sharing all. So there I used to sit, owl-like, yet not <\p>
without liberal and hospitable thoughts. I counted the innumerable <\p>
clusters of my vine, and fore-reckoned the abundance of my vintage. It <\p>
gladdened me to anticipate the surprise of the Community, when, like an <\p>
allegorical figure of rich October, I should make my appearance, with <\p>
shoulders bent beneath the burden of ripe grapes, and some of the <\p>
crushed ones crimsoning my brow as with a bloodstain. <\p>
Ascending into this natural turret, I peeped in turn out of several of <\p>
its small windows. The pine-tree, being ancient, rose high above the <\p>
rest of the wood, which was of comparatively recent growth. Even where <\p>
I sat, about midway between the root and the topmost bough, my position <\p>
was lofty enough to serve as an observatory, not for starry <\p>
investigations, but for those sublunary matters in which lay a lore as <\p>
infinite as that of the planets. Through one loophole I saw the river <\p>
lapsing calmly onward, while in the meadow, near its brink, a few of <\p>
the brethren were digging peat for our winter's fuel. On the interior <\p>
cart-road of our farm I discerned Hollingsworth, with a yoke of oxen <\p>
hitched to a drag of stones, that were to be piled into a fence, on <\p>
which we employed ourselves at the odd intervals of other labor. The <\p>
harsh tones of his voice, shouting to the sluggish steers, made me <\p>
sensible, even at such a distance, that he was ill at ease, and that <\p>
the balked philanthropist had the battle-spirit in his heart. <\p>
"Haw, Buck!" quoth he. "Come along there, ye lazy ones! What are ye <\p>
about, now? Gee!" <\p>
"Mankind, in Hollingsworth's opinion," thought I, "is but another yoke <\p>
of oxen, as stubborn, stupid, and sluggish as our old Brown and Bright. <\p>
He vituperates us aloud, and curses us in his heart, and will begin to <\p>
prick us with the goad-stick, by and by. But are we his oxen? And <\p>
what right has he to be the driver? And why, when there is enough else <\p>
to do, should we waste our strength in dragging home the ponderous load <\p>
of his philanthropic absurdities? At my height above the earth, the <\p>
whole matter looks ridiculous!" <\p>
Turning towards the farmhouse, I saw Priscilla (for, though a great way <\p>
off, the eye of faith assured me that it was she) sitting at Zenobia's <\p>
window, and making little purses, I suppose; or, perhaps, mending the <\p>
Community's old linen. A bird flew past my tree; and, as it clove its <\p>
way onward into the sunny atmosphere, I flung it a message for <\p>
Priscilla. <\p>
"Tell her," said I, "that her fragile thread of life has inextricably <\p>
knotted itself with other and tougher threads, and most likely it will <\p>
be broken. Tell her that Zenobia will not be long her friend. Say that <\p>
Hollingsworth's heart is on fire with his own purpose, but icy for all <\p>
human affection; and that, if she has given him her love, it is like <\p>
casting a flower into a sepulchre. And say that if any mortal really <\p>
cares for her, it is myself; and not even I for her realities,--poor <\p>
little seamstress, as Zenobia rightly called her!--but for the <\p>
fancy-work with which I have idly decked her out!" <\p>
The pleasant scent of the wood, evolved by the hot sun, stole up to my <\p>
nostrils, as if I had been an idol in its niche. Many trees mingled <\p>
their fragrance into a thousand-fold odor. Possibly there was a <\p>
sensual influence in the broad light of noon that lay beneath me. It <\p>
may have been the cause, in part, that I suddenly found myself <\p>
possessed by a mood of disbelief in moral beauty or heroism, and a <\p>
conviction of the folly of attempting to benefit the world. Our <\p>
especial scheme of reform, which, from my observatory, I could take in <\p>
with the bodily eye, looked so ridiculous that it was impossible not to <\p>
laugh aloud. <\p>
"But the joke is a little too heavy," thought I. "If I were wise, I <\p>
should get out of the scrape with all diligence, and then laugh at my <\p>
companions for remaining in it." <\p>
While thus musing, I heard with perfect distinctness, somewhere in the <\p>
wood beneath, the peculiar laugh which I have described as one of the <\p>
disagreeable characteristics of Professor Westervelt. It brought my <\p>
thoughts back to our recent interview. I recognized as chiefly due to <\p>
this man's influence the sceptical and sneering view which just now had <\p>
filled my mental vision in regard to all life's better purposes. And <\p>
it was through his eyes, more than my own, that I was looking at <\p>
Hollingsworth, with his glorious if impracticable dream, and at the <\p>
noble earthliness of Zenobia's character, and even at Priscilla, whose <\p>
impalpable grace lay so singularly between disease and beauty. The <\p>
essential charm of each had vanished. There are some spheres the <\p>
contact with which inevitably degrades the high, debases the pure, <\p>
deforms the beautiful. It must be a mind of uncommon strength, and <\p>
little impressibility, that can permit itself the habit of such <\p>
intercourse, and not be permanently deteriorated; and yet the <\p>
Professor's tone represented that of worldly society at large, where a <\p>
cold scepticism smothers what it can of our spiritual aspirations, and <\p>
makes the rest ridiculous. I detested this kind of man; and all the <\p>
more because a part of my own nature showed itself responsive to him. <\p>
Voices were now approaching through the region of the wood which lay in <\p>
the vicinity of my tree. Soon I caught glimpses of two figures--a <\p>
woman and a man--Zenobia and the stranger--earnestly talking together <\p>
as they advanced. <\p>
Zenobia had a rich though varying color. It was, most of the while, a <\p>
flame, and anon a sudden paleness. Her eyes glowed, so that their <\p>
light sometimes flashed upward to me, as when the sun throws a dazzle <\p>
from some bright object on the ground. Her gestures were free, and <\p>
strikingly impressive. The whole woman was alive with a passionate <\p>
intensity, which I now perceived to be the phase in which her beauty <\p>
culminated. Any passion would have become her well; and passionate <\p>
love, perhaps, the best of all. This was not love, but anger, largely <\p>
intermixed with scorn. Yet the idea strangely forced itself upon me, <\p>
that there was a sort of familiarity between these two companions, <\p>
necessarily the result of an intimate love,--on Zenobia's part, at <\p>
least,--in days gone by, but which had prolonged itself into as <\p>
intimate a hatred, for all futurity. As they passed among the trees, <\p>
reckless as her movement was, she took good heed that even the hem of <\p>
her garment should not brush against the stranger's person. I wondered <\p>
whether there had always been a chasm, guarded so religiously, betwixt <\p>
these two. <\p>
As for Westervelt, he was not a whit more warmed by Zenobia's passion <\p>
than a salamander by the heat of its native furnace. He would have <\p>
been absolutely statuesque, save for a look of slight perplexity, <\p>
tinctured strongly with derision. It was a crisis in which his <\p>
intellectual perceptions could not altogether help him out. He failed <\p>
to comprehend, and cared but little for comprehending, why Zenobia <\p>
should put herself into such a fume; but satisfied his mind that it was <\p>
all folly, and only another shape of a woman's manifold absurdity, <\p>
which men can never understand. How many a woman's evil fate has yoked <\p>
her with a man like this! Nature thrusts some of us into the world <\p>
miserably incomplete on the emotional side, with hardly any <\p>
sensibilities except what pertain to us as animals. No passion, save <\p>
of the senses; no holy tenderness, nor the delicacy that results from <\p>
this. Externally they bear a close resemblance to other men, and have <\p>
perhaps all save the finest grace; but when a woman wrecks herself on <\p>
such a being, she ultimately finds that the real womanhood within her <\p>
has no corresponding part in him. Her deepest voice lacks a response; <\p>
the deeper her cry, the more dead his silence. The fault may be none <\p>
of his; he cannot give her what never lived within his soul. But the <\p>
wretchedness on her side, and the moral deterioration attendant on a <\p>
false and shallow life, without strength enough to keep itself sweet, <\p>
are among the most pitiable wrongs that mortals suffer. <\p>
Now, as I looked down from my upper region at this man and <\p>
woman,--outwardly so fair a sight, and wandering like two lovers in the <\p>
wood,--I imagined that Zenobia, at an earlier period of youth, might <\p>
have fallen into the misfortune above indicated. And when her <\p>
passionate womanhood, as was inevitable, had discovered its mistake, <\p>
here had ensued the character of eccentricity and defiance which <\p>
distinguished the more public portion of her life. <\p>
Seeing how aptly matters had chanced thus far, I began to think it the <\p>
design of fate to let me into all Zenobia's secrets, and that therefore <\p>
the couple would sit down beneath my tree, and carry on a conversation <\p>
which would leave me nothing to inquire. No doubt, however, had it so <\p>
happened, I should have deemed myself honorably bound to warn them of a <\p>
listener's presence by flinging down a handful of unripe grapes, or by <\p>
sending an unearthly groan out of my hiding-place, as if this were one <\p>
of the trees of Dante's ghostly forest. But real life never arranges <\p>
itself exactly like a romance. In the first place, they did not sit <\p>
down at all. Secondly, even while they passed beneath the tree, <\p>
Zenobia's utterance was so hasty and broken, and Westervelt's so cool <\p>
and low, that I hardly could make out an intelligible sentence on <\p>
either side. What I seem to remember, I yet suspect, may have been <\p>
patched together by my fancy, in brooding over the matter afterwards. <\p>
"Why not fling the girl off," said Westervelt, "and let her go?" <\p>
"She clung to me from the first," replied Zenobia. "I neither know nor <\p>
care what it is in me that so attaches her. But she loves me, and I <\p>
will not fail her." <\p>
"She will plague you, then," said he, "in more ways than one." <\p>
"The poor child!" exclaimed Zenobia. "She can do me neither good nor <\p>
harm. How should she?" <\p>
I know not what reply Westervelt whispered; nor did Zenobia's <\p>
subsequent exclamation give me any clew, except that it evidently <\p>
inspired her with horror and disgust. <\p>
"With what kind of a being am I linked?" cried she. "If my Creator <\p>
cares aught for my soul, let him release me from this miserable bond!" <\p>
"I did not think it weighed so heavily," said her companion.. <\p>
"Nevertheless," answered Zenobia, "it will strangle me at last!" <\p>
And then I heard her utter a helpless sort of moan; a sound which, <\p>
struggling out of the heart of a person of her pride and strength, <\p>
affected me more than if she had made the wood dolorously vocal with a <\p>
thousand shrieks and wails. <\p>
Other mysterious words, besides what are above written, they spoke <\p>
together; but I understood no more, and even question whether I fairly <\p>
understood so much as this. By long brooding over our recollections, <\p>
we subtilize them into something akin to imaginary stuff, and hardly <\p>
capable of being distinguished from it. In a few moments they were <\p>
completely beyond ear-shot. A breeze stirred after them, and awoke the <\p>
leafy tongues of the surrounding trees, which forthwith began to <\p>
babble, as if innumerable gossips had all at once got wind of Zenobia's <\p>
secret. But, as the breeze grew stronger, its voice among the branches <\p>
was as if it said, "Hush! Hush!" and I resolved that to no mortal <\p>
would I disclose what I had heard. And, though there might be room for <\p>
casuistry, such, I conceive, is the most equitable rule in all similar <\p>
conjunctures. <\p>
XIII. ZENOBIA'S LEGEND <\p>
The illustrious Society of Blithedale, though it toiled in downright <\p>
earnest for the good of mankind, yet not unfrequently illuminated its <\p>
laborious life with an afternoon or evening of pastime. Picnics under <\p>
the trees were considerably in vogue; and, within doors, fragmentary <\p>
bits of theatrical performance, such as single acts of tragedy or <\p>
comedy, or dramatic proverbs and charades. Zenobia, besides, was fond <\p>
of giving us readings from Shakespeare, and often with a depth of <\p>
tragic power, or breadth of comic effect, that made one feel it an <\p>
intolerable wrong to the world that she did not at once go upon the <\p>
stage. Tableaux vivants were another of our occasional modes of <\p>
amusement, in which scarlet shawls, old silken robes, ruffs, velvets, <\p>
furs, and all kinds of miscellaneous trumpery converted our familiar <\p>
companions into the people of a pictorial world. We had been thus <\p>
engaged on the evening after the incident narrated in the last chapter. <\p>
Several splendid works of art--either arranged after engravings from <\p>
the old masters, or original illustrations of scenes in history or <\p>
romance--had been presented, and we were earnestly entreating Zenobia <\p>
for more. <\p>
She stood with a meditative air, holding a large piece of gauze, or <\p>
some such ethereal stuff, as if considering what picture should next <\p>
occupy the frame; while at her feet lay a heap of many-colored <\p>
garments, which her quick fancy and magic skill could so easily convert <\p>
into gorgeous draperies for heroes and princesses. <\p>
"I am getting weary of this," said she, after a moment's thought. "Our <\p>
own features, and our own figures and airs, show a little too <\p>
intrusively through all the characters we assume. We have so much <\p>
familiarity with one another's realities, that we cannot remove <\p>
ourselves, at pleasure, into an imaginary sphere. Let us have no more <\p>
pictures to-night; but, to make you what poor amends I can, how would <\p>
you like to have me trump up a wild, spectral legend, on the spur of <\p>
the moment?" <\p>
Zenobia had the gift of telling a fanciful little story, off-hand, in a <\p>
way that made it greatly more effective than it was usually found to be <\p>
when she afterwards elaborated the same production with her pen. Her <\p>
proposal, therefore, was greeted with acclamation. <\p>
"Oh, a story, a story, by all means!" cried the young girls. "No <\p>
matter how marvellous; we will believe it, every word. And let it be a <\p>
ghost story, if you please." <\p>
"No, not exactly a ghost story," answered Zenobia; "but something so <\p>
nearly like it that you shall hardly tell the difference. And, <\p>
Priscilla, stand you before me, where I may look at you, and get my <\p>
inspiration out of your eyes. They are very deep and dreamy to-night." <\p>
I know not whether the following version of her story will retain any <\p>
portion of its pristine character; but, as Zenobia told it wildly and <\p>
rapidly, hesitating at no extravagance, and dashing at absurdities <\p>
which I am too timorous to repeat,--giving it the varied emphasis of <\p>
her inimitable voice, and the pictorial illustration of her mobile <\p>
face, while through it all we caught the freshest aroma of the <\p>
thoughts, as they came bubbling out of her mind,--thus narrated, and <\p>
thus heard, the legend seemed quite a remarkable affair. I scarcely <\p>
knew, at the time, whether she intended us to laugh or be more <\p>
seriously impressed. From beginning to end, it was undeniable <\p>
nonsense, but not necessarily the worse for that. <\p>
THE SILVERY VEIL <\p>
You have heard, my dear friends, of the Veiled Lady, who grew suddenly <\p>
so very famous, a few months ago. And have you never thought how <\p>
remarkable it was that this marvellous creature should vanish, all at <\p>
once, while her renown was on the increase, before the public had grown <\p>
weary of her, and when the enigma of her character, instead of being <\p>
solved, presented itself more mystically at every exhibition? Her last <\p>
appearance, as you know, was before a crowded audience. The next <\p>
evening,--although the bills had announced her, at the corner of every <\p>
street, in red letters of a gigantic size,--there was no Veiled Lady to <\p>
be seen! Now, listen to my simple little tale, and you shall hear the <\p>
very latest incident in the known life--(if life it may be called, <\p>
which seemed to have no more reality than the candle-light image of <\p>
one's self which peeps at us outside of a dark windowpane)--the life of <\p>
this shadowy phenomenon. <\p>
A party of young gentlemen, you are to understand, were enjoying <\p>
themselves, one afternoon,--as young gentlemen are sometimes fond of <\p>
doing,--over a bottle or two of champagne; and, among other ladies less <\p>
mysterious, the subject of the Veiled Lady, as was very natural, <\p>
happened to come up before them for discussion. She rose, as it were, <\p>
with the sparkling effervescence of their wine, and appeared in a more <\p>
airy and fantastic light on account of the medium through which they <\p>
saw her. They repeated to one another, between jest and earnest, all <\p>
the wild stories that were in vogue; nor, I presume, did they hesitate <\p>
to add any small circumstance that the inventive whim of the moment <\p>
might suggest, to heighten the marvellousness of their theme. <\p>
"But what an audacious report was that," observed one, "which pretended <\p>
to assert the identity of this strange creature with a young <\p>
lady,"--and here he mentioned her name,--"the daughter of one of our <\p>
most distinguished families!" <\p>
"Ah, there is more in that story than can well be accounted for," <\p>
remarked another. "I have it on good authority, that the young lady in <\p>
question is invariably out of sight, and not to be traced, even by her <\p>
own family, at the hours when the Veiled Lady is before the public; nor <\p>
can any satisfactory explanation be given of her disappearance. And <\p>
just look at the thing: Her brother is a young fellow of spirit. He <\p>
cannot but be aware of these rumors in reference to his sister. Why, <\p>
then, does he not come forward to defend her character, unless he is <\p>
conscious that an investigation would only make the matter worse?" <\p>
It is essential to the purposes of my legend to distinguish one of <\p>
these young gentlemen from his companions; so, for the sake of a soft <\p>
and pretty name (such as we of the literary sisterhood invariably <\p>
bestow upon our heroes), I deem it fit to call him Theodore. <\p>
"Pshaw!" exclaimed Theodore; "her brother is no such fool! Nobody, <\p>
unless his brain be as full of bubbles as this wine, can seriously <\p>
think of crediting that ridiculous rumor. Why, if my senses did not <\p>
play me false (which never was the case yet), I affirm that I saw that <\p>
very lady, last evening, at the exhibition, while this veiled <\p>
phenomenon was playing off her juggling tricks! What can you say to <\p>
that?" <\p>
"Oh, it was a spectral illusion that you saw!" replied his friends, <\p>
with a general laugh. "The Veiled Lady is quite up to such a thing." <\p>
However, as the above-mentioned fable could not hold its ground against <\p>
Theodore's downright refutation, they went on to speak of other stories <\p>
which the wild babble of the town had set afloat. Some upheld that the <\p>
veil covered the most beautiful countenance in the world; others,--and <\p>
certainly with more reason, considering the sex of the Veiled <\p>
Lady,--that the face was the most hideous and horrible, and that this <\p>
was her sole motive for hiding it. It was the face of a corpse; it was <\p>
the head of a skeleton; it was a monstrous visage, with snaky locks, <\p>
like Medusa's, and one great red eye in the centre of the forehead. <\p>
Again, it was affirmed that there was no single and unchangeable set of <\p>
features beneath the veil; but that whosoever should be bold enough to <\p>
lift it would behold the features of that person, in all the world, who <\p>
was destined to be his fate; perhaps he would be greeted by the tender <\p>
smile of the woman whom he loved, or, quite as probably, the deadly <\p>
scowl of his bitterest enemy would throw a blight over his life. They <\p>
quoted, moreover, this startling explanation of the whole affair: that <\p>
the magician who exhibited the Veiled Lady--and who, by the bye, was <\p>
the handsomest man in the whole world--had bartered his own soul for <\p>
seven years' possession of a familiar fiend, and that the last year of <\p>
the contract was wearing towards its close. <\p>
If it were worth our while, I could keep you till an hour beyond <\p>
midnight listening to a thousand such absurdities as these. But <\p>
finally our friend Theodore, who prided himself upon his common-sense, <\p>
found the matter getting quite beyond his patience. <\p>
"I offer any wager you like," cried he, setting down his glass so <\p>
forcibly as to break the stem of it, "that this very evening I find out <\p>
the mystery of the Veiled Lady!" <\p>
Young men, I am told, boggle at nothing over their wine; so, after a <\p>
little more talk, a wager of considerable amount was actually laid, the <\p>
money staked, and Theodore left to choose his own method of settling <\p>
the dispute. <\p>
How he managed it I know not, nor is it of any great importance to this <\p>
veracious legend. The most natural way, to be sure, was by bribing the <\p>
doorkeeper,--or possibly he preferred clambering in at the window. <\p>
But, at any rate, that very evening, while the exhibition was going <\p>
forward in the hall, Theodore contrived to gain admittance into the <\p>
private withdrawing-room whither the Veiled Lady was accustomed to <\p>
retire at the close of her performances. There he waited, listening, I <\p>
suppose, to the stifled hum of the great audience; and no doubt he <\p>
could distinguish the deep tones of the magician, causing the wonders <\p>
that he wrought to appear more dark and intricate, by his mystic <\p>
pretence of an explanation. Perhaps, too, in the intervals of the wild <\p>
breezy music which accompanied the exhibition, he might hear the low <\p>
voice of the Veiled Lady, conveying her sibylline responses. Firm as <\p>
Theodore's nerves might be, and much as he prided himself on his sturdy <\p>
perception of realities, I should not be surprised if his heart <\p>
throbbed at a little more than its ordinary rate. <\p>
Theodore concealed himself behind a screen. In due time the <\p>
performance was brought to a close, and whether the door was softly <\p>
opened, or whether her bodiless presence came through the wall, is more <\p>
than I can say, but, all at once, without the young man's knowing how <\p>
it happened, a veiled figure stood in the centre of the room. It was <\p>
one thing to be in presence of this mystery in the hall of exhibition, <\p>
where the warm, dense life of hundreds of other mortals kept up the <\p>
beholder's courage, and distributed her influence among so many; it was <\p>
another thing to be quite alone with her, and that, too, with a <\p>
hostile, or, at least, an unauthorized and unjustifiable purpose. I <\p>
further imagine that Theodore now began to be sensible of something <\p>
more serious in his enterprise than he had been quite aware of while he <\p>
sat with his boon-companions over their sparkling wine. <\p>
Very strange, it must be confessed, was the movement with which the <\p>
figure floated to and fro over the carpet, with the silvery veil <\p>
covering her from head to foot; so impalpable, so ethereal, so without <\p>
substance, as the texture seemed, yet hiding her every outline in an <\p>
impenetrability like that of midnight. Surely, she did not walk! She <\p>
floated, and flitted, and hovered about the room; no sound of a <\p>
footstep, no perceptible motion of a limb; it was as if a wandering <\p>
breeze wafted her before it, at its own wild and gentle pleasure. But, <\p>
by and by, a purpose began to be discernible, throughout the seeming <\p>
vagueness of her unrest. She was in quest of something. Could it be <\p>
that a subtile presentiment had informed her of the young man's <\p>
presence? And if so, did the Veiled Lady seek or did she shun him? <\p>
The doubt in Theodore's mind was speedily resolved; for, after a moment <\p>
or two of these erratic flutterings, she advanced more decidedly, and <\p>
stood motionless before the screen. <\p>
"Thou art here!" said a soft, low voice. "Come forth, Theodore!" Thus <\p>
summoned by his name, Theodore, as a man of courage, had no choice. He <\p>
emerged from his concealment, and presented himself before the Veiled <\p>
Lady, with the wine-flush, it may be, quite gone out of his cheeks. <\p>
"What wouldst thou with me?" she inquired, with the same gentle <\p>
composure that was in her former utterance. <\p>
"Mysterious creature," replied Theodore, "I would know who and what you <\p>
are!" <\p>
"My lips are forbidden to betray the secret," said the Veiled Lady. <\p>
"At whatever risk, I must discover it," rejoined Theodore. <\p>
"Then," said the Mystery, "there is no way save to lift my veil." <\p>
And Theodore, partly recovering his audacity, stept forward on the <\p>
instant, to do as the Veiled Lady had suggested. But she floated <\p>
backward to the opposite side of the room, as if the young man's breath <\p>
had possessed power enough to waft her away. <\p>
"Pause, one little instant," said the soft, low voice, "and learn the <\p>
conditions of what thou art so bold to undertake. Thou canst go hence, <\p>
and think of me no more; or, at thy option, thou canst lift this <\p>
mysterious veil, beneath which I am a sad and lonely prisoner, in a <\p>
bondage which is worse to me than death. But, before raising it, I <\p>
entreat thee, in all maiden modesty, to bend forward and impress a kiss <\p>
where my breath stirs the veil; and my virgin lips shall come forward <\p>
to meet thy lips; and from that instant, Theodore, thou shalt be mine, <\p>
and I thine, with never more a veil between us. And all the felicity <\p>
of earth and of the future world shall be thine and mine together. So <\p>
much may a maiden say behind the veil. If thou shrinkest from this, <\p>
there is yet another way." "And what is that?" asked Theodore. "Dost <\p>
thou hesitate," said the Veiled Lady, "to pledge thyself to me, by <\p>
meeting these lips of mine, while the veil yet hides my face? Has not <\p>
thy heart recognized me? Dost thou come hither, not in holy faith, nor <\p>
with a pure and generous purpose, but in scornful scepticism and idle <\p>
curiosity? Still, thou mayest lift the veil! But, from that instant, <\p>
Theodore, I am doomed to be thy evil fate; nor wilt thou ever taste <\p>
another breath of happiness!" <\p>
There was a shade of inexpressible sadness in the utterance of these <\p>
last words. But Theodore, whose natural tendency was towards <\p>
scepticism, felt himself almost injured and insulted by the Veiled <\p>
Lady's proposal that he should pledge himself, for life and eternity, <\p>
to so questionable a creature as herself; or even that she should <\p>
suggest an inconsequential kiss, taking into view the probability that <\p>
her face was none of the most bewitching. A delightful idea, truly, <\p>
that he should salute the lips of a dead girl, or the jaws of a <\p>
skeleton, or the grinning cavity of a monster's mouth! Even should she <\p>
prove a comely maiden enough in other respects, the odds were ten to <\p>
one that her teeth were defective; a terrible drawback on the <\p>
delectableness of a kiss. <\p>
"Excuse me, fair lady," said Theodore, and I think he nearly burst into <\p>
a laugh, "if I prefer to lift the veil first; and for this affair of <\p>
the kiss, we may decide upon it afterwards." <\p>
"Thou hast made thy choice," said the sweet, sad voice behind the veil; <\p>
and there seemed a tender but unresentful sense of wrong done to <\p>
womanhood by the young man's contemptuous interpretation of her offer. <\p>
"I must not counsel thee to pause, although thy fate is still in thine <\p>
own hand!" <\p>
Grasping at the veil, he flung it upward, and caught a glimpse of a <\p>
pale, lovely face beneath; just one momentary glimpse, and then the <\p>
apparition vanished, and the silvery veil fluttered slowly down and lay <\p>
upon the floor. Theodore was alone. Our legend leaves him there. His <\p>
retribution was, to pine forever and ever for another sight of that <\p>
dim, mournful face,--which might have been his life-long household <\p>
fireside joy,--to desire, and waste life in a feverish quest, and never <\p>
meet it more. <\p>
But what, in good sooth, had become of the Veiled Lady? Had all her <\p>
existence been comprehended within that mysterious veil, and was she <\p>
now annihilated? Or was she a spirit, with a heavenly essence, but <\p>
which might have been tamed down to human bliss, had Theodore been <\p>
brave and true enough to claim her? Hearken, my sweet friends,--and <\p>
hearken, dear Priscilla,--and you shall learn the little more that <\p>
Zenobia can tell you. <\p>
Just at the moment, so far as can be ascertained, when the Veiled Lady <\p>
vanished, a maiden, pale and shadowy, rose up amid a knot of visionary <\p>
people, who were seeking for the better life. She was so gentle and so <\p>
sad,--a nameless melancholy gave her such hold upon their <\p>
sympathies,--that they never thought of questioning whence she came. <\p>
She might have heretofore existed, or her thin substance might have <\p>
been moulded out of air at the very instant when they first beheld her. <\p>
It was all one to them; they took her to their hearts. Among them was a <\p>
lady to whom, more than to all the rest, this pale, mysterious girl <\p>
attached herself. <\p>
But one morning the lady was wandering in the woods, and there met her <\p>
a figure in an Oriental robe, with a dark beard, and holding in his <\p>
hand a silvery veil. He motioned her to stay. Being a woman of some <\p>
nerve, she did not shriek, nor run away, nor faint, as many ladies <\p>
would have been apt to do, but stood quietly, and bade him speak. The <\p>
truth was, she had seen his face before, but had never feared it, <\p>
although she knew him to be a terrible magician. <\p>
"Lady," said he, with a warning gesture, "you are in peril!" "Peril!" <\p>
she exclaimed. "And of what nature?" <\p>
"There is a certain maiden," replied the magician, "who has come out of <\p>
the realm of mystery, and made herself your most intimate companion. <\p>
Now, the fates have so ordained it, that, whether by her own will or <\p>
no, this stranger is your deadliest enemy. In love, in worldly <\p>
fortune, in all your pursuit of happiness, she is doomed to fling a <\p>
blight over your prospects. There is but one possibility of thwarting <\p>
her disastrous influence." <\p>
"Then tell me that one method," said the lady. <\p>
"Take this veil," he answered, holding forth the silvery texture. "It <\p>
is a spell; it is a powerful enchantment, which I wrought for her sake, <\p>
and beneath which she was once my prisoner. Throw it, at unawares, <\p>
over the head of this secret foe, stamp your foot, and cry, 'Arise, <\p>
Magician! Here is the Veiled Lady!' and immediately I will rise up <\p>
through the earth, and seize her; and from that moment you are safe!" <\p>
So the lady took the silvery veil, which was like woven air, or like <\p>
some substance airier than nothing, and that would float upward and be <\p>
lost among the clouds, were she once to let it go. Returning homeward, <\p>
she found the shadowy girl amid the knot of visionary <\p>
transcendentalists, who were still seeking for the better life. She <\p>
was joyous now, and had a rose-bloom in her cheeks, and was one of the <\p>
prettiest creatures, and seemed one of the happiest, that the world <\p>
could show. But the lady stole noiselessly behind her and threw the <\p>
veil over her head. As the slight, ethereal texture sank inevitably <\p>
down over her figure, the poor girl strove to raise it, and met her <\p>
dear friend's eyes with one glance of mortal terror, and deep, deep <\p>
reproach. It could not change her purpose. <\p>
"Arise, Magician!" she exclaimed, stamping her foot upon the earth. <\p>
"Here is the Veiled Lady!" <\p>
At the word, up rose the bearded man in the Oriental robes,--the <\p>
beautiful, the dark magician, who had bartered away his soul! He threw <\p>
his arms around the Veiled Lady, and she was his bond-slave for <\p>
evermore! <\p>
Zenobia, all this while, had been holding the piece of gauze, and so <\p>
managed it as greatly to increase the dramatic effect of the legend at <\p>
those points where the magic veil was to be described. Arriving at the <\p>
catastrophe, and uttering the fatal words, she flung the gauze over <\p>
Priscilla's head; and for an instant her auditors held their breath, <\p>
half expecting, I verily believe, that the magician would start up <\p>
through the floor, and carry off our poor little friend before our eyes. <\p>
As for Priscilla, she stood droopingly in the midst of us, making no <\p>
attempt to remove the veil. <\p>
"How do you find yourself, my love?" said Zenobia, lifting a corner of <\p>
the gauze, and peeping beneath it with a mischievous smile. "Ah, the <\p>
dear little soul! Why, she is really going to faint! Mr. Coverdale, <\p>
Mr. Coverdale, pray bring a glass of water!" <\p>
Her nerves being none of the strongest, Priscilla hardly recovered her <\p>
equanimity during the rest of the evening. This, to be sure, was a <\p>
great pity; but, nevertheless, we thought it a very bright idea of <\p>
Zenobia's to bring her legend to so effective a conclusion. <\p>
XIV. ELIOT'S PULPIT <\p>
Our Sundays at Blithedale were not ordinarily kept with such rigid <\p>
observance as might have befitted the descendants of the Pilgrims, <\p>
whose high enterprise, as we sometimes flattered ourselves, we had <\p>
taken up, and were carrying it onward and aloft, to a point which they <\p>
never dreamed of attaining. <\p>
On that hallowed day, it is true, we rested from our labors. Our oxen, <\p>
relieved from their week-day yoke, roamed at large through the pasture; <\p>
each yoke-fellow, however, keeping close beside his mate, and <\p>
continuing to acknowledge, from the force of habit and sluggish <\p>
sympathy, the union which the taskmaster had imposed for his own hard <\p>
ends. As for us human yoke-fellows, chosen companions of toil, whose <\p>
hoes had clinked together throughout the week, we wandered off, in <\p>
various directions, to enjoy our interval of repose. Some, I believe, <\p>
went devoutly to the village church. Others, it may be, ascended a <\p>
city or a country pulpit, wearing the clerical robe with so much <\p>
dignity that you would scarcely have suspected the yeoman's frock to <\p>
have been flung off only since milking-time. Others took long rambles <\p>
among the rustic lanes and by-paths, pausing to look at black old <\p>
farmhouses, with their sloping roofs; and at the modern cottage, so <\p>
like a plaything that it seemed as if real joy or sorrow could have no <\p>
scope within; and at the more pretending villa, with its range of <\p>
wooden columns supporting the needless insolence of a great portico. <\p>
Some betook themselves into the wide, dusky barn, and lay there for <\p>
hours together on the odorous hay; while the sunstreaks and the shadows <\p>
strove together,--these to make the barn solemn, those to make it <\p>
cheerful,--and both were conquerors; and the swallows twittered a <\p>
cheery anthem, flashing into sight, or vanishing as they darted to and <\p>
fro among the golden rules of sunshine. And others went a little way <\p>
into the woods, and threw themselves on mother earth, pillowing their <\p>
heads on a heap of moss, the green decay of an old log; and, dropping <\p>
asleep, the bumblebees and mosquitoes sung and buzzed about their ears, <\p>
causing the slumberers to twitch and start, without awaking. <\p>
With Hollingsworth, Zenobia, Priscilla, and myself, it grew to be a <\p>
custom to spend the Sabbath afternoon at a certain rock. It was known <\p>
to us under the name of Eliot's pulpit, from a tradition that the <\p>
venerable Apostle Eliot had preached there, two centuries gone by, to <\p>
an Indian auditory. The old pine forest, through which the Apostle's <\p>
voice was wont to sound, had fallen an immemorial time ago. But the <\p>
soil, being of the rudest and most broken surface, had apparently never <\p>
been brought under tillage; other growths, maple and beech and birch, <\p>
had succeeded to the primeval trees; so that it was still as wild a <\p>
tract of woodland as the great-great-great-great grandson of one of <\p>
Eliot's Indians (had any such posterity been in existence) could have <\p>
desired for the site and shelter of his wigwam. These after-growths, <\p>
indeed, lose the stately solemnity of the original forest. If left in <\p>
due neglect, however, they run into an entanglement of softer wildness, <\p>
among the rustling leaves of which the sun can scatter cheerfulness as <\p>
it never could among the dark-browed pines. <\p>
The rock itself rose some twenty or thirty feet, a shattered granite <\p>
bowlder, or heap of bowlders, with an irregular outline and many <\p>
fissures, out of which sprang shrubs, bushes, and even trees; as if the <\p>
scanty soil within those crevices were sweeter to their roots than any <\p>
other earth. At the base of the pulpit, the broken bowlders inclined <\p>
towards each other, so as to form a shallow cave, within which our <\p>
little party had sometimes found protection from a summer shower. On <\p>
the threshold, or just across it, grew a tuft of pale columbines, in <\p>
their season, and violets, sad and shadowy recluses, such as Priscilla <\p>
was when we first knew her; children of the sun, who had never seen <\p>
their father, but dwelt among damp mosses, though not akin to them. At <\p>
the summit, the rock was overshadowed by the canopy of a birch-tree, <\p>
which served as a sounding-board for the pulpit. Beneath this shade <\p>
(with my eyes of sense half shut and those of the imagination widely <\p>
opened) I used to see the holy Apostle of the Indians, with the <\p>
sunlight flickering down upon him through the leaves, and glorifying <\p>
his figure as with the half-perceptible glow of a transfiguration. <\p>
I the more minutely describe the rock, and this little Sabbath <\p>
solitude, because Hollingsworth, at our solicitation, often ascended <\p>
Eliot's pulpit, and not exactly preached, but talked to us, his few <\p>
disciples, in a strain that rose and fell as naturally as the wind's <\p>
breath among the leaves of the birch-tree. No other speech of man has <\p>
ever moved me like some of those discourses. It seemed most pitiful--a <\p>
positive calamity to the world--that a treasury of golden thoughts <\p>
should thus be scattered, by the liberal handful, down among us three, <\p>
when a thousand hearers might have been the richer for them; and <\p>
Hollingsworth the richer, likewise, by the sympathy of multitudes. <\p>
After speaking much or little, as might happen, he would descend from <\p>
his gray pulpit, and generally fling himself at full length on the <\p>
ground, face downward. Meanwhile, we talked around him on such topics <\p>
as were suggested by the discourse. <\p>
Since her interview with Westervelt, Zenobia's continual inequalities <\p>
of temper had been rather difficult for her friends to bear. On the <\p>
first Sunday after that incident, when Hollingsworth had clambered down <\p>
from Eliot's pulpit, she declaimed with great earnestness and passion, <\p>
nothing short of anger, on the injustice which the world did to women, <\p>
and equally to itself, by not allowing them, in freedom and honor, and <\p>
with the fullest welcome, their natural utterance in public. <\p>
"It shall not always be so!" cried she. "If I live another year, I <\p>
will lift up my own voice in behalf of woman's wider liberty!" <\p>
She perhaps saw me smile. <\p>
"What matter of ridicule do you find in this, Miles Coverdale?" <\p>
exclaimed Zenobia, with a flash of anger in her eyes. "That smile, <\p>
permit me to say, makes me suspicious of a low tone of feeling and <\p>
shallow thought. It is my belief--yes, and my prophecy, should I die <\p>
before it happens--that, when my sex shall achieve its rights, there <\p>
will be ten eloquent women where there is now one eloquent man. Thus <\p>
far, no woman in the world has ever once spoken out her whole heart and <\p>
her whole mind. The mistrust and disapproval of the vast bulk of <\p>
society throttles us, as with two gigantic hands at our throats! We <\p>
mumble a few weak words, and leave a thousand better ones unsaid. You <\p>
let us write a little, it is true, on a limited range of subjects. But <\p>
the pen is not for woman. Her power is too natural and immediate. It <\p>
is with the living voice alone that she can compel the world to <\p>
recognize the light of her intellect and the depth of her heart!" <\p>
Now,--though I could not well say so to Zenobia,--I had not smiled from <\p>
any unworthy estimate of woman, or in denial of the claims which she is <\p>
beginning to put forth. What amused and puzzled me was the fact, that <\p>
women, however intellectually superior, so seldom disquiet themselves <\p>
about the rights or wrongs of their sex, unless their own individual <\p>
affections chance to lie in idleness, or to be ill at ease. They are <\p>
not natural reformers, but become such by the pressure of exceptional <\p>
misfortune. I could measure Zenobia's inward trouble by the animosity <\p>
with which she now took up the general quarrel of woman against man. <\p>
"I will give you leave, Zenobia," replied I, "to fling your utmost <\p>
scorn upon me, if you ever hear me utter a sentiment unfavorable to the <\p>
widest liberty which woman has yet dreamed of. I would give her all <\p>
she asks, and add a great deal more, which she will not be the party to <\p>
demand, but which men, if they were generous and wise, would grant of <\p>
their own free motion. For instance, I should love dearly--for the <\p>
next thousand years, at least--to have all government devolve into the <\p>
hands of women. I hate to be ruled by my own sex; it excites my <\p>
jealousy, and wounds my pride. It is the iron sway of bodily force <\p>
which abases us, in our compelled submission. But how sweet the free, <\p>
generous courtesy with which I would kneel before a woman-ruler!" <\p>
"Yes, if she were young and beautiful," said Zenobia, laughing. "But <\p>
how if she were sixty, and a fright?" <\p>
"Ah! it is you that rate womanhood low," said I. "But let me go on. I <\p>
have never found it possible to suffer a bearded priest so near my <\p>
heart and conscience as to do me any spiritual good. I blush at the <\p>
very thought! Oh, in the better order of things, Heaven grant that the <\p>
ministry of souls may be left in charge of women! The gates of the <\p>
Blessed City will be thronged with the multitude that enter in, when <\p>
that day comes! The task belongs to woman. God meant it for her. He <\p>
has endowed her with the religious sentiment in its utmost depth and <\p>
purity, refined from that gross, intellectual alloy with which every <\p>
masculine theologist--save only One, who merely veiled himself in <\p>
mortal and masculine shape, but was, in truth, divine--has been prone <\p>
to mingle it. I have always envied the Catholics their faith in that <\p>
sweet, sacred Virgin Mother, who stands between them and the Deity, <\p>
intercepting somewhat of his awful splendor, but permitting his love to <\p>
stream upon the worshipper more intelligibly to human comprehension <\p>
through the medium of a woman's tenderness. Have I not said enough, <\p>
Zenobia?" <\p>
"I cannot think that this is true," observed Priscilla, who had been <\p>
gazing at me with great, disapproving eyes. "And I am sure I do not <\p>
wish it to be true!" <\p>
"Poor child!" exclaimed Zenobia, rather contemptuously. "She is the <\p>
type of womanhood, such as man has spent centuries in making it. He is <\p>
never content unless he can degrade himself by stooping towards what he <\p>
loves. In denying us our rights, he betrays even more blindness to his <\p>
own interests than profligate disregard of ours!" <\p>
"Is this true?" asked Priscilla with simplicity, turning to <\p>
Hollingsworth. "Is it all true, that Mr. Coverdale and Zenobia have <\p>
been saying?" <\p>
"No, Priscilla!" answered Hollingsworth with his customary bluntness. <\p>
"They have neither of them spoken one true word yet." <\p>
"Do you despise woman?" said Zenobia. <\p>
"Ah, Hollingsworth, that would be most ungrateful!" <\p>
"Despise her? No!" cried Hollingsworth, lifting his great shaggy head <\p>
and shaking it at us, while his eyes glowed almost fiercely. "She is <\p>
the most admirable handiwork of God, in her true place and character. <\p>
Her place is at man's side. Her office, that of the sympathizer; the <\p>
unreserved, unquestioning believer; the recognition, withheld in every <\p>
other manner, but given, in pity, through woman's heart, lest man <\p>
should utterly lose faith in himself; the echo of God's own voice, <\p>
pronouncing, 'It is well done!' All the separate action of woman is, <\p>
and ever has been, and always shall be, false, foolish, vain, <\p>
destructive of her own best and holiest qualities, void of every good <\p>
effect, and productive of intolerable mischiefs! Man is a wretch <\p>
without woman; but woman is a monster--and, thank Heaven, an almost <\p>
impossible and hitherto imaginary monster--without man as her <\p>
acknowledged principal! As true as I had once a mother whom I loved, <\p>
were there any possible prospect of woman's taking the social stand <\p>
which some of them,--poor, miserable, abortive creatures, who only <\p>
dream of such things because they have missed woman's peculiar <\p>
happiness, or because nature made them really neither man nor <\p>
woman!--if there were a chance of their attaining the end which these <\p>
petticoated monstrosities have in view, I would call upon my own sex to <\p>
use its physical force, that unmistakable evidence of sovereignty, to <\p>
scourge them back within their proper bounds! But it will not be <\p>
needful. The heart of time womanhood knows where its own sphere is, <\p>
and never seeks to stray beyond it!" <\p>
Never was mortal blessed--if blessing it were--with a glance of such <\p>
entire acquiescence and unquestioning faith, happy in its completeness, <\p>
as our little Priscilla unconsciously bestowed on Hollingsworth. She <\p>
seemed to take the sentiment from his lips into her heart, and brood <\p>
over it in perfect content. The very woman whom he pictured--the <\p>
gentle parasite, the soft reflection of a more powerful existence--sat <\p>
there at his feet. <\p>
I looked at Zenobia, however, fully expecting her to resent--as I felt, <\p>
by the indignant ebullition of my own blood, that she ought this <\p>
outrageous affirmation of what struck me as the intensity of masculine <\p>
egotism. It centred everything in itself, and deprived woman of her <\p>
very soul, her inexpressible and unfathomable all, to make it a mere <\p>
incident in the great sum of man. Hollingsworth had boldly uttered <\p>
what he, and millions of despots like him, really felt. Without <\p>
intending it, he had disclosed the wellspring of all these troubled <\p>
waters. Now, if ever, it surely behooved Zenobia to be the champion of <\p>
her sex. <\p>
But, to my surprise, and indignation too, she only looked humbled. Some <\p>
tears sparkled in her eyes, but they were wholly of grief, not anger. <\p>
"Well, be it so," was all she said. "I, at least, have deep cause to <\p>
think you right. Let man be but manly and godlike, and woman is only <\p>
too ready to become to him what you say!" <\p>
I smiled--somewhat bitterly, it is true--in contemplation of my own <\p>
ill-luck. How little did these two women care for me, who had freely <\p>
conceded all their claims, and a great deal more, out of the fulness of <\p>
my heart; while Hollingsworth, by some necromancy of his horrible <\p>
injustice, seemed to have brought them both to his feet! <\p>
"Women almost invariably behave thus," thought I. "What does the fact <\p>
mean? Is it their nature? Or is it, at last, the result of ages of <\p>
compelled degradation? And, in either case, will it be possible ever <\p>
to redeem them?" <\p>
An intuition now appeared to possess all the party, that, for this <\p>
time, at least, there was no more to be said. With one accord, we <\p>
arose from the ground, and made our way through the tangled undergrowth <\p>
towards one of those pleasant wood-paths that wound among the <\p>
overarching trees. Some of the branches hung so low as partly to <\p>
conceal the figures that went before from those who followed. Priscilla <\p>
had leaped up more lightly than the rest of us, and ran along in <\p>
advance, with as much airy activity of spirit as was typified in the <\p>
motion of a bird, which chanced to be flitting from tree to tree, in <\p>
the same direction as herself. Never did she seem so happy as that <\p>
afternoon. She skipt, and could not help it, from very playfulness of <\p>
heart. <\p>
Zenobia and Hollingsworth went next, in close contiguity, but not with <\p>
arm in arm. Now, just when they had passed the impending bough of a <\p>
birch-tree, I plainly saw Zenobia take the hand of Hollingsworth in <\p>
both her own, press it to her bosom, and let it fall again! <\p>
The gesture was sudden, and full of passion; the impulse had evidently <\p>
taken her by surprise; it expressed all! Had Zenobia knelt before him, <\p>
or flung herself upon his breast, and gasped out, "I love you, <\p>
Hollingsworth!" I could not have been more certain of what it meant. <\p>
They then walked onward, as before. But, methought, as the declining <\p>
sun threw Zenobia's magnified shadow along the path, I beheld it <\p>
tremulous; and the delicate stem of the flower which she wore in her <\p>
hair was likewise responsive to her agitation. <\p>
Priscilla--through the medium of her eyes, at least could not possibly <\p>
have been aware of the gesture above described. Yet, at that instant, <\p>
I saw her droop. The buoyancy, which just before had been so <\p>
bird-like, was utterly departed; the life seemed to pass out of her, <\p>
and even the substance of her figure to grow thin and gray. I almost <\p>
imagined her a shadow, tiding gradually into the dimness of the wood. <\p>
Her pace became so slow that Hollingsworth and Zenobia passed by, and <\p>
I, without hastening my footsteps, overtook her. <\p>
"Come, Priscilla," said I, looking her intently in the face, which was <\p>
very pale and sorrowful, "we must make haste after our friends. Do you <\p>
feel suddenly ill? A moment ago, you flitted along so lightly that I <\p>
was comparing you to a bird. Now, on the contrary, it is as if you had <\p>
a heavy heart, and a very little strength to bear it with. Pray take my <\p>
arm!" <\p>
"No," said Priscilla, "I do not think it would help me. It is my <\p>
heart, as you say, that makes me heavy; and I know not why. Just now, <\p>
I felt very happy." <\p>
No doubt it was a kind of sacrilege in me to attempt to come within her <\p>
maidenly mystery; but, as she appeared to be tossed aside by her other <\p>
friends, or carelessly let fall, like a flower which they had done <\p>
with, I could not resist the impulse to take just one peep beneath her <\p>
folded petals. <\p>
"Zenobia and yourself are dear friends of late," I remarked. "At <\p>
first,--that first evening when you came to us,--she did not receive <\p>
you quite so warmly as might have been wished." <\p>
"I remember it," said Priscilla. "No wonder she hesitated to love me, <\p>
who was then a stranger to her, and a girl of no grace or beauty,--she <\p>
being herself so beautiful!" <\p>
"But she loves you now, of course?" suggested I. "And at this very <\p>
instant you feel her to be your dearest friend?" <\p>
"Why do you ask me that question?" exclaimed Priscilla, as if <\p>
frightened at the scrutiny into her feelings which I compelled her to <\p>
make. "It somehow puts strange thoughts into my mind. But I do love <\p>
Zenobia dearly! If she only loves me half as well, I shall be happy!" <\p>
"How is it possible to doubt that, Priscilla?" I rejoined. "But <\p>
observe how pleasantly and happily Zenobia and Hollingsworth are <\p>
walking together. I call it a delightful spectacle. It truly rejoices <\p>
me that Hollingsworth has found so fit and affectionate a friend! So <\p>
many people in the world mistrust him,--so many disbelieve and <\p>
ridicule, while hardly any do him justice, or acknowledge him for the <\p>
wonderful man he is,--that it is really a blessed thing for him to have <\p>
won the sympathy of such a woman as Zenobia. Any man might be proud of <\p>
that. Any man, even if he be as great as Hollingsworth, might love so <\p>
magnificent a woman. How very beautiful Zenobia is! And Hollingsworth <\p>
knows it, too." <\p>
There may have been some petty malice in what I said. Generosity is a <\p>
very fine thing, at a proper time and within due limits. But it is an <\p>
insufferable bore to see one man engrossing every thought of all the <\p>
women, and leaving his friend to shiver in outer seclusion, without <\p>
even the alternative of solacing himself with what the more fortunate <\p>
individual has rejected. Yes, it was out of a foolish bitterness of <\p>
heart that I had spoken. <\p>
"Go on before," said Priscilla abruptly, and with true feminine <\p>
imperiousness, which heretofore I had never seen her exercise. "It <\p>
pleases me best to loiter along by myself. I do not walk so fast as <\p>
you." <\p>
With her hand she made a little gesture of dismissal. It provoked me; <\p>
yet, on the whole, was the most bewitching thing that Priscilla had <\p>
ever done. I obeyed her, and strolled moodily homeward, wondering--as <\p>
I had wondered a thousand times already--how Hollingsworth meant to <\p>
dispose of these two hearts, which (plainly to my perception, and, as I <\p>
could not but now suppose, to his) he had engrossed into his own huge <\p>
egotism. <\p>
There was likewise another subject hardly less fruitful of speculation. <\p>
In what attitude did Zenobia present herself to Hollingsworth? Was it <\p>
in that of a free woman, with no mortgage on her affections nor <\p>
claimant to her hand, but fully at liberty to surrender both, in <\p>
exchange for the heart and hand which she apparently expected to <\p>
receive? But was it a vision that I had witnessed in the wood? Was <\p>
Westervelt a goblin? Were those words of passion and agony, which <\p>
Zenobia had uttered in my hearing, a mere stage declamation? Were they <\p>
formed of a material lighter than common air? Or, supposing them to <\p>
bear sterling weight, was it a perilous and dreadful wrong which she <\p>
was meditating towards herself and Hollingsworth? <\p>
Arriving nearly at the farmhouse, I looked back over the long slope of <\p>
pasture land, and beheld them standing together, in the light of <\p>
sunset, just on the spot where, according to the gossip of the <\p>
Community, they meant to build their cottage. Priscilla, alone and <\p>
forgotten, was lingering in the shadow of the wood. <\p>
XV. A CRISIS <\p>
Thus the summer was passing away,--a summer of toil, of interest, of <\p>
something that was not pleasure, but which went deep into my heart, and <\p>
there became a rich experience. I found myself looking forward to <\p>
years, if not to a lifetime, to be spent on the same system. The <\p>
Community were now beginning to form their permanent plans. One of our <\p>
