purposes was to erect a Phalanstery (as I think we called it, after <\p>
Fourier; but the phraseology of those days is not very fresh in my <\p>
remembrance), where the great and general family should have its <\p>
abiding-place. Individual members, too, who made it a point of <\p>
religion to preserve the sanctity of an exclusive home, were selecting <\p>
sites for their cottages, by the wood-side, or on the breezy swells, or <\p>
in the sheltered nook of some little valley, according as their taste <\p>
might lean towards snugness or the picturesque. Altogether, by <\p>
projecting our minds outward, we had imparted a show of novelty to <\p>
existence, and contemplated it as hopefully as if the soil beneath our <\p>
feet had not been fathom-deep with the dust of deluded generations, on <\p>
every one of which, as on ourselves, the world had imposed itself as a <\p>
hitherto unwedded bride. <\p>
Hollingsworth and myself had often discussed these prospects. It was <\p>
easy to perceive, however, that he spoke with little or no fervor, but <\p>
either as questioning the fulfilment of our anticipations, or, at any <\p>
rate, with a quiet consciousness that it was no personal concern of <\p>
his. Shortly after the scene at Eliot's pulpit, while he and I were <\p>
repairing an old stone fence, I amused myself with sallying forward <\p>
into the future time. <\p>
"When we come to be old men," I said, "they will call us uncles, or <\p>
fathers,--Father Hollingsworth and Uncle Coverdale,--and we will look <\p>
back cheerfully to these early days, and make a romantic story for the <\p>
young People (and if a little more romantic than truth may warrant, it <\p>
will be no harm) out of our severe trials and hardships. In a century <\p>
or two, we shall, every one of us, be mythical personages, or <\p>
exceedingly picturesque and poetical ones, at all events. They will <\p>
have a great public hall, in which your portrait, and mine, and twenty <\p>
other faces that are living now, shall be hung up; and as for me, I <\p>
will be painted in my shirtsleeves, and with the sleeves rolled up, to <\p>
show my muscular development. What stories will be rife among them <\p>
about our mighty strength!" continued I, lifting a big stone and <\p>
putting it into its place, "though our posterity will really be far <\p>
stronger than ourselves, after several generations of a simple, <\p>
natural, and active life. What legends of Zenobia's beauty, and <\p>
Priscilla's slender and shadowy grace, and those mysterious qualities <\p>
which make her seem diaphanous with spiritual light! In due course of <\p>
ages, we must all figure heroically in an epic poem; and we will <\p>
ourselves--at least, I will--bend unseen over the future poet, and lend <\p>
him inspiration while he writes it." <\p>
"You seem," said Hollingsworth, "to be trying how much nonsense you can <\p>
pour out in a breath." <\p>
"I wish you would see fit to comprehend," retorted I, "that the <\p>
profoundest wisdom must be mingled with nine tenths of nonsense, else <\p>
it is not worth the breath that utters it. But I do long for the <\p>
cottages to be built, that the creeping plants may begin to run over <\p>
them, and the moss to gather on the walls, and the trees--which we will <\p>
set out--to cover them with a breadth of shadow. This spick-and-span <\p>
novelty does not quite suit my taste. It is time, too, for children to <\p>
be born among us. The first-born child is still to come. And I shall <\p>
never feel as if this were a real, practical, as well as poetical <\p>
system of human life, until somebody has sanctified it by death." <\p>
"A pretty occasion for martyrdom, truly!" said Hollingsworth. <\p>
"As good as any other," I replied. "I wonder, Hollingsworth, who, of <\p>
all these strong men, and fair women and maidens, is doomed the first <\p>
to die. Would it not be well, even before we have absolute need of it, <\p>
to fix upon a spot for a cemetery? Let us choose the rudest, roughest, <\p>
most uncultivable spot, for Death's garden ground; and Death shall <\p>
teach us to beautify it, grave by grave. By our sweet, calm way of <\p>
dying, and the airy elegance out of which we will shape our funeral <\p>
rites, and the cheerful allegories which we will model into tombstones, <\p>
the final scene shall lose its terrors; so that hereafter it may be <\p>
happiness to live, and bliss to die. None of us must die young. Yet, <\p>
should Providence ordain it so, the event shall not be sorrowful, but <\p>
affect us with a tender, delicious, only half-melancholy, and almost <\p>
smiling pathos!" <\p>
"That is to say," muttered Hollingsworth, "you will die like a heathen, <\p>
as you certainly live like one. But, listen to me, Coverdale. Your <\p>
fantastic anticipations make me discern all the more forcibly what a <\p>
wretched, unsubstantial scheme is this, on which we have wasted a <\p>
precious summer of our lives. Do you seriously imagine that any such <\p>
realities as you, and many others here, have dreamed of, will ever be <\p>
brought to pass?" <\p>
"Certainly I do," said I. "Of course, when the reality comes, it will <\p>
wear the every-day, commonplace, dusty, and rather homely garb that <\p>
reality always does put on. But, setting aside the ideal charm, I hold <\p>
that our highest anticipations have a solid footing on common sense." <\p>
"You only half believe what you say," rejoined Hollingsworth; "and as <\p>
for me, I neither have faith in your dream, nor would care the value of <\p>
this pebble for its realization, were that possible. And what more do <\p>
you want of it? It has given you a theme for poetry. Let that content <\p>
you. But now I ask you to be, at last, a man of sobriety and <\p>
earnestness, and aid me in an enterprise which is worth all our <\p>
strength, and the strength of a thousand mightier than we." <\p>
There can be no need of giving in detail the conversation that ensued. <\p>
It is enough to say that Hollingsworth once more brought forward his <\p>
rigid and unconquerable idea,--a scheme for the reformation of the <\p>
wicked by methods moral, intellectual, and industrial, by the sympathy <\p>
of pure, humble, and yet exalted minds, and by opening to his pupils <\p>
the possibility of a worthier life than that which had become their <\p>
fate. It appeared, unless he overestimated his own means, that <\p>
Hollingsworth held it at his choice (and he did so choose) to obtain <\p>
possession of the very ground on which we had planted our Community, <\p>
and which had not yet been made irrevocably ours, by purchase. It was <\p>
just the foundation that he desired. Our beginnings might readily be <\p>
adapted to his great end. The arrangements already completed would <\p>
work quietly into his system. So plausible looked his theory, and, more <\p>
than that, so practical,--such an air of reasonableness had he, by <\p>
patient thought, thrown over it,--each segment of it was contrived to <\p>
dovetail into all the rest with such a complicated applicability, and <\p>
so ready was he with a response for every objection, that, really, so <\p>
far as logic and argument went, he had the matter all his own way. <\p>
"But," said I, "whence can you, having no means of your own, derive the <\p>
enormous capital which is essential to this experiment? State Street, <\p>
I imagine, would not draw its purser strings very liberally in aid of <\p>
such a speculation." <\p>
"I have the funds--as much, at least, as is needed for a <\p>
commencement--at command," he answered. "They can be produced within a <\p>
month, if necessary." <\p>
My thoughts reverted to Zenobia. It could only be her wealth which <\p>
Hollingsworth was appropriating so lavishly. And on what conditions <\p>
was it to be had? Did she fling it into the scheme with the <\p>
uncalculating generosity that characterizes a woman when it is her <\p>
impulse to be generous at all? And did she fling herself along with <\p>
it? But Hollingsworth did not volunteer an explanation. <\p>
"And have you no regrets," I inquired, "in overthrowing this fair <\p>
system of our new life, which has been planned so deeply, and is now <\p>
beginning to flourish so hopefully around us? How beautiful it is, <\p>
and, so far as we can yet see, how practicable! The ages have waited <\p>
for us, and here we are, the very first that have essayed to carry on <\p>
our mortal existence in love and mutual help! Hollingsworth, I would <\p>
be loath to take the ruin of this enterprise upon my conscience." <\p>
"Then let it rest wholly upon mine!" he answered, knitting his black <\p>
brows. "I see through the system. It is full of <\p>
defects,--irremediable and damning ones!--from first to last, there is <\p>
nothing else! I grasp it in my hand, and find no substance whatever. <\p>
There is not human nature in it." <\p>
"Why are you so secret in your operations?" I asked. "God forbid that <\p>
I should accuse you of intentional wrong; but the besetting sin of a <\p>
philanthropist, it appears to me, is apt to be a moral obliquity. His <\p>
sense of honor ceases to be the sense of other honorable men. At some <\p>
point of his course--I know not exactly when or where--he is tempted to <\p>
palter with the right, and can scarcely forbear persuading himself that <\p>
the importance of his public ends renders it allowable to throw aside <\p>
his private conscience. Oh, my dear friend, beware this error! If you <\p>
meditate the overthrow of this establishment, call together our <\p>
companions, state your design, support it with all your eloquence, but <\p>
allow them an opportunity of defending themselves." <\p>
"It does not suit me," said Hollingsworth. "Nor is it my duty to do <\p>
so." <\p>
"I think it is," replied I. <\p>
Hollingsworth frowned; not in passion, but, like fate, inexorably. <\p>
"I will not argue the point," said he. "What I desire to know of you <\p>
is,--and you can tell me in one word,--whether I am to look for your <\p>
cooperation in this great scheme of good? Take it up with me! Be my <\p>
brother in it! It offers you (what you have told me, over and over <\p>
again, that you most need) a purpose in life, worthy of the extremest <\p>
self-devotion,--worthy of martyrdom, should God so order it! In this <\p>
view, I present it to you. You can greatly benefit mankind. Your <\p>
peculiar faculties, as I shall direct them, are capable of being so <\p>
wrought into this enterprise that not one of them need lie idle. Strike <\p>
hands with me, and from this moment you shall never again feel the <\p>
languor and vague wretchedness of an indolent or half-occupied man. <\p>
There may be no more aimless beauty in your life; but, in its stead, <\p>
there shall be strength, courage, immitigable will,--everything that a <\p>
manly and generous nature should desire! We shall succeed! We shall <\p>
have done our best for this miserable world; and happiness (which never <\p>
comes but incidentally) will come to us unawares." <\p>
It seemed his intention to say no more. But, after he had quite broken <\p>
off, his deep eyes filled with tears, and he held out both his hands to <\p>
me. <\p>
"Coverdale," he murmured, "there is not the man in this wide world whom <\p>
I can love as I could you. Do not forsake me!" <\p>
As I look back upon this scene, through the coldness and dimness of so <\p>
many years, there is still a sensation as if Hollingsworth had caught <\p>
hold of my heart, and were pulling it towards him with an almost <\p>
irresistible force. It is a mystery to me how I withstood it. But, in <\p>
truth, I saw in his scheme of philanthropy nothing but what was odious. <\p>
A loathsomeness that was to be forever in my daily work! A great black <\p>
ugliness of sin, which he proposed to collect out of a thousand human <\p>
hearts, and that we should spend our lives in an experiment of <\p>
transmuting it into virtue! Had I but touched his extended hand, <\p>
Hollingsworth's magnetism would perhaps have penetrated me with his own <\p>
conception of all these matters. But I stood aloof. I fortified <\p>
myself with doubts whether his strength of purpose had not been too <\p>
gigantic for his integrity, impelling him to trample on considerations <\p>
that should have been paramount to every other. <\p>
"Is Zenobia to take a part in your enterprise?" I asked. <\p>
"She is," said Hollingsworth. <\p>
"She!--the beautiful!--the gorgeous!" I exclaimed. "And how have you <\p>
prevailed with such a woman to work in this squalid element?" <\p>
"Through no base methods, as you seem to suspect," he answered; "but by <\p>
addressing whatever is best and noblest in her." <\p>
Hollingsworth was looking on the ground. But, as he often did <\p>
so,--generally, indeed, in his habitual moods of thought,--I could not <\p>
judge whether it was from any special unwillingness now to meet my <\p>
eyes. What it was that dictated my next question, I cannot precisely <\p>
say. Nevertheless, it rose so inevitably into my mouth, and, as it <\p>
were, asked itself so involuntarily, that there must needs have been an <\p>
aptness in it. <\p>
"What is to become of Priscilla?" <\p>
Hollingsworth looked at me fiercely, and with glowing eyes. He could <\p>
not have shown any other kind of expression than that, had he meant to <\p>
strike me with a sword. <\p>
"Why do you bring in the names of these women?" said he, after a moment <\p>
of pregnant silence. "What have they to do with the proposal which I <\p>
make you? I must have your answer! Will you devote yourself, and <\p>
sacrifice all to this great end, and be my friend of friends forever?" <\p>
"In Heaven's name, Hollingsworth," cried I, getting angry, and glad to <\p>
be angry, because so only was it possible to oppose his tremendous <\p>
concentrativeness and indomitable will, "cannot you conceive that a man <\p>
may wish well to the world, and struggle for its good, on some other <\p>
plan than precisely that which you have laid down? And will you cast <\p>
off a friend for no unworthiness, but merely because he stands upon his <\p>
right as an individual being, and looks at matters through his own <\p>
optics, instead of yours?" <\p>
"Be with me," said Hollingsworth, "or be against me! There is no third <\p>
choice for you." <\p>
"Take this, then, as my decision," I answered. "I doubt the wisdom of <\p>
your scheme. Furthermore, I greatly fear that the methods by which you <\p>
allow yourself to pursue it are such as cannot stand the scrutiny of an <\p>
unbiassed conscience." <\p>
"And you will not join me?" <\p>
"No!" <\p>
I never said the word--and certainly can never have it to say <\p>
hereafter--that cost me a thousandth part so hard an effort as did that <\p>
one syllable. The heart-pang was not merely figurative, but an <\p>
absolute torture of the breast. I was gazing steadfastly at <\p>
Hollingsworth. It seemed to me that it struck him, too, like a bullet. <\p>
A ghastly paleness--always so terrific on a swarthy face--overspread <\p>
his features. There was a convulsive movement of his throat, as if he <\p>
were forcing down some words that struggled and fought for utterance. <\p>
Whether words of anger, or words of grief, I cannot tell; although many <\p>
and many a time I have vainly tormented myself with conjecturing which <\p>
of the two they were. One other appeal to my friendship,--such as <\p>
once, already, Hollingsworth had made,--taking me in the revulsion that <\p>
followed a strenuous exercise of opposing will, would completely have <\p>
subdued me. But he left the matter there. "Well!" said he. <\p>
And that was all! I should have been thankful for one word more, even <\p>
had it shot me through the heart, as mine did him. But he did not <\p>
speak it; and, after a few moments, with one accord, we set to work <\p>
again, repairing the stone fence. Hollingsworth, I observed, wrought <\p>
like a Titan; and, for my own part, I lifted stones which at this <\p>
day--or, in a calmer mood, at that one--I should no more have thought <\p>
it possible to stir than to carry off the gates of Gaza on my back. <\p>
XVI. LEAVE-TAKINGS <\p>
A few days after the tragic passage-at-arms between Hollingsworth and <\p>
me, I appeared at the dinner-table actually dressed in a coat, instead <\p>
of my customary blouse; with a satin cravat, too, a white vest, and <\p>
several other things that made me seem strange and outlandish to <\p>
myself. As for my companions, this unwonted spectacle caused a great <\p>
stir upon the wooden benches that bordered either side of our homely <\p>
board. <\p>
"What's in the wind now, Miles?" asked one of them. "Are you deserting <\p>
us?" <\p>
"Yes, for a week or two," said I. "It strikes me that my health demands <\p>
a little relaxation of labor, and a short visit to the seaside, during <\p>
the dog-days." <\p>
"You look like it!" grumbled Silas Foster, not greatly pleased with the <\p>
idea of losing an efficient laborer before the stress of the season was <\p>
well over. "Now, here's a pretty fellow! His shoulders have broadened <\p>
a matter of six inches since he came among us; he can do his day's <\p>
work, if he likes, with any man or ox on the farm; and yet he talks <\p>
about going to the seashore for his health! Well, well, old woman," <\p>
added he to his wife, "let me have a plateful of that pork and cabbage! <\p>
I begin to feel in a very weakly way. When the others have had their <\p>
turn, you and I will take a jaunt to Newport or Saratoga!" <\p>
"Well, but, Mr. Foster," said I, "you must allow me to take a little <\p>
breath." <\p>
"Breath!" retorted the old yeoman. "Your lungs have the play of a pair <\p>
of blacksmith's bellows already. What on earth do you want more? But <\p>
go along! I understand the business. We shall never see your face <\p>
here again. Here ends the reformation of the world, so far as Miles <\p>
Coverdale has a hand in it!" <\p>
"By no means," I replied. "I am resolute to die in the last ditch, for <\p>
the good of the cause." <\p>
"Die in a ditch!" muttered gruff Silas, with genuine Yankee intolerance <\p>
of any intermission of toil, except on Sunday, the Fourth of July, the <\p>
autumnal cattle-show, Thanksgiving, or the annual Fast,--"die in a <\p>
ditch! I believe, in my conscience, you would, if there were no <\p>
steadier means than your own labor to keep you out of it!" <\p>
The truth was, that an intolerable discontent and irksomeness had come <\p>
over me. Blithedale was no longer what it had been. Everything was <\p>
suddenly faded. The sunburnt and arid aspect of our woods and <\p>
pastures, beneath the August sky, did but imperfectly symbolize the <\p>
lack of dew and moisture, that, since yesterday, as it were, had <\p>
blighted my fields of thought, and penetrated to the innermost and <\p>
shadiest of my contemplative recesses. The change will be recognized <\p>
by many, who, after a period of happiness, have endeavored to go on <\p>
with the same kind of life, in the same scene, in spite of the <\p>
alteration or withdrawal of some principal circumstance. They discover <\p>
(what heretofore, perhaps, they had not known) that it was this which <\p>
gave the bright color and vivid reality to the whole affair. <\p>
I stood on other terms than before, not only with Hollingsworth, but <\p>
with Zenobia and Priscilla. As regarded the two latter, it was that <\p>
dreamlike and miserable sort of change that denies you the privilege to <\p>
complain, because you can assert no positive injury, nor lay your <\p>
finger on anything tangible. It is a matter which you do not see, but <\p>
feel, and which, when you try to analyze it, seems to lose its very <\p>
existence, and resolve itself into a sickly humor of your own. Your <\p>
understanding, possibly, may put faith in this denial. But your heart <\p>
will not so easily rest satisfied. It incessantly remonstrates, <\p>
though, most of the time, in a bass-note, which you do not separately <\p>
distinguish; but, now and then, with a sharp cry, importunate to be <\p>
heard, and resolute to claim belief. "Things are not as they were!" it <\p>
keeps saying. "You shall not impose on me! I will never be quiet! I <\p>
will throb painfully! I will be heavy, and desolate, and shiver with <\p>
cold! For I, your deep heart, know when to be miserable, as once I <\p>
knew when to be happy! All is changed for us! You are beloved no <\p>
more!" And were my life to be spent over again, I would invariably <\p>
lend my ear to this Cassandra of the inward depths, however clamorous <\p>
the music and the merriment of a more superficial region. <\p>
My outbreak with Hollingsworth, though never definitely known to our <\p>
associates, had really an effect upon the moral atmosphere of the <\p>
Community. It was incidental to the closeness of relationship into <\p>
which we had brought ourselves, that an unfriendly state of feeling <\p>
could not occur between any two members without the whole society being <\p>
more or less commoted and made uncomfortable thereby. This species of <\p>
nervous sympathy (though a pretty characteristic enough, sentimentally <\p>
considered, and apparently betokening an actual bond of love among us) <\p>
was yet found rather inconvenient in its practical operation, mortal <\p>
tempers being so infirm and variable as they are. If one of us happened <\p>
to give his neighbor a box on the ear, the tingle was immediately felt <\p>
on the same side of everybody's head. Thus, even on the supposition <\p>
that we were far less quarrelsome than the rest of the world, a great <\p>
deal of time was necessarily wasted in rubbing our ears. <\p>
Musing on all these matters, I felt an inexpressible longing for at <\p>
least a temporary novelty. I thought of going across the Rocky <\p>
Mountains, or to Europe, or up the Nile; of offering myself a volunteer <\p>
on the Exploring Expedition; of taking a ramble of years, no matter in <\p>
what direction, and coming back on the other side of the world. Then, <\p>
should the colonists of Blithedale have established their enterprise on <\p>
a permanent basis, I might fling aside my pilgrim staff and dusty <\p>
shoon, and rest as peacefully here as elsewhere. Or, in case <\p>
Hollingsworth should occupy the ground with his School of Reform, as he <\p>
now purposed, I might plead earthly guilt enough, by that time, to give <\p>
me what I was inclined to think the only trustworthy hold on his <\p>
affections. Meanwhile, before deciding on any ultimate plan, I <\p>
determined to remove myself to a little distance, and take an exterior <\p>
view of what we had all been about. <\p>
In truth, it was dizzy work, amid such fermentation of opinions as was <\p>
going on in the general brain of the Community. It was a kind of <\p>
Bedlam, for the time being, although out of the very thoughts that were <\p>
wildest and most destructive might grow a wisdom, holy, calm, and pure, <\p>
and that should incarnate itself with the substance of a noble and <\p>
happy life. But, as matters now were, I felt myself (and, having a <\p>
decided tendency towards the actual, I never liked to feel it) getting <\p>
quite out of my reckoning, with regard to the existing state of the <\p>
world. I was beginning to lose the sense of what kind of a world it <\p>
was, among innumerable schemes of what it might or ought to be. It was <\p>
impossible, situated as we were, not to imbibe the idea that everything <\p>
in nature and human existence was fluid, or fast becoming so; that the <\p>
crust of the earth in many places was broken, and its whole surface <\p>
portentously upheaving; that it was a day of crisis, and that we <\p>
ourselves were in the critical vortex. Our great globe floated in the <\p>
atmosphere of infinite space like an unsubstantial bubble. No <\p>
sagacious man will long retain his sagacity, if he live exclusively <\p>
among reformers and progressive people, without periodically returning <\p>
into the settled system of things, to correct himself by a new <\p>
observation from that old standpoint. <\p>
It was now time for me, therefore, to go and hold a little talk with <\p>
the conservatives, the writers of "The North American Review," the <\p>
merchants, the politicians, the Cambridge men, and all those <\p>
respectable old blockheads who still, in this intangibility and <\p>
mistiness of affairs, kept a death-grip on one or two ideas which had <\p>
not come into vogue since yesterday morning. <\p>
The brethren took leave of me with cordial kindness; and as for the <\p>
sisterhood, I had serious thoughts of kissing them all round, but <\p>
forbore to do so, because, in all such general salutations, the penance <\p>
is fully equal to the pleasure. So I kissed none of them; and nobody, <\p>
to say the truth, seemed to expect it. <\p>
"Do you wish me," I said to Zenobia, "to announce in town, and at the <\p>
watering-places, your purpose to deliver a course of lectures on the <\p>
rights of women?" <\p>
"Women possess no rights," said Zenobia, with a half-melancholy smile; <\p>
"or, at all events, only little girls and grandmothers would have the <\p>
force to exercise them." <\p>
She gave me her hand freely and kindly, and looked at me, I thought, <\p>
with a pitying expression in her eyes; nor was there any settled light <\p>
of joy in them on her own behalf, but a troubled and passionate flame, <\p>
flickering and fitful. <\p>
"I regret, on the whole, that you are leaving us," she said; "and all <\p>
the more, since I feel that this phase of our life is finished, and can <\p>
never be lived over again. Do you know, Mr. Coverdale, that I have <\p>
been several times on the point of making you my confidant, for lack of <\p>
a better and wiser one? But you are too young to be my father <\p>
confessor; and you would not thank me for treating you like one of <\p>
those good little handmaidens who share the bosom secrets of a <\p>
tragedy-queen." <\p>
"I would, at least, be loyal and faithful," answered I; "and would <\p>
counsel you with an honest purpose, if not wisely." <\p>
"Yes," said Zenobia, "you would be only too wise, too honest. Honesty <\p>
and wisdom are such a delightful pastime, at another person's expense!" <\p>
"Ah, Zenobia," I exclaimed, "if you would but let me speak!" <\p>
"By no means," she replied, "especially when you have just resumed the <\p>
whole series of social conventionalisms, together with that <\p>
strait-bodied coat. I would as lief open my heart to a lawyer or a <\p>
clergyman! No, no, Mr. Coverdale; if I choose a counsellor, in the <\p>
present aspect of my affairs, it must be either an angel or a madman; <\p>
and I rather apprehend that the latter would be likeliest of the two to <\p>
speak the fitting word. It needs a wild steersman when we voyage <\p>
through chaos! The anchor is up,--farewell!" <\p>
Priscilla, as soon as dinner was over, had betaken herself into a <\p>
corner, and set to work on a little purse. As I approached her, she <\p>
let her eyes rest on me with a calm, serious look; for, with all her <\p>
delicacy of nerves, there was a singular self-possession in Priscilla, <\p>
and her sensibilities seemed to lie sheltered from ordinary commotion, <\p>
like the water in a deep well. <\p>
"Will you give me that purse, Priscilla," said I, "as a parting <\p>
keepsake?" <\p>
"Yes," she answered, "if you will wait till it is finished." <\p>
"I must not wait, even for that," I replied. "Shall I find you here, <\p>
on my return?" <\p>
"I never wish to go away," said she. <\p>
"I have sometimes thought," observed I, smiling, "that you, Priscilla, <\p>
are a little prophetess, or, at least, that you have spiritual <\p>
intimations respecting matters which are dark to us grosser people. If <\p>
that be the case, I should like to ask you what is about to happen; for <\p>
I am tormented with a strong foreboding that, were I to return even so <\p>
soon as to-morrow morning, I should find everything changed. Have you <\p>
any impressions of this nature?" <\p>
"Ah, no," said Priscilla, looking at me apprehensively. "If any such <\p>
misfortune is coming, the shadow has not reached me yet. Heaven <\p>
forbid! I should be glad if there might never be any change, but one <\p>
summer follow another, and all just like this." <\p>
"No summer ever came back, and no two summers ever were alike," said I, <\p>
with a degree of Orphic wisdom that astonished myself. "Times change, <\p>
and people change; and if our hearts do not change as readily, so much <\p>
the worse for us. Good-by, Priscilla!" <\p>
I gave her hand a pressure, which, I think, she neither resisted nor <\p>
returned. Priscilla's heart was deep, but of small compass; it had <\p>
room but for a very few dearest ones, among whom she never reckoned me. <\p>
On the doorstep I met Hollingsworth. I had a momentary impulse to hold <\p>
out my hand, or at least to give a parting nod, but resisted both. <\p>
When a real and strong affection has come to an end, it is not well to <\p>
mock the sacred past with any show of those commonplace civilities that <\p>
belong to ordinary intercourse. Being dead henceforth to him, and he <\p>
to me, there could be no propriety in our chilling one another with the <\p>
touch of two corpse-like hands, or playing at looks of courtesy with <\p>
eyes that were impenetrable beneath the glaze and the film. We passed, <\p>
therefore, as if mutually invisible. <\p>
I can nowise explain what sort of whim, prank, or perversity it was, <\p>
that, after all these leave-takings, induced me to go to the pigsty, <\p>
and take leave of the swine! There they lay, buried as deeply among <\p>
the straw as they could burrow, four huge black grunters, the very <\p>
symbols of slothful ease and sensual comfort. They were asleep, <\p>
drawing short and heavy breaths, which heaved their big sides up and <\p>
down. Unclosing their eyes, however, at my approach, they looked dimly <\p>
forth at the outer world, and simultaneously uttered a gentle grunt; <\p>
not putting themselves to the trouble of an additional breath for that <\p>
particular purpose, but grunting with their ordinary inhalation. They <\p>
were involved, and almost stifled and buried alive, in their own <\p>
corporeal substance. The very unreadiness and oppression wherewith <\p>
these greasy citizens gained breath enough to keep their life-machinery <\p>
in sluggish movement appeared to make them only the more sensible of <\p>
the ponderous and fat satisfaction of their existence. Peeping at me <\p>
an instant out of their small, red, hardly perceptible eyes, they dropt <\p>
asleep again; yet not so far asleep but that their unctuous bliss was <\p>
still present to them, betwixt dream and reality. <\p>
"You must come back in season to eat part of a spare-rib," said Silas <\p>
Foster, giving my hand a mighty squeeze. "I shall have these fat <\p>
fellows hanging up by the heels, heads downward, pretty soon, I tell <\p>
you!" <\p>
"O cruel Silas, what a horrible idea!" cried I. "All the rest of us, <\p>
men, women, and livestock, save only these four porkers, are bedevilled <\p>
with one grief or another; they alone are happy,--and you mean to cut <\p>
their throats and eat them! It would be more for the general comfort <\p>
to let them eat us; and bitter and sour morsels we should be!" <\p>
XVII. THE HOTEL <\p>
Arriving in town (where my bachelor-rooms, long before this time, had <\p>
received some other occupant), I established myself, for a day or two, <\p>
in a certain, respectable hotel. It was situated somewhat aloof from <\p>
my former track in life; my present mood inclining me to avoid most of <\p>
my old companions, from whom I was now sundered by other interests, and <\p>
who would have been likely enough to amuse themselves at the expense of <\p>
the amateur workingman. The hotel-keeper put me into a back room of <\p>
the third story of his spacious establishment. The day was lowering, <\p>
with occasional gusts of rain, and an ugly tempered east wind, which <\p>
seemed to come right off the chill and melancholy sea, hardly mitigated <\p>
by sweeping over the roofs, and amalgamating itself with the dusky <\p>
element of city smoke. All the effeminacy of past days had returned <\p>
upon me at once. Summer as it still was, I ordered a coal fire in the <\p>
rusty grate, and was glad to find myself growing a little too warm with <\p>
an artificial temperature. <\p>
My sensations were those of a traveller, long sojourning in remote <\p>
regions, and at length sitting down again amid customs once familiar. <\p>
There was a newness and an oldness oddly combining themselves into one <\p>
impression. It made me acutely sensible how strange a piece of <\p>
mosaic-work had lately been wrought into my life. True, if you look at <\p>
it in one way, it had been only a summer in the country. But, <\p>
considered in a profounder relation, it was part of another age, a <\p>
different state of society, a segment of an existence peculiar in its <\p>
aims and methods, a leaf of some mysterious volume interpolated into <\p>
the current history which time was writing off. At one moment, the <\p>
very circumstances now surrounding me--my coal fire and the dingy room <\p>
in the bustling hotel--appeared far off and intangible; the next <\p>
instant Blithedale looked vague, as if it were at a distance both in <\p>
time and space, and so shadowy that a question might be raised whether <\p>
the whole affair had been anything more than the thoughts of a <\p>
speculative man. I had never before experienced a mood that so robbed <\p>
the actual world of its solidity. It nevertheless involved a charm, on <\p>
which--a devoted epicure of my own emotions--I resolved to pause, and <\p>
enjoy the moral sillabub until quite dissolved away. <\p>
Whatever had been my taste for solitude and natural scenery, yet the <\p>
thick, foggy, stifled element of cities, the entangled life of many men <\p>
together, sordid as it was, and empty of the beautiful, took quite as <\p>
strenuous a hold upon my mind. I felt as if there could never be <\p>
enough of it. Each characteristic sound was too suggestive to be <\p>
passed over unnoticed. Beneath and around me, I heard the stir of the <\p>
hotel; the loud voices of guests, landlord, or bar-keeper; steps <\p>
echoing on the staircase; the ringing of a bell, announcing arrivals or <\p>
departures; the porter lumbering past my door with baggage, which he <\p>
thumped down upon the floors of neighboring chambers; the lighter feet <\p>
of chambermaids scudding along the passages;--it is ridiculous to think <\p>
what an interest they had for me! From the street came the tumult of <\p>
the pavements, pervading the whole house with a continual uproar, so <\p>
broad and deep that only an unaccustomed ear would dwell upon it. A <\p>
company of the city soldiery, with a full military band, marched in <\p>
front of the hotel, invisible to me, but stirringly audible both by its <\p>
foot-tramp and the clangor of its instruments. Once or twice all the <\p>
city bells jangled together, announcing a fire, which brought out the <\p>
engine-men and their machines, like an army with its artillery rushing <\p>
to battle. Hour by hour the clocks in many steeples responded one to <\p>
another. <\p>
In some public hall, not a great way off, there seemed to be an <\p>
exhibition of a mechanical diorama; for three times during the day <\p>
occurred a repetition of obstreperous music, winding up with the rattle <\p>
of imitative cannon and musketry, and a huge final explosion. Then <\p>
ensued the applause of the spectators, with clap of hands and thump of <\p>
sticks, and the energetic pounding of their heels. All this was just <\p>
as valuable, in its way, as the sighing of the breeze among the <\p>
birch-trees that overshadowed Eliot's pulpit. <\p>
Yet I felt a hesitation about plunging into this muddy tide of human <\p>
activity and pastime. It suited me better, for the present, to linger <\p>
on the brink, or hover in the air above it. So I spent the first day, <\p>
and the greater part of the second, in the laziest manner possible, in <\p>
a rocking-chair, inhaling the fragrance of a series of cigars, with my <\p>
legs and slippered feet horizontally disposed, and in my hand a novel <\p>
purchased of a railroad bibliopolist. The gradual waste of my cigar <\p>
accomplished itself with an easy and gentle expenditure of breath. My <\p>
book was of the dullest, yet had a sort of sluggish flow, like that of <\p>
a stream in which your boat is as often aground as afloat. Had there <\p>
been a more impetuous rush, a more absorbing passion of the narrative, <\p>
I should the sooner have struggled out of its uneasy current, and have <\p>
given myself up to the swell and subsidence of my thoughts. But, as it <\p>
was, the torpid life of the book served as an unobtrusive accompaniment <\p>
to the life within me and about me. At intervals, however, when its <\p>
effect grew a little too soporific,--not for my patience, but for the <\p>
possibility of keeping my eyes open, I bestirred myself, started from <\p>
the rocking-chair, and looked out of the window. <\p>
A gray sky; the weathercock of a steeple that rose beyond the opposite <\p>
range of buildings, pointing from the eastward; a sprinkle of small, <\p>
spiteful-looking raindrops on the window-pane. In that ebb-tide of my <\p>
energies, had I thought of venturing abroad, these tokens would have <\p>
checked the abortive purpose. <\p>
After several such visits to the window, I found myself getting pretty <\p>
well acquainted with that little portion of the backside of the <\p>
universe which it presented to my view. Over against the hotel and its <\p>
adjacent houses, at the distance of forty or fifty yards, was the rear <\p>
of a range of buildings which appeared to be spacious, modern, and <\p>
calculated for fashionable residences. The interval between was <\p>
apportioned into grass-plots, and here and there an apology for a <\p>
garden, pertaining severally to these dwellings. There were <\p>
apple-trees, and pear and peach trees, too, the fruit on which looked <\p>
singularly large, luxuriant, and abundant, as well it might, in a <\p>
situation so warm and sheltered, and where the soil had doubtless been <\p>
enriched to a more than natural fertility. In two or three places <\p>
grapevines clambered upon trellises, and bore clusters already purple, <\p>
and promising the richness of Malta or Madeira in their ripened juice. <\p>
The blighting winds of our rigid climate could not molest these trees <\p>
and vines; the sunshine, though descending late into this area, and too <\p>
early intercepted by the height of the surrounding houses, yet lay <\p>
tropically there, even when less than temperate in every other region. <\p>
Dreary as was the day, the scene was illuminated by not a few sparrows <\p>
and other birds, which spread their wings, and flitted and fluttered, <\p>
and alighted now here, now there, and busily scratched their food out <\p>
of the wormy earth. Most of these winged people seemed to have their <\p>
domicile in a robust and healthy buttonwood-tree. It aspired upward, <\p>
high above the roofs of the houses, and spread a dense head of foliage <\p>
half across the area. <\p>
There was a cat--as there invariably is in such places--who evidently <\p>
thought herself entitled to the privileges of forest life in this close <\p>
heart of city conventionalisms. I watched her creeping along the low, <\p>
flat roofs of the offices, descending a flight of wooden steps, gliding <\p>
among the grass, and besieging the buttonwood-tree, with murderous <\p>
purpose against its feathered citizens. But, after all, they were <\p>
birds of city breeding, and doubtless knew how to guard themselves <\p>
against the peculiar perils of their position. <\p>
Bewitching to my fancy are all those nooks and crannies where Nature, <\p>
like a stray partridge, hides her head among the long-established <\p>
haunts of men! It is likewise to be remarked, as a general rule, that <\p>
there is far more of the picturesque, more truth to native and <\p>
characteristic tendencies, and vastly greater suggestiveness in the <\p>
back view of a residence, whether in town or country, than in its <\p>
front. The latter is always artificial; it is meant for the world's <\p>
eye, and is therefore a veil and a concealment. Realities keep in the <\p>
rear, and put forward an advance guard of show and humbug. The <\p>
posterior aspect of any old farmhouse, behind which a railroad has <\p>
unexpectedly been opened, is so different from that looking upon the <\p>
immemorial highway, that the spectator gets new ideas of rural life and <\p>
individuality in the puff or two of steam-breath which shoots him past <\p>
the premises. In a city, the distinction between what is offered to <\p>
the public and what is kept for the family is certainly not less <\p>
striking. <\p>
But, to return to my window at the back of the hotel. Together with a <\p>
due contemplation of the fruit-trees, the grapevines, the <\p>
buttonwood-tree, the cat, the birds, and many other particulars, I <\p>
failed not to study the row of fashionable dwellings to which all these <\p>
appertained. Here, it must be confessed, there was a general sameness. <\p>
From the upper story to the first floor, they were so much alike, that <\p>
I could only conceive of the inhabitants as cut out on one identical <\p>
pattern, like little wooden toy-people of German manufacture. One <\p>
long, united roof, with its thousands of slates glittering in the rain, <\p>
extended over the whole. After the distinctness of separate characters <\p>
to which I had recently been accustomed, it perplexed and annoyed me <\p>
not to be able to resolve this combination of human interests into <\p>
well-defined elements. It seemed hardly worth while for more than one <\p>
of those families to be in existence, since they all had the same <\p>
glimpse of the sky, all looked into the same area, all received just <\p>
their equal share of sunshine through the front windows, and all <\p>
listened to precisely the same noises of the street on which they <\p>
boarded. Men are so much alike in their nature, that they grow <\p>
intolerable unless varied by their circumstances. <\p>
Just about this time a waiter entered my room. The truth was, I had <\p>
rung the bell and ordered a sherry-cobbler. <\p>
"Can you tell me," I inquired, "what families reside in any of those <\p>
houses opposite?" <\p>
"The one right opposite is a rather stylish boarding-house," said the <\p>
waiter. "Two of the gentlemen boarders keep horses at the stable of <\p>
our establishment. They do things in very good style, sir, the people <\p>
that live there." <\p>
I might have found out nearly as much for myself, on examining the <\p>
house a little more closely, in one of the upper chambers I saw a young <\p>
man in a dressing-gown, standing before the glass and brushing his hair <\p>
for a quarter of an hour together. He then spent an equal space of <\p>
time in the elaborate arrangement of his cravat, and finally made his <\p>
appearance in a dress-coat, which I suspected to be newly come from the <\p>
tailor's, and now first put on for a dinner-party. At a window of the <\p>
next story below, two children, prettily dressed, were looking out. By <\p>
and by a middle-aged gentleman came softly behind them, kissed the <\p>
little girl, and playfully pulled the little boy's ear. It was a papa, <\p>
no doubt, just come in from his counting-room or office; and anon <\p>
appeared mamma, stealing as softly behind papa as he had stolen behind <\p>
the children, and laying her hand on his shoulder to surprise him. <\p>
Then followed a kiss between papa and mamma; but a noiseless one, for <\p>
the children did not turn their heads. <\p>
"I bless God for these good folks!" thought I to myself. "I have not <\p>
seen a prettier bit of nature, in all my summer in the country, than <\p>
they have shown me here, in a rather stylish boarding-house. I will <\p>
pay them a little more attention by and by." <\p>
On the first floor, an iron balustrade ran along in front of the tall <\p>
and spacious windows, evidently belonging to a back drawing-room; and <\p>
far into the interior, through the arch of the sliding-doors, I could <\p>
discern a gleam from the windows of the front apartment. There were no <\p>
signs of present occupancy in this suite of rooms; the curtains being <\p>
enveloped in a protective covering, which allowed but a small portion <\p>
of their crimson material to be seen. But two housemaids were <\p>
industriously at work; so that there was good prospect that the <\p>
boarding-house might not long suffer from the absence of its most <\p>
expensive and profitable guests. Meanwhile, until they should appear, <\p>
I cast my eyes downward to the lower regions. There, in the dusk that <\p>
so early settles into such places, I saw the red glow of the kitchen <\p>
range. The hot cook, or one of her subordinates, with a ladle in her <\p>
hand, came to draw a cool breath at the back door. As soon as she <\p>
disappeared, an Irish man-servant, in a white jacket, crept slyly <\p>
forth, and threw away the fragments of a china dish, which, <\p>
unquestionably, he had just broken. Soon afterwards, a lady, showily <\p>
dressed, with a curling front of what must have been false hair, and <\p>
reddish-brown, I suppose, in hue,--though my remoteness allowed me only <\p>
to guess at such particulars,--this respectable mistress of the <\p>
boarding-house made a momentary transit across the kitchen window, and <\p>
appeared no more. It was her final, comprehensive glance, in order to <\p>
make sure that soup, fish, and flesh were in a proper state of <\p>
readiness, before the serving up of dinner. <\p>
There was nothing else worth noticing about the house, unless it be <\p>
that on the peak of one of the dormer windows which opened out of the <\p>
roof sat a dove, looking very dreary and forlorn; insomuch that I <\p>
wondered why she chose to sit there, in the chilly rain, while her <\p>
kindred were doubtless nestling in a warm and comfortable dove-cote. <\p>
All at once this dove spread her wings, and, launching herself in the <\p>
air, came flying so straight across the intervening space, that I fully <\p>
expected her to alight directly on my window-sill. In the latter part <\p>
of her course, however, she swerved aside, flew upward, and vanished, <\p>
as did, likewise, the slight, fantastic pathos with which I had <\p>
invested her. <\p>
XVIII. THE BOARDING-HOUSE <\p>
The next day, as soon as I thought of looking again towards the <\p>
opposite house, there sat the dove again, on the peak of the same <\p>
dormer window! It was by no means an early hour, for the preceding <\p>
evening I had ultimately mustered enterprise enough to visit the <\p>
theatre, had gone late to bed, and slept beyond all limit, in my <\p>
remoteness from Silas Foster's awakening horn. Dreams had tormented me <\p>
throughout the night. The train of thoughts which, for months past, <\p>
had worn a track through my mind, and to escape which was one of my <\p>
chief objects in leaving Blithedale, kept treading remorselessly to and <\p>
fro in their old footsteps, while slumber left me impotent to regulate <\p>
them. It was not till I had quitted my three friends that they first <\p>
began to encroach upon my dreams. In those of the last night, <\p>
Hollingsworth and Zenobia, standing on either side of my bed, had bent <\p>
across it to exchange a kiss of passion. Priscilla, beholding <\p>
this,--for she seemed to be peeping in at the chamber window,--had <\p>
melted gradually away, and left only the sadness of her expression in <\p>
my heart. There it still lingered, after I awoke; one of those <\p>
unreasonable sadnesses that you know not how to deal with, because it <\p>
involves nothing for common-sense to clutch. <\p>
It was a gray and dripping forenoon; gloomy enough in town, and still <\p>
gloomier in the haunts to which my recollections persisted in <\p>
transporting me. For, in spite of my efforts to think of something <\p>
else, I thought how the gusty rain was drifting over the slopes and <\p>
valleys of our farm; how wet must be the foliage that overshadowed the <\p>
pulpit rock; how cheerless, in such a day, my hermitage--the <\p>
tree-solitude of my owl-like humors--in the vine-encircled heart of the <\p>
tall pine! It was a phase of homesickness. I had wrenched myself too <\p>
suddenly out of an accustomed sphere. There was no choice, now, but to <\p>
bear the pang of whatever heartstrings were snapt asunder, and that <\p>
illusive torment (like the ache of a limb long ago cut off) by which a <\p>
past mode of life prolongs itself into the succeeding one. I was full <\p>
of idle and shapeless regrets. The thought impressed itself upon me <\p>
that I had left duties unperformed. With the power, perhaps, to act in <\p>
the place of destiny and avert misfortune from my friends, I had <\p>
resigned them to their fate. That cold tendency, between instinct and <\p>
intellect, which made me pry with a speculative interest into people's <\p>
passions and impulses, appeared to have gone far towards unhumanizing <\p>
my heart. <\p>
But a man cannot always decide for himself whether his own heart is <\p>
cold or warm. It now impresses me that, if I erred at all in regard to <\p>
Hollingsworth, Zenobia, and Priscilla, it was through too much <\p>
sympathy, rather than too little. <\p>
To escape the irksomeness of these meditations, I resumed my post at <\p>
the window. At first sight, there was nothing new to be noticed. The <\p>
general aspect of affairs was the same as yesterday, except that the <\p>
more decided inclemency of to-day had driven the sparrows to shelter, <\p>
and kept the cat within doors; whence, however, she soon emerged, <\p>
pursued by the cook, and with what looked like the better half of a <\p>
roast chicken in her mouth. The young man in the dress-coat was <\p>
invisible; the two children, in the story below, seemed to be romping <\p>
about the room, under the superintendence of a nursery-maid. The <\p>
damask curtains of the drawing-room, on the first floor, were now fully <\p>
displayed, festooned gracefully from top to bottom of the windows, <\p>
which extended from the ceiling to the carpet. A narrower window, at <\p>
the left of the drawing-room, gave light to what was probably a small <\p>
boudoir, within which I caught the faintest imaginable glimpse of a <\p>
girl's figure, in airy drapery. Her arm was in regular movement, as if <\p>
she were busy with her German worsted, or some other such pretty and <\p>
unprofitable handiwork. <\p>
While intent upon making out this girlish shape, I became sensible that <\p>
a figure had appeared at one of the windows of the drawing-room. There <\p>
was a presentiment in my mind; or perhaps my first glance, imperfect <\p>
and sidelong as it was, had sufficed to convey subtile information of <\p>
the truth. At any rate, it was with no positive surprise, but as if I <\p>
had all along expected the incident, that, directing my eyes <\p>
thitherward, I beheld--like a full-length picture, in the space between <\p>
the heavy festoons of the window curtains--no other than Zenobia! At <\p>
the same instant, my thoughts made sure of the identity of the figure <\p>
in the boudoir. It could only be Priscilla. <\p>
Zenobia was attired, not in the almost rustic costume which she had <\p>
heretofore worn, but in a fashionable morning-dress. There was, <\p>
nevertheless, one familiar point. She had, as usual, a flower in her <\p>
hair, brilliant and of a rare variety, else it had not been Zenobia. <\p>
After a brief pause at the window, she turned away, exemplifying, in <\p>
the few steps that removed her out of sight, that noble and beautiful <\p>
motion which characterized her as much as any other personal charm. Not <\p>
one woman in a thousand could move so admirably as Zenobia. Many women <\p>
can sit gracefully; some can stand gracefully; and a few, perhaps, can <\p>
assume a series of graceful positions. But natural movement is the <\p>
result and expression of the whole being, and cannot be well and nobly <\p>
performed unless responsive to something in the character. I often <\p>
used to think that music--light and airy, wild and passionate, or the <\p>
full harmony of stately marches, in accordance with her varying <\p>
mood--should have attended Zenobia's footsteps. <\p>
I waited for her reappearance. It was one peculiarity, distinguishing <\p>
Zenobia from most of her sex, that she needed for her moral well-being, <\p>
and never would forego, a large amount of physical exercise. At <\p>
Blithedale, no inclemency of sky or muddiness of earth had ever impeded <\p>
her daily walks. Here in town, she probably preferred to tread the <\p>
extent of the two drawing-rooms, and measure out the miles by spaces of <\p>
forty feet, rather than bedraggle her skirts over the sloppy pavements. <\p>
Accordingly, in about the time requisite to pass through the arch of <\p>
the sliding-doors to the front window, and to return upon her steps, <\p>
there she stood again, between the festoons of the crimson curtains. <\p>
But another personage was now added to the scene. Behind Zenobia <\p>
appeared that face which I had first encountered in the wood-path; the <\p>
man who had passed, side by side with her, in such mysterious <\p>
familiarity and estrangement, beneath my vine curtained hermitage in <\p>
the tall pine-tree. It was Westervelt. And though he was looking <\p>
closely over her shoulder, it still seemed to me, as on the former <\p>
occasion, that Zenobia repelled him,--that, perchance, they mutually <\p>
repelled each other, by some incompatibility of their spheres. <\p>
This impression, however, might have been altogether the result of <\p>
fancy and prejudice in me. The distance was so great as to obliterate <\p>
any play of feature by which I might otherwise have been made a <\p>
partaker of their counsels. <\p>
There now needed only Hollingsworth and old Moodie to complete the knot <\p>
of characters, whom a real intricacy of events, greatly assisted by my <\p>
method of insulating them from other relations, had kept so long upon <\p>
my mental stage, as actors in a drama. In itself, perhaps, it was no <\p>
very remarkable event that they should thus come across me, at the <\p>
moment when I imagined myself free. Zenobia, as I well knew, had <\p>
retained an establishment in town, and had not unfrequently withdrawn <\p>
herself from Blithedale during brief intervals, on one of which <\p>
occasions she had taken Priscilla along with her. Nevertheless, there <\p>
seemed something fatal in the coincidence that had borne me to this one <\p>
spot, of all others in a great city, and transfixed me there, and <\p>
compelled me again to waste my already wearied sympathies on affairs <\p>
which were none of mine, and persons who cared little for me. It <\p>
irritated my nerves; it affected me with a kind of heart-sickness. <\p>
After the effort which it cost me to fling them off,--after <\p>
consummating my escape, as I thought, from these goblins of flesh and <\p>
blood, and pausing to revive myself with a breath or two of an <\p>
atmosphere in which they should have no share,--it was a positive <\p>
despair to find the same figures arraying themselves before me, and <\p>
presenting their old problem in a shape that made it more insoluble <\p>
than ever. <\p>
I began to long for a catastrophe. If the noble temper of <\p>
Hollingsworth's soul were doomed to be utterly corrupted by the too <\p>
powerful purpose which had grown out of what was noblest in him; if the <\p>
rich and generous qualities of Zenobia's womanhood might not save her; <\p>
if Priscilla must perish by her tenderness and faith, so simple and so <\p>
devout, then be it so! Let it all come! As for me, I would look on, <\p>
as it seemed my part to do, understandingly, if my intellect could <\p>
fathom the meaning and the moral, and, at all events, reverently and <\p>
sadly. The curtain fallen, I would pass onward with my poor individual <\p>
life, which was now attenuated of much of its proper substance, and <\p>
diffused among many alien interests. <\p>
Meanwhile, Zenobia and her companion had retreated from the window. <\p>
Then followed an interval, during which I directed my eves towards the <\p>
figure in the boudoir. Most certainly it was Priscilla, although <\p>
dressed with a novel and fanciful elegance. The vague perception of <\p>
it, as viewed so far off, impressed me as if she had suddenly passed <\p>
out of a chrysalis state and put forth wings. Her hands were not now <\p>
in motion. She had dropt her work, and sat with her head thrown back, <\p>
in the same attitude that I had seen several times before, when she <\p>
seemed to be listening to an imperfectly distinguished sound. <\p>
Again the two figures in the drawing-room became visible. They were <\p>
now a little withdrawn from the window, face to face, and, as I could <\p>
see by Zenobia's emphatic gestures, were discussing some subject in <\p>
which she, at least, felt a passionate concern. By and by she broke <\p>
away, and vanished beyond my ken. Westervelt approached the window, <\p>
and leaned his forehead against a pane of glass, displaying the sort of <\p>
smile on his handsome features which, when I before met him, had let me <\p>
into the secret of his gold-bordered teeth. Every human being, when <\p>
given over to the Devil, is sure to have the wizard mark upon him, in <\p>
one form or another. I fancied that this smile, with its peculiar <\p>
revelation, was the Devil's signet on the Professor. <\p>
This man, as I had soon reason to know, was endowed with a cat-like <\p>
circumspection; and though precisely the most unspiritual quality in <\p>
the world, it was almost as effective as spiritual insight in making <\p>
him acquainted with whatever it suited him to discover. He now proved <\p>
it, considerably to my discomfiture, by detecting and recognizing me, <\p>
at my post of observation. Perhaps I ought to have blushed at being <\p>
caught in such an evident scrutiny of Professor Westervelt and his <\p>
affairs. Perhaps I did blush. Be that as it might, I retained <\p>
presence of mind enough not to make my position yet more irksome by the <\p>
poltroonery of drawing back. <\p>
Westervelt looked into the depths of the drawing-room, and beckoned. <\p>
Immediately afterwards Zenobia appeared at the window, with color much <\p>
heightened, and eyes which, as my conscience whispered me, were <\p>
shooting bright arrows, barbed with scorn, across the intervening <\p>
space, directed full at my sensibilities as a gentleman. If the truth <\p>
must be told, far as her flight-shot was, those arrows hit the mark. <\p>
She signified her recognition of me by a gesture with her head and <\p>
hand, comprising at once a salutation and dismissal. The next moment <\p>
she administered one of those pitiless rebukes which a woman always has <\p>
at hand, ready for any offence (and which she so seldom spares on due <\p>
occasion), by letting down a white linen curtain between the festoons <\p>
of the damask ones. It fell like the drop-curtain of a theatre, in the <\p>
interval between the acts. <\p>
Priscilla had disappeared from the boudoir. But the dove still kept <\p>
her desolate perch on the peak of the attic window. <\p>
XIX. ZENOBIA'S DRAWING-ROOM <\p>
The remainder of the day, so far as I was concerned, was spent in <\p>
meditating on these recent incidents. I contrived, and alternately <\p>
rejected, innumerable methods of accounting for the presence of Zenobia <\p>
and Priscilla, and the connection of Westervelt with both. It must be <\p>
owned, too, that I had a keen, revengeful sense of the insult inflicted <\p>
by Zenobia's scornful recognition, and more particularly by her letting <\p>
down the curtain; as if such were the proper barrier to be interposed <\p>
between a character like hers and a perceptive faculty like mine. For, <\p>
was mine a mere vulgar curiosity? Zenobia should have known me better <\p>
than to suppose it. She should have been able to appreciate that <\p>
quality of the intellect and the heart which impelled me (often against <\p>
my own will, and to the detriment of my own comfort) to live in other <\p>
lives, and to endeavor--by generous sympathies, by delicate intuitions, <\p>
by taking note of things too slight for record, and by bringing my <\p>
human spirit into manifold accordance with the companions whom God <\p>
assigned me--to learn the secret which was hidden even from themselves. <\p>
Of all possible observers, methought a woman like Zenobia and a man <\p>
like Hollingsworth should have selected me. And now when the event has <\p>
long been past, I retain the same opinion of my fitness for the office. <\p>
True, I might have condemned them. Had I been judge as well as <\p>
witness, my sentence might have been stern as that of destiny itself. <\p>
But, still, no trait of original nobility of character, no struggle <\p>
against temptation,--no iron necessity of will, on the one hand, nor <\p>
extenuating circumstance to be derived from passion and despair, on the <\p>
other,--no remorse that might coexist with error, even if powerless to <\p>
prevent it,--no proud repentance that should claim retribution as a <\p>
meed,--would go unappreciated. True, again, I might give my full <\p>
assent to the punishment which was sure to follow. But it would be <\p>
given mournfully, and with undiminished love. And, after all was <\p>
finished, I would come as if to gather up the white ashes of those who <\p>
had perished at the stake, and to tell the world--the wrong being now <\p>
atoned for--how much had perished there which it had never yet known <\p>
how to praise. <\p>
I sat in my rocking-chair, too far withdrawn from the window to expose <\p>
myself to another rebuke like that already inflicted. My eyes still <\p>
wandered towards the opposite house, but without effecting any new <\p>
discoveries. Late in the afternoon, the weathercock on the church <\p>
spire indicated a change of wind; the sun shone dimly out, as if the <\p>
golden wine of its beams were mingled half-and-half with water. <\p>
Nevertheless, they kindled up the whole range of edifices, threw a glow <\p>
over the windows, glistened on the wet roofs, and, slowly withdrawing <\p>
upward, perched upon the chimney-tops; thence they took a higher <\p>
flight, and lingered an instant on the tip of the spire, making it the <\p>
final point of more cheerful light in the whole sombre scene. The next <\p>
moment, it was all gone. The twilight fell into the area like a shower <\p>
of dusky snow, and before it was quite dark, the gong of the hotel <\p>
summoned me to tea. <\p>
When I returned to my chamber, the glow of an astral lamp was <\p>
penetrating mistily through the white curtain of Zenobia's <\p>
drawing-room. The shadow of a passing figure was now and then cast <\p>
upon this medium, but with too vague an outline for even my adventurous <\p>
conjectures to read the hieroglyphic that it presented. <\p>
All at once, it occurred to me how very absurd was my behavior in thus <\p>
tormenting myself with crazy hypotheses as to what was going on within <\p>
that drawing-room, when it was at my option to be personally present <\p>
there, My relations with Zenobia, as yet unchanged,--as a familiar <\p>
friend, and associated in the same life-long enterprise,--gave me the <\p>
right, and made it no more than kindly courtesy demanded, to call on <\p>
her. Nothing, except our habitual independence of conventional rules <\p>
at Blithedale, could have kept me from sooner recognizing this duty. <\p>
At all events, it should now be performed. <\p>
In compliance with this sudden impulse, I soon found myself actually <\p>
within the house, the rear of which, for two days past, I had been so <\p>
sedulously watching. A servant took my card, and, immediately <\p>
returning, ushered me upstairs. On the way, I heard a rich, and, as it <\p>
were, triumphant burst of music from a piano, in which I felt Zenobia's <\p>
character, although heretofore I had known nothing of her skill upon <\p>
the instrument. Two or three canary-birds, excited by this gush of <\p>
sound, sang piercingly, and did their utmost to produce a kindred <\p>
melody. A bright illumination streamed through, the door of the front <\p>
drawing-room; and I had barely stept across the threshold before <\p>
Zenobia came forward to meet me, laughing, and with an extended hand. <\p>
"Ah, Mr. Coverdale," said she, still smiling, but, as I thought, with a <\p>
good deal of scornful anger underneath, "it has gratified me to see the <\p>
interest which you continue to take in my affairs! I have long <\p>
recognized you as a sort of transcendental Yankee, with all the native <\p>
propensity of your countrymen to investigate matters that come within <\p>
their range, but rendered almost poetical, in your case, by the refined <\p>
methods which you adopt for its gratification. After all, it was an <\p>
unjustifiable stroke, on my part,--was it not?--to let down the window <\p>
curtain!" <\p>
"I cannot call it a very wise one," returned I, with a secret <\p>
bitterness, which, no doubt, Zenobia appreciated. "It is really <\p>
impossible to hide anything in this world, to say nothing of the next. <\p>
All that we ought to ask, therefore, is, that the witnesses of our <\p>
conduct, and the speculators on our motives, should be capable of <\p>
taking the highest view which the circumstances of the case may admit. <\p>
So much being secured, I, for one, would be most happy in feeling <\p>
myself followed everywhere by an indefatigable human sympathy." <\p>
"We must trust for intelligent sympathy to our guardian angels, if any <\p>
there be," said Zenobia. "As long as the only spectator of my poor <\p>
tragedy is a young man at the window of his hotel, I must still claim <\p>
the liberty to drop the curtain." <\p>
While this passed, as Zenobia's hand was extended, I had applied the <\p>
very slightest touch of my fingers to her own. In spite of an external <\p>
freedom, her manner made me sensible that we stood upon no real terms <\p>
of confidence. The thought came sadly across me, how great was the <\p>
contrast betwixt this interview and our first meeting. Then, in the <\p>
warm light of the country fireside, Zenobia had greeted me cheerily and <\p>
hopefully, with a full sisterly grasp of the hand, conveying as much <\p>
kindness in it as other women could have evinced by the pressure of <\p>
both arms around my neck, or by yielding a cheek to the brotherly <\p>
salute. The difference was as complete as between her appearance at <\p>
that time--so simply attired, and with only the one superb flower in <\p>
her hair--and now, when her beauty was set off by all that dress and <\p>
ornament could do for it. And they did much. Not, indeed, that they <\p>
created or added anything to what Nature had lavishly done for Zenobia. <\p>
But, those costly robes which she had on, those flaming jewels on her <\p>
neck, served as lamps to display the personal advantages which required <\p>
nothing less than such an illumination to be fully seen. Even her <\p>
characteristic flower, though it seemed to be still there, had <\p>
undergone a cold and bright transfiguration; it was a flower <\p>
exquisitely imitated in jeweller's work, and imparting the last touch <\p>
that transformed Zenobia into a work of art. <\p>
"I scarcely feel," I could not forbear saying, "as if we had ever met <\p>
before. How many years ago it seems since we last sat beneath Eliot's <\p>
pulpit, with Hollingsworth extended on the fallen leaves, and Priscilla <\p>
at his feet! Can it be, Zenobia, that you ever really numbered <\p>
yourself with our little band of earnest, thoughtful, philanthropic <\p>
laborers?" <\p>
"Those ideas have their time and place," she answered coldly. "But I <\p>
fancy it must be a very circumscribed mind that can find room for no <\p>
other." <\p>
Her manner bewildered me. Literally, moreover, I was dazzled by the <\p>
brilliancy of the room. A chandelier hung down in the centre, glowing <\p>
with I know not how many lights; there were separate lamps, also, on <\p>
two or three tables, and on marble brackets, adding their white <\p>
radiance to that of the chandelier. The furniture was exceedingly <\p>
rich. Fresh from our old farmhouse, with its homely board and benches <\p>
in the dining-room, and a few wicker chairs in the best parlor, it <\p>
struck me that here was the fulfilment of every fantasy of an <\p>
imagination revelling in various methods of costly self-indulgence and <\p>
splendid ease. Pictures, marbles, vases,--in brief, more shapes of <\p>
luxury than there could be any object in enumerating, except for an <\p>
auctioneer's advertisement,--and the whole repeated and doubled by the <\p>
reflection of a great mirror, which showed me Zenobia's proud figure, <\p>
likewise, and my own. It cost me, I acknowledge, a bitter sense of <\p>
shame, to perceive in myself a positive effort to bear up against the <\p>
effect which Zenobia sought to impose on me. I reasoned against her, <\p>
in my secret mind, and strove so to keep my footing. In the <\p>
gorgeousness with which she had surrounded herself,--in the redundance <\p>
of personal ornament, which the largeness of her physical nature and <\p>
the rich type of her beauty caused to seem so suitable,--I malevolently <\p>
beheld the true character of the woman, passionate, luxurious, lacking <\p>
simplicity, not deeply refined, incapable of pure and perfect taste. <\p>
But, the next instant, she was too powerful for all my opposing <\p>
struggles. I saw how fit it was that she should make herself as <\p>
gorgeous as she pleased, and should do a thousand things that would <\p>
have been ridiculous in the poor, thin, weakly characters of other <\p>
women. To this day, however, I hardly know whether I then beheld <\p>
Zenobia in her truest attitude, or whether that were the truer one in <\p>
which she had presented herself at Blithedale. In both, there was <\p>
something like the illusion which a great actress flings around her. <\p>
"Have you given up Blithedale forever?" I inquired. <\p>
"Why should you think so?" asked she. <\p>
"I cannot tell," answered I; "except that it appears all like a dream <\p>
that we were ever there together." <\p>
"It is not so to me," said Zenobia. "I should think it a poor and <\p>
meagre nature that is capable of but one set of forms, and must convert <\p>
all the past into a dream merely because the present happens to be <\p>
unlike it. Why should we be content with our homely life of a few <\p>
months past, to the exclusion of all other modes? It was good; but <\p>
there are other lives as good, or better. Not, you will understand, <\p>
that I condemn those who give themselves up to it more entirely than I, <\p>
for myself, should deem it wise to do." <\p>
It irritated me, this self-complacent, condescending, qualified <\p>
approval and criticism of a system to which many individuals--perhaps <\p>
as highly endowed as our gorgeous Zenobia--had contributed their all of <\p>
earthly endeavor, and their loftiest aspirations. I determined to make <\p>
proof if there were any spell that would exorcise her out of the part <\p>
which she seemed to be acting. She should be compelled to give me a <\p>
glimpse of something true; some nature, some passion, no matter whether <\p>
right or wrong, provided it were real. <\p>
"Your allusion to that class of circumscribed characters who can live <\p>
only in one mode of life," remarked I coolly, "reminds me of our poor <\p>
friend Hollingsworth. Possibly he was in your thoughts when you spoke <\p>
thus. Poor fellow! It is a pity that, by the fault of a narrow <\p>
education, he should have so completely immolated himself to that one <\p>
idea of his, especially as the slightest modicum of common-sense would <\p>
teach him its utter impracticability. Now that I have returned into <\p>
the world, and can look at his project from a distance, it requires <\p>
quite all my real regard for this respectable and well-intentioned man <\p>
to prevent me laughing at him,--as I find society at large does." <\p>
Zenobia's eyes darted lightning, her cheeks flushed, the vividness of <\p>
her expression was like the effect of a powerful light flaming up <\p>
suddenly within her. My experiment had fully succeeded. She had shown <\p>
me the true flesh and blood of her heart, by thus involuntarily <\p>
resenting my slight, pitying, half-kind, half-scornful mention of the <\p>
man who was all in all with her. She herself probably felt this; for <\p>
it was hardly a moment before she tranquillized her uneven breath, and <\p>
seemed as proud and self-possessed as ever. <\p>
"I rather imagine," said she quietly, "that your appreciation falls <\p>
short of Mr. Hollingsworth's just claims. Blind enthusiasm, absorption <\p>
in one idea, I grant, is generally ridiculous, and must be fatal to the <\p>
respectability of an ordinary man; it requires a very high and powerful <\p>
character to make it otherwise. But a great man--as, perhaps, you do <\p>
not know--attains his normal condition only through the inspiration of <\p>
one great idea. As a friend of Mr. Hollingsworth, and, at the same <\p>
time, a calm observer, I must tell you that he seems to me such a man. <\p>
But you are very pardonable for fancying him ridiculous. Doubtless, he <\p>
is so--to you! There can be no truer test of the noble and heroic, in <\p>
any individual, than the degree in which he possesses the faculty of <\p>
distinguishing heroism from absurdity." <\p>
I dared make no retort to Zenobia's concluding apothegm. In truth, I <\p>
admired her fidelity. It gave me a new sense of Hollingsworth's native <\p>
power, to discover that his influence was no less potent with this <\p>
beautiful woman here, in the midst of artificial life, than it had been <\p>
at the foot of the gray rock, and among the wild birch-trees of the <\p>
wood-path, when she so passionately pressed his hand against her heart. <\p>
The great, rude, shaggy, swarthy man! And Zenobia loved him! <\p>
"Did you bring Priscilla with you?" I resumed. "Do you know I have <\p>
sometimes fancied it not quite safe, considering the susceptibility of <\p>
her temperament, that she should be so constantly within the sphere of <\p>
a man like Hollingsworth. Such tender and delicate natures, among your <\p>
sex, have often, I believe, a very adequate appreciation of the heroic <\p>
element in men. But then, again, I should suppose them as likely as <\p>
any other women to make a reciprocal impression. Hollingsworth could <\p>
hardly give his affections to a person capable of taking an independent <\p>
stand, but only to one whom he might absorb into himself. He has <\p>
certainly shown great tenderness for Priscilla." <\p>
Zenobia had turned aside. But I caught the reflection of her face in <\p>
the mirror, and saw that it was very pale,--as pale, in her rich <\p>
attire, as if a shroud were round her. <\p>
"Priscilla is here," said she, her voice a little lower than usual. <\p>
"Have not you learnt as much from your chamber window? Would you like <\p>
to see her?" <\p>
She made a step or two into the back drawing-room, and <\p>
called,--"Priscilla! Dear Priscilla!" <\p>
XX. THEY VANISH <\p>
Priscilla immediately answered the summons, and made her appearance <\p>
through the door of the boudoir. I had conceived the idea, which I now <\p>
recognized as a very foolish one, that Zenobia would have taken <\p>
measures to debar me from an interview with this girl, between whom and <\p>
herself there was so utter an opposition of their dearest interests, <\p>
that, on one part or the other, a great grief, if not likewise a great <\p>
wrong, seemed a matter of necessity. But, as Priscilla was only a leaf <\p>
floating on the dark current of events, without influencing them by her <\p>
own choice or plan, as she probably guessed not whither the stream was <\p>
bearing her, nor perhaps even felt its inevitable movement,--there <\p>
could be no peril of her communicating to me any intelligence with <\p>
regard to Zenobia's purposes. <\p>
On perceiving me, she came forward with great quietude of manner; and <\p>
when I held out my hand, her own moved slightly towards it, as if <\p>
attracted by a feeble degree of magnetism. <\p>
"I am glad to see you, my dear Priscilla," said I, still holding her <\p>
hand; "but everything that I meet with nowadays makes me wonder whether <\p>
I am awake. You, especially, have always seemed like a figure in a <\p>
dream, and now more than ever." <\p>
"Oh, there is substance in these fingers of mine," she answered, giving <\p>
my hand the faintest possible pressure, and then taking away her own. <\p>
"Why do you call me a dream? Zenobia is much more like one than I; she <\p>
is so very, very beautiful! And, I suppose," added Priscilla, as if <\p>
thinking aloud, "everybody sees it, as I do." <\p>
But, for my part, it was Priscilla's beauty, not Zenobia's, of which I <\p>
was thinking at that moment. She was a person who could be quite <\p>
obliterated, so far as beauty went, by anything unsuitable in her <\p>
attire; her charm was not positive and material enough to bear up <\p>
against a mistaken choice of color, for instance, or fashion. It was <\p>
safest, in her case, to attempt no art of dress; for it demanded the <\p>
most perfect taste, or else the happiest accident in the world, to give <\p>
her precisely the adornment which she needed. She was now dressed in <\p>
pure white, set off with some kind of a gauzy fabric, which--as I bring <\p>
up her figure in my memory, with a faint gleam on her shadowy hair, and <\p>
her dark eyes bent shyly on mine, through all the vanished years--seems <\p>
to be floating about her like a mist. I wondered what Zenobia meant by <\p>
evolving so much loveliness out of this poor girl. It was what few <\p>
women could afford to do; for, as I looked from one to the other, the <\p>
sheen and splendor of Zenobia's presence took nothing from Priscilla's <\p>
softer spell, if it might not rather be thought to add to it. <\p>
"What do you think of her?" asked Zenobia. <\p>
I could not understand the look of melancholy kindness with which <\p>
Zenobia regarded her. She advanced a step, and beckoning Priscilla <\p>
near her, kissed her cheek; then, with a slight gesture of repulse, she <\p>
moved to the other side of the room. I followed. <\p>
"She is a wonderful creature," I said. "Ever since she came among us, <\p>
I have been dimly sensible of just this charm which you have brought <\p>
out. But it was never absolutely visible till now. She is as lovely <\p>
as a flower!" <\p>
"Well, say so if you like," answered Zenobia. "You are a poet,--at <\p>
least, as poets go nowadays,--and must be allowed to make an <\p>
opera-glass of your imagination, when you look at women. I wonder, in <\p>
such Arcadian freedom of falling in love as we have lately enjoyed, it <\p>
never occurred to you to fall in love with Priscilla. In society, <\p>
indeed, a genuine American never dreams of stepping across the <\p>
inappreciable air-line which separates one class from another. But <\p>
what was rank to the colonists of Blithedale?" <\p>
"There were other reasons," I replied, "why I should have demonstrated <\p>
myself an ass, had I fallen in love with Priscilla. By the bye, has <\p>
