Hollingsworth ever seen her in this dress?" <\p>
"Why do you bring up his name at every turn?" asked Zenobia in an <\p>
undertone, and with a malign look which wandered from my face to <\p>
Priscilla's. "You know not what you do! It is dangerous, sir, believe <\p>
me, to tamper thus with earnest human passions, out of your own mere <\p>
idleness, and for your sport. I will endure it no longer! Take care <\p>
that it does not happen again! I warn you!" <\p>
"You partly wrong me, if not wholly," I responded. "It is an uncertain <\p>
sense of some duty to perform, that brings my thoughts, and therefore <\p>
my words, continually to that one point." <\p>
"Oh, this stale excuse of duty!" said Zenobia, in a whisper so full of <\p>
scorn that it penetrated me like the hiss of a serpent. "I have often <\p>
heard it before, from those who sought to interfere with me, and I know <\p>
precisely what it signifies. Bigotry; self-conceit; an insolent <\p>
curiosity; a meddlesome temper; a cold-blooded criticism, founded on a <\p>
shallow interpretation of half-perceptions; a monstrous scepticism in <\p>
regard to any conscience or any wisdom, except one's own; a most <\p>
irreverent propensity to thrust Providence aside, and substitute one's <\p>
self in its awful place,--out of these, and other motives as miserable <\p>
as these, comes your idea of duty! But, beware, sir! With all your <\p>
fancied acuteness, you step blindfold into these affairs. For any <\p>
mischief that may follow your interference, I hold you responsible!" <\p>
It was evident that, with but a little further provocation, the lioness <\p>
would turn to bay; if, indeed, such were not her attitude already. I <\p>
bowed, and not very well knowing what else to do, was about to <\p>
withdraw. But, glancing again towards Priscilla, who had retreated <\p>
into a corner, there fell upon my heart an intolerable burden of <\p>
despondency, the purport of which I could not tell, but only felt it to <\p>
bear reference to her. I approached and held out my hand; a gesture, <\p>
however, to which she made no response. It was always one of her <\p>
peculiarities that she seemed to shrink from even the most friendly <\p>
touch, unless it were Zenobia's or Hollingsworth's. Zenobia, all this <\p>
while, stood watching us, but with a careless expression, as if it <\p>
mattered very little what might pass. <\p>
"Priscilla," I inquired, lowering my voice, "when do you go back to <\p>
Blithedale?" <\p>
"Whenever they please to take me," said she. <\p>
"Did you come away of your own free will?" I asked. <\p>
"I am blown about like a leaf," she replied. "I never have any free <\p>
will." <\p>
"Does Hollingsworth know that you are here?" said I. <\p>
"He bade me come," answered Priscilla. <\p>
She looked at me, I thought, with an air of surprise, as if the idea <\p>
were incomprehensible that she should have taken this step without his <\p>
agency. <\p>
"What a gripe this man has laid upon her whole being!" muttered I <\p>
between my teeth. <\p>
"Well, as Zenobia so kindly intimates, I have no more business here. I <\p>
wash my hands of it all. On Hollingsworth's head be the consequences! <\p>
Priscilla," I added aloud, "I know not that ever we may meet again. <\p>
Farewell!" <\p>
As I spoke the word, a carriage had rumbled along the street, and stopt <\p>
before the house. The doorbell rang, and steps were immediately <\p>
afterwards heard on the staircase. Zenobia had thrown a shawl over her <\p>
dress. <\p>
"Mr. Coverdale," said she, with cool courtesy, "you will perhaps excuse <\p>
us. We have an engagement, and are going out." <\p>
"Whither?" I demanded. <\p>
"Is not that a little more than you are entitled to inquire?" said she, <\p>
with a smile. "At all events, it does not suit me to tell you." <\p>
The door of the drawing-room opened, and Westervelt appeared. I <\p>
observed that he was elaborately dressed, as if for some grand <\p>
entertainment. My dislike for this man was infinite. At that moment <\p>
it amounted to nothing less than a creeping of the flesh, as when, <\p>
feeling about in a dark place, one touches something cold and slimy, <\p>
and questions what the secret hatefulness may be. And still I could <\p>
not but acknowledge that, for personal beauty, for polish of manner, <\p>
for all that externally befits a gentleman, there was hardly another <\p>
like him. After bowing to Zenobia, and graciously saluting Priscilla <\p>
in her corner, he recognized me by a slight but courteous inclination. <\p>
"Come, Priscilla," said Zenobia; "it is time. Mr. Coverdale, <\p>
good-evening." <\p>
As Priscilla moved slowly forward, I met her in the middle of the <\p>
drawing-room. <\p>
"Priscilla," said I, in the hearing of them all, "do you know whither <\p>
you are going?" <\p>
"I do not know," she answered. <\p>
"Is it wise to go, and is it your choice to go?" I asked. "If not, I <\p>
am your friend, and Hollingsworth's friend. Tell me so, at once." <\p>
"Possibly," observed Westervelt, smiling, "Priscilla sees in me an <\p>
older friend than either Mr. Coverdale or Mr. Hollingsworth. I shall <\p>
willingly leave the matter at her option." <\p>
While thus speaking, he made a gesture of kindly invitation, and <\p>
Priscilla passed me, with the gliding movement of a sprite, and took <\p>
his offered arm. He offered the other to Zenobia; but she turned her <\p>
proud and beautiful face upon him with a look which--judging from what <\p>
I caught of it in profile--would undoubtedly have smitten the man dead, <\p>
had he possessed any heart, or had this glance attained to it. It <\p>
seemed to rebound, however, from his courteous visage, like an arrow <\p>
from polished steel. They all three descended the stairs; and when I <\p>
likewise reached the street door, the carriage was already rolling away. <\p>
XXI. AN OLD ACQUAINTANCE <\p>
Thus excluded from everybody's confidence, and attaining no further, by <\p>
my most earnest study, than to an uncertain sense of something hidden <\p>
from me, it would appear reasonable that I should have flung off all <\p>
these alien perplexities. Obviously, my best course was to betake <\p>
myself to new scenes. Here I was only an intruder. Elsewhere there <\p>
might be circumstances in which I could establish a personal interest, <\p>
and people who would respond, with a portion of their sympathies, for <\p>
so much as I should bestow of mine. <\p>
Nevertheless, there occurred to me one other thing to be done. <\p>
Remembering old Moodie, and his relationship with Priscilla, I <\p>
determined to seek an interview, for the purpose of ascertaining <\p>
whether the knot of affairs was as inextricable on that side as I found <\p>
it on all others. Being tolerably well acquainted with the old man's <\p>
haunts, I went, the next day, to the saloon of a certain establishment <\p>
about which he often lurked. It was a reputable place enough, <\p>
affording good entertainment in the way of meat, drink, and fumigation; <\p>
and there, in my young and idle days and nights, when I was neither <\p>
nice nor wise, I had often amused myself with watching the staid humors <\p>
and sober jollities of the thirsty souls around me. <\p>
At my first entrance, old Moodie was not there. The more patiently to <\p>
await him, I lighted a cigar, and establishing myself in a corner, took <\p>
a quiet, and, by sympathy, a boozy kind of pleasure in the customary <\p>
life that was going forward. The saloon was fitted up with a good deal <\p>
of taste. There were pictures on the walls, and among them an <\p>
oil-painting of a beefsteak, with such an admirable show of juicy <\p>
tenderness, that the beholder sighed to think it merely visionary, and <\p>
incapable of ever being put upon a gridiron. Another work of high art <\p>
was the lifelike representation of a noble sirloin; another, the <\p>
hindquarters of a deer, retaining the hoofs and tawny fur; another, the <\p>
head and shoulders of a salmon; and, still more exquisitely finished, a <\p>
brace of canvasback ducks, in which the mottled feathers were depicted <\p>
with the accuracy of a daguerreotype. Some very hungry painter, I <\p>
suppose, had wrought these subjects of still-life, heightening his <\p>
imagination with his appetite, and earning, it is to be hoped, the <\p>
privilege of a daily dinner off whichever of his pictorial viands he <\p>
liked best. <\p>
Then there was a fine old cheese, in which you could almost discern the <\p>
mites; and some sardines, on a small plate, very richly done, and <\p>
looking as if oozy with the oil in which they had been smothered. All <\p>
these things were so perfectly imitated, that you seemed to have the <\p>
genuine article before you, and yet with an indescribable, ideal charm; <\p>
it took away the grossness from what was fleshiest and fattest, and <\p>
thus helped the life of man, even in its earthliest relations, to <\p>
appear rich and noble, as well as warm, cheerful, and substantial. <\p>
There were pictures, too, of gallant revellers, those of the old time, <\p>
Flemish, apparently, with doublets and slashed sleeves, drinking their <\p>
wine out of fantastic, long-stemmed glasses; quaffing joyously, <\p>
quaffing forever, with inaudible laughter and song; while the champagne <\p>
bubbled immortally against their moustaches, or the purple tide of <\p>
Burgundy ran inexhaustibly down their throats. <\p>
But, in an obscure corner of the saloon, there was a little Picture <\p>
excellently done, moreover of a ragged, bloated, New England toper, <\p>
stretched out on a bench, in the heavy, apoplectic sleep of <\p>
drunkenness. The death-in-life was too well portrayed. You smelt the <\p>
fumy liquor that had brought on this syncope. Your only comfort lay in <\p>
the forced reflection, that, real as he looked, the poor caitiff was <\p>
but imaginary, a bit of painted canvass, whom no delirium tremens, nor <\p>
so much as a retributive headache, awaited, on the morrow. <\p>
By this time, it being past eleven o'clock, the two bar-keepers of the <\p>
saloon were in pretty constant activity. One of these young men had a <\p>
rare faculty in the concoction of gin-cocktails. It was a spectacle to <\p>
behold, how, with a tumbler in each hand, he tossed the contents from <\p>
one to the other. Never conveying it awry, nor spilling the least <\p>
drop, he compelled the frothy liquor, as it seemed to me, to spout <\p>
forth from one glass and descend into the other, in a great parabolic <\p>
curve, as well-defined and calculable as a planet's orbit. He had a <\p>
good forehead, with a particularly large development just above the <\p>
eyebrows; fine intellectual gifts, no doubt, which he had educated to <\p>
this profitable end; being famous for nothing but gin-cocktails, and <\p>
commanding a fair salary by his one accomplishment. These cocktails, <\p>
and other artificial combinations of liquor, (of which there were at <\p>
least a score, though mostly, I suspect, fantastic in their <\p>
differences,) were much in favor with the younger class of customers, <\p>
who, at farthest, had only reached the second stage of potatory life. <\p>
The staunch, old soakers, on the other hand men who, if put on tap, <\p>
would have yielded a red alcoholic liquor, by way of blood usually <\p>
confined themselves to plain brandy-and-water, gin, or West India rum; <\p>
and, oftentimes, they prefaced their dram with some medicinal remark as <\p>
to the wholesomeness and stomachic qualities of that particular drink. <\p>
Two or three appeared to have bottles of their own behind the counter; <\p>
and, winking one red eye to the bar-keeper, he forthwith produced these <\p>
choicest and peculiar cordials, which it was a matter of great interest <\p>
and favor, among their acquaintances, to obtain a sip of. <\p>
Agreeably to the Yankee habit, under whatever circumstances, the <\p>
deportment of all these good fellows, old or young, was decorous and <\p>
thoroughly correct. They grew only the more sober in their cups; there <\p>
was no confused babble nor boisterous laughter. They sucked in the <\p>
joyous fire of the decanters and kept it smouldering in their inmost <\p>
recesses, with a bliss known only to the heart which it warmed and <\p>
comforted. Their eyes twinkled a little, to be sure; they hemmed <\p>
vigorously after each glass, and laid a hand upon the pit of the <\p>
stomach, as if the pleasant titillation there was what constituted the <\p>
tangible part of their enjoyment. In that spot, unquestionably, and <\p>
not in the brain, was the acme of the whole affair. But the true <\p>
purpose of their drinking--and one that will induce men to drink, or do <\p>
something equivalent, as long as this weary world shall endure--was the <\p>
renewed youth and vigor, the brisk, cheerful sense of things present <\p>
and to come, with which, for about a quarter of an hour, the dram <\p>
permeated their systems. And when such quarters of an hour can be <\p>
obtained in some mode less baneful to the great sum of a man's <\p>
life,--but, nevertheless, with a little spice of impropriety, to give <\p>
it a wild flavor,--we temperance people may ring out our bells for <\p>
victory! <\p>
The prettiest object in the saloon was a tiny fountain, which threw up <\p>
its feathery jet through the counter, and sparkled down again into an <\p>
oval basin, or lakelet, containing several goldfishes. There was a bed <\p>
of bright sand at the bottom, strewn with coral and rock-work; and the <\p>
fishes went gleaming about, now turning up the sheen of a golden side, <\p>
and now vanishing into the shadows of the water, like the fanciful <\p>
thoughts that coquet with a poet in his dream. Never before, I <\p>
imagine, did a company of water-drinkers remain so entirely <\p>
uncontaminated by the bad example around them; nor could I help <\p>
wondering that it had not occurred to any freakish inebriate to empty a <\p>
glass of liquor into their lakelet. What a delightful idea! Who would <\p>
not be a fish, if he could inhale jollity with the essential element of <\p>
his existence! <\p>
I had begun to despair of meeting old Moodie, when, all at once, I <\p>
recognized his hand and arm protruding from behind a screen that was <\p>
set up for the accommodation of bashful topers. As a matter of course, <\p>
he had one of Priscilla's little purses, and was quietly insinuating it <\p>
under the notice of a person who stood near. This was always old <\p>
Moodie's way. You hardly ever saw him advancing towards you, but <\p>
became aware of his proximity without being able to guess how he had <\p>
come thither. He glided about like a spirit, assuming visibility close <\p>
to your elbow, offering his petty trifles of merchandise, remaining <\p>
long enough for you to purchase, if so disposed, and then taking <\p>
himself off, between two breaths, while you happened to be thinking of <\p>
something else. <\p>
By a sort of sympathetic impulse that often controlled me in those more <\p>
impressible days of my life, I was induced to approach this old man in <\p>
a mode as undemonstrative as his own. Thus, when, according to his <\p>
custom, he was probably just about to vanish, he found me at his elbow. <\p>
"Ah!" said he, with more emphasis than was usual with him. "It is Mr. <\p>
Coverdale!" <\p>
"Yes, Mr. Moodie, your old acquaintance," answered I. "It is some time <\p>
now since we ate luncheon together at Blithedale, and a good deal <\p>
longer since our little talk together at the street corner." <\p>
"That was a good while ago," said the old man. <\p>
And he seemed inclined to say not a word more. His existence looked so <\p>
colorless and torpid,--so very faintly shadowed on the canvas of <\p>
reality,--that I was half afraid lest he should altogether disappear, <\p>
even while my eyes were fixed full upon his figure. He was certainly <\p>
the wretchedest old ghost in the world, with his crazy hat, the dingy <\p>
handkerchief about his throat, his suit of threadbare gray, and <\p>
especially that patch over his right eye, behind which he always seemed <\p>
to be hiding himself. There was one method, however, of bringing him <\p>
out into somewhat stronger relief. A glass of brandy would effect it. <\p>
Perhaps the gentler influence of a bottle of claret might do the same. <\p>
Nor could I think it a matter for the recording angel to write down <\p>
against me, if--with my painful consciousness of the frost in this old <\p>
man's blood, and the positive ice that had congealed about his heart--I <\p>
should thaw him out, were it only for an hour, with the summer warmth <\p>
of a little wine. What else could possibly be done for him? How else <\p>
could he be imbued with energy enough to hope for a happier state <\p>
hereafter? How else be inspired to say his prayers? For there are <\p>
states of our spiritual system when the throb of the soul's life is too <\p>
faint and weak to render us capable of religious aspiration. <\p>
"Mr. Moodie," said I, "shall we lunch together? And would you like to <\p>
drink a glass of wine?" <\p>
His one eye gleamed. He bowed; and it impressed me that he grew to be <\p>
more of a man at once, either in anticipation of the wine, or as a <\p>
grateful response to my good fellowship in offering it. <\p>
"With pleasure," he replied. <\p>
The bar-keeper, at my request, showed us into a private room, and soon <\p>
afterwards set some fried oysters and a bottle of claret on the table; <\p>
and I saw the old man glance curiously at the label of the bottle, as <\p>
if to learn the brand. <\p>
"It should be good wine," I remarked, "if it have any right to its <\p>
label." <\p>
"You cannot suppose, sir," said Moodie, with a sigh, "that a poor old <\p>
fellow like me knows any difference in wines." <\p>
And yet, in his way of handling the glass, in his preliminary snuff at <\p>
the aroma, in his first cautious sip of the wine, and the gustatory <\p>
skill with which he gave his palate the full advantage of it, it was <\p>
impossible not to recognize the connoisseur. <\p>
"I fancy, Mr. Moodie," said I, "you are a much better judge of wines <\p>
than I have yet learned to be. Tell me fairly,--did you never drink it <\p>
where the grape grows?" <\p>
"How should that have been, Mr. Coverdale?" answered old Moodie shyly; <\p>
but then he took courage, as it were, and uttered a feeble little <\p>
laugh. "The flavor of this wine," added he, "and its perfume still <\p>
more than its taste, makes me remember that I was once a young man." <\p>
"I wish, Mr. Moodie," suggested I,--not that I greatly cared about it, <\p>
however, but was only anxious to draw him into some talk about <\p>
Priscilla and Zenobia,--"I wish, while we sit over our wine, you would <\p>
favor me with a few of those youthful reminiscences." <\p>
"Ah," said he, shaking his head, "they might interest you more than you <\p>
suppose. But I had better be silent, Mr. Coverdale. If this good <\p>
wine,--though claret, I suppose, is not apt to play such a trick,--but <\p>
if it should make my tongue run too freely, I could never look you in <\p>
the face again." <\p>
"You never did look me in the face, Mr. Moodie," I replied, "until this <\p>
very moment." <\p>
"Ah!" sighed old Moodie. <\p>
It was wonderful, however, what an effect the mild grape-juice wrought <\p>
upon him. It was not in the wine, but in the associations which it <\p>
seemed to bring up. Instead of the mean, slouching, furtive, painfully <\p>
depressed air of an old city vagabond, more like a gray kennel-rat than <\p>
any other living thing, he began to take the aspect of a decayed <\p>
gentleman. Even his garments--especially after I had myself quaffed a <\p>
glass or two--looked less shabby than when we first sat down. There <\p>
was, by and by, a certain exuberance and elaborateness of gesture and <\p>
manner, oddly in contrast with all that I had hitherto seen of him. <\p>
Anon, with hardly any impulse from me, old Moodie began to talk. His <\p>
communications referred exclusively to a long-past and more fortunate <\p>
period of his life, with only a few unavoidable allusions to the <\p>
circumstances that had reduced him to his present state. But, having <\p>
once got the clew, my subsequent researches acquainted me with the main <\p>
facts of the following narrative; although, in writing it out, my pen <\p>
has perhaps allowed itself a trifle of romantic and legendary license, <\p>
worthier of a small poet than of a grave biographer. <\p>
XXII. FAUNTLEROY <\p>
Five-and-twenty years ago, at the epoch of this story, there dwelt in <\p>
one of the Middle States a man whom we shall call Fauntleroy; a man of <\p>
wealth, and magnificent tastes, and prodigal expenditure. His home <\p>
might almost be styled a palace; his habits, in the ordinary sense, <\p>
princely. His whole being seemed to have crystallized itself into an <\p>
external splendor, wherewith he glittered in the eyes of the world, and <\p>
had no other life than upon this gaudy surface. He had married a <\p>
lovely woman, whose nature was deeper than his own. But his affection <\p>
for her, though it showed largely, was superficial, like all his other <\p>
manifestations and developments; he did not so truly keep this noble <\p>
creature in his heart, as wear her beauty for the most brilliant <\p>
ornament of his outward state. And there was born to him a child, a <\p>
beautiful daughter, whom he took from the beneficent hand of God with <\p>
no just sense of her immortal value, but as a man already rich in gems <\p>
would receive another jewel. If he loved her, it was because she shone. <\p>
After Fauntleroy had thus spent a few empty years, coruscating <\p>
continually an unnatural light, the source of it--which was merely his <\p>
gold--began to grow more shallow, and finally became exhausted. He saw <\p>
himself in imminent peril of losing all that had heretofore <\p>
distinguished him; and, conscious of no innate worth to fall back upon, <\p>
he recoiled from this calamity with the instinct of a soul shrinking <\p>
from annihilation. To avoid it,--wretched man!--or rather to defer it, <\p>
if but for a month, a day, or only to procure himself the life of a few <\p>
breaths more amid the false glitter which was now less his own than <\p>
ever,--he made himself guilty of a crime. It was just the sort of <\p>
crime, growing out of its artificial state, which society (unless it <\p>
should change its entire constitution for this man's unworthy sake) <\p>
neither could nor ought to pardon. More safely might it pardon murder. <\p>
Fauntleroy's guilt was discovered. He fled; his wife perished, by the <\p>
necessity of her innate nobleness, in its alliance with a being so <\p>
ignoble; and betwixt her mother's death and her father's ignominy, his <\p>
daughter was left worse than orphaned. <\p>
There was no pursuit after Fauntleroy. His family connections, who had <\p>
great wealth, made such arrangements with those whom he had attempted <\p>
to wrong as secured him from the retribution that would have overtaken <\p>
an unfriended criminal. The wreck of his estate was divided among his <\p>
creditors: His name, in a very brief space, was forgotten by the <\p>
multitude who had passed it so diligently from mouth to mouth. Seldom, <\p>
indeed, was it recalled, even by his closest former intimates. Nor <\p>
could it have been otherwise. The man had laid no real touch on any <\p>
mortal's heart. Being a mere image, an optical delusion, created by <\p>
the sunshine of prosperity, it was his law to vanish into the shadow of <\p>
the first intervening cloud. He seemed to leave no vacancy; a <\p>
phenomenon which, like many others that attended his brief career, went <\p>
far to prove the illusiveness of his existence. <\p>
Not, however, that the physical substance of Fauntleroy had literally <\p>
melted into vapor. He had fled northward to the New England <\p>
metropolis, and had taken up his abode, under another name, in a <\p>
squalid street or court of the older portion of the city. There he <\p>
dwelt among poverty-stricken wretches, sinners, and forlorn good <\p>
people, Irish, and whomsoever else were neediest. Many families were <\p>
clustered in each house together, above stairs and below, in the little <\p>
peaked garrets, and even in the dusky cellars. The house where <\p>
Fauntleroy paid weekly rent for a chamber and a closet had been a <\p>
stately habitation in its day. An old colonial governor had built it, <\p>
and lived there, long ago, and held his levees in a great room where <\p>
now slept twenty Irish bedfellows; and died in Fauntleroy's chamber, <\p>
which his embroidered and white-wigged ghost still haunted. Tattered <\p>
hangings, a marble hearth, traversed with many cracks and fissures, a <\p>
richly carved oaken mantelpiece, partly hacked away for kindling-stuff, <\p>
a stuccoed ceiling, defaced with great, unsightly patches of the naked <\p>
laths,--such was the chamber's aspect, as if, with its splinters and <\p>
rags of dirty splendor, it were a kind of practical gibe at this poor, <\p>
ruined man of show. <\p>
At first, and at irregular intervals, his relatives allowed Fauntleroy <\p>
a little pittance to sustain life; not from any love, perhaps, but lest <\p>
poverty should compel him, by new offences, to add more shame to that <\p>
with which he had already stained them. But he showed no tendency to <\p>
further guilt. His character appeared to have been radically changed <\p>
(as, indeed, from its shallowness, it well might) by his miserable <\p>
fate; or, it may be, the traits now seen in him were portions of the <\p>
same character, presenting itself in another phase. Instead of any <\p>
longer seeking to live in the sight of the world, his impulse was to <\p>
shrink into the nearest obscurity, and to be unseen of men, were it <\p>
possible, even while standing before their eyes. He had no pride; it <\p>
was all trodden in the dust. No ostentation; for how could it survive, <\p>
when there was nothing left of Fauntleroy, save penury and shame! His <\p>
very gait demonstrated that he would gladly have faded out of view, and <\p>
have crept about invisibly, for the sake of sheltering himself from the <\p>
irksomeness of a human glance. Hardly, it was averred, within the <\p>
memory of those who knew him now, had he the hardihood to show his full <\p>
front to the world. He skulked in corners, and crept about in a sort <\p>
of noonday twilight, making himself gray and misty, at all hours, with <\p>
his morbid intolerance of sunshine. <\p>
In his torpid despair, however, he had done an act which that condition <\p>
of the spirit seems to prompt almost as often as prosperity and hope. <\p>
Fauntleroy was again married. He had taken to wife a forlorn, <\p>
meek-spirited, feeble young woman, a seamstress, whom he found dwelling <\p>
with her mother in a contiguous chamber of the old gubernatorial <\p>
residence. This poor phantom--as the beautiful and noble companion of <\p>
his former life had done brought him a daughter. And sometimes, as from <\p>
one dream into another, Fauntleroy looked forth out of his present <\p>
grimy environment into that past magnificence, and wondered whether the <\p>
grandee of yesterday or the pauper of to-day were real. But, in my <\p>
mind, the one and the other were alike impalpable. In truth, it was <\p>
Fauntleroy's fatality to behold whatever he touched dissolve. After a <\p>
few years, his second wife (dim shadow that she had always been) faded <\p>
finally out of the world, and left Fauntleroy to deal as he might with <\p>
their pale and nervous child. And, by this time, among his distant <\p>
relatives,--with whom he had grown a weary thought, linked with <\p>
contagious infamy, and which they were only too willing to get rid <\p>
of,--he was himself supposed to be no more. <\p>
The younger child, like his elder one, might be considered as the true <\p>
offspring of both parents, and as the reflection of their state. She <\p>
was a tremulous little creature, shrinking involuntarily from all <\p>
mankind, but in timidity, and no sour repugnance. There was a lack of <\p>
human substance in her; it seemed as if, were she to stand up in a <\p>
sunbeam, it would pass right through her figure, and trace out the <\p>
cracked and dusty window-panes upon the naked floor. But, <\p>
nevertheless, the poor child had a heart; and from her mother's gentle <\p>
character she had inherited a profound and still capacity of affection. <\p>
And so her life was one of love. She bestowed it partly on her father, <\p>
but in greater part on an idea. <\p>
For Fauntleroy, as they sat by their cheerless fireside,--which was no <\p>
fireside, in truth, but only a rusty stove,--had often talked to the <\p>
little girl about his former wealth, the noble loveliness of his first <\p>
wife, and the beautiful child whom she had given him. Instead of the <\p>
fairy tales which other parents tell, he told Priscilla this. And, out <\p>
of the loneliness of her sad little existence, Priscilla's love grew, <\p>
and tended upward, and twined itself perseveringly around this unseen <\p>
sister; as a grapevine might strive to clamber out of a gloomy hollow <\p>
among the rocks, and embrace a young tree standing in the sunny warmth <\p>
above. It was almost like worship, both in its earnestness and its <\p>
humility; nor was it the less humble--though the more earnest--because <\p>
Priscilla could claim human kindred with the being whom she, so <\p>
devoutly loved. As with worship, too, it gave her soul the refreshment <\p>
of a purer atmosphere. Save for this singular, this melancholy, and <\p>
yet beautiful affection, the child could hardly have lived; or, had she <\p>
lived, with a heart shrunken for lack of any sentiment to fill it, she <\p>
must have yielded to the barren miseries of her position, and have <\p>
grown to womanhood characterless and worthless. But now, amid all the <\p>
sombre coarseness of her father's outward life, and of her own, <\p>
Priscilla had a higher and imaginative life within. Some faint gleam <\p>
thereof was often visible upon her face. It was as if, in her spiritual <\p>
visits to her brilliant sister, a portion of the latter's brightness <\p>
had permeated our dim Priscilla, and still lingered, shedding a faint <\p>
illumination through the cheerless chamber, after she came back. <\p>
As the child grew up, so pallid and so slender, and with much <\p>
unaccountable nervousness, and all the weaknesses of neglected infancy <\p>
still haunting her, the gross and simple neighbors whispered strange <\p>
things about Priscilla. The big, red, Irish matrons, whose innumerable <\p>
progeny swarmed out of the adjacent doors, used to mock at the pale <\p>
Western child. They fancied--or, at least, affirmed it, between jest <\p>
and earnest--that she was not so solid flesh and blood as other <\p>
children, but mixed largely with a thinner element. They called her <\p>
ghost-child, and said that she could indeed vanish when she pleased, <\p>
but could never, in her densest moments, make herself quite visible. <\p>
The sun at midday would shine through her; in the first gray of the <\p>
twilight, she lost all the distinctness of her outline; and, if you <\p>
followed the dim thing into a dark corner, behold! she was not there. <\p>
And it was true that Priscilla had strange ways; strange ways, and <\p>
stranger words, when she uttered any words at all. Never stirring out <\p>
of the old governor's dusky house, she sometimes talked of distant <\p>
places and splendid rooms, as if she had just left them. Hidden things <\p>
were visible to her (at least so the people inferred from obscure hints <\p>
escaping unawares out of her mouth), and silence was audible. And in <\p>
all the world there was nothing so difficult to be endured, by those <\p>
who had any dark secret to conceal, as the glance of Priscilla's timid <\p>
and melancholy eyes. <\p>
Her peculiarities were the theme of continual gossip among the other <\p>
inhabitants of the gubernatorial mansion. The rumor spread thence into <\p>
a wider circle. Those who knew old Moodie, as he was now called, used <\p>
often to jeer him, at the very street-corners, about his daughter's <\p>
gift of second-sight and prophecy. It was a period when science <\p>
(though mostly through its empirical professors) was bringing forward, <\p>
anew, a hoard of facts and imperfect theories, that had partially won <\p>
credence in elder times, but which modern scepticism had swept away as <\p>
rubbish. These things were now tossed up again, out of the surging <\p>
ocean of human thought and experience. The story of Priscilla's <\p>
preternatural manifestations, therefore, attracted a kind of notice of <\p>
which it would have been deemed wholly unworthy a few years earlier. <\p>
One day a gentleman ascended the creaking staircase, and inquired which <\p>
was old Moodie's chamber door. And, several times, he came again. He <\p>
was a marvellously handsome man,--still youthful, too, and fashionably <\p>
dressed. Except that Priscilla, in those days, had no beauty, and, in <\p>
the languor of her existence, had not yet blossomed into womanhood, <\p>
there would have been rich food for scandal in these visits; for the <\p>
girl was unquestionably their sole object, although her father was <\p>
supposed always to be present. But, it must likewise be added, there <\p>
was something about Priscilla that calumny could not meddle with; and <\p>
thus far was she privileged, either by the preponderance of what was <\p>
spiritual, or the thin and watery blood that left her cheek so pallid. <\p>
Yet, if the busy tongues of the neighborhood spared Priscilla in one <\p>
way, they made themselves amends by renewed and wilder babble on <\p>
another score. They averred that the strange gentleman was a wizard, <\p>
and that he had taken advantage of Priscilla's lack of earthly <\p>
substance to subject her to himself, as his familiar spirit, through <\p>
whose medium he gained cognizance of whatever happened, in regions near <\p>
or remote. The boundaries of his power were defined by the verge of <\p>
the pit of Tartarus on the one hand, and the third sphere of the <\p>
celestial world on the other. Again, they declared their suspicion <\p>
that the wizard, with all his show of manly beauty, was really an aged <\p>
and wizened figure, or else that his semblance of a human body was only <\p>
a necromantic, or perhaps a mechanical contrivance, in which a demon <\p>
walked about. In proof of it, however, they could merely instance a <\p>
gold band around his upper teeth, which had once been visible to <\p>
several old women, when he smiled at them from the top of the <\p>
governor's staircase. Of course this was all absurdity, or mostly so. <\p>
But, after every possible deduction, there remained certain very <\p>
mysterious points about the stranger's character, as well as the <\p>
connection that he established with Priscilla. Its nature at that <\p>
period was even less understood than now, when miracles of this kind <\p>
have grown so absolutely stale, that I would gladly, if the truth <\p>
allowed, dismiss the whole matter from my narrative. <\p>
We must now glance backward, in quest of the beautiful daughter of <\p>
Fauntleroy's prosperity. What had become of her? Fauntleroy's only <\p>
brother, a bachelor, and with no other relative so near, had adopted <\p>
the forsaken child. She grew up in affluence, with native graces <\p>
clustering luxuriantly about her. In her triumphant progress towards <\p>
womanhood, she was adorned with every variety of feminine <\p>
accomplishment. But she lacked a mother's care. With no adequate <\p>
control, on any hand (for a man, however stern, however wise, can never <\p>
sway and guide a female child), her character was left to shape itself. <\p>
There was good in it, and evil. Passionate, self-willed, and <\p>
imperious, she had a warm and generous nature; showing the richness of <\p>
the soil, however, chiefly by the weeds that flourished in it, and <\p>
choked up the herbs of grace. In her girlhood her uncle died. As <\p>
Fauntleroy was supposed to be likewise dead, and no other heir was <\p>
known to exist, his wealth devolved on her, although, dying suddenly, <\p>
the uncle left no will. After his death there were obscure passages in <\p>
Zenobia's history. There were whispers of an attachment, and even a <\p>
secret marriage, with a fascinating and accomplished but unprincipled <\p>
young man. The incidents and appearances, however, which led to this <\p>
surmise soon passed away, and were forgotten. <\p>
Nor was her reputation seriously affected by the report. In fact, so <\p>
great was her native power and influence, and such seemed the careless <\p>
purity of her nature, that whatever Zenobia did was generally <\p>
acknowledged as right for her to do. The world never criticised her so <\p>
harshly as it does most women who transcend its rules. It almost <\p>
yielded its assent, when it beheld her stepping out of the common path, <\p>
and asserting the more extensive privileges of her sex, both <\p>
theoretically and by her practice. The sphere of ordinary womanhood <\p>
was felt to be narrower than her development required. <\p>
A portion of Zenobia's more recent life is told in the foregoing pages. <\p>
Partly in earnest,--and, I imagine, as was her disposition, half in a <\p>
proud jest, or in a kind of recklessness that had grown upon her, out <\p>
of some hidden grief,--she had given her countenance, and promised <\p>
liberal pecuniary aid, to our experiment of a better social state. And <\p>
Priscilla followed her to Blithedale. The sole bliss of her life had <\p>
been a dream of this beautiful sister, who had never so much as known <\p>
of her existence. By this time, too, the poor girl was enthralled in <\p>
an intolerable bondage, from which she must either free herself or <\p>
perish. She deemed herself safest near Zenobia, into whose large heart <\p>
she hoped to nestle. <\p>
One evening, months after Priscilla's departure, when Moodie (or shall <\p>
we call him Fauntleroy?) was sitting alone in the state-chamber of the <\p>
old governor, there came footsteps up the staircase. There was a pause <\p>
on the landing-place. A lady's musical yet haughty accents were heard <\p>
making an inquiry from some denizen of the house, who had thrust a head <\p>
out of a contiguous chamber. There was then a knock at Moodie's door. <\p>
"Come in!" said he. <\p>
And Zenobia entered. The details of the interview that followed being <\p>
unknown to me,--while, notwithstanding, it would be a pity quite to <\p>
lose the picturesqueness of the situation,--I shall attempt to sketch <\p>
it, mainly from fancy, although with some general grounds of surmise in <\p>
regard to the old man's feelings. <\p>
She gazed wonderingly at the dismal chamber. Dismal to her, who beheld <\p>
it only for an instant; and how much more so to him, into whose brain <\p>
each bare spot on the ceiling, every tatter of the paper-hangings, and <\p>
all the splintered carvings of the mantelpiece, seen wearily through <\p>
long years, had worn their several prints! Inexpressibly miserable is <\p>
this familiarity with objects that have been from the first disgustful. <\p>
"I have received a strange message," said Zenobia, after a moment's <\p>
silence, "requesting, or rather enjoining it upon me, to come hither. <\p>
Rather from curiosity than any other motive,--and because, though a <\p>
woman, I have not all the timidity of one,--I have complied. Can it be <\p>
you, sir, who thus summoned me?" <\p>
"It was," answered Moodie. <\p>
"And what was your purpose?" she continued. "You require charity, <\p>
perhaps? In that case, the message might have been more fitly worded. <\p>
But you are old and poor, and age and poverty should be allowed their <\p>
privileges. Tell me, therefore, to what extent you need my aid." <\p>
"Put up your purse," said the supposed mendicant, with an inexplicable <\p>
smile. "Keep it,--keep all your wealth,--until I demand it all, or <\p>
none! My message had no such end in view. You are beautiful, they <\p>
tell me; and I desired to look at you." <\p>
He took the one lamp that showed the discomfort and sordidness of his <\p>
abode, and approaching Zenobia held it up, so as to gain the more <\p>
perfect view of her, from top to toe. So obscure was the chamber, that <\p>
you could see the reflection of her diamonds thrown upon the dingy <\p>
wall, and flickering with the rise and fall of Zenobia's breath. It was <\p>
the splendor of those jewels on her neck, like lamps that burn before <\p>
some fair temple, and the jewelled flower in her hair, more than the <\p>
murky, yellow light, that helped him to see her beauty. But he beheld <\p>
it, and grew proud at heart; his own figure, in spite of his mean <\p>
habiliments, assumed an air of state and grandeur. <\p>
"It is well," cried old Moodie. "Keep your wealth. You are right <\p>
worthy of it. Keep it, therefore, but with one condition only." <\p>
Zenobia thought the old man beside himself, and was moved with pity. <\p>
"Have you none to care for you?" asked she. "No daughter?--no <\p>
kind-hearted neighbor?--no means of procuring the attendance which you <\p>
need? Tell me once again, can I do nothing for you?" <\p>
"Nothing," he replied. "I have beheld what I wished. Now leave me. <\p>
Linger not a moment longer, or I may be tempted to say what would bring <\p>
a cloud over that queenly brow. Keep all your wealth, but with only <\p>
this one condition: Be kind--be no less kind than sisters are--to my <\p>
poor Priscilla!" <\p>
And, it may be, after Zenobia withdrew, Fauntleroy paced his gloomy <\p>
chamber, and communed with himself as follows,--or, at all events, it <\p>
is the only solution which I can offer of the enigma presented in his <\p>
character:--"I am unchanged,--the same man as of yore!" said he. "True, <\p>
my brother's wealth--he dying intestate--is legally my own. I know it; <\p>
yet of my own choice, I live a beggar, and go meanly clad, and hide <\p>
myself behind a forgotten ignominy. Looks this like ostentation? Ah! <\p>
but in Zenobia I live again! Beholding her, so beautiful,--so fit to <\p>
be adorned with all imaginable splendor of outward state,--the cursed <\p>
vanity, which, half a lifetime since, dropt off like tatters of once <\p>
gaudy apparel from my debased and ruined person, is all renewed for her <\p>
sake. Were I to reappear, my shame would go with me from darkness into <\p>
daylight. Zenobia has the splendor, and not the shame. Let the world <\p>
admire her, and be dazzled by her, the brilliant child of my <\p>
prosperity! It is Fauntleroy that still shines through her!" But <\p>
then, perhaps, another thought occurred to him. <\p>
"My poor Priscilla! And am I just to her, in surrendering all to this <\p>
beautiful Zenobia? Priscilla! I love her best,--I love her only!--but <\p>
with shame, not pride. So dim, so pallid, so shrinking,--the daughter <\p>
of my long calamity! Wealth were but a mockery in Priscilla's hands. <\p>
What is its use, except to fling a golden radiance around those who <\p>
grasp it? Yet let Zenobia take heed! Priscilla shall have no wrong!" <\p>
But, while the man of show thus meditated,--that very evening, so far <\p>
as I can adjust the dates of these strange incidents,--Priscilla poor, <\p>
pallid flower!--was either snatched from Zenobia's hand, or flung <\p>
wilfully away! <\p>
XXIII. A VILLAGE HALL <\p>
Well, I betook myself away, and wandered up and down, like an exorcised <\p>
spirit that had been driven from its old haunts after a mighty <\p>
struggle. It takes down the solitary pride of man, beyond most other <\p>
things, to find the impracticability of flinging aside affections that <\p>
have grown irksome. The bands that were silken once are apt to become <\p>
iron fetters when we desire to shake them off. Our souls, after all, <\p>
are not our own. We convey a property in them to those with whom we <\p>
associate; but to what extent can never be known, until we feel the <\p>
tug, the agony, of our abortive effort to resume an exclusive sway over <\p>
ourselves. Thus, in all the weeks of my absence, my thoughts <\p>
continually reverted back, brooding over the bygone months, and <\p>
bringing up incidents that seemed hardly to have left a trace of <\p>
themselves in their passage. I spent painful hours in recalling these <\p>
trifles, and rendering them more misty and unsubstantial than at first <\p>
by the quantity of speculative musing thus kneaded in with them. <\p>
Hollingsworth, Zenobia, Priscilla! These three had absorbed my life <\p>
into themselves. Together with an inexpressible longing to know their <\p>
fortunes, there was likewise a morbid resentment of my own pain, and a <\p>
stubborn reluctance to come again within their sphere. <\p>
All that I learned of them, therefore, was comprised in a few brief and <\p>
pungent squibs, such as the newspapers were then in the habit of <\p>
bestowing on our socialist enterprise. There was one paragraph, which <\p>
if I rightly guessed its purport bore reference to Zenobia, but was too <\p>
darkly hinted to convey even thus much of certainty. Hollingsworth, <\p>
too, with his philanthropic project, afforded the penny-a-liners a <\p>
theme for some savage and bloody minded jokes; and, considerably to my <\p>
surprise, they affected me with as much indignation as if we had still <\p>
been friends. <\p>
Thus passed several weeks; time long enough for my brown and <\p>
toil-hardened hands to reaccustom themselves to gloves. Old habits, <\p>
such as were merely external, returned upon me with wonderful <\p>
promptitude. My superficial talk, too, assumed altogether a worldly <\p>
tone. Meeting former acquaintances, who showed themselves inclined to <\p>
ridicule my heroic devotion to the cause of human welfare, I spoke of <\p>
the recent phase of my life as indeed fair matter for a jest. But, I <\p>
also gave them to understand that it was, at most, only an experiment, <\p>
on which I had staked no valuable amount of hope or fear. It had <\p>
enabled me to pass the summer in a novel and agreeable way, had <\p>
afforded me some grotesque specimens of artificial simplicity, and <\p>
could not, therefore, so far as I was concerned, be reckoned a failure. <\p>
In no one instance, however, did I voluntarily speak of my three <\p>
friends. They dwelt in a profounder region. The more I consider <\p>
myself as I then was, the more do I recognize how deeply my connection <\p>
with those three had affected all my being. <\p>
As it was already the epoch of annihilated space, I might in the time I <\p>
was away from Blithedale have snatched a glimpse at England, and been <\p>
back again. But my wanderings were confined within a very limited <\p>
sphere. I hopped and fluttered, like a bird with a string about its <\p>
leg, gyrating round a small circumference, and keeping up a restless <\p>
activity to no purpose. Thus it was still in our familiar <\p>
Massachusetts--in one of its white country villages--that I must next <\p>
particularize an incident. <\p>
The scene was one of those lyceum halls, of which almost every village <\p>
has now its own, dedicated to that sober and pallid, or rather <\p>
drab-colored, mode of winter-evening entertainment, the lecture. Of <\p>
late years this has come strangely into vogue, when the natural <\p>
tendency of things would seem to be to substitute lettered for oral <\p>
methods of addressing the public. But, in halls like this, besides the <\p>
winter course of lectures, there is a rich and varied series of other <\p>
exhibitions. Hither comes the ventriloquist, with all his mysterious <\p>
tongues; the thaumaturgist, too, with his miraculous transformations of <\p>
plates, doves, and rings, his pancakes smoking in your hat, and his <\p>
cellar of choice liquors represented in one small bottle. Here, also, <\p>
the itinerant professor instructs separate classes of ladies and <\p>
gentlemen in physiology, and demonstrates his lessons by the aid of <\p>
real skeletons, and manikins in wax, from Paris. Here is to be heard <\p>
the choir of Ethiopian melodists, and to be seen the diorama of Moscow <\p>
or Bunker Hill, or the moving panorama of the Chinese wall. Here is <\p>
displayed the museum of wax figures, illustrating the wide catholicism <\p>
of earthly renown, by mixing up heroes and statesmen, the pope and the <\p>
Mormon prophet, kings, queens, murderers, and beautiful ladies; every <\p>
sort of person, in short, except authors, of whom I never beheld even <\p>
the most famous done in wax. And here, in this many-purposed hall <\p>
(unless the selectmen of the village chance to have more than their <\p>
share of the Puritanism, which, however diversified with later <\p>
patchwork, still gives its prevailing tint to New England <\p>
character),--here the company of strolling players sets up its little <\p>
stage, and claims patronage for the legitimate drama. <\p>
But, on the autumnal evening which I speak of, a number of printed <\p>
handbills--stuck up in the bar-room, and on the sign-post of the hotel, <\p>
and on the meeting-house porch, and distributed largely through the <\p>
village--had promised the inhabitants an interview with that celebrated <\p>
and hitherto inexplicable phenomenon, the Veiled Lady! <\p>
The hall was fitted up with an amphitheatrical descent of seats towards <\p>
a platform, on which stood a desk, two lights, a stool, and a capacious <\p>
antique chair. The audience was of a generally decent and respectable <\p>
character: old farmers, in their Sunday black coats, with shrewd, hard, <\p>
sun-dried faces, and a cynical humor, oftener than any other <\p>
expression, in their eyes; pretty girls, in many-colored attire; pretty <\p>
young men,--the schoolmaster, the lawyer, or student at law, the <\p>
shop-keeper,--all looking rather suburban than rural. In these days, <\p>
there is absolutely no rusticity, except when the actual labor of the <\p>
soil leaves its earth-mould on the person. There was likewise a <\p>
considerable proportion of young and middle-aged women, many of them <\p>
stern in feature, with marked foreheads, and a very definite line of <\p>
eyebrow; a type of womanhood in which a bold intellectual development <\p>
seems to be keeping pace with the progressive delicacy of the physical <\p>
constitution. Of all these people I took note, at first, according to <\p>
my custom. But I ceased to do so the moment that my eyes fell on an <\p>
individual who sat two or three seats below me, immovable, apparently <\p>
deep in thought, with his back, of course, towards me, and his face <\p>
turned steadfastly upon the platform. <\p>
After sitting awhile in contemplation of this person's familiar <\p>
contour, I was irresistibly moved to step over the intervening benches, <\p>
lay my hand on his shoulder, put my mouth close to his ear, and address <\p>
him in a sepulchral, melodramatic whisper: "Hollingsworth! where have <\p>
you left Zenobia?" <\p>
His nerves, however, were proof against my attack. He turned half <\p>
around, and looked me in the face with great sad eyes, in which there <\p>
was neither kindness nor resentment, nor any perceptible surprise. <\p>
"Zenobia, when I last saw her," he answered, "was at Blithedale." <\p>
He said no more. But there was a great deal of talk going on near me, <\p>
among a knot of people who might be considered as representing the <\p>
mysticism, or rather the mystic sensuality, of this singular age. The <\p>
nature of the exhibition that was about to take place had probably <\p>
given the turn to their conversation. <\p>
I heard, from a pale man in blue spectacles, some stranger stories than <\p>
ever were written in a romance; told, too, with a simple, unimaginative <\p>
steadfastness, which was terribly efficacious in compelling the auditor <\p>
to receive them into the category of established facts. He cited <\p>
instances of the miraculous power of one human being over the will and <\p>
passions of another; insomuch that settled grief was but a shadow <\p>
beneath the influence of a man possessing this potency, and the strong <\p>
love of years melted away like a vapor. At the bidding of one of these <\p>
wizards, the maiden, with her lover's kiss still burning on her lips, <\p>
would turn from him with icy indifference; the newly made widow would <\p>
dig up her buried heart out of her young husband's grave before the <\p>
sods had taken root upon it; a mother with her babe's milk in her bosom <\p>
would thrust away her child. Human character was but soft wax in his <\p>
hands; and guilt, or virtue, only the forms into which he should see <\p>
fit to mould it. The religious sentiment was a flame which he could <\p>
blow up with his breath, or a spark that he could utterly extinguish. <\p>
It is unutterable, the horror and disgust with which I listened, and <\p>
saw that, if these things were to be believed, the individual soul was <\p>
virtually annihilated, and all that is sweet and pure in our present <\p>
life debased, and that the idea of man's eternal responsibility was <\p>
made ridiculous, and immortality rendered at once impossible, and not <\p>
worth acceptance. But I would have perished on the spot sooner than <\p>
believe it. <\p>
The epoch of rapping spirits, and all the wonders that have followed in <\p>
their train,--such as tables upset by invisible agencies, bells <\p>
self-tolled at funerals, and ghostly music performed on <\p>
jew's-harps,--had not yet arrived. Alas, my countrymen, methinks we <\p>
have fallen on an evil age! If these phenomena have not humbug at the <\p>
bottom, so much the worse for us. What can they indicate, in a <\p>
spiritual way, except that the soul of man is descending to a lower <\p>
point than it has ever before reached while incarnate? We are pursuing <\p>
a downward course in the eternal march, and thus bring ourselves into <\p>
the same range with beings whom death, in requital of their gross and <\p>
evil lives, has degraded below humanity! To hold intercourse with <\p>
spirits of this order, we must stoop and grovel in some element more <\p>
vile than earthly dust. These goblins, if they exist at all, are but <\p>
the shadows of past mortality, outcasts, mere refuse stuff, adjudged <\p>
unworthy of the eternal world, and, on the most favorable supposition, <\p>
dwindling gradually into nothingness. The less we have to say to them <\p>
the better, lest we share their fate! <\p>
The audience now began to be impatient; they signified their desire for <\p>
the entertainment to commence by thump of sticks and stamp of <\p>
boot-heels. Nor was it a great while longer before, in response to <\p>
their call, there appeared a bearded personage in Oriental robes, <\p>
looking like one of the enchanters of the Arabian Nights. He came upon <\p>
the platform from a side door, saluted the spectators, not with a <\p>
salaam, but a bow, took his station at the desk, and first blowing his <\p>
nose with a white handkerchief, prepared to speak. The environment of <\p>
the homely village hall, and the absence of many ingenious contrivances <\p>
of stage effect with which the exhibition had heretofore been set off, <\p>
seemed to bring the artifice of this character more openly upon the <\p>
surface. No sooner did I behold the bearded enchanter, than, laying my <\p>
hand again on Hollingsworth's shoulder, I whispered in his ear, "Do you <\p>
know him?" <\p>
"I never saw the man before," he muttered, without turning his head. <\p>
But I had seen him three times already. <\p>
Once, on occasion of my first visit to the Veiled Lady; a second time, <\p>
in the wood-path at Blithedale; and lastly, in Zenobia's drawing-room. <\p>
It was Westervelt. A quick association of ideas made me shudder from <\p>
head to foot; and again, like an evil spirit, bringing up reminiscences <\p>
of a man's sins, I whispered a question in Hollingsworth's ear,--"What <\p>
have you done with Priscilla?" <\p>
He gave a convulsive start, as if I had thrust a knife into him, <\p>
writhed himself round on his seat, glared fiercely into my eyes, but <\p>
answered not a word. <\p>
The Professor began his discourse, explanatory of the psychological <\p>
phenomena, as he termed them, which it was his purpose to exhibit to <\p>
the spectators. There remains no very distinct impression of it on my <\p>
memory. It was eloquent, ingenious, plausible, with a delusive show of <\p>
spirituality, yet really imbued throughout with a cold and dead <\p>
materialism. I shivered, as at a current of chill air issuing out of a <\p>
sepulchral vault, and bringing the smell of corruption along with it. <\p>
He spoke of a new era that was dawning upon the world; an era that <\p>
would link soul to soul, and the present life to what we call futurity, <\p>
with a closeness that should finally convert both worlds into one <\p>
great, mutually conscious brotherhood. He described (in a strange, <\p>
philosophical guise, with terms of art, as if it were a matter of <\p>
chemical discovery) the agency by which this mighty result was to be <\p>
effected; nor would it have surprised me, had he pretended to hold up a <\p>
portion of his universally pervasive fluid, as he affirmed it to be, in <\p>
a glass phial. <\p>
At the close of his exordium, the Professor beckoned with his <\p>
hand,--once, twice, thrice,--and a figure came gliding upon the <\p>
platform, enveloped in a long veil of silvery whiteness. It fell about <\p>
her like the texture of a summer cloud, with a kind of vagueness, so <\p>
that the outline of the form beneath it could not be accurately <\p>
discerned. But the movement of the Veiled Lady was graceful, free, and <\p>
unembarrassed, like that of a person accustomed to be the spectacle of <\p>
thousands; or, possibly, a blindfold prisoner within the sphere with <\p>
which this dark earthly magician had surrounded her, she was wholly <\p>
unconscious of being the central object to all those straining eyes. <\p>
Pliant to his gesture (which had even an obsequious courtesy, but at <\p>
the same time a remarkable decisiveness), the figure placed itself in <\p>
the great chair. Sitting there, in such visible obscurity, it was, <\p>
perhaps, as much like the actual presence of a disembodied spirit as <\p>
anything that stage trickery could devise. The hushed breathing of the <\p>
spectators proved how high-wrought were their anticipations of the <\p>
wonders to be performed through the medium of this incomprehensible <\p>
creature. I, too, was in breathless suspense, but with a far different <\p>
presentiment of some strange event at hand. <\p>
"You see before you the Veiled Lady," said the bearded Professor, <\p>
advancing to the verge of the platform. "By the agency of which I have <\p>
just spoken, she is at this moment in communion with the spiritual <\p>
world. That silvery veil is, in one sense, an enchantment, having been <\p>
dipped, as it were, and essentially imbued, through the potency of my <\p>
art, with the fluid medium of spirits. Slight and ethereal as it <\p>
seems, the limitations of time and space have no existence within its <\p>
folds. This hall--these hundreds of faces, encompassing her within so <\p>
narrow an amphitheatre--are of thinner substance, in her view, than the <\p>
airiest vapor that the clouds are made of. She beholds the Absolute!" <\p>
As preliminary to other and far more wonderful psychological <\p>
experiments, the exhibitor suggested that some of his auditors should <\p>
endeavor to make the Veiled Lady sensible of their presence by such <\p>
methods--provided only no touch were laid upon her person--as they <\p>
might deem best adapted to that end. Accordingly, several deep-lunged <\p>
country fellows, who looked as if they might have blown the apparition <\p>
away with a breath, ascended the platform. Mutually encouraging one <\p>
another, they shouted so close to her ear that the veil stirred like a <\p>
wreath of vanishing mist; they smote upon the floor with bludgeons; <\p>
they perpetrated so hideous a clamor, that methought it might have <\p>
reached, at least, a little way into the eternal sphere. Finally, with <\p>
the assent of the Professor, they laid hold of the great chair, and <\p>
were startled, apparently, to find it soar upward, as if lighter than <\p>
the air through which it rose. But the Veiled Lady remained seated and <\p>
motionless, with a composure that was hardly less than awful, because <\p>
implying so immeasurable a distance betwixt her and these rude <\p>
persecutors. <\p>
"These efforts are wholly without avail," observed the Professor, who <\p>
had been looking on with an aspect of serene indifference. "The roar <\p>
of a battery of cannon would be inaudible to the Veiled Lady. And yet, <\p>
were I to will it, sitting in this very hall, she could hear the desert <\p>
wind sweeping over the sands as far off as Arabia; the icebergs <\p>
grinding one against the other in the polar seas; the rustle of a leaf <\p>
in an East Indian forest; the lowest whispered breath of the <\p>
bashfullest maiden in the world, uttering the first confession of her <\p>
love. Nor does there exist the moral inducement, apart from my own <\p>
behest, that could persuade her to lift the silvery veil, or arise out <\p>
of that chair." <\p>
Greatly to the Professor's discomposure, however, just as he spoke <\p>
these words, the Veiled Lady arose. There was a mysterious tremor that <\p>
shook the magic veil. The spectators, it may be, imagined that she was <\p>
about to take flight into that invisible sphere, and to the society of <\p>
those purely spiritual beings with whom they reckoned her so near akin. <\p>
Hollingsworth, a moment ago, had mounted the platform, and now stood <\p>
gazing at the figure, with a sad intentness that brought the whole <\p>
power of his great, stern, yet tender soul into his glance. <\p>
"Come," said he, waving his hand towards her. "You are safe!" <\p>
She threw off the veil, and stood before that multitude of people pale, <\p>
tremulous, shrinking, as if only then had she discovered that a <\p>
thousand eyes were gazing at her. Poor maiden! How strangely had she <\p>
been betrayed! Blazoned abroad as a wonder of the world, and <\p>
performing what were adjudged as miracles,--in the faith of many, a <\p>
seeress and a prophetess; in the harsher judgment of others, a <\p>
mountebank,--she had kept, as I religiously believe, her virgin reserve <\p>
and sanctity of soul throughout it all. Within that encircling veil, <\p>
though an evil hand had flung it over her, there was as deep a <\p>
seclusion as if this forsaken girl had, all the while, been sitting <\p>
under the shadow of Eliot's pulpit, in the Blithedale woods, at the <\p>
feet of him who now summoned her to the shelter of his arms. And the <\p>
true heart-throb of a woman's affection was too powerful for the <\p>
jugglery that had hitherto environed her. She uttered a shriek, and <\p>
fled to Hollingsworth, like one escaping from her deadliest enemy, and <\p>
was safe forever. <\p>
XXIV. THE MASQUERADERS <\p>
Two nights had passed since the foregoing occurrences, when, in a <\p>
breezy September forenoon, I set forth from town, on foot, towards <\p>
Blithedale. It was the most delightful of all days for a walk, with a <\p>
dash of invigorating ice-temper in the air, but a coolness that soon <\p>
gave place to the brisk glow of exercise, while the vigor remained as <\p>
elastic as before. The atmosphere had a spirit and sparkle in it. <\p>
Each breath was like a sip of ethereal wine, tempered, as I said, with <\p>
a crystal lump of ice. I had started on this expedition in an <\p>
exceedingly sombre mood, as well befitted one who found himself tending <\p>
towards home, but was conscious that nobody would be quite overjoyed to <\p>
greet him there. My feet were hardly off the pavement, however, when <\p>
this morbid sensation began to yield to the lively influences of air <\p>
and motion. Nor had I gone far, with fields yet green on either side, <\p>
before my step became as swift and light as if Hollingsworth were <\p>
waiting to exchange a friendly hand-grip, and Zenobia's and Priscilla's <\p>
open arms would welcome the wanderer's reappearance. It has happened <\p>
to me on other occasions, as well as this, to prove how a state of <\p>
physical well-being can create a kind of joy, in spite of the <\p>
profoundest anxiety of mind. <\p>
The pathway of that walk still runs along, with sunny freshness, <\p>
through my memory. I know not why it should be so. But my mental eye <\p>
can even now discern the September grass, bordering the pleasant <\p>
roadside with a brighter verdure than while the summer heats were <\p>
scorching it; the trees, too, mostly green, although here and there a <\p>
branch or shrub has donned its vesture of crimson and gold a week or <\p>
two before its fellows. I see the tufted barberry-bushes, with their <\p>
small clusters of scarlet fruit; the toadstools, likewise,--some <\p>
spotlessly white, others yellow or red,--mysterious growths, springing <\p>
suddenly from no root or seed, and growing nobody can tell how or <\p>
wherefore. In this respect they resembled many of the emotions in my <\p>
breast. And I still see the little rivulets, chill, clear, and bright, <\p>
that murmured beneath the road, through subterranean rocks, and <\p>
deepened into mossy pools, where tiny fish were darting to and fro, and <\p>
within which lurked the hermit frog. But no,--I never can account for <\p>
it, that, with a yearning interest to learn the upshot of all my story, <\p>
and returning to Blithedale for that sole purpose, I should examine <\p>
these things so like a peaceful-bosomed naturalist. Nor why, amid all <\p>
my sympathies and fears, there shot, at times, a wild exhilaration <\p>
through my frame. <\p>
Thus I pursued my way along the line of the ancient stone wall that <\p>
Paul Dudley built, and through white villages, and past orchards of <\p>
ruddy apples, and fields of ripening maize, and patches of woodland, <\p>
and all such sweet rural scenery as looks the fairest, a little beyond <\p>
the suburbs of a town. Hollingsworth, Zenobia, Priscilla! They glided <\p>
mistily before me, as I walked. Sometimes, in my solitude, I laughed <\p>
with the bitterness of self-scorn, remembering how unreservedly I had <\p>
given up my heart and soul to interests that were not mine. What had I <\p>
ever had to do with them? And why, being now free, should I take this <\p>
thraldom on me once again? It was both sad and dangerous, I whispered <\p>
to myself, to be in too close affinity with the passions, the errors, <\p>
and the misfortunes of individuals who stood within a circle of their <\p>
own, into which, if I stept at all, it must be as an intruder, and at a <\p>
peril that I could not estimate. <\p>
Drawing nearer to Blithedale, a sickness of the spirits kept <\p>
alternating with my flights of causeless buoyancy. I indulged in a <\p>
hundred odd and extravagant conjectures. Either there was no such <\p>
place as Blithedale, nor ever had been, nor any brotherhood of <\p>
thoughtful laborers, like what I seemed to recollect there, or else it <\p>
was all changed during my absence. It had been nothing but dream work <\p>
and enchantment. I should seek in vain for the old farmhouse, and for <\p>
the greensward, the potato-fields, the root-crops, and acres of Indian <\p>
corn, and for all that configuration of the land which I had imagined. <\p>
It would be another spot, and an utter strangeness. <\p>
These vagaries were of the spectral throng so apt to steal out of an <\p>
unquiet heart. They partly ceased to haunt me, on my arriving at a <\p>
point whence, through the trees, I began to catch glimpses of the <\p>
Blithedale farm. That surely was something real. There was hardly a <\p>
square foot of all those acres on which I had not trodden heavily, in <\p>
one or another kind of toil. The curse of Adam's posterity--and, curse <\p>
or blessing be it, it gives substance to the life around us--had first <\p>
come upon me there. In the sweat of my brow I had there earned bread <\p>
and eaten it, and so established my claim to be on earth, and my <\p>
fellowship with all the sons of labor. I could have knelt down, and <\p>
have laid my breast against that soil. The red clay of which my frame <\p>
was moulded seemed nearer akin to those crumbling furrows than to any <\p>
other portion of the world's dust. There was my home, and there might <\p>
be my grave. <\p>
I felt an invincible reluctance, nevertheless, at the idea of <\p>
presenting myself before my old associates, without first ascertaining <\p>
the state in which they were. A nameless foreboding weighed upon me. <\p>
Perhaps, should I know all the circumstances that had occurred, I might <\p>
find it my wisest course to turn back, unrecognized, unseen, and never <\p>
look at Blithedale more. Had it been evening, I would have stolen <\p>
softly to some lighted window of the old farmhouse, and peeped darkling <\p>
in, to see all their well-known faces round the supper-board. Then, <\p>
were there a vacant seat, I might noiselessly unclose the door, glide <\p>
in, and take my place among them, without a word. My entrance might be <\p>
so quiet, my aspect so familiar, that they would forget how long I had <\p>
been away, and suffer me to melt into the scene, as a wreath of vapor <\p>
melts into a larger cloud. I dreaded a boisterous greeting. Beholding <\p>
me at table, Zenobia, as a matter of course, would send me a cup of <\p>
tea, and Hollingsworth fill my plate from the great dish of pandowdy, <\p>
and Priscilla, in her quiet way, would hand the cream, and others help <\p>
me to the bread and butter. Being one of them again, the knowledge of <\p>
what had happened would come to me without a shock. For still, at <\p>
every turn of my shifting fantasies, the thought stared me in the face <\p>
that some evil thing had befallen us, or was ready to befall. <\p>
Yielding to this ominous impression, I now turned aside into the woods, <\p>
resolving to spy out the posture of the Community as craftily as the <\p>
wild Indian before he makes his onset. I would go wandering about the <\p>
outskirts of the farm, and, perhaps, catching sight of a solitary <\p>
acquaintance, would approach him amid the brown shadows of the trees (a <\p>
kind of medium fit for spirits departed and revisitant, like myself), <\p>
and entreat him to tell me how all things were. <\p>
The first living creature that I met was a partridge, which sprung up <\p>
beneath my feet, and whirred away; the next was a squirrel, who <\p>
chattered angrily at me from an overhanging bough. I trod along by the <\p>
dark, sluggish river, and remember pausing on the bank, above one of <\p>
its blackest and most placid pools (the very spot, with the barkless <\p>
stump of a tree aslantwise over the water, is depicting itself to my <\p>
fancy at this instant), and wondering how deep it was, and if any <\p>
overladen soul had ever flung its weight of mortality in thither, and <\p>
if it thus escaped the burden, or only made it heavier. And perhaps the <\p>
skeleton of the drowned wretch still lay beneath the inscrutable depth, <\p>
clinging to some sunken log at the bottom with the gripe of its old <\p>
despair. So slight, however, was the track of these gloomy ideas, that <\p>
I soon forgot them in the contemplation of a brood of wild ducks, which <\p>
were floating on the river, and anon took flight, leaving each a bright <\p>
streak over the black surface. By and by, I came to my hermitage, in <\p>
the heart of the white-pine tree, and clambering up into it, sat down <\p>
to rest. The grapes, which I had watched throughout the summer, now <\p>
dangled around me in abundant clusters of the deepest purple, <\p>
deliciously sweet to the taste, and, though wild, yet free from that <\p>
ungentle flavor which distinguishes nearly all our native and <\p>
uncultivated grapes. Methought a wine might be pressed out of them <\p>
possessing a passionate zest, and endowed with a new kind of <\p>
intoxicating quality, attended with such bacchanalian ecstasies as the <\p>
tamer grapes of Madeira, France, and the Rhine are inadequate to <\p>
produce. And I longed to quaff a great goblet of it that moment! <\p>
While devouring the grapes, I looked on all sides out of the peep-holes <\p>
of my hermitage, and saw the farmhouse, the fields, and almost every <\p>
part of our domain, but not a single human figure in the landscape. <\p>
Some of the windows of the house were open, but with no more signs of <\p>
life than in a dead man's unshut eyes. The barn-door was ajar, and <\p>
swinging in the breeze. The big old dog,--he was a relic of the former <\p>
dynasty of the farm,--that hardly ever stirred out of the yard, was <\p>
nowhere to be seen. What, then, had become of all the fraternity and <\p>
sisterhood? Curious to ascertain this point, I let myself down out of <\p>
the tree, and going to the edge of the wood, was glad to perceive our <\p>
herd of cows chewing the cud or grazing not far off. I fancied, by <\p>
their manner, that two or three of them recognized me (as, indeed, they <\p>
ought, for I had milked them and been their chamberlain times without <\p>
number); but, after staring me in the face a little while, they <\p>
phlegmatically began grazing and chewing their cuds again. Then I grew <\p>
foolishly angry at so cold a reception, and flung some rotten fragments <\p>
of an old stump at these unsentimental cows. <\p>
Skirting farther round the pasture, I heard voices and much laughter <\p>
proceeding from the interior of the wood. Voices, male and feminine; <\p>
laughter, not only of fresh young throats, but the bass of grown <\p>
people, as if solemn organ-pipes should pour out airs of merriment. Not <\p>
a voice spoke, but I knew it better than my own; not a laugh, but its <\p>
cadences were familiar. The wood, in this portion of it, seemed as <\p>
full of jollity as if Comus and his crew were holding their revels in <\p>
one of its usually lonesome glades. Stealing onward as far as I durst, <\p>
without hazard of discovery, I saw a concourse of strange figures <\p>
beneath the overshadowing branches. They appeared, and vanished, and <\p>
came again, confusedly with the streaks of sunlight glimmering down <\p>
upon them. <\p>
Among them was an Indian chief, with blanket, feathers, and war-paint, <\p>
and uplifted tomahawk; and near him, looking fit to be his woodland <\p>
bride, the goddess Diana, with the crescent on her head, and attended <\p>
by our big lazy dog, in lack of any fleeter hound. Drawing an arrow <\p>
from her quiver, she let it fly at a venture, and hit the very tree <\p>
behind which I happened to be lurking. Another group consisted of a <\p>
Bavarian broom-girl, a negro of the Jim Crow order, one or two <\p>
foresters of the Middle Ages, a Kentucky woodsman in his trimmed <\p>
hunting-shirt and deerskin leggings, and a Shaker elder, quaint, <\p>
demure, broad-brimmed, and square-skirted. Shepherds of Arcadia, and <\p>
allegoric figures from the "Faerie Queen," were oddly mixed up with <\p>
these. Arm in arm, or otherwise huddled together in strange <\p>
discrepancy, stood grim Puritans, gay Cavaliers, and Revolutionary <\p>
officers with three-cornered cocked hats, and queues longer than their <\p>
swords. A bright-complexioned, dark-haired, vivacious little gypsy, <\p>
with a red shawl over her head, went from one group to another, telling <\p>
fortunes by palmistry; and Moll Pitcher, the renowned old witch of <\p>
Lynn, broomstick in hand, showed herself prominently in the midst, as <\p>
if announcing all these apparitions to be the offspring of her <\p>
necromantic art. But Silas Foster, who leaned against a tree near by, <\p>
in his customary blue frock and smoking a short pipe, did more to <\p>
disenchant the scene, with his look of shrewd, acrid, Yankee <\p>
observation, than twenty witches and necromancers could have done in <\p>
the way of rendering it weird and fantastic. <\p>
A little farther off, some old-fashioned skinkers and drawers, all with <\p>
portentously red noses, were spreading a banquet on the leaf-strewn <\p>
earth; while a horned and long-tailed gentleman (in whom I recognized <\p>
the fiendish musician erst seen by Tam O'Shanter) tuned his fiddle, and <\p>
summoned the whole motley rout to a dance, before partaking of the <\p>
festal cheer. So they joined hands in a circle, whirling round so <\p>
swiftly, so madly, and so merrily, in time and tune with the Satanic <\p>
music, that their separate incongruities were blended all together, and <\p>
they became a kind of entanglement that went nigh to turn one's brain <\p>
with merely looking at it. Anon they stopt all of a sudden, and <\p>
staring at one another's figures, set up a roar of laughter; whereat a <\p>
shower of the September leaves (which, all day long, had been <\p>
hesitating whether to fall or no) were shaken off by the movement of <\p>
the air, and came eddying down upon the revellers. <\p>
Then, for lack of breath, ensued a silence, at the deepest point of <\p>
which, tickled by the oddity of surprising my grave associates in this <\p>
masquerading trim, I could not possibly refrain from a burst of <\p>
laughter on my own separate account. <\p>
"Hush!" I heard the pretty gypsy fortuneteller say. "Who is that <\p>
laughing?" <\p>
"Some profane intruder!" said the goddess Diana. "I shall send an <\p>
arrow through his heart, or change him into a stag, as I did Actaeon, <\p>
if he peeps from behind the trees!" <\p>
"Me take his scalp!" cried the Indian chief, brandishing his tomahawk, <\p>
and cutting a great caper in the air. <\p>
"I'll root him in the earth with a spell that I have at my tongue's <\p>
end!" squeaked Moll Pitcher. "And the green moss shall grow all over <\p>
him, before he gets free again!" <\p>
"The voice was Miles Coverdale's," said the fiendish fiddler, with a <\p>
whisk of his tail and a toss of his horns. "My music has brought him <\p>
hither. He is always ready to dance to the Devil's tune!" <\p>
Thus put on the right track, they all recognized the voice at once, and <\p>
set up a simultaneous shout. <\p>
"Miles! Miles! Miles Coverdale, where are you?" they cried. "Zenobia! <\p>
Queen Zenobia! here is one of your vassals lurking in the wood. <\p>
Command him to approach and pay his duty!" <\p>
The whole fantastic rabble forthwith streamed off in pursuit of me, so <\p>
that I was like a mad poet hunted by chimeras. Having fairly the start <\p>
of them, however, I succeeded in making my escape, and soon left their <\p>
merriment and riot at a good distance in the rear. Its fainter tones <\p>
assumed a kind of mournfulness, and were finally lost in the hush and <\p>
solemnity of the wood. In my haste, I stumbled over a heap of logs and <\p>
sticks that had been cut for firewood, a great while ago, by some <\p>
former possessor of the soil, and piled up square, in order to be <\p>
carted or sledded away to the farmhouse. But, being forgotten, they <\p>
had lain there perhaps fifty years, and possibly much longer; until, by <\p>
the accumulation of moss, and the leaves falling over them, and <\p>
decaying there, from autumn to autumn, a green mound was formed, in <\p>
which the softened outline of the woodpile was still perceptible. In <\p>
the fitful mood that then swayed my mind, I found something strangely <\p>
