affecting in this simple circumstance. I imagined the long-dead <\p>
woodman, and his long-dead wife and children, coming out of their chill <\p>
graves, and essaying to make a fire with this heap of mossy fuel! <\p>
From this spot I strayed onward, quite lost in reverie, and neither <\p>
knew nor cared whither I was going, until a low, soft, well-remembered <\p>
voice spoke, at a little distance. <\p>
"There is Mr. Coverdale!" <\p>
"Miles Coverdale!" said another voice,--and its tones were very stern. <\p>
"Let him come forward, then!" <\p>
"Yes, Mr. Coverdale," cried a woman's voice,--clear and melodious, but, <\p>
just then, with something unnatural in its chord,--"you are welcome! <\p>
But you come half an hour too late, and have missed a scene which you <\p>
would have enjoyed!" <\p>
I looked up and found myself nigh Eliot's pulpit, at the base of which <\p>
sat Hollingsworth, with Priscilla at his feet and Zenobia standing <\p>
before them. <\p>
XXV. THE THREE TOGETHER <\p>
Hollingsworth was in his ordinary working-dress. Priscilla wore a <\p>
pretty and simple gown, with a kerchief about her neck, and a calash, <\p>
which she had flung back from her head, leaving it suspended by the <\p>
strings. But Zenobia (whose part among the maskers, as may be <\p>
supposed, was no inferior one) appeared in a costume of fanciful <\p>
magnificence, with her jewelled flower as the central ornament of what <\p>
resembled a leafy crown, or coronet. She represented the Oriental <\p>
princess by whose name we were accustomed to know her. Her attitude <\p>
was free and noble; yet, if a queen's, it was not that of a queen <\p>
triumphant, but dethroned, on trial for her life, or, perchance, <\p>
condemned already. The spirit of the conflict seemed, nevertheless, to <\p>
be alive in her. Her eyes were on fire; her cheeks had each a crimson <\p>
spot, so exceedingly vivid, and marked with so definite an outline, <\p>
that I at first doubted whether it were not artificial. In a very <\p>
brief space, however, this idea was shamed by the paleness that ensued, <\p>
as the blood sunk suddenly away. Zenobia now looked like marble. <\p>
One always feels the fact, in an instant, when he has intruded on those <\p>
who love, or those who hate, at some acme of their passion that puts <\p>
them into a sphere of their own, where no other spirit can pretend to <\p>
stand on equal ground with them. I was confused,--affected even with a <\p>
species of terror,--and wished myself away. The intenseness of their <\p>
feelings gave them the exclusive property of the soil and atmosphere, <\p>
and left me no right to be or breathe there. <\p>
"Hollingsworth,--Zenobia,--I have just returned to Blithedale," said I, <\p>
"and had no thought of finding you here. We shall meet again at the <\p>
house. I will retire." <\p>
"This place is free to you," answered Hollingsworth. <\p>
"As free as to ourselves," added Zenobia. "This long while past, you <\p>
have been following up your game, groping for human emotions in the <\p>
dark corners of the heart. Had you been here a little sooner, you <\p>
might have seen them dragged into the daylight. I could even wish to <\p>
have my trial over again, with you standing by to see fair play! Do <\p>
you know, Mr. Coverdale, I have been on trial for my life?" <\p>
She laughed, while speaking thus. But, in truth, as my eyes wandered <\p>
from one of the group to another, I saw in Hollingsworth all that an <\p>
artist could desire for the grim portrait of a Puritan magistrate <\p>
holding inquest of life and death in a case of witchcraft; in Zenobia, <\p>
the sorceress herself, not aged, wrinkled, and decrepit, but fair <\p>
enough to tempt Satan with a force reciprocal to his own; and, in <\p>
Priscilla, the pale victim, whose soul and body had been wasted by her <\p>
spells. Had a pile of fagots been heaped against the rock, this hint <\p>
of impending doom would have completed the suggestive picture. <\p>
"It was too hard upon me," continued Zenobia, addressing Hollingsworth, <\p>
"that judge, jury, and accuser should all be comprehended in one man! <\p>
I demur, as I think the lawyers say, to the jurisdiction. But let the <\p>
learned Judge Coverdale seat himself on the top of the rock, and you <\p>
and me stand at its base, side by side, pleading our cause before him! <\p>
There might, at least, be two criminals instead of one." <\p>
"You forced this on me," replied Hollingsworth, looking her sternly in <\p>
the face. "Did I call you hither from among the masqueraders yonder? <\p>
Do I assume to be your judge? No; except so far as I have an <\p>
unquestionable right of judgment, in order to settle my own line of <\p>
behavior towards those with whom the events of life bring me in <\p>
contact. True, I have already judged you, but not on the world's <\p>
part,--neither do I pretend to pass a sentence!" <\p>
"Ah, this is very good!" cried Zenobia with a smile. "What strange <\p>
beings you men are, Mr. Coverdale!--is it not so? It is the simplest <\p>
thing in the world with you to bring a woman before your secret <\p>
tribunals, and judge and condemn her unheard, and then tell her to go <\p>
free without a sentence. The misfortune is, that this same secret <\p>
tribunal chances to be the only judgment-seat that a true woman stands <\p>
in awe of, and that any verdict short of acquittal is equivalent to a <\p>
death sentence!" <\p>
The more I looked at them, and the more I heard, the stronger grew my <\p>
impression that a crisis had just come and gone. On Hollingsworth's <\p>
brow it had left a stamp like that of irrevocable doom, of which his <\p>
own will was the instrument. In Zenobia's whole person, beholding her <\p>
more closely, I saw a riotous agitation; the almost delirious <\p>
disquietude of a great struggle, at the close of which the vanquished <\p>
one felt her strength and courage still mighty within her, and longed <\p>
to renew the contest. My sensations were as if I had come upon a <\p>
battlefield before the smoke was as yet cleared away. <\p>
And what subjects had been discussed here? All, no doubt, that for so <\p>
many months past had kept my heart and my imagination idly feverish. <\p>
Zenobia's whole character and history; the true nature of her <\p>
mysterious connection with Westervelt; her later purposes towards <\p>
Hollingsworth, and, reciprocally, his in reference to her; and, <\p>
finally, the degree in which Zenobia had been cognizant of the plot <\p>
against Priscilla, and what, at last, had been the real object of that <\p>
scheme. On these points, as before, I was left to my own conjectures. <\p>
One thing, only, was certain. Zenobia and Hollingsworth were friends <\p>
no longer. If their heartstrings were ever intertwined, the knot had <\p>
been adjudged an entanglement, and was now violently broken. <\p>
But Zenobia seemed unable to rest content with the matter in the <\p>
posture which it had assumed. <\p>
"Ah! do we part so?" exclaimed she, seeing Hollingsworth about to <\p>
retire. <\p>
"And why not?" said he, with almost rude abruptness. "What is there <\p>
further to be said between us?" <\p>
"Well, perhaps nothing," answered Zenobia, looking him in the face, and <\p>
smiling. "But we have come many times before to this gray rock, and we <\p>
have talked very softly among the whisperings of the birch-trees. They <\p>
were pleasant hours! I love to make the latest of them, though not <\p>
altogether so delightful, loiter away as slowly as may be. And, <\p>
besides, you have put many queries to me at this, which you design to <\p>
be our last interview; and being driven, as I must acknowledge, into a <\p>
corner, I have responded with reasonable frankness. But now, with your <\p>
free consent, I desire the privilege of asking a few questions, in my <\p>
turn." <\p>
"I have no concealments," said Hollingsworth. <\p>
"We shall see," answered Zenobia. "I would first inquire whether you <\p>
have supposed me to be wealthy?" <\p>
"On that point," observed Hollingsworth, "I have had the opinion which <\p>
the world holds." <\p>
"And I held it likewise," said Zenobia. "Had I not, Heaven is my <\p>
witness the knowledge should have been as free to you as me. It is <\p>
only three days since I knew the strange fact that threatens to make me <\p>
poor; and your own acquaintance with it, I suspect, is of at least as <\p>
old a date. I fancied myself affluent. You are aware, too, of the <\p>
disposition which I purposed making of the larger portion of my <\p>
imaginary opulence,--nay, were it all, I had not hesitated. Let me ask <\p>
you, further, did I ever propose or intimate any terms of compact, on <\p>
which depended this--as the world would consider it--so important <\p>
sacrifice?" <\p>
"You certainly spoke of none," said Hollingsworth. <\p>
"Nor meant any," she responded. "I was willing to realize your dream <\p>
freely,--generously, as some might think,--but, at all events, fully, <\p>
and heedless though it should prove the ruin of my fortune. If, in your <\p>
own thoughts, you have imposed any conditions of this expenditure, it <\p>
is you that must be held responsible for whatever is sordid and <\p>
unworthy in them. And now one other question. Do you love this girl?" <\p>
"O Zenobia!" exclaimed Priscilla, shrinking back, as if longing for the <\p>
rock to topple over and hide her. <\p>
"Do you love her?" repeated Zenobia. <\p>
"Had you asked me that question a short time since," replied <\p>
Hollingsworth, after a pause, during which, it seemed to me, even the <\p>
birch-trees held their whispering breath, "I should have told <\p>
you--'No!' My feelings for Priscilla differed little from those of an <\p>
elder brother, watching tenderly over the gentle sister whom God has <\p>
given him to protect." <\p>
"And what is your answer now?" persisted Zenobia. <\p>
"I do love her!" said Hollingsworth, uttering the words with a deep <\p>
inward breath, instead of speaking them outright. "As well declare it <\p>
thus as in any other way. I do love her!" <\p>
"Now, God be judge between us," cried Zenobia, breaking into sudden <\p>
passion, "which of us two has most mortally offended Him! At least, I <\p>
am a woman, with every fault, it may be, that a woman ever had,--weak, <\p>
vain, unprincipled (like most of my sex; for our virtues, when we have <\p>
any, are merely impulsive and intuitive), passionate, too, and pursuing <\p>
my foolish and unattainable ends by indirect and cunning, though <\p>
absurdly chosen means, as an hereditary bond-slave must; false, <\p>
moreover, to the whole circle of good, in my reckless truth to the <\p>
little good I saw before me,--but still a woman! A creature whom only <\p>
a little change of earthly fortune, a little kinder smile of Him who <\p>
sent me hither, and one true heart to encourage and direct me, might <\p>
have made all that a woman can be! But how is it with you? Are you a <\p>
man? No; but a monster! A cold, heartless, self-beginning and <\p>
self-ending piece of mechanism!" <\p>
"With what, then, do you charge me!" asked Hollingsworth, aghast, and <\p>
greatly disturbed by this attack. "Show me one selfish end, in all I <\p>
ever aimed at, and you may cut it out of my bosom with a knife!" <\p>
"It is all self!" answered Zenobia with still intenser bitterness. <\p>
"Nothing else; nothing but self, self, self! The fiend, I doubt not, <\p>
has made his choicest mirth of you these seven years past, and <\p>
especially in the mad summer which we have spent together. I see it <\p>
now! I am awake, disenchanted, disinthralled! Self, self, self! You <\p>
have embodied yourself in a project. You are a better masquerader than <\p>
the witches and gypsies yonder; for your disguise is a self-deception. <\p>
See whither it has brought you! First, you aimed a death-blow, and a <\p>
treacherous one, at this scheme of a purer and higher life, which so <\p>
many noble spirits had wrought out. Then, because Coverdale could not <\p>
be quite your slave, you threw him ruthlessly away. And you took me, <\p>
too, into your plan, as long as there was hope of my being available, <\p>
and now fling me aside again, a broken tool! But, foremost and <\p>
blackest of your sins, you stifled down your inmost consciousness!--you <\p>
did a deadly wrong to your own heart!--you were ready to sacrifice this <\p>
girl, whom, if God ever visibly showed a purpose, He put into your <\p>
charge, and through whom He was striving to redeem you!" <\p>
"This is a woman's view," said Hollingsworth, growing deadly pale,--"a <\p>
woman's, whose whole sphere of action is in the heart, and who can <\p>
conceive of no higher nor wider one!" <\p>
"Be silent!" cried Zenobia imperiously. "You know neither man nor <\p>
woman! The utmost that can be said in your behalf--and because I would <\p>
not be wholly despicable in my own eyes, but would fain excuse my <\p>
wasted feelings, nor own it wholly a delusion, therefore I say it--is, <\p>
that a great and rich heart has been ruined in your breast. Leave me, <\p>
now. You have done with me, and I with you. Farewell!" <\p>
"Priscilla," said Hollingsworth, "come." Zenobia smiled; possibly I <\p>
did so too. Not often, in human life, has a gnawing sense of injury <\p>
found a sweeter morsel of revenge than was conveyed in the tone with <\p>
which Hollingsworth spoke those two words. It was the abased and <\p>
tremulous tone of a man whose faith in himself was shaken, and who <\p>
sought, at last, to lean on an affection. Yes; the strong man bowed <\p>
himself and rested on this poor Priscilla! Oh, could she have failed <\p>
him, what a triumph for the lookers-on! <\p>
And, at first, I half imagined that she was about to fail him. She <\p>
rose up, stood shivering like the birch leaves that trembled over her <\p>
head, and then slowly tottered, rather than walked, towards Zenobia. <\p>
Arriving at her feet, she sank down there, in the very same attitude <\p>
which she had assumed on their first meeting, in the kitchen of the old <\p>
farmhouse. Zenobia remembered it. <\p>
"Ah, Priscilla!" said she, shaking her head, "how much is changed since <\p>
then! You kneel to a dethroned princess. You, the victorious one! <\p>
But he is waiting for you. Say what you wish, and leave me." <\p>
"We are sisters!" gasped Priscilla. <\p>
I fancied that I understood the word and action. It meant the offering <\p>
of herself, and all she had, to be at Zenobia's disposal. But the <\p>
latter would not take it thus. <\p>
"True, we are sisters!" she replied; and, moved by the sweet word, she <\p>
stooped down and kissed Priscilla; but not lovingly, for a sense of <\p>
fatal harm received through her seemed to be lurking in Zenobia's <\p>
heart. "We had one father! You knew it from the first; I, but a <\p>
little while,--else some things that have chanced might have been <\p>
spared you. But I never wished you harm. You stood between me and an <\p>
end which I desired. I wanted a clear path. No matter what I meant. <\p>
It is over now. Do you forgive me?" <\p>
"O Zenobia," sobbed Priscilla, "it is I that feel like the guilty one!" <\p>
"No, no, poor little thing!" said Zenobia, with a sort of contempt. <\p>
"You have been my evil fate, but there never was a babe with less <\p>
strength or will to do an injury. Poor child! Methinks you have but a <\p>
melancholy lot before you, sitting all alone in that wide, cheerless <\p>
heart, where, for aught you know,--and as I, alas! believe,--the fire <\p>
which you have kindled may soon go out. Ah, the thought makes me <\p>
shiver for you! What will you do, Priscilla, when you find no spark <\p>
among the ashes?" <\p>
"Die!" she answered. <\p>
"That was well said!" responded Zenobia, with an approving smile. <\p>
"There is all a woman in your little compass, my poor sister. <\p>
Meanwhile, go with him, and live!" <\p>
She waved her away with a queenly gesture, and turned her own face to <\p>
the rock. I watched Priscilla, wondering what judgment she would pass <\p>
between Zenobia and Hollingsworth; how interpret his behavior, so as to <\p>
reconcile it with true faith both towards her sister and herself; how <\p>
compel her love for him to keep any terms whatever with her sisterly <\p>
affection! But, in truth, there was no such difficulty as I imagined. <\p>
Her engrossing love made it all clear. Hollingsworth could have no <\p>
fault. That was the one principle at the centre of the universe. And <\p>
the doubtful guilt or possible integrity of other people, appearances, <\p>
self-evident facts, the testimony of her own senses,--even <\p>
Hollingsworth's self-accusation, had he volunteered it,--would have <\p>
weighed not the value of a mote of thistledown on the other side. So <\p>
secure was she of his right, that she never thought of comparing it <\p>
with another's wrong, but left the latter to itself. <\p>
Hollingsworth drew her arm within his, and soon disappeared with her <\p>
among the trees. I cannot imagine how Zenobia knew when they were out <\p>
of sight; she never glanced again towards them. But, retaining a proud <\p>
attitude so long as they might have thrown back a retiring look, they <\p>
were no sooner departed,--utterly departed,--than she began slowly to <\p>
sink down. It was as if a great, invisible, irresistible weight were <\p>
pressing her to the earth. Settling upon her knees, she leaned her <\p>
forehead against the rock, and sobbed convulsively; dry sobs they <\p>
seemed to be, such as have nothing to do with tears. <\p>
XXVI. ZENOBIA AND COVERDALE <\p>
Zenobia had entirely forgotten me. She fancied herself alone with her <\p>
great grief. And had it been only a common pity that I felt for <\p>
her,--the pity that her proud nature would have repelled, as the one <\p>
worst wrong which the world yet held in reserve,--the sacredness and <\p>
awfulness of the crisis might have impelled me to steal away silently, <\p>
so that not a dry leaf should rustle under my feet. I would have left <\p>
her to struggle, in that solitude, with only the eye of God upon her. <\p>
But, so it happened, I never once dreamed of questioning my right to be <\p>
there now, as I had questioned it just before, when I came so suddenly <\p>
upon Hollingsworth and herself, in the passion of their recent debate. <\p>
It suits me not to explain what was the analogy that I saw or imagined <\p>
between Zenobia's situation and mine; nor, I believe, will the reader <\p>
detect this one secret, hidden beneath many a revelation which perhaps <\p>
concerned me less. In simple truth, however, as Zenobia leaned her <\p>
forehead against the rock, shaken with that tearless agony, it seemed <\p>
to me that the self-same pang, with hardly mitigated torment, leaped <\p>
thrilling from her heartstrings to my own. Was it wrong, therefore, if <\p>
I felt myself consecrated to the priesthood by sympathy like this, and <\p>
called upon to minister to this woman's affliction, so far as mortal <\p>
could? <\p>
But, indeed, what could mortal do for her? Nothing! The attempt would <\p>
be a mockery and an anguish. Time, it is true, would steal away her <\p>
grief, and bury it and the best of her heart in the same grave. But <\p>
Destiny itself, methought, in its kindliest mood, could do no better <\p>
for Zenobia, in the way of quick relief; than to cause the impending <\p>
rock to impend a little farther, and fall upon her head. So I leaned <\p>
against a tree, and listened to her sobs, in unbroken silence. She was <\p>
half prostrate, half kneeling, with her forehead still pressed against <\p>
the rock. Her sobs were the only sound; she did not groan, nor give <\p>
any other utterance to her distress. It was all involuntary. <\p>
At length she sat up, put back her hair, and stared about her with a <\p>
bewildered aspect, as if not distinctly recollecting the scene through <\p>
which she had passed, nor cognizant of the situation in which it left <\p>
her. Her face and brow were almost purple with the rush of blood. <\p>
They whitened, however, by and by, and for some time retained this <\p>
deathlike hue. She put her hand to her forehead, with a gesture that <\p>
made me forcibly conscious of an intense and living pain there. <\p>
Her glance, wandering wildly to and fro, passed over me several times, <\p>
without appearing to inform her of my presence. But, finally, a look <\p>
of recognition gleamed from her eyes into mine. <\p>
"Is it you, Miles Coverdale?" said she, smiling. "Ah, I perceive what <\p>
you are about! You are turning this whole affair into a ballad. Pray <\p>
let me hear as many stanzas as you happen to have ready." <\p>
"Oh, hush, Zenobia!" I answered. "Heaven knows what an ache is in my <\p>
soul!" <\p>
"It is genuine tragedy, is it not?" rejoined Zenobia, with a sharp, <\p>
light laugh. "And you are willing to allow, perhaps, that I have had <\p>
hard measure. But it is a woman's doom, and I have deserved it like a <\p>
woman; so let there be no pity, as, on my part, there shall be no <\p>
complaint. It is all right, now, or will shortly be so. But, Mr. <\p>
Coverdale, by all means write this ballad, and put your soul's ache <\p>
into it, and turn your sympathy to good account, as other poets do, and <\p>
as poets must, unless they choose to give us glittering icicles instead <\p>
of lines of fire. As for the moral, it shall be distilled into the <\p>
final stanza, in a drop of bitter honey." <\p>
"What shall it be, Zenobia?" I inquired, endeavoring to fall in with <\p>
her mood. <\p>
"Oh, a very old one will serve the purpose," she replied. "There are <\p>
no new truths, much as we have prided ourselves on finding some. A <\p>
moral? Why, this: That, in the battlefield of life, the downright <\p>
stroke, that would fall only on a man's steel headpiece, is sure to <\p>
light on a woman's heart, over which she wears no breastplate, and <\p>
whose wisdom it is, therefore, to keep out of the conflict. Or, this: <\p>
That the whole universe, her own sex and yours, and Providence, or <\p>
Destiny, to boot, make common cause against the woman who swerves one <\p>
hair's-breadth out of the beaten track. Yes; and add (for I may as <\p>
well own it, now) that, with that one hair's-breadth, she goes all <\p>
astray, and never sees the world in its true aspect afterwards." <\p>
"This last is too stern a moral," I observed. "Cannot we soften it a <\p>
little?" <\p>
"Do it if you like, at your own peril, not on my responsibility," she <\p>
answered. Then, with a sudden change of subject, she went on: "After <\p>
all, he has flung away what would have served him better than the poor, <\p>
pale flower he kept. What can Priscilla do for him? Put passionate <\p>
warmth into his heart, when it shall be chilled with frozen hopes? <\p>
Strengthen his hands, when they are weary with much doing and no <\p>
performance? No! but only tend towards him with a blind, instinctive <\p>
love, and hang her little, puny weakness for a clog upon his arm! She <\p>
cannot even give him such sympathy as is worth the name. For will he <\p>
never, in many an hour of darkness, need that proud intellectual <\p>
sympathy which he might have had from me?--the sympathy that would <\p>
flash light along his course, and guide, as well as cheer him? Poor <\p>
Hollingsworth! Where will he find it now?" <\p>
"Hollingsworth has a heart of ice!" said I bitterly. "He is a wretch!" <\p>
"Do him no wrong," interrupted Zenobia, turning haughtily upon me. <\p>
"Presume not to estimate a man like Hollingsworth. It was my fault, <\p>
all along, and none of his. I see it now! He never sought me. Why <\p>
should he seek me? What had I to offer him? A miserable, bruised, and <\p>
battered heart, spoilt long before he met me. A life, too, hopelessly <\p>
entangled with a villain's! He did well to cast me off. God be <\p>
praised, he did it! And yet, had he trusted me, and borne with me a <\p>
little longer, I would have saved him all this trouble." <\p>
She was silent for a time, and stood with her eyes fixed on the ground. <\p>
Again raising them, her look was more mild and calm. <\p>
"Miles Coverdale!" said she. <\p>
"Well, Zenobia," I responded. "Can I do you any service?" <\p>
"Very little," she replied. "But it is my purpose, as you may well <\p>
imagine, to remove from Blithedale; and, most likely, I may not see <\p>
Hollingsworth again. A woman in my position, you understand, feels <\p>
scarcely at her ease among former friends. New faces,--unaccustomed <\p>
looks,--those only can she tolerate. She would pine among familiar <\p>
scenes; she would be apt to blush, too, under the eyes that knew her <\p>
secret; her heart might throb uncomfortably; she would mortify herself, <\p>
I suppose, with foolish notions of having sacrificed the honor of her <\p>
sex at the foot of proud, contumacious man. Poor womanhood, with its <\p>
rights and wrongs! Here will be new matter for my course of lectures, <\p>
at the idea of which you smiled, Mr. Coverdale, a month or two ago. <\p>
But, as you have really a heart and sympathies, as far as they go, and <\p>
as I shall depart without seeing Hollingsworth, I must entreat you to <\p>
be a messenger between him and me." <\p>
"Willingly," said I, wondering at the strange way in which her mind <\p>
seemed to vibrate from the deepest earnest to mere levity. "What is <\p>
the message?" <\p>
"True,--what is it?" exclaimed Zenobia. "After all, I hardly know. On <\p>
better consideration, I have no message. Tell him,--tell him something <\p>
pretty and pathetic, that will come nicely and sweetly into your <\p>
ballad,--anything you please, so it be tender and submissive enough. <\p>
Tell him he has murdered me! Tell him that I'll haunt him! "--She <\p>
spoke these words with the wildest energy.--"And give him--no, give <\p>
Priscilla--this!" <\p>
Thus saying, she took the jewelled flower out of her hair; and it <\p>
struck me as the act of a queen, when worsted in a combat, discrowning <\p>
herself, as if she found a sort of relief in abasing all her pride. <\p>
"Bid her wear this for Zenobia's sake," she continued. "She is a <\p>
pretty little creature, and will make as soft and gentle a wife as the <\p>
veriest Bluebeard could desire. Pity that she must fade so soon! These <\p>
delicate and puny maidens always do. Ten years hence, let <\p>
Hollingsworth look at my face and Priscilla's, and then choose betwixt <\p>
them. Or, if he pleases, let him do it now." <\p>
How magnificently Zenobia looked as she said this! The effect of her <\p>
beauty was even heightened by the over-consciousness and <\p>
self-recognition of it, into which, I suppose, Hollingsworth's scorn <\p>
had driven her. She understood the look of admiration in my face; <\p>
and--Zenobia to the last--it gave her pleasure. <\p>
"It is an endless pity," said she, "that I had not bethought myself of <\p>
winning your heart, Mr. Coverdale, instead of Hollingsworth's. I think <\p>
I should have succeeded, and many women would have deemed you the <\p>
worthier conquest of the two. You are certainly much the handsomest <\p>
man. But there is a fate in these things. And beauty, in a man, has <\p>
been of little account with me since my earliest girlhood, when, for <\p>
once, it turned my head. Now, farewell!" <\p>
"Zenobia, whither are you going?" I asked. <\p>
"No matter where," said she. "But I am weary of this place, and sick <\p>
to death of playing at philanthropy and progress. Of all varieties of <\p>
mock-life, we have surely blundered into the very emptiest mockery in <\p>
our effort to establish the one true system. I have done with it; and <\p>
Blithedale must find another woman to superintend the laundry, and you, <\p>
Mr. Coverdale, another nurse to make your gruel, the next time you fall <\p>
ill. It was, indeed, a foolish dream! Yet it gave us some pleasant <\p>
summer days, and bright hopes, while they lasted. It can do no more; <\p>
nor will it avail us to shed tears over a broken bubble. Here is my <\p>
hand! Adieu!" <\p>
She gave me her hand with the same free, whole-souled gesture as on the <\p>
first afternoon of our acquaintance, and, being greatly moved, I <\p>
bethought me of no better method of expressing my deep sympathy than to <\p>
carry it to my lips. In so doing, I perceived that this white hand--so <\p>
hospitably warm when I first touched it, five months since--was now <\p>
cold as a veritable piece of snow. <\p>
"How very cold!" I exclaimed, holding it between both my own, with the <\p>
vain idea of warming it. "What can be the reason? It is really <\p>
deathlike!" <\p>
"The extremities die first, they say," answered Zenobia, laughing. "And <\p>
so you kiss this poor, despised, rejected hand! Well, my dear friend, <\p>
I thank you. You have reserved your homage for the fallen. Lip of man <\p>
will never touch my hand again. I intend to become a Catholic, for the <\p>
sake of going into a nunnery. When you next hear of Zenobia, her face <\p>
will be behind the black veil; so look your last at it now,--for all is <\p>
over. Once more, farewell!" <\p>
She withdrew her hand, yet left a lingering pressure, which I felt long <\p>
afterwards. So intimately connected as I had been with perhaps the <\p>
only man in whom she was ever truly interested, Zenobia looked on me as <\p>
the representative of all the past, and was conscious that, in bidding <\p>
me adieu, she likewise took final leave of Hollingsworth, and of this <\p>
whole epoch of her life. Never did her beauty shine out more <\p>
lustrously than in the last glimpse that I had of her. She departed, <\p>
and was soon hidden among the trees. But, whether it was the strong <\p>
impression of the foregoing scene, or whatever else the cause, I was <\p>
affected with a fantasy that Zenobia had not actually gone, but was <\p>
still hovering about the spot and haunting it. I seemed to feel her <\p>
eyes upon me. It was as if the vivid coloring of her character had <\p>
left a brilliant stain upon the air. By degrees, however, the <\p>
impression grew less distinct. I flung myself upon the fallen leaves <\p>
at the base of Eliot's pulpit. The sunshine withdrew up the tree <\p>
trunks and flickered on the topmost boughs; gray twilight made the wood <\p>
obscure; the stars brightened out; the pendent boughs became wet with <\p>
chill autumnal dews. But I was listless, worn out with emotion on my <\p>
own behalf and sympathy for others, and had no heart to leave my <\p>
comfortless lair beneath the rock. <\p>
I must have fallen asleep, and had a dream, all the circumstances of <\p>
which utterly vanished at the moment when they converged to some <\p>
tragical catastrophe, and thus grew too powerful for the thin sphere of <\p>
slumber that enveloped them. Starting from the ground, I found the <\p>
risen moon shining upon the rugged face of the rock, and myself all in <\p>
a tremble. <\p>
XXVII. MIDNIGHT <\p>
It could not have been far from midnight when I came beneath <\p>
Hollingsworth's window, and, finding it open, flung in a tuft of grass <\p>
with earth at the roots, and heard it fall upon the floor. He was <\p>
either awake or sleeping very lightly; for scarcely a moment had gone <\p>
by before he looked out and discerned me standing in the moonlight. <\p>
"Is it you, Coverdale?" he asked. "What is the matter?" <\p>
"Come down to me, Hollingsworth!" I answered. "I am anxious to speak <\p>
with you." <\p>
The strange tone of my own voice startled me, and him, probably, no <\p>
less. He lost no time, and soon issued from the house-door, with his <\p>
dress half arranged. <\p>
"Again, what is the matter?" he asked impatiently. <\p>
"Have you seen Zenobia," said I, "since you parted from her at Eliot's <\p>
pulpit?" <\p>
"No," answered Hollingsworth; "nor did I expect it." <\p>
His voice was deep, but had a tremor in it, <\p>
Hardly had he spoken, when Silas Foster thrust his head, done up in a <\p>
cotton handkerchief, out of another window, and took what he called as <\p>
it literally was--a squint at us. <\p>
"Well, folks, what are ye about here?" he demanded. "Aha! are you <\p>
there, Miles Coverdale? You have been turning night into day since you <\p>
left us, I reckon; and so you find it quite natural to come prowling <\p>
about the house at this time o' night, frightening my old woman out of <\p>
her wits, and making her disturb a tired man out of his best nap. In <\p>
with you, you vagabond, and to bed!" <\p>
"Dress yourself quickly, Foster," said I. "We want your assistance." <\p>
I could not, for the life of me, keep that strange tone out of my <\p>
voice. Silas Foster, obtuse as were his sensibilities, seemed to feel <\p>
the ghastly earnestness that was conveyed in it as well as <\p>
Hollingsworth did. He immediately withdrew his head, and I heard him <\p>
yawning, muttering to his wife, and again yawning heavily, while he <\p>
hurried on his clothes. Meanwhile I showed Hollingsworth a delicate <\p>
handkerchief, marked with a well-known cipher, and told where I had <\p>
found it, and other circumstances, which had filled me with a suspicion <\p>
so terrible that I left him, if he dared, to shape it out for himself. <\p>
By the time my brief explanation was finished, we were joined by Silas <\p>
Foster in his blue woollen frock. <\p>
"Well, boys," cried he peevishly, "what is to pay now?" <\p>
"Tell him, Hollingsworth," said I. <\p>
Hollingsworth shivered perceptibly, and drew in a hard breath betwixt <\p>
his teeth. He steadied himself, however, and, looking the matter more <\p>
firmly in the face than I had done, explained to Foster my suspicions, <\p>
and the grounds of them, with a distinctness from which, in spite of my <\p>
utmost efforts, my words had swerved aside. The tough-nerved yeoman, <\p>
in his comment, put a finish on the business, and brought out the <\p>
hideous idea in its full terror, as if he were removing the napkin from <\p>
the face of a corpse. <\p>
"And so you think she's drowned herself?" he cried. I turned away my <\p>
face. <\p>
"What on earth should the young woman do that for?" exclaimed Silas, <\p>
his eyes half out of his head with mere surprise. "Why, she has more <\p>
means than she can use or waste, and lacks nothing to make her <\p>
comfortable, but a husband, and that's an article she could have, any <\p>
day. There's some mistake about this, I tell you!" <\p>
"Come," said I, shuddering; "let us go and ascertain the truth." <\p>
"Well, well," answered Silas Foster; "just as you say. We'll take the <\p>
long pole, with the hook at the end, that serves to get the bucket out <\p>
of the draw-well when the rope is broken. With that, and a couple of <\p>
long-handled hay-rakes, I'll answer for finding her, if she's anywhere <\p>
to be found. Strange enough! Zenobia drown herself! No, no; I don't <\p>
believe it. She had too much sense, and too much means, and enjoyed <\p>
life a great deal too well." <\p>
When our few preparations were completed, we hastened, by a shorter <\p>
than the customary route, through fields and pastures, and across a <\p>
portion of the meadow, to the particular spot on the river-bank which I <\p>
had paused to contemplate in the course of my afternoon's ramble. A <\p>
nameless presentiment had again drawn me thither, after leaving Eliot's <\p>
pulpit. I showed my companions where I had found the handkerchief, and <\p>
pointed to two or three footsteps, impressed into the clayey margin, <\p>
and tending towards the water. Beneath its shallow verge, among the <\p>
water-weeds, there were further traces, as yet unobliterated by the <\p>
sluggish current, which was there almost at a standstill. Silas Foster <\p>
thrust his face down close to these footsteps, and picked up a shoe <\p>
that had escaped my observation, being half imbedded in the mud. <\p>
"There's a kid shoe that never was made on a Yankee last," observed he. <\p>
"I know enough of shoemaker's craft to tell that. French manufacture; <\p>
and see what a high instep! and how evenly she trod in it! There never <\p>
was a woman that stept handsomer in her shoes than Zenobia did. Here," <\p>
he added, addressing Hollingsworth, "would you like to keep the shoe?" <\p>
Hollingsworth started back. <\p>
"Give it to me, Foster," said I. <\p>
I dabbled it in the water, to rinse off the mud, and have kept it ever <\p>
since. Not far from this spot lay an old, leaky punt, drawn up on the <\p>
oozy river-side, and generally half full of water. It served the <\p>
angler to go in quest of pickerel, or the sportsman to pick up his wild <\p>
ducks. Setting this crazy bark afloat, I seated myself in the stern <\p>
with the paddle, while Hollingsworth sat in the bows with the hooked <\p>
pole, and Silas Foster amidships with a hay-rake. <\p>
"It puts me in mind of my young days," remarked Silas, "when I used to <\p>
steal out of bed to go bobbing for hornpouts and eels. <\p>
Heigh-ho!--well, life and death together make sad work for us all! <\p>
Then I was a boy, bobbing for fish; and now I am getting to be an old <\p>
fellow, and here I be, groping for a dead body! I tell you what, lads; <\p>
if I thought anything had really happened to Zenobia, I should feel <\p>
kind o' sorrowful." <\p>
"I wish, at least, you would hold your tongue," muttered I. <\p>
The moon, that night, though past the full, was still large and oval, <\p>
and having risen between eight and nine o'clock, now shone aslantwise <\p>
over the river, throwing the high, opposite bank, with its woods, into <\p>
deep shadow, but lighting up the hither shore pretty effectually. Not a <\p>
ray appeared to fall on the river itself. It lapsed imperceptibly <\p>
away, a broad, black, inscrutable depth, keeping its own secrets from <\p>
the eye of man, as impenetrably as mid-ocean could. <\p>
"Well, Miles Coverdale," said Foster, "you are the helmsman. How do <\p>
you mean to manage this business?" <\p>
"I shall let the boat drift, broadside foremost, past that stump," I <\p>
replied. "I know the bottom, having sounded it in fishing. The shore, <\p>
on this side, after the first step or two, goes off very abruptly; and <\p>
there is a pool, just by the stump, twelve or fifteen feet deep. The <\p>
current could not have force enough to sweep any sunken object, even if <\p>
partially buoyant, out of that hollow." <\p>
"Come, then," said Silas; "but I doubt whether I can touch bottom with <\p>
this hay-rake, if it's as deep as you say. Mr. Hollingsworth, I think <\p>
you'll be the lucky man to-night, such luck as it is." <\p>
We floated past the stump. Silas Foster plied his rake manfully, <\p>
poking it as far as he could into the water, and immersing the whole <\p>
length of his arm besides. Hollingsworth at first sat motionless, with <\p>
the hooked pole elevated in the air. But, by and by, with a nervous <\p>
and jerky movement, he began to plunge it into the blackness that <\p>
upbore us, setting his teeth, and making precisely such thrusts, <\p>
methought, as if he were stabbing at a deadly enemy. I bent over the <\p>
side of the boat. So obscure, however, so awfully mysterious, was that <\p>
dark stream, that--and the thought made me shiver like a leaf--I might <\p>
as well have tried to look into the enigma of the eternal world, to <\p>
discover what had become of Zenobia's soul, as into the river's depths, <\p>
to find her body. And there, perhaps, she lay, with her face upward, <\p>
while the shadow of the boat, and my own pale face peering downward, <\p>
passed slowly betwixt her and the sky! <\p>
Once, twice, thrice, I paddled the boat upstream, and again suffered it <\p>
to glide, with the river's slow, funereal motion, downward. Silas <\p>
Foster had raked up a large mass of stuff, which, as it came towards <\p>
the surface, looked somewhat like a flowing garment, but proved to be a <\p>
monstrous tuft of water-weeds. Hollingsworth, with a gigantic effort, <\p>
upheaved a sunken log. When once free of the bottom, it rose partly <\p>
out of water,--all weedy and slimy, a devilish-looking object, which <\p>
the moon had not shone upon for half a hundred years,--then plunged <\p>
again, and sullenly returned to its old resting-place, for the remnant <\p>
of the century. <\p>
"That looked ugly!" quoth Silas. "I half thought it was the Evil One, <\p>
on the same errand as ourselves,--searching for Zenobia." <\p>
"He shall never get her," said I, giving the boat a strong impulse. <\p>
"That's not for you to say, my boy," retorted the yeoman. "Pray God he <\p>
never has, and never may. Slow work this, however! I should really be <\p>
glad to find something! Pshaw! What a notion that is, when the only <\p>
good luck would be to paddle, and drift, and poke, and grope, <\p>
hereabouts, till morning, and have our labor for our pains! For my <\p>
part, I shouldn't wonder if the creature had only lost her shoe in the <\p>
mud, and saved her soul alive, after all. My stars! how she will laugh <\p>
at us, to-morrow morning!" <\p>
It is indescribable what an image of Zenobia--at the breakfast-table, <\p>
full of warm and mirthful life--this surmise of Silas Foster's brought <\p>
before my mind. The terrible phantasm of her death was thrown by it <\p>
into the remotest and dimmest background, where it seemed to grow as <\p>
improbable as a myth. <\p>
"Yes, Silas, it may be as you say," cried I. The drift of the stream <\p>
had again borne us a little below the stump, when I felt--yes, felt, <\p>
for it was as if the iron hook had smote my breast--felt <\p>
Hollingsworth's pole strike some object at the bottom of the river! <\p>
He started up, and almost overset the boat. <\p>
"Hold on!" cried Foster; "you have her!" <\p>
Putting a fury of strength into the effort, Hollingsworth heaved amain, <\p>
and up came a white swash to the surface of the river. It was the flow <\p>
of a woman's garments. A little higher, and we saw her dark hair <\p>
streaming down the current. Black River of Death, thou hadst yielded <\p>
up thy victim! Zenobia was found! <\p>
Silas Foster laid hold of the body; Hollingsworth likewise grappled <\p>
with it; and I steered towards the bank, gazing all the while at <\p>
Zenobia, whose limbs were swaying in the current close at the boat's <\p>
side. Arriving near the shore, we all three stept into the water, bore <\p>
her out, and laid her on the ground beneath a tree. <\p>
"Poor child!" said Foster,--and his dry old heart, I verily believe, <\p>
vouchsafed a tear, "I'm sorry for her!" <\p>
Were I to describe the perfect horror of the spectacle, the reader <\p>
might justly reckon it to me for a sin and shame. For more than twelve <\p>
long years I have borne it in my memory, and could now reproduce it as <\p>
freshly as if it were still before my eyes. Of all modes of death, <\p>
methinks it is the ugliest. Her wet garments swathed limbs of terrible <\p>
inflexibility. She was the marble image of a death-agony. Her arms <\p>
had grown rigid in the act of struggling, and were bent before her with <\p>
clenched hands; her knees, too, were bent, and--thank God for it!--in <\p>
the attitude of prayer. Ah, that rigidity! It is impossible to bear <\p>
the terror of it. It seemed,--I must needs impart so much of my own <\p>
miserable idea,--it seemed as if her body must keep the same position <\p>
in the coffin, and that her skeleton would keep it in the grave; and <\p>
that when Zenobia rose at the day of judgment, it would be in just the <\p>
same attitude as now! <\p>
One hope I had, and that too was mingled half with fear. She knelt as <\p>
if in prayer. With the last, choking consciousness, her soul, bubbling <\p>
out through her lips, it may be, had given itself up to the Father, <\p>
reconciled and penitent. But her arms! They were bent before her, as <\p>
if she struggled against Providence in never-ending hostility. Her <\p>
hands! They were clenched in immitigable defiance. Away with the <\p>
hideous thought. The flitting moment after Zenobia sank into the dark <\p>
pool--when her breath was gone, and her soul at her lips was as long, <\p>
in its capacity of God's infinite forgiveness, as the lifetime of the <\p>
world! <\p>
Foster bent over the body, and carefully examined it. <\p>
"You have wounded the poor thing's breast," said he to Hollingsworth, <\p>
"close by her heart, too!" <\p>
"Ha!" cried Hollingsworth with a start. <\p>
And so he had, indeed, both before and after death! <\p>
"See!" said Foster. "That's the place where the iron struck her. It <\p>
looks cruelly, but she never felt it!" <\p>
He endeavored to arrange the arms of the corpse decently by its side. <\p>
His utmost strength, however, scarcely sufficed to bring them down; and <\p>
rising again, the next instant, they bade him defiance, exactly as <\p>
before. He made another effort, with the same result. <\p>
"In God's name, Silas Foster," cried I with bitter indignation, "let <\p>
that dead woman alone!" <\p>
"Why, man, it's not decent!" answered he, staring at me in amazement. <\p>
"I can't bear to see her looking so! Well, well," added he, after a <\p>
third effort, "'tis of no use, sure enough; and we must leave the women <\p>
to do their best with her, after we get to the house. The sooner <\p>
that's done, the better." <\p>
We took two rails from a neighboring fence, and formed a bier by laying <\p>
across some boards from the bottom of the boat. And thus we bore <\p>
Zenobia homeward. Six hours before, how beautiful! At midnight, what <\p>
a horror! A reflection occurs to me that will show ludicrously, I <\p>
doubt not, on my page, but must come in for its sterling truth. Being <\p>
the woman that she was, could Zenobia have foreseen all these ugly <\p>
circumstances of death,--how ill it would become her, the altogether <\p>
unseemly aspect which she must put on, and especially old Silas <\p>
Foster's efforts to improve the matter,--she would no more have <\p>
committed the dreadful act than have exhibited herself to a public <\p>
assembly in a badly fitting garment! Zenobia, I have often thought, <\p>
was not quite simple in her death. She had seen pictures, I suppose, <\p>
of drowned persons in lithe and graceful attitudes. And she deemed it <\p>
well and decorous to die as so many village maidens have, wronged in <\p>
their first love, and seeking peace in the bosom of the old familiar <\p>
stream,--so familiar that they could not dread it,--where, in <\p>
childhood, they used to bathe their little feet, wading mid-leg deep, <\p>
unmindful of wet skirts. But in Zenobia's case there was some tint of <\p>
the Arcadian affectation that had been visible enough in all our lives <\p>
for a few months past. <\p>
This, however, to my conception, takes nothing from the tragedy. For, <\p>
has not the world come to an awfully sophisticated pass, when, after a <\p>
certain degree of acquaintance with it, we cannot even put ourselves to <\p>
death in whole-hearted simplicity? Slowly, slowly, with many a dreary <\p>
pause,--resting the bier often on some rock or balancing it across a <\p>
mossy log, to take fresh hold,--we bore our burden onward through the <\p>
moonlight, and at last laid Zenobia on the floor of the old farmhouse. <\p>
By and by came three or four withered women and stood whispering around <\p>
the corpse, peering at it through their spectacles, holding up their <\p>
skinny hands, shaking their night-capped heads, and taking counsel of <\p>
one another's experience what was to be done. <\p>
With those tire-women we left Zenobia. <\p>
XXVIII. BLITHEDALE PASTURE <\p>
Blithedale, thus far in its progress, had never found the necessity of <\p>
a burial-ground. There was some consultation among us in what spot <\p>
Zenobia might most fitly be laid. It was my own wish that she should <\p>
sleep at the base of Eliot's pulpit, and that on the rugged front of <\p>
the rock the name by which we familiarly knew her, Zenobia,--and not <\p>
another word, should be deeply cut, and left for the moss and lichens <\p>
to fill up at their long leisure. But Hollingsworth (to whose ideas on <\p>
this point great deference was due) made it his request that her grave <\p>
might be dug on the gently sloping hillside, in the wide pasture, <\p>
where, as we once supposed, Zenobia and he had planned to build their <\p>
cottage. And thus it was done, accordingly. <\p>
She was buried very much as other people have been for hundreds of <\p>
years gone by. In anticipation of a death, we Blithedale colonists had <\p>
sometimes set our fancies at work to arrange a funereal ceremony, which <\p>
should be the proper symbolic expression of our spiritual faith and <\p>
eternal hopes; and this we meant to substitute for those customary <\p>
rites which were moulded originally out of the Gothic gloom, and by <\p>
long use, like an old velvet pall, have so much more than their first <\p>
death-smell in them. But when the occasion came we found it the <\p>
simplest and truest thing, after all, to content ourselves with the old <\p>
fashion, taking away what we could, but interpolating no novelties, and <\p>
particularly avoiding all frippery of flowers and cheerful emblems. <\p>
The procession moved from the farmhouse. Nearest the dead walked an <\p>
old man in deep mourning, his face mostly concealed in a white <\p>
handkerchief, and with Priscilla leaning on his arm. Hollingsworth and <\p>
myself came next. We all stood around the narrow niche in the cold <\p>
earth; all saw the coffin lowered in; all heard the rattle of the <\p>
crumbly soil upon its lid,--that final sound, which mortality awakens <\p>
on the utmost verge of sense, as if in the vain hope of bringing an <\p>
echo from the spiritual world. <\p>
I noticed a stranger,--a stranger to most of those present, though <\p>
known to me,--who, after the coffin had descended, took up a handful of <\p>
earth and flung it first into the grave. I had given up <\p>
Hollingsworth's arm, and now found myself near this man. <\p>
"It was an idle thing--a foolish thing--for Zenobia to do," said he. <\p>
"She was the last woman in the world to whom death could have been <\p>
necessary. It was too absurd! I have no patience with her." <\p>
"Why so?" I inquired, smothering my horror at his cold comment, in my <\p>
eager curiosity to discover some tangible truth as to his relation with <\p>
Zenobia. "If any crisis could justify the sad wrong she offered to <\p>
herself, it was surely that in which she stood. Everything had failed <\p>
her; prosperity in the world's sense, for her opulence was gone,--the <\p>
heart's prosperity, in love. And there was a secret burden on her, the <\p>
nature of which is best known to you. Young as she was, she had tried <\p>
life fully, had no more to hope, and something, perhaps, to fear. Had <\p>
Providence taken her away in its own holy hand, I should have thought <\p>
it the kindest dispensation that could be awarded to one so wrecked." <\p>
"You mistake the matter completely," rejoined Westervelt. <\p>
"What, then, is your own view of it?" I asked. <\p>
"Her mind was active, and various in its powers," said he. "Her heart <\p>
had a manifold adaptation; her constitution an infinite buoyancy, which <\p>
(had she possessed only a little patience to await the reflux of her <\p>
troubles) would have borne her upward triumphantly for twenty years to <\p>
come. Her beauty would not have waned--or scarcely so, and surely not <\p>
beyond the reach of art to restore it--in all that time. She had <\p>
life's summer all before her, and a hundred varieties of brilliant <\p>
success. What an actress Zenobia might have been! It was one of her <\p>
least valuable capabilities. How forcibly she might have wrought upon <\p>
the world, either directly in her own person, or by her influence upon <\p>
some man, or a series of men, of controlling genius! Every prize that <\p>
could be worth a woman's having--and many prizes which other women are <\p>
too timid to desire--lay within Zenobia's reach." <\p>
"In all this," I observed, "there would have been nothing to satisfy <\p>
her heart." <\p>
"Her heart!" answered Westervelt contemptuously. "That troublesome <\p>
organ (as she had hitherto found it) would have been kept in its due <\p>
place and degree, and have had all the gratification it could fairly <\p>
claim. She would soon have established a control over it. Love had <\p>
failed her, you say. Had it never failed her before? Yet she survived <\p>
it, and loved again,--possibly not once alone, nor twice either. And <\p>
now to drown herself for yonder dreamy philanthropist!" <\p>
"Who are you," I exclaimed indignantly, "that dare to speak thus of the <\p>
dead? You seem to intend a eulogy, yet leave out whatever was noblest <\p>
in her, and blacken while you mean to praise. I have long considered <\p>
you as Zenobia's evil fate. Your sentiments confirm me in the idea, <\p>
but leave me still ignorant as to the mode in which you have influenced <\p>
her life. The connection may have been indissoluble, except by death. <\p>
Then, indeed,--always in the hope of God's infinite mercy,--I cannot <\p>
deem it a misfortune that she sleeps in yonder grave!" <\p>
"No matter what I was to her," he answered gloomily, yet without actual <\p>
emotion. "She is now beyond my reach. Had she lived, and hearkened to <\p>
my counsels, we might have served each other well. But there Zenobia <\p>
lies in yonder pit, with the dull earth over her. Twenty years of a <\p>
brilliant lifetime thrown away for a mere woman's whim!" <\p>
Heaven deal with Westervelt according to his nature and deserts!--that <\p>
is to say, annihilate him. He was altogether earthy, worldly, made for <\p>
time and its gross objects, and incapable--except by a sort of dim <\p>
reflection caught from other minds--of so much as one spiritual idea. <\p>
Whatever stain Zenobia had was caught from him; nor does it seldom <\p>
happen that a character of admirable qualities loses its better life <\p>
because the atmosphere that should sustain it is rendered poisonous by <\p>
such breath as this man mingled with Zenobia's. Yet his reflections <\p>
possessed their share of truth. It was a woeful thought, that a woman <\p>
of Zenobia's diversified capacity should have fancied herself <\p>
irretrievably defeated on the broad battlefield of life, and with no <\p>
refuge, save to fall on her own sword, merely because Love had gone <\p>
against her. It is nonsense, and a miserable wrong,--the result, like <\p>
so many others, of masculine egotism,--that the success or failure of <\p>
woman's existence should be made to depend wholly on the affections, <\p>
and on one species of affection, while man has such a multitude of <\p>
other chances, that this seems but an incident. For its own sake, if <\p>
it will do no more, the world should throw open all its avenues to the <\p>
passport of a woman's bleeding heart. <\p>
As we stood around the grave, I looked often towards Priscilla, <\p>
dreading to see her wholly overcome with grief. And deeply grieved, in <\p>
truth, she was. But a character so simply constituted as hers has room <\p>
only for a single predominant affection. No other feeling can touch <\p>
the heart's inmost core, nor do it any deadly mischief. Thus, while we <\p>
see that such a being responds to every breeze with tremulous <\p>
vibration, and imagine that she must be shattered by the first rude <\p>
blast, we find her retaining her equilibrium amid shocks that might <\p>
have overthrown many a sturdier frame. So with Priscilla; her one <\p>
possible misfortune was Hollingsworth's unkindness; and that was <\p>
destined never to befall her, never yet, at least, for Priscilla has <\p>
not died. <\p>
But Hollingsworth! After all the evil that he did, are we to leave him <\p>
thus, blest with the entire devotion of this one true heart, and with <\p>
wealth at his disposal to execute the long-contemplated project that <\p>
had led him so far astray? What retribution is there here? My mind <\p>
being vexed with precisely this query, I made a journey, some years <\p>
since, for the sole purpose of catching a last glimpse of <\p>
Hollingsworth, and judging for myself whether he were a happy man or <\p>
no. I learned that he inhabited a small cottage, that his way of life <\p>
was exceedingly retired, and that my only chance of encountering him or <\p>
Priscilla was to meet them in a secluded lane, where, in the latter <\p>
part of the afternoon, they were accustomed to walk. I did meet them, <\p>
accordingly. As they approached me, I observed in Hollingsworth's face <\p>
a depressed and melancholy look, that seemed habitual; the powerfully <\p>
built man showed a self-distrustful weakness, and a childlike or <\p>
childish tendency to press close, and closer still, to the side of the <\p>
slender woman whose arm was within his. In Priscilla's manner there <\p>
was a protective and watchful quality, as if she felt herself the <\p>
guardian of her companion; but, likewise, a deep, submissive, <\p>
unquestioning reverence, and also a veiled happiness in her fair and <\p>
quiet countenance. <\p>
Drawing nearer, Priscilla recognized me, and gave me a kind and <\p>
friendly smile, but with a slight gesture, which I could not help <\p>
interpreting as an entreaty not to make myself known to Hollingsworth. <\p>
Nevertheless, an impulse took possession of me, and compelled me to <\p>
address him. <\p>
"I have come, Hollingsworth," said I, "to view your grand edifice for <\p>
the reformation of criminals. Is it finished yet?" <\p>
"No, nor begun," answered he, without raising his eyes. "A very small <\p>
one answers all my purposes." <\p>
Priscilla threw me an upbraiding glance. But I spoke again, with a <\p>
bitter and revengeful emotion, as if flinging a poisoned arrow at <\p>
Hollingsworth's heart. <\p>
"Up to this moment," I inquired, "how many criminals have you reformed?" <\p>
"Not one," said Hollingsworth, with his eyes still fixed on the ground. <\p>
"Ever since we parted, I have been busy with a single murderer." <\p>
Then the tears gushed into my eyes, and I forgave him; for I remembered <\p>
the wild energy, the passionate shriek, with which Zenobia had spoken <\p>
those words, "Tell him he has murdered me! Tell him that I'll haunt <\p>
him!"--and I knew what murderer he meant, and whose vindictive shadow <\p>
dogged the side where Priscilla was not. <\p>
The moral which presents itself to my reflections, as drawn from <\p>
Hollingsworth's character and errors, is simply this, that, admitting <\p>
what is called philanthropy, when adopted as a profession, to be often <\p>
useful by its energetic impulse to society at large, it is perilous to <\p>
the individual whose ruling passion, in one exclusive channel, it thus <\p>
becomes. It ruins, or is fearfully apt to ruin, the heart, the rich <\p>
juices of which God never meant should be pressed violently out and <\p>
distilled into alcoholic liquor by an unnatural process, but should <\p>
render life sweet, bland, and gently beneficent, and insensibly <\p>
influence other hearts and other lives to the same blessed end. I see <\p>
in Hollingsworth an exemplification of the most awful truth in Bunyan's <\p>
book of such, from the very gate of heaven there is a by-way to the pit! <\p>
But, all this while, we have been standing by Zenobia's grave. I have <\p>
never since beheld it, but make no question that the grass grew all the <\p>
better, on that little parallelogram of pasture land, for the decay of <\p>
the beautiful woman who slept beneath. How Nature seems to love us! <\p>
And how readily, nevertheless, without a sigh or a complaint, she <\p>
converts us to a meaner purpose, when her highest one--that of a <\p>
conscious intellectual life and sensibility has been untimely balked! <\p>
While Zenobia lived, Nature was proud of her, and directed all eyes <\p>
upon that radiant presence, as her fairest handiwork. Zenobia <\p>
perished. Will not Nature shed a tear? Ah, no!--she adopts the <\p>
calamity at once into her system, and is just as well pleased, for <\p>
aught we can see, with the tuft of ranker vegetation that grew out of <\p>
Zenobia's heart, as with all the beauty which has bequeathed us no <\p>
earthly representative except in this crop of weeds. It is because the <\p>
spirit is inestimable that the lifeless body is so little valued. <\p>
XXIX. MILES COVERDALE'S CONFESSION <\p>
It remains only to say a few words about myself. Not improbably, the <\p>
reader might be willing to spare me the trouble; for I have made but a <\p>
poor and dim figure in my own narrative, establishing no separate <\p>
interest, and suffering my colorless life to take its hue from other <\p>
lives. But one still retains some little consideration for one's self; <\p>
so I keep these last two or three pages for my individual and sole <\p>
behoof. <\p>
But what, after all, have I to tell? Nothing, nothing, nothing! I <\p>
left Blithedale within the week after Zenobia's death, and went back <\p>
thither no more. The whole soil of our farm, for a long time <\p>
afterwards, seemed but the sodded earth over her grave. I could not <\p>
toil there, nor live upon its products. Often, however, in these years <\p>
that are darkening around me, I remember our beautiful scheme of a <\p>
noble and unselfish life; and how fair, in that first summer, appeared <\p>
the prospect that it might endure for generations, and be perfected, as <\p>
the ages rolled away, into the system of a people and a world! Were my <\p>
former associates now there,--were there only three or four of those <\p>
true-hearted men still laboring in the sun,--I sometimes fancy that I <\p>
should direct my world-weary footsteps thitherward, and entreat them to <\p>
receive me, for old friendship's sake. More and more I feel that we <\p>
had struck upon what ought to be a truth. Posterity may dig it up, and <\p>
profit by it. The experiment, so far as its original projectors were <\p>
concerned, proved, long ago, a failure; first lapsing into Fourierism, <\p>
and dying, as it well deserved, for this infidelity to its own higher <\p>
spirit. Where once we toiled with our whole hopeful hearts, the town <\p>
paupers, aged, nerveless, and disconsolate, creep sluggishly afield. <\p>
Alas, what faith is requisite to bear up against such results of <\p>
generous effort! <\p>
My subsequent life has passed,--I was going to say happily, but, at all <\p>
events, tolerably enough. I am now at middle age, well, well, a step <\p>
or two beyond the midmost point, and I care not a fig who knows it!--a <\p>
bachelor, with no very decided purpose of ever being otherwise. I have <\p>
been twice to Europe, and spent a year or two rather agreeably at each <\p>
visit. Being well to do in the world, and having nobody but myself to <\p>
care for, I live very much at my ease, and fare sumptuously every day. <\p>
As for poetry, I have given it up, notwithstanding that Dr. <\p>
Griswold--as the reader, of course, knows--has placed me at a fair <\p>
elevation among our minor minstrelsy, on the strength of my pretty <\p>
little volume, published ten years ago. As regards human progress (in <\p>
spite of my irrepressible yearnings over the Blithedale reminiscences), <\p>
let them believe in it who can, and aid in it who choose. If I could <\p>
earnestly do either, it might be all the better for my comfort. As <\p>
Hollingsworth once told me, I lack a purpose. How strange! He was <\p>
ruined, morally, by an overplus of the very same ingredient, the want <\p>
of which, I occasionally suspect, has rendered my own life all an <\p>
emptiness. I by no means wish to die. Yet, were there any cause, in <\p>
this whole chaos of human struggle, worth a sane man's dying for, and <\p>
which my death would benefit, then--provided, however, the effort did <\p>
not involve an unreasonable amount of trouble--methinks I might be bold <\p>
to offer up my life. If Kossuth, for example, would pitch the <\p>
battlefield of Hungarian rights within an easy ride of my abode, and <\p>
choose a mild, sunny morning, after breakfast, for the conflict, Miles <\p>
Coverdale would gladly be his man, for one brave rush upon the levelled <\p>
bayonets. Further than that, I should be loath to pledge myself. <\p>
I exaggerate my own defects. The reader must not take my own word for <\p>
it, nor believe me altogether changed from the young man who once hoped <\p>
strenuously, and struggled not so much amiss. Frostier heads than mine <\p>
have gained honor in the world; frostier hearts have imbibed new <\p>
warmth, and been newly happy. Life, however, it must be owned, has <\p>
come to rather an idle pass with me. Would my friends like to know <\p>
what brought it thither? There is one secret,--I have concealed it all <\p>
along, and never meant to let the least whisper of it escape,--one <\p>
foolish little secret, which possibly may have had something to do with <\p>
these inactive years of meridian manhood, with my bachelorship, with <\p>
the unsatisfied retrospect that I fling back on life, and my listless <\p>
glance towards the future. Shall I reveal it? It is an absurd thing <\p>
for a man in his afternoon,--a man of the world, moreover, with these <\p>
three white hairs in his brown mustache and that deepening track of a <\p>
crow's-foot on each temple,--an absurd thing ever to have happened, and <\p>
quite the absurdest for an old bachelor, like me, to talk about. But <\p>
it rises to my throat; so let it come. <\p>
I perceive, moreover, that the confession, brief as it shall be, will <\p>
throw a gleam of light over my behavior throughout the foregoing <\p>
incidents, and is, indeed, essential to the full understanding of my <\p>
story. The reader, therefore, since I have disclosed so much, is <\p>
entitled to this one word more. As I write it, he will charitably <\p>
suppose me to blush, and turn away my face: <\p>
I--I myself--was in love--with--Priscilla! <\p>
